editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

ma & pulchra. Strong in precepts, beautifull in methode. And if both the≈øe be to be found in any Catechi≈øme, ours ≈øhall carry away the honour of it. But I de≈øire not to be like a tedious Mu≈øician, euer tuning, neuer playing; I come therefore fir≈øt to let you ≈øee the milke of our Catechi≈øme, in a briefe and ≈øhort view of it, and then hauing brought you from the ≈øpoone to the knife, to let you behold your more ≈øolide meate out of it. You ≈øhall find it ≈øufficient both for babes in Chri≈øt, and growne men And if you be expert in the fir≈øt, then may you remoue a forme higher; for I would not haue a Chri≈øtian like a dying man, or one ≈øicke of a Pal≈øey, that hauing his ≈øen≈øes, memory, and ≈øpeech, ≈øhould want facultie loco-motiue, or power to ≈øtirre his hands, or his feete: that being neither deafe nor dumbe to heare or an≈øwere, ≈øhould yet haue withered hands, or lame legges to liue as a Chri≈øtian. Arti≈øans might liue as well as landed men by their earnings, if they had not a wor≈øe boone with ≈øo excellent a facultie, of idlene≈ø≈øe, and ill husbandry. It ≈øhould bee a ≈øhame for vs to haue the Philo≈øophers ≈øtone of the true≈øt riches, and yet to liue like beggars. Behold (O Chri≈øtian) the tran≈øcendent obiects of thy a≈øpiring thoughts, and euer keepe thy ≈øoule vpon the wing in meditations of the kingdome of heauen, and the righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe thereof: loathing tho≈øe muck-wormes of the world, which like the Gentles breed of putrifaction, or Beetles feeding in the dung, can reli≈øh nothing but earthly things, or thinke of no other godline≈ø≈øe but gaine.2 Tim. 2.7. But I mu≈øt take heed lea≈øt I runne into the inconvenience obiected by that Spartane to the Athenians, That wi≈øe men did con≈øult, and the ignorant giue ≈øentence. We may ea≈øily iudge our ≈øuperiours (con≈øulting of remedies) to be guilty of the increa≈øing of the maladies and mi≈øchiefes of the State. Drunkenne≈ø≈øe and the nur≈øeries of it, v≈øurping Sobrieties kingdome, as Adoniah did Salomons, haue gotten ≈øo ≈øtrong an head, that they can hardly be re≈øi≈øted. Onely let the Magi≈øtrate take to him≈øelfe a firme forehead, couragious heart, bu≈øie hands, and not partiall, execute lawes with ≈øtrictne≈ø≈øe and re≈øolution, and God ≈øhall ble≈ø≈øe the ≈øame with happie ≈øucce≈ø≈øe: If otherwi≈øe, God will ≈øuffer wickedne≈ø≈øe to puni≈øh it ≈øelfe, and that no power can turne the ≈øtreame, becau≈øe God will haue it carry the offenders headlong to their perpetuall
ruine, and his owne revenge: yet mu≈øt the good Magi≈øtrate, even ≈øwimme again≈øt the tyde, knowing that without conque≈øt, it is glorious to haue re≈øi≈øted: in this alone he were an enemie if he ≈øhould doe nothing, becau≈øe he ≈øees ≈øo little good come of all his traveile. Let but (worthy Magi≈øtrates) the endeuour be yours, and you may with comfort leaue the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe to God; and ≈øo I cea≈øe, neuer cea≈øing to pray for you.

closer.signed: Yours in all Chri≈øtian dutie and ≈øeruice, IOHN YATES.

div.head: ‚ùß An adverti≈øement to the READER.
div.p:
THe truth and triall of this treati≈øe (carefull Reader) may I hope the better be accepted without di≈øtru≈øt or di≈øta≈øte, becau≈øe it hath pa≈ø≈øed thorow the fire, fanne and furnace of two iudicious and learned Divines, whom for honours ≈øake, I am bound to mention vnto thee. The one is the Reverend and wor≈øhipfull Mr Tho: Goad, Dr of Divinitie, by who≈øe labour this worke is carefully corrected, and iudiciou≈øly ≈øupplied, where it might offend through want or weakne≈ø≈øe, in any part or power of it: his ≈øtarres or his ≈øpits (that I may v≈øe Origens notes) haue beene welcome to this my Tractate. I expected his vnpartiall ≈øentence, and he hath done iu≈øtly to ≈øhut his friend out of doores, while this worke was di≈øcu≈ø≈øed. Know therefore with me (good Reader) by whom thou ha≈øt profited, and be thankfull. The other is Mr Alexander Richard≈øon, now decea≈øed, to whom I haue done the office of a Chri≈øtian brother, in ray≈øing vp ≈øeed to the dead, to continue his name, that his memory and worth might not be put out of I≈ørael. This ≈økilfull Arti≈øt hath ca≈øt and coyned the heads, and I would to God he had handled them before his death. Some few ≈øpecialties are vpon nece≈ø≈øary cau≈øe altered, but
they are of ≈øo ≈ømall moment, that they make no great breach in the body, neither in thy knowledge in viewing of the order and methode of Religion. I know if the di≈øcour≈øe as well as the heads had proceeded from the ≈øame hand, they would haue beene more accurate and perfect. A ≈øhaft ≈øhot by the hand of a Gyant, and a childe differ much; yet will I not in a fond admiration, and api≈øh imitation of any per≈øon make all his deeds and doctrines like the reflection of a looking gla≈ø≈øe, to frame all thoughts and things by his ≈øhadow. This were but to catch Doterels, and ≈øhew feats of actiuitie, to deceiue the ≈øimple. Againe, if ≈øome little thing be cen≈øured in the fir≈øt inventor, I hope they that loue him, will not thinke, as good friends as they deale with him, like Gnatts, which after they haue made a ≈øweete kinde of Mu≈øicke, euermore ≈øting before they depart. I feare not thy profit in it, if thou will ≈øubmit both it and thy ≈øelfe to the true touch-≈øtone, I meane the ≈øacred Scriptures; otherwi≈øe with Perillus thou mayest peri≈øh in thy owne inventions, and thine owne cunning at the la≈øt will fayle thee, and leaue thee as Ab≈øolons Mule left his rebellious Ma≈øter betweene heauen and earth. Con≈øider therefore what is ≈øaid, and the Lord giue thee vnder≈øtanding in all things, that thou maye≈øt be no le≈ø≈øe wi≈øe, then good. Amen.

div.head: ‚ùß The Catechi≈øme defined, and di≈øtributed.
CHAPTER I. Of Faith in God.
div.p: Que≈øtion.

p.hi: WHat inducements to Religion are prefixed before your Catechi≈øme?

div.p: An≈øwere.

Foure; fir≈øt, the giuing vp of my name to God in Bapti≈øme, and that in the dreadfull name of Father, Sonne, and holy Gho≈øt. Secondly, that being not able to giue it vp my ≈øelfe, it was done by others, according to the auncient cu≈øtome of the Church, ever conioyning Bapti≈øme and confe≈ø≈øion together, Math. 3.6. Aug. epi≈øt. 24. Papi≈øts would haue it to contract ≈øpirituall kindred, but ≈øurely it maketh hone≈øt loue among≈øt neighbours. Thirdly, they that gaue it vp for me, did promi≈øe in my name, that I ≈øhould liue according to Religion. Fourthly, I beleeue in con≈øcience, that I am bound to performe what they haue promi≈øed. Thus becau≈øe I am Gods, and bound to him by ≈øureties, vowes, promi≈øes, and Con≈øcience it ≈øelfe, It is my dutie being now come to yeares of di≈øcretion, to learne to beleeue in him, and obey him.
Q. What then is Religion?
A. It is the acknowledgement of the truth, which is after godline≈ø≈øe, Tit. 1.1.
Q. What are the parts?
A. Faith and workes; the ≈øumme of the one is contained in the Creed: of the other, in the ten Commandements, Lords Prayer, and the Sacraments. Tit. 3.8.
Q. What is Faith?
A. A confidence in God, grounded vpon knowledge, Ioh. 16.30. We know and by this beleeue.
Q. How is faith grounded vpon knowledge?
A. In regard of God and his Church: the maker of the Covenant, and the people with whom it is made, Ier. 31.33.
Q. How in re≈øpect of God?
A. As we beleeue in one God, and three per≈øons for our happine≈ø≈øe, Ioh. 14.1.
Q. How in one God?
A. In re≈øpect of nature, e≈ø≈øence, and being. Deut. 4.35.
Q. How in three per≈øons?
A. Three in regard of divine relation, or reall re≈øpects in that one mo≈øt pure e≈ø≈øence, Math. 28.19.
Q. What is the e≈ø≈øence?
A. That whereby God is of him≈øelfe, the mo≈øt ab≈øolute and fir≈øt being. I≈øa. 41.4.
Q. What is a per≈øon?
A. That one pure God, with the relation of a Father, Sonne, and holy Gho≈øt, 1 Ioh. 5.7.
Q. Doth the relation adde any thing to the e≈ø≈øence?
A. Nothing but re≈øpect or relation, as Abraham the Father of the faithful hath the ≈øame nature as he is a Father and as he is a man.
Q. What is the Relation?
A. It is either to ≈øend or be ≈øent, and both the≈øe are done either by nature, or coun≈øell. Ioh. 15.26. the ≈øpirit proceedeth from the Father and Sonne by nature, and is ≈øent to vs by coun≈øell.
Q. Is there no other Relation?

A. Yes; either to beget, or be begotten, and the Father begets his onely Sonne by nature, and the re≈øt of his children
by Coun≈øell. Heb. 1.3. Iam. 1.18. A man hauing the relation of a Father is ≈øaid to beget Children by nature, or coun≈øell, as adopted children are freely begotten, not of the bodie but the will. Iam. 1.18. Of his owne will beget he vs, not ≈øo his onely Sonne, who is as naturall to his Father, as burning to the fire, and as I≈øaac to Abraham.
Q. What then is the fir≈øt per≈øon?
A. God the Father, who by nature begets his Sonne, and by his coun≈øell creats the world. Heb. 1.2.5.
Q. What is the propertie of the Father?
A. To beget, and not to be begotten. Ioh. 3.16.
Q. What is his manner of ≈øub≈øi≈øting?

A. To be the fir≈øt per≈øon; for, the begetter is before the begotten, and yet being Relatiues they are together in nature, for no man is a Father before he haue a ≈øonne, though in order the Father be fir≈øt.
Q. What is the Fathers worke?
A. Creation; for, I beleeue in him as maker of heauen and earth: and the rea≈øon is, becau≈øe he is the fir≈øt per≈øon, to whom the fir≈øt worke belongs.
Q. What is Creation?
A. A worke of the Father, who of him≈øelfe by his ≈øonne and ≈øpirit, makes the world of nothing, exceeding Good, Gen. 1.31. Heb. 1.3.
Q. What is giuen to the Father in re≈øpect of Creation?
A. Almightie power; for, the Father in him≈øelfe is pure act, which act is power as it may be felt of his creatures, which are in power to be.
Q. What is omnipotencie?
A. It is that whereby the Father is able to doe all that he doth, and more then he doth, if it contradict not his owne nature, or the nature of things.
Q. How is Creation divided?
A. Into heauen and earth. Gen. 1.1.
Q. What meane you by heauen?
A. The third heauen, with the Angels, both which were made perfect in the very fir≈øt beginning of time. Gen. 1.1.
Q. What meane you by earth?

A. All that matter which was clo≈øed and compa≈ø≈øed about with the third heauen, and was made at the ≈øame in≈øtant with it to prohibite & keepe out vacuitie, or emptine≈ø≈øe, and fill vp the whole compa≈ø≈øe of it, otherwi≈øe the parts of them≈øelues would haue fallen together to haue kept out that enemy of nature. Gen. 1.1.
Q. Are we to vnder≈øtand no more by earth then that fir≈øt matter?

A. Yes, wee are to vnder≈øtand the forming of it into the foure elements, fire, ayre, water, and earth; as likewi≈øe the filling of it and them with inhabitants, both aboue and below: as al≈øo the providence of the Father in pre≈øeruing and governing of them all to their ends and v≈øes: for the Father carries the worke according to his proper manner of working, vntill we come to Redemption, and there the Sonne takes it vpon him in a peculiar manner.
Q. What is the ≈øecond per≈øon.
A. The Sonne, who is begotten of the Father by nature, and by coun≈øell redeemes mankind.
Q. What is the Relatiue propertie of the Sonne?
A. To be begotten. Heb. 1.5.
Q. What is his manner of ≈øub≈øi≈øting?
A. To be the ≈øecond per≈øon in order, not in nature, for the begotten in relation is naturally as ≈øoone as the begetter.
Q. What is his worke?
A. Redemption. Ephe≈ø. 1.7.
Q. What is Redemption?
A. It is a ≈øatisfaction made to the Iu≈øtice of God the Father for Man by a Redeemer.
Q. Who is the Redeemer?
A. Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, his onely Sonne our Lord.
Q. Why call you him Ie≈øus?
A. Becau≈øe he is a Sauiour of his people from their ≈øinnes. Math. 1.21.
Q. Why Chri≈øt?
A. In regard of his offices, as he is anointed our King, Prie≈øt, and Prophet. P≈øal. 45.7. Luk. 4.18. Act. 4.27. and 10.38.
Q. VVhy his onely Sonne?
A. Becau≈øe the Father can haue no more ≈øonnes by nature but one.
Q. Why our Lord?
A. By the right of Redemption. Rom. 14.9.
Q. How is our Redemption wrought?
A. By the humiliation and exaltation of the Sonne of God. Luke 24.26.
Q. VVhat be the ≈øeuerall degrees of his humiliation?
A. Seuen; There be ≈øome others left out of the Creed; but the≈øe expre≈ø≈øed are the principall.
Q. What are they?
A. 1. His conception; 2. his natiuitie; 3. his pa≈ø≈øion vnder Pilate; 4. his crucifying; 5. his dying; 6. his buriall; 7. his de≈øcent into hell.
Q. VVhat are meant by all the≈øe?
A. That Chri≈øt mu≈øt not onely ≈øatisfie in generall, but that he mu≈øt pa≈ø≈øe through the degrees of our ≈øorrowes, and beare our afflictions. I≈øa. 53.4.5.
Q. VVhat be the ≈øeuerall degrees of his exaltation?

A. Foure; which are his Re≈øurrection, A≈øcen≈øion, Sitting at Gods right hand, and returne to Iudgement. As in his humiliation he tooke our receits, and ta≈øted the bitter potion for vs, ≈øo all Phy≈øicke being ended of that kinde, he giues vs his receits of Redemption, Ephe≈ø. 1.7. Iu≈øtification, Rom. 3.24. Reconciliation, Colo≈ø. 1.20. Sanctification, 1 Pet. 1.2. Entrance into glory, Heb. 10.19. The≈øe are Cordials for vs, and for him after all his penall receits.
Q. What is the third per≈øon?

A. The holy Spirit, who by nature proceedeth from the Father, and the Sonne, and by coun≈øell applyeth Chri≈øt to the Church, and euery member thereof, the Father being the fir≈øt per≈øon elects, the Sonne redeemes, and the Spirit
≈øanctifies. Ioh. 14.26. and 15.26. Rom. 8.16. 1 Cor. 2.12. Ioh. 3.5. 2 Cor. 1.21. Rom. 8.23.
Q. VVhat is his Relatiue propertie?

A. To proceede. Vnder≈øtanding begets an Image of it ≈øelfe, and loues it, and ≈øo from the be≈øt vnder≈øtanding to the be≈øt obiect of it, proceedes a mutuall loue. The begetter loues the begotten, and the begotten loues the begetter, and their loue is equall to them≈øelues, and proceedes from them both, and to vs. The will of the Father, by the wi≈øedome of his Sonne, and power of his good Spirit is ≈øayd to doe all.
Q What is his manner of ≈øub≈øi≈øting?

A. To be the third per≈øon in order, for proceeding from two, he mu≈øt needs be the third, and yet in nature as ≈øoone as either of them; for the louers and the loued, are Relalatiues, and therefore together in nature.
Q. VVhat is his worke?
A. Application, or Sanctification, Ephe≈ø. 5.26.27. The Sonne hauing prepared the remedie, leaues it to be applyed by the Spirit, Ioh. 16.7.

div.head: CHAPTER II. Of the Faith of the Church.
div.p: Hitherto of Faith in God.
Que≈øtion.

p.hi: WHat is the Faith of the Church?

div.p: An≈øwere.
Whereby beleeuing in God, we al≈øo beleeue, that wee are of the Church, and made partakers of all good things promi≈øed vnto it.
Q. VVhat is the Church?
A. That number of all tho≈øe that are applyed to Chri≈øt by the ≈øpirit; Now as this vnion is made by faith, it is called the militant Church, as by vi≈øion, the triumphant.
Q. Why is it called holy?
A. Becau≈øe it is an holy Societie of Saints, in regard of the Spirits worke. 1 Pet. 2.9. Reu. 11.2. and 21.19.
Q. Why Catholicke?
A. Becau≈øe it is vniuer≈øall, in re≈øpect of all times, per≈øons, and places, a familie both in heauen and earth. Math. 26.13. Ephe≈ø. 3.15. 1 Ioh. 2.1. Reu. 7.9.
Q. What are the benefits God be≈øtoweth vpon it?

A. Two in this life, as the communion of Saints, and remi≈ø≈øion of ≈øinnes: and two in the life to come, as the re≈øurrection of the body, and life enerla≈øting, Lamen. 3.23. P≈øal. 68.19. Col. 1.5. and 3.3.4. 1 Ioh. 3.2.
Q. VVhat is the communion of Saints.

A. It is our communicating with God, and the godly, both in grace and glory, or that fellow≈øhip that wee haue with Chri≈øt our head, and all his members. P≈øal. 16.5. & 73.26. I≈øa. 55.1. Act. 4.32. Gal. 6.10. Ephe≈ø. 4.3.4.5.6. Heb. 10.24. Phil. 2.1.2. 1 Cor. 10.16. Reue. 3.18. and 6.20.
Q. What is the remi≈ø≈øion of Sinne?

A. It is a worke of mercy, whereby the Father being offended, and reconciled by his Sonne, doth witne≈ø≈øe to our con≈øciences by his holy Spirit, that all our ≈øinnes are di≈øcharged, and that we are graciou≈øly receiued againe into his fauour. Iob 33.27.28. 1 King. 8.47. Ho≈ø. 14.2. I≈øa. 33.24. and 62.11. God in forgiuing our ≈øinnes doth both couer and cure them. 1 Ioh. 1.9.
Q. What is the re≈øurrection of the body?

A. It is a ≈øtanding vp from the dead, by the power of Chri≈øts re≈øurrection, whereby our corruptible bodies are made incorruptible, and filled with all glory and excellencie, Iob 19.25.26. Ioh. 5.28. Act. 3.19. 1 Cor. 15.42.43. 2 Cor. 5.1. Heb. 11.35.
Q. What meane you by life Euerla≈øting?

A. That mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed and happie e≈øtate in which all the Elect of God ≈øhall raigne with Chri≈øt their head in the third heauen, after this life, and after the day of iudgement,
and that both in body and ≈øoule for euer and euer. P≈øal. 16.11. I≈øa. 64.4. Ioh. 17.20.21. 1 Cor. 2.9. and 13.12. and 15.28. 2 Cor. 12.4. Phil. 3.21. Reue. 21.22. and 22.2.

div.head: CHAPTER III. Of good Workes.
div.p: Hitherto of Faith.
Que≈øtion.

p.hi: WHat are the workes of Faith?

div.p: An≈øwere.
That ready act of faith to doe as we are bidden. Rom. 6.16. 1 Sam. 12.25. Iam. 2.14.17. Ioh. 14.15. 1 The≈ø. 1.3. Tit. 3.1.8.
Q. How are the≈øe workes deuided?

A. They are either our walking with God, or conferring with him, or receiuing from him. 2 Cor. 7.1. Phil. 1.6. 2 The≈ø. 1.11. Heb. 6.17.18. Faith bids the clean≈øed, goe away and ≈øinne no more, but walke after the Spirit, it prouokes to prayer, and giues vs full confirmation of Gods loue.
Q. What is our walking with God?
A. It is our due ob≈øeruation of his lawes in all our wayes. P≈øal. 119.6.
Q. What is the law of God?
A. The rule that God hath pre≈øcribed vs, for the holy performance of all our actions. I≈øa. 8.20. Rom. 2.15. & 7.7.
Q. How is the Law di≈øtributed?
A. It is either concerning the wor≈øhip of God, or loue of our neighbour. Mark. 12.29.30.31.
Q. What is the fir≈øt Commandement, concerning the wor≈øhip of God?
A. Thou ≈øhalt haue no other Gods before myface. Gen. 39.9. Iob 31.23.24. P≈øal. 112.1. Pro. 3.5. I≈øa. 8.13. and 51.12. Hab. 1.16. Luke 12.45. Phil. 3.19. Colo≈ø. 3.5.
Q. What is the ≈øumme of this precept?
A. The hauing of the true God, and him alone, and that with the whole man, in the be≈øt of all his powers.
Q. What is the ≈øecond Commandement?
A. Thou ≈øhalt not make to thy ≈øelfe any grauen Image. Exod. 20.4.5.6. P≈øal. 44.21. and 106.35.39. Deut. 4.12. I≈øa. 42.2. Ho≈ø. 14.8. Hab. 2.18. Math. 15.9. 1 Ioh. 5.21.
Q. What is the ≈øumme hereof?
A. That we wor≈øhip God with his owne wor≈øhip, and not our owne deui≈øes.
Q. What is the third Commandement?
A. Thou ≈øhalt not take the name of the Lord thy God in vaine. &c. Deut. 28.58. P≈øal. 5.16.17. Dan. 4.34. Math. 6.9. Rom. 11.33. 1 Tim. 6.1.
Q. What is the ≈øumme thereof?
A. Due reuerence to be ≈øhewed in the wor≈øhip of God.
Q. What is the fourth Commandement?
A. Remember thou keepe holy the Sabboth day, &c. Neh. 13.15. to 22. Exod. 20.8.9.10.11. I≈øa. 58.13. Ier. 17.27. Reu. 1.10.
Q. What is the ≈øumme of this law?
A. All diligence in publique Prayer to God, and in learning the will of God, e≈øpecially vpon his owne day.

div.head: CHAPTER IIII. Of Charitie.
div.p: Hitherto of holine≈ø≈øe in the fir≈øt Table.
Que≈øtion.
WHat is that Iu≈øtice that we owe to our neighbour?
An≈øwere.
That we doe to him, as we would he ≈øhould do to vs. Mark. 12.31.
Q. What is the fir≈øt Commandement of this Table?
A. Honour thy father and mother, &c. Exod. 20.12.
Q. What is the ≈øumme thereof?
A. Due re≈øpect to our ≈øuperiours, inferiours, and equalls, to honour all according to their place and degree.
Q. What is the ≈øecond precept?
A. Thou ≈øhalt not kill. Exod. 20.13.
Q. What is the ≈øumme of it?

A. Pre≈øeruation of life, as farre as may ≈øtand with the
good of the Church, and Common wealth.
Q. What is the third Commandement?
A. Thou ≈øhalt not commit adulterie. Exod. 20.14.

The Lord teach vs to li≈øten to him here, lea≈øt neglecting the light of his word, wee feele the heat of his wrath in hell, and be made to finde that to our co≈øt, which neuer had our care, and to ≈øinart with paine, for what we neuer heard with patience. But if I ≈øhould in≈øi≈øt vpon euery head as I might well, and with profit, I ≈øhould write a Salmeron-like Commentary vpon Petrarches remedies, & yet doubt whether ≈øo this worke would be perfect: ≈øure I am a life would bee too little to write it, and but enough to read it. I will hereafter goe on with the heads as ≈øhortly as I may, and giue as much good coun≈øell in a narrow roome as I ≈øhal be able. Brevitie where it is neither ob≈øcure nor defectiue is very plea≈øing, even to the daintie≈øt iudgements. I will as neere as I may in ≈øo large an Art imitate tho≈øe that draw great per≈øonages in little tablets, and de≈øcribe worlds of Countries in the compa≈ø≈øe of ≈ømall Maps: I hope if wee haue ≈øpeciall care of matter and methode, wee ≈øhall make this Doctrine more portable for memory, and readier for v≈øe. If our precepts as nailes driue out one another, you may iu≈øtly impute it to want of Art. I ≈øhall follow him that is now with God, and which I confe≈ø≈øe hath broken the Ice before me. The forme of the Art is to liue well. There is a naturall life which we liue by the vnion of body and ≈øoule; and there is a ≈øpirituall life, which we haue by the knot ≈øpoken of, to wit, our vnion with God by Religion. Now all men, in that they will haue ≈øome Religion, may be ≈øaid to liue ≈øpiritually, but they cannot liue well, becau≈øe they want a true rule of life. The follies of the Heathen are baits for babes, no bookes for Chri≈øtians:
which onely depend vpon God and his word, to teach them truely how to liue, but let vs cleare our definition by Scripture. 1. Tim. 6.3. A doctrine according to godline≈ø≈øe. Tit. 1.1. The acknowledgement of the truth which is after godline≈ø≈øe. Fir≈øt, this Art is in God. Secondly, wee receiue it from him as the paterne and patent of his will. Thirdly, our examples are to accord with it. Hence godline≈ø≈øe in the example, mu≈øt an≈øwere godline≈ø≈øe in the rule, and godline≈ø≈øe in the rule mu≈øt bee according to that which is in God. God plots the rule, then he publi≈øheth it, as his will and command; and la≈øtly, lookes for obedience at our hands. A king fir≈øt plots his government in him≈øelfe, then by Proclamation makes it knowne vnto his ≈øubiects; and la≈øtly, vnder penaltie enioynes the keeping of it. A Scrivener fir≈øt makes letters in his head, then pens them downe with his hand, and guides the Scholler accordingly: So, God is the Author of Religion, then he publi≈øheth it, and wee are to liue after it. To liue well in practi≈øe, is to liue well by precept; and precept that brings vs to the Prince of our happine≈ø≈øe. Pro. 2.5. it is called the feare and knowledge of God. Iam. 3.15. It is ≈øayd to be wi≈øedome from aboue. 2. Pet. 1.3. through this knowledge wee receiue of God all things that pertaine vnto life and godline≈ø≈øe. To conclude, giue thy ≈øelfe wholy to learne this Art, and deferre it not to thy la≈øt: wilt thou charge this greate≈øt burden vpon the weake≈øt bea≈øt? If thou can≈øt not pa≈ø≈øe over the foord when the waters are low, how wilt thou doe when they are ri≈øen? Twigges at the fir≈øt will bend to euery hand, which afterwards will not be bowed with all thy might. Sparkes are ≈øooner quenched then flames, and greene wounds ≈øooner cured then fe≈øtred ≈øores: he that driueth a naile, fir≈øt ≈øtriketh ea≈øily, and afterwards redoubleth in ≈øtrength, in ≈øo much as the more blowes he ≈øtriketh, the more it is fa≈øtened, and the harder it will be to draw it forth againe: ≈øo betimes breake the bands, ≈øhake off the ≈øhakles of ≈øinnes, and be daily labouring to ≈øaue thy poore ≈øoule.

div.head: CHAPTER II. Of Faith in God.
div.p: Que≈øtion.

p.hi: VVHat are the parts?

div.p: An≈øwere.

Faith in God, and obedience towards God. In the old Te≈øtement is devided into feare and ≈øeruice, Deut. 6.13. Io≈øh. 24.14.1. Sam. 12.24. Ob 28.28. P≈øal. 2.11. Eccl. 12.13. Feare is the head or beginning of this wi≈øedome, P≈øal. 111.20. Pro. 9.10. and therefore to ≈øerue God without it, is a head-le≈ø≈øe Religion. Yet on the other ≈øide, what comfort can we haue in ≈øuch an head, or Ma≈øculine di≈øpo≈øition, if with the I≈øraelites brood it ≈øhould be ≈ømoothered in the birth; or recoile like Zarah in Thamars wombe. So perfect is this Art, that wee mu≈øt haue cleane fingers as well as cleane hearts. It is the plea of Ignorants in doing euill, to ≈øy they haue good hearts; which vndoubtedly are the wor≈øt; for the≈øe two parts will euer goe together. Divine Philo≈øophie will teach vs to referre all our ≈øpeculations to action, yea, our very affections. Feare in Scripture is ever accompanied with ≈øeruice, & ≈øeeing God hath ≈øo wedded them together, let no man pre≈øume vpon any condition to devorce them; as Papi≈øts doe with a dead faith: but their di≈øpen≈øation therein is the di≈ø≈øipation of the truth, which will haue ≈øeruice and obedience the true probats of faith and feare. And as Dalilah ≈øaid to Samp≈øon, How can≈øt thou ≈øay thou loue≈øt mee when thy heart is not with mee? So how can they profe≈ø≈øe they loue God, who≈øe hearts obey him not? In the new Te≈øtament, Religion is di≈øtributed into faith and lone. 2. Tim. 1.13. Keepe the paterne of whole≈øome words, which thou ha≈øt receiued of me in faith and loue. Loue ≈øprings from faith. 1. Tim. 1.5. And faith workes by loue.
Gal. 5.6. and loue fulfils the law. Rom. 13.10. not by action, but intention; for it is the end of the law. 1. Tim. 1.5. God accepting ≈øincere loue for perfect dutie. By faith wee are ≈øpiritually glued and cimented to God, that we may bee one ≈øpirituall body with him; in which ≈øen≈øe it is ≈øaid, He that is glued to the Lord is one ≈øpirit. 1. Cor. 6.17. Cords will bind, ≈øo will the cords of loue. Ho≈ø. 11.4. Zach. 11.7. But cords may be vnknitt: Nailes will fa≈øten, and wee haue the words of the wi≈øe as nailes fa≈øtned by the ma≈øters of the a≈ø≈øemblies. Eccl. 12.11. but yet nailes may ≈ølip, or leaue a chinke: onely the glew of faith. ioynes all clo≈øe together, or rather both the≈øe parts will cau≈øe vs, with full purpo≈øe of heart to cleaue vnto the Lord, Act. 11.23. The heat of faith and loue will dige≈øt this whole Art, that it may be di≈øtributed into the veines of euery good word and worke. The≈øe two will make vp a perfect paire of compa≈ø≈øes, that can truely take the latitude of this Art. And fir≈øt mu≈øt wee haue faith as the one foote pitcht vpon the Center, which is God, whiles obedience as the other walkes about in a perfect circle of all good duties. The fire of faith, and light of life, will evince again≈øt the gates of hell, the vndoubted truth of Religion. So that by the≈øe ≈øweete and cordiall flames may the ≈øoule of euery Chri≈øtian warme it ≈øelfe, again≈øt all tho≈øe cold de≈øpaires whereunto Satan tempteth.
Q. What is Faith?

A. The fir≈øt part of Religion, whereby from knowledge I beleeue in God; the fir≈øt act of faith is pa≈ø≈øiue in receiuing what God giueth. And ≈øo layes hold of happine≈ø≈øe, workes it not: Faith makes iu≈øt, as the hand makes rich, that is filled with the wealth of another; or, as the Iewellers boxe, ba≈øe in it ≈øelfe, is made precious for the pearles it containeth: Here may wee iu≈øtly ≈øay, it is a poorer and meaner act to beleeue, then loue; nay, rather pa≈ø≈øion then action; for, we are fir≈øt apprehended of God before we apprehend him againe Phil 3.12. This grace is mo≈øt freely graced, that it might the more frankely reflect all vpon God a gaine. And becau≈øe it is the roote of all the re≈øt will
teach humilitie, & exclude boa≈øting: like the ful eare of corn that hanges downe the head towards the originall, or if any be ≈øo graciou≈øly exalted, and freely favoured aboue his fellowes, that his ≈øtalke is ≈øo ≈øtiffe, that it beares him vp aboue the re≈øt of his ridge, then faith will make him looke vp to heauen aboue, not in the thoughts of pride, but in the humble vowes of thankefulne≈ø≈øe, and ≈øay with Mary, the Lord hath regarded the low e≈øtate of his ≈øervant. Thus will faith (rightly vnder≈øtood) teach vs to knead nature in the durt and du≈øt, and ≈øpoyle our free will of all her proud ragges, loading her with reproches, and giue all glory to him, that ≈øayes he will not giue it vnto another. Papi≈øts being of late more a≈øhamed then before, doe confe≈ø≈øe all is giuen: but (≈øay they) is it not all one to pay a ≈øumme, and haue ≈øo much giuen mee as may pay it? No doubt, Faith receiues a full di≈øcharge, makes it not. We rather by Faith receiue an acquitance ≈øealed in the blood of Chri≈øt, then the blood of Chri≈øt to make our owne workes meritorious, which we may offer to God in payment for our ≈øelues. Eternall life. Rom. 6.23. is both merit and mercie, we take it as a gift, Chri≈øt earnes it as wages, Ephe. 2.8. Saluation through faith, yet not of our ≈øelues. Here lies the errour of the Papi≈øts, euen in faith it ≈øelfe, and euery other good grace of the ≈øpirit, that our free will hath his intervention and operation, betwixt Gods giuing and our taking: ≈øo that if God will but beare halfe the charges by his co-operation, man ≈øhall vnder-take to merit his owne glory, and fulfill the royall law ≈øo abundantly, that he ≈øhall haue ≈øomething over and aboue, to be very beneficiall and helpefull to his needie neighbours. But the way of the law is longer then our pur≈øey hearts, and ≈øhort legges can reach to the end and perfection of it. As Con≈øtantine ≈øayd to Ace≈øius the Novatian, Set vp ladders and climbe to heauen: ≈øo I to Papi≈øts, ≈øcale heauen by your workes; as for vs we haue found another way, and that is to a≈øcend vpon Iacobs ladder. Wee leaue tuggling and ≈øtrugling that way to preuaile, and fall with Iacob to wre≈øtle with Chri≈øt for a ble≈ø≈øing. And though we
goe lymping by our ≈øinnes, yet by our conquering Faith wee ≈øhall be Princes with God. By this therefore the vaunt of Papi≈øts, mu≈øt needs avaunt: yet further, faith in another act will cut the very winde-pipe of our free-will, and merit. It is wittily ≈øayd of one, that faith in regard of his pa≈ø≈øiue act is rather a beggarly receiver, then a de≈øerving worker: all our conver≈øion is pa≈ø≈øiue; but ≈øee faith in our actiue conver≈øion, and you ≈øhall ≈øee workes a forme too low to come in any ≈øuch reque≈øt, as to iu≈øtifie. For what is faith, but as the hand of the ≈øoule? and what is the dutie of the hand, but eyther to hold or to worke? This hand then holds in the fir≈øt part of Divinitie, and workes in the ≈øecond. Now without all que≈øtion, Iu≈øtification is to be taught in our fir≈øt part, and therefore goes before obedience; and faith, which is as an in≈øtrument or hand, for to hold Chri≈øt to iu≈øtification, is mightie and operatiue both for ≈øanctification and new obedience. Workes therefore are the effects of ≈øanctification, and ≈øanctification is the effect of iu≈øtification; hence is it impo≈ø≈øible to be iu≈øtified by workes as cau≈øes, as effects and fruits they may ≈øhew it. If then the ≈øecret apprehen≈øion of the clo≈øed hand of faith hide what it holdeth; ≈øee the hand of faith open to iu≈øtifie the cau≈øe by the evidence of the effects, & in this ≈øen≈øe workes may iu≈øtifie and perfect faith, as the ≈øecond part of any Art doth the fir≈øt. Iam. 2.22.24. Papi≈øts again≈øt the whole order of Diuinitie would haue our workes to v≈øher in our Iu≈øtification, nay, as parents to beget it. Whereas they are in very deed the companions and pages, or honorable attendants of faith, and the righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe it holdeth. Faith is both the mindes te≈øtimony in regard of the word, and the wills Amen, in regard of the ≈øpirit. Creed comes of credo, which ≈øignifies to ≈øee a thing certainely, and yeeld to it affiance. It is compounded of cernere, and dare. Pro certo videre, & pro certo dare. Hence Faiths motto, Caco nulli. By faith wee know whom wee haue beleeued. 2. Tim. 1.12. And our Creed puts vs in mind of knowledge and affiance in faith: ≈øo the word it ≈øelfe teacheth no le≈ø≈øe;
for Faith comes of Fides, and fides of fiat dictum, where we haue God to ≈øay the word, and we ≈øay Amen vnto it. The auncient Romanes at the very gate of their Pantheon, pictured faith with two hands clo≈øed together, intimating, that there was no comming to God but by the hand of faith. And Grace, which ≈øcorneth not to learne of Nature any good (though not Athens but Ieru≈øalem mu≈øt teach this le≈ø≈øon) can take this advice, as Mo≈øes heard the good coun≈øell of a Midianite, that he that commeth to God mu≈øt beleeue that God, is, and that hee is a rewarder of all them that ≈øeeke him diligently. Heb. 11.6. That faith is the fir≈øt part is cleare. Ier. 31.33.34. and 32.40. Fir≈øt, God writes in vs this principle of life, and then we obey him. Ezek. 11.19.20. and 36.26. Fir≈øt, he puts in his ≈øpirit, and then cau≈øeth vs to walke in his ≈øtatutes. Such is the ≈øervile, or rather bruiti≈øh nature of man, that he can neither be ≈øtirred, or ≈øtayed in any good cour≈øe, except there go a new forming of his heart, before there be any reforming of his life. As dead bodies are rubbed without heat: ≈øo doe wee in vaine force vpon our ≈øelues, an heartle≈ø≈øe Religion without faith; all our life here is but a vitall death without it; till wee liue that life wee doe but carry our carca≈ø≈øes vp and downe carele≈øly, and doe nothing plea≈øing vnto God. Heb. 11.6. secondly, that faith is from knowledge, appeares Ioh. 6.69. and 16.30. and 17.3. Heb. 11.1. and that with affiance in God. P≈øal. 40.4. Mark. 11.22. hence faith is a confidence in God, vpon a particular a≈ø≈øurance from God, that he is my God. Mark. 9.24. Rom. 4.20.21.2. Tim. 1.12. Faith layes not hold of God, as we take hold of a tree, or ≈øome ≈øuch like ≈øencele≈ø≈øe thing, but as we v≈øe to doe in our ≈øalutations, when there is a mutuall imbracing and ki≈ø≈øing of each other. [a≈øpa≈øamenoi] Heb. 12.13.
Q. Seeing faith ≈øolely re≈øts vpon God, what is God?

A. God in regard of him≈øelfe onely knows him≈ølefe, as dwelling in the light vnaprochable, whom neuer man ≈øaw, neither can ≈øee. 1. Tim. 6.16. Ioh. 1.18. 1. Ioh. 4.12. The Sunne and the fire ≈øay of them≈øelues, come not too neere, how much
more the light which none can atraine vnto. Here the well is not onely deepe, but wee want a bucket to draw withall. God to Mo≈øes, Exod. 33.20. giues both the rule and the rea≈øon; thou can≈øt not ≈øee my face and liue: for, there ≈øhall none ≈øee me and liue. I mu≈øt contract my meditations, lea≈øt the Art grow too big with amplifications. It would be an excellent worke, to write a booke by it ≈øelfe of the knowledge of Iehovah Elohim: It ≈øhall now be ≈øufficient to lay downe the precepts, with ≈øhort expo≈øitions, and as pregnant proofes as we can.
Q. What followes from hence?

A. That God is both incomprehen≈øible by rea≈øon, and vnnameable by words, and con≈øequently aboue all Arts; for Grammar and Logicke are the mo≈øt generall, and goe before all other ≈øciences, nothing being to be conceiued without them. Iob 11.7.8.9. God is not to be found out by rea≈øon, therefore he cannot be mea≈øured by quantitie. Iob 36.26. too great for the finite vnder≈øtanding. God being the fir≈øt is mo≈øt intelligible, for prioritie of nature, ever goes with per≈øpicuitie of apprehen≈øion: But this is in God him≈øelfe, who be≈øt knowes his owne being, yea, better then any thing be≈øide it: although man better knowes other things then him≈øelfe. Gen. 32.29. Iudg. 13.18. Gods name, as his nature, is ≈øecret, and not be ≈øought; and this doth wonderfully ≈øtrengthen faith; for, if God were not greater then our apprehen≈øion, he could not helpe vs infinitely. The holding of God by faith, is better then our beholding him by rea≈øon. Ephe. 3.20. God is able to doe exceeding abundantly, aboue all we can aske by words, or thinke by rea≈øon.

Q. May wee then inquire nothing?

A. Duet. 29.29. Secret things belong to the Lord our God, but things revealed belong to vs, and our children for euer. Exod. 19.12. The people may not goe vp into the Mount, yet may they ≈øtand at the foote to heare God ≈øpeake vnto them. Exod. 33.20.23. We may ≈øee Gods back-parts, but not his face. Rom. 1.19. that which may be knowne of God.
≈øome-thing is not to be knowne, as being too ≈øubtile for the eye of any creature. The beames of the Sunne are made vi≈øible by reflection: and letters being refracted and broken in a paire of ≈øpectacles are made liable to a dimme eye: ≈øo Almightie God by his word and workes ≈øhining in his creatures, as in a gla≈ø≈øe, is ≈øeene of vs. P≈øal. 19.1.7. & 104.24. and 119.105. Rom. 1.20. Iam. 1.23.25. but mo≈øt of all by the eye of faith, looking in both. Heb. 11.3.27. Wee cannot looke vpon the body of the Sunne, neither can we ≈øee at all without the light of it: ≈øo, as wee cannot looke vpon the face and e≈ø≈øence of God, ≈øo neither can we ≈øee any thing at all without him; hee therefore mu≈øt name him≈øelfe, and ≈øo de≈øcribe him≈øelfe as wee may apprehend him by his owne Logicke and Grammar. It was well and mode≈øtly ≈øpoken by that Emperour to Ambro≈øe, Wee ≈øpeake of the≈øe things, not as wee ought, but as wee can: I haue euer thought with my ≈øelfe that here a fooli≈øh wi≈øedome is better then a wi≈øe ignorance, and that it is ≈øufficient to be one of Gods Court, though I may be none of his coun≈øell. I will labour to know all that I need; and all that I may without prying into Gods Arke; a≈ø≈øuring my ≈øelfe that he that is thus content to dwell with his poore ≈øervants in the≈øe ≈ømoky cottages of their mortality where we (through our vnquiet corruptions) will not ≈øuffer our ≈øelues to haue the full fruition of him, ≈øhall haue wonderfull happine≈ø≈øe in our dwellings with him in tho≈øe eternall Tabernacles that are aboue. Alas, whiles the ≈øhadow of our ≈øinfull ma≈ø≈øe hides his beautie from our eyes, it is well if we can ≈øee any thing. This earthly Moone of the Church, hath her fulls and wainings; and mu≈øt haue ≈øo long as ≈øhe wadeth in this planetary world: It is enough when ≈øhee is fixed aboue, to be in the full of her glory. Here wee haue but the dim ≈øhadowes of our future ble≈ø≈øedne≈ø≈øe. Onely at the right hand of our God are plea≈øures for evermore; and ≈øuch plea≈øures as if ever they could bee fully expre≈ø≈øed or conceiued, were not worthy of our longings, nor able to ≈øatisfie vs. For as God is infinite, and never to be comprehended e≈ø≈øentially:
≈øo our ioyes are bottomle≈ø≈øe, and ever ≈øpringing vp with new occa≈øions of our ble≈ø≈øedne≈ø≈øe. Oh then that wee could ≈øo much the more long to enioy them, by how much le≈ø≈øe wee are able to comprehend them.

div.head: CHAPTER III. Of Gods Backe-parts.
div.p: Que≈øtion.

p.hi: VVHat may then be ≈øeene?

div.p: An≈øwere.

His backe-parts, according or our mea≈øure and manner, that is, the mea≈øure of our apprehen≈øion, and manner of receiving. All ve≈ø≈øels are filled at the mouth, according to their holding: ≈øo, God, according vnto our nece≈ø≈øities, knowes how to name him≈øelfe, and that ≈øo plainely as our capacities may vnder≈øtand him. Exod. 3.14. God names him≈øelfe. Exod. 6.3. He appeares by one name and not by another: that is, by his ≈øufficiencie to giue Canaan, not by his efficiencie in doing it as yet. Exod. 33.19.20. God will not ≈øhew Mo≈øes his glory, but he will ≈øit his goodne≈ø≈øe to pa≈ø≈øe before him: and ver. 22.23. hee covers and vncovers, as Mo≈øes might be≈øt ≈øee him. We (like narrow mouth'd ve≈ø≈øels) mu≈øt receiue this knowledge by drops, and that with the greater difficultie, becau≈øe wee are full alreadie; for, as in nature there is no vacuitie, but either aire or more ≈øolide ≈øub≈øtance fills all: ≈øo in the minde, as it is emptie of grace and goodne≈ø≈øe, ≈øo is it filled with vaine conceitedne≈ø≈øe, which is an exceeding hinderance to better knowledge; and therefore, as in a ve≈ø≈øell, ≈øo much liquor as goes in, ≈øo much aire goes out: ≈øo, the vnder≈øtanding, as it is filled with wi≈øedom:, ≈øo is it emptied of folly. Hence it comes to pa≈ø≈øe, that the be≈øt ve≈ø≈øell cannot be quite full in this life, becau≈øe of the remainders of corruption. We mu≈øt therefore
neither be impatient of Gods delay in revealing him≈øelfe, nor content with our ≈ømall mea≈øure; but ever be indevouring to haue one drop added to another, vntil it ≈øhall plea≈øe God to fill our ve≈ø≈øell to the brim. There is nothing created, what hat his being and perfection together, euery thing growes from ≈øtrength to ≈øtrength, till it come to his compleate ≈øtature. Onely herein grace is contrary to nature, ever ≈øtronge≈øt at la≈øt, and at be≈øt changeth not, like his fountaine, in whom is no ≈øhadow by turning. Surely, he that here maketh profe≈ø≈øion of goodne≈ø≈øe, if he find not him≈øelfe be≈øt at la≈øt, may well feare he was never good. The ri≈øing of a river is exceeding narrow and ≈øhallow, yet hauing coa≈øted about, and drawing necre the ≈øea, begins to make a little ≈øea within his owne bankes: ≈øo here ≈ølender beginnings, will grow larger in the end, if they creepe neerer and neerer to God. I know when wee are at the furthe≈øt, wee can but ≈øee his backe parts, who≈øe face we mu≈øt ever adore in an holy ignorance. Wee mu≈øt v≈øe ≈øpeciall labour to learne a little, or el≈øe wee ≈øhall get nothing: if the que≈øtion bee, whether God mu≈øt de≈øcend to vs in teaching, or wee a≈øcend to him in learning? wife moderation (I thinke) hath determined it mo≈øt equall, that each part remit ≈øomewhat, that both may meete in the midde≈øt: wee mu≈øt not thinke it ≈øufficient (≈øeeing God hath ≈øo far conde≈øcended vnto vs as to ≈øhew vs his back-parts) to eate the corne out of the eare, becau≈øe we will not abide the labour to grinde, and knead it: neither mu≈øt wee be over-curious, lea≈øt with the brightne≈ø≈øe of his glory we blind our ≈øelues. Tho≈øe things (≈øayth AMBROSE) which GOD will haue hidden, ≈øearch not, tho≈øe things which hee hath manife≈øted, deny not; lea≈øt in the one thou bee vnlawfully curious, in the other demnably vngratefull.
Q. Will then the knowledge of his backe-parts ≈øuffice for our happine≈ø≈øe?

A. We may not ≈øee further and liue, neither need wee ≈øee further that we may liue. Exod. 33.20.23. thou can≈øt not ≈øee my face and liue, but my backe-parts thou ≈øhalt ≈øee, and therefore liue: further then our rule wee are to attempt nothing, neither haue we any facultie or power ≈øo to doe. Wee may follow the current to the Sea by many bankes, but then mu≈øt we ≈øtand on the ≈øhoare, and admire the Ocean: the little ≈øtreames of Creation emptie them≈øelues into the great rivers of Redemption, and they into a maine Sea of goodne≈ø≈øe; and here wee mu≈øt ≈øtand and wonder, keeping our ≈øelues within our rode and reach.
Q. What are the≈øe backe parts?

A. All that may be ≈øeene of God: we cannot looke on him for any thing that is before him, and therefore wee mu≈øt ca≈øt our eyes after him in his word and workes. Exod. 33.23. Deut. 4.12. Iob 4.16. The back-parts of God are ≈øome ≈øimilitude of his face and here it is fat all for our great doctors of Rome in their Theologie, to interferre as hor≈øes doe, hewing hoofe again≈øt hoofe, and to cro≈ø≈øe-cut them≈øelues in their owne imaginations, devi≈øes, and groundle≈ø≈øe conceits; for this ≈øimilitude con≈øi≈øts not in the works of mens hands, but in the words of Gods owne mouth, and the workes of his owne hands. I≈ørael heard the voyoe
of words, but ≈øaw no ≈øimilitude, ≈øaue a voyce. There is no v≈øe of the Starres, when the Sunne ≈øhines, no more is there of Popi≈øh Idoles, where the word is permitted to ≈øpeake. Exod. 33.22. but the divine proclamation taught Mo≈øes more fully, Exod. 34.6. the line of the creatures can in a liuely manner poynt out the Creatour: but the law is the life of this learning, P≈øal. 19.1. with 7. rowle his word vnder thy tongue, chew on it in the≈øe meditations till thou feele ≈øome ≈øweetnes in the palate of thy ≈øoule. Q. How are the backe-parts of God devided.

A. Into his ≈øufficiencie in being, and efficiencie in working: the one in his nature, the other in his workes, Iudg. 2.10. They neither knew the Lord nor his workes. P≈øal. 78.7. That they might ≈øet their hope in God, and not forget his workes. Exod. 6.3. God is fir≈øt ≈øufficient to performe his promi≈øes, and then efficient of them. Rom. 3.20.22. Seeing this is ≈øo, let vs never pre≈øcribe his wi≈øedome, ha≈øten his mercy. His grace for the pre≈øent ≈øhall be enough for vs; his glory will bee more then enough. With men the rule is good, fir≈øt try, and then tru≈øt: but with God we mu≈øt fir≈øt tru≈øt him, as ≈øufficient to helpe vs, and then try him in his workes: and wee may be a≈ø≈øured, that it is as po≈ø≈øible for him to deceiue vs, as not to be. Either now di≈øtru≈øt his being, or el≈øe confe≈ø≈øe thy happine≈ø≈øe, and with patience expect his promi≈øed con≈øolation. Thus may we well hearten and harden our ≈øelues for all attempts.
Q. What is Gods ≈øufficiencie?

A. Whereby be being all-≈øufficient in him≈øelfe, bee is al≈øo all-≈øufficient for vs. Gen. 17.1.2. Cor. 12.9. Hope of advantage is the Load-≈øtone that drawes the iron hearts of men, why then ≈øhould not God that is rich in mercy haue more
≈øuters? Alas, ≈øhall a little ab≈øence in performance breede a lingring con≈øumption of friend≈øhip? Can wee part with earthly things in pre≈øent po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, for hope of better in future rever≈øion, and giue the all-≈øufficient no time for the reture of his promi≈øes? No age afforded more para≈øites, fewer friends; we flatter with God, when we ≈øay, we loue him, and leaue him for delay. The mo≈øt are friendly in ≈øight, ≈øerviceable in expectation, hollow in loue, tru≈øtle≈ø≈øe in experience; they will giue God a glad welcome whil≈øt he is a doing for them, and as willing afarewell when hee doth de≈øi≈øt, nay, a little withdraw for triall: but hee that truely knowes the ≈øufficiencie of his God, will wait vpon his efficiencie without grudging. Rats and Mice runne to the full Barne, leaue it when it is emptie: So, dung-hill creatures for their bellies ≈øerue God, and flintch from him in their want.
Q. What followes from hence?

A. The con≈øideration of the name Shadai, which is compounded of Sha, a Relatiue, contracted of A≈øher, ≈øignifying which or what, and Dai, a Noune, ≈øignifying ≈øufficiencie. So that the name by this reckoning is thus much, he which is ≈øufficiency it ≈øelfe. Or as others would haue it from Shadh, a Pappe, all (as it were) ≈øucking their happine≈ø≈øe from God. Others againe of Shadhadb, to penetrate or goe through euery thing, and ≈øo ≈øignifies Almightie. The Grecians tran≈ølate it by Antarkees, or Pantocrator: God being ≈øufficient to ble≈ø≈øe his owne, and de≈øtroy their enemies. Gen. 28.3. El-Shadai, God which is ≈øufficiencie it ≈øelfe ble≈ø≈øe thee. Ioel. 1.15. As a de≈øtruction, Mi Shadai, from the Almightie, who can cru≈øh the proude≈øt and ≈øtoute≈øt of his enemies. Hence may we learne to humble our ≈øelues vnder his mightie band, and to ca≈øt our care vpon him. 1. Pet. 5.6.7. Remembring that all our ≈øafetie and ≈øufficiencie hangs vpon him. Wo then when God our ≈øufficiencie is plea≈øed to try vs with any woe or want, then (remembring our ≈øelues to be but wormes Het vs not turne againe when he treads vpon vs. If hee call for his owne, or cut ≈øhort ours
de≈øires, it is not for vs to ≈øtorme or ≈øtartle, but quiet our ≈øelues with our tru≈øt in him. I haue ≈øeene ill debters, that borrow with prayers, and keepe with thankes, repay with enmitie. Wee certainely mi≈ø-take our tenure, if we thinke our ≈øelues owners, when we are but Tenants at will. Or take that for ab≈øolute gift, which our God intends as loane. It is Gods great bountie wee may haue right to any thing, though not Lord≈øhip over it: of our very liues we are but keepers no commanders. Wee may all ≈øay as the poore man did of the Hatchet, alas ma≈øter it is but borrowed. Out of Gods ≈øufficiencie comes all ours, and therefore it is not for vs to be proud of any thing, no more then for vaine whifflers of their borrowed chaines, or ≈øilly groomes of the Stable, of their ma≈øters Hor≈øes.
Q. Wherein con≈øi≈øts the all-≈øufficiencie of God?

A. In e≈ø≈øence, and ≈øub≈øi≈øtence, one God, three per≈øons. He that is ≈øufficient to make vs happei, mu≈øt haue a being to giue being to our happine≈ø≈øe, and ≈øub≈øi≈øting, that it may exi≈øt in vs. Iehovah may giue vs being, and yet better not to be, then be mi≈øerable. Baptize them in the name (not names) of the father, ≈øonne, and holy Gho≈øt: one name, one nature, yet with this threefold relation, of Father, Sonne, and Spirit: and here our thoughts mu≈øt walke warily, the path is narrow: the conceit of three ≈øub≈øtances, or one ≈øub≈øi≈øtence is damnable. The breaking of Relatiues is the ruine of Sub≈øtantiues. herein (if ever) heavenly wi≈øedome mu≈øt be≈øtirre it ≈øelfe, in directing vs, that wee may ≈øo ≈øever the≈øe apprehen≈øions, that none be neglected; and ≈øo conioynethem that they be not confounded. The Sonne is no other thing from the Father, and yet another per≈øon: and ≈øo the holy
Gho≈øt is no other thing from them both, and yet another per≈øon. And here the gagling gee≈øe (I meane the Rhemi≈øts) are worthy to haue their tongues pulled out of their heads, and (as Hierome ≈øayd of his ∆≤igilantius) made into gobbets: who not contenting them≈øelues, like Shemeies to raile on Caluin, and rattle vp our Engli≈øh Students for reading him, bla≈øpheme in confuting his bla≈øphemies (as they call them.) That Chri≈øt is of God his Father is mo≈øt true, as his eternall e≈ø≈øence is taken per≈øonally: but as the ≈øimple nature is con≈øidered in it ≈øelfe, without relation of per≈øons, there the e≈ø≈øence is the ≈øame in all three, and not placed all in the fir≈øt per≈øon, and borrowed of him by the other. Neither ≈øhall they, nor any other hereticks once bee able to hi≈ø≈øe at the rea≈øons, or ≈øtand before the face of them, as the ≈øpirit of God layes them downe. Exod. 3.14. Chri≈øt in regard of his per≈øon is ≈øaid to be with God, and in regard of his e≈ø≈øence to bee God, and therefore as his per≈øon is from or with another, ≈øo his e≈ø≈øence is of him≈øelfe. Ioh. 17.20. All that is Chri≈øts is the Fathers, and all that is the Fathers is Chri≈øts. The Father therefore hauing the Godhead of him≈øelfe, it followeth that the Sonne hath it likewi≈øe of him≈øelfe. Againe, it is contradiction of ≈øay, God of him≈øelfe, and God of another. As likewi≈øe mo≈øt ab≈øurde to hold one and the ≈øelfe ≈øame nature begotten & vnbegotten; for, ≈øo there ≈øhould be a fir≈øt, ≈øecond, and third nature, as there is a fir≈øt, ≈øecond, and third per≈øon, and ≈øo three Gods as well as three per≈øons. But this will better appeare by the ≈øequele. Oh, the nece≈ø≈øitie of this high knowledge, which who attaines not, may babble when he prayeth, and bee ≈øuper≈øtitious when he wor≈øhippeth. Onely here is our greater helpe that we haue the manhood of Chri≈øt, as a Iacobs ladder to climbe vp to the God-head. Ioh. 1.18. No man hath ≈øeene God at any time: the onely begotten ≈øonne of the Father, as out of his bo≈øome, hath revealed him vnto vs. So that in this intricate way to the throne of grace, it will not availe vs, as
