p.hi: VVHat is Gods E≈ø≈øence?

div.p: An≈øwere.

It is that whereby be is the fir≈øt and mo≈øt ab≈øolute being. Being is that whereby a thing is truely and really in e≈ø≈øence, or exi≈øtence. And it is either the fir≈øt being, or that which is from the fir≈øt. Now God is the fir≈øt. I≈øa. 41.4. and 48.12. and therefore e≈ø≈øentially one. I≈øa. 46.9. Deut. 6.4. Eth. 4.6. Furthermore, God is ab≈øolute, as being independent from any other. There was a fir≈øt man, and a fir≈øt in euery kinde of creature, but no ab≈øolute fir≈øt, ≈øaue God. Exed. 3.14. Ioh. 8.58. If any aske me why wee define the e≈ø≈øence of God, ≈øeeing wee formerly ≈øayd it was not knowne of vs, our an≈øwere is, wee define it relatiuely, not ≈øimply, to wit, as it is a fir≈øt, and that ab≈øolute fir≈øt being is knowne be≈øt in it ≈øelfe, and ≈øo is God; for, there is nothing more intelligible then he; yet of vs nothing is le≈ø≈øe knowne, we come to him by ≈øeconds, and the begins of other things. Which proue nece≈ø≈øarily a fir≈øt, and that ab≈øolutely; for, two will proue one to goe before, and dependent beings will proue an independent. The Sunne beames are more vi≈øible to our eyes, when they are ca≈øt obliquely vpon their obiects, then when they fall directly: ≈øo, wee mu≈øt ≈øhew you God rather in the ble≈ø≈øings we receiue from him, then tho≈øe excellencies which are in him. It is the be≈øt and the
longe≈øt le≈ø≈øon even thus to learne him, and of ≈øure≈øt v≈øe: which alone if wee take not out, it were better not to haue liued. Oh, that we would often exerci≈øe, to acquaint our nature, and draw it into ≈øome familiaricie with God, the very ≈øoule and being of it. And though at fir≈øt wee make but our fire of greene wood, yet not to bee tyred with blowing, vntill our devotions be ≈øet on flame. If we endeuour, God will helpe, by enlightning our vnder≈øtandings, till we be wholly enflamed with a loue of him. And as Mo≈øes, by often talking with God, had a glorious gli≈øtering ≈øet vpon his countenance: ≈øo, wee by our often frequenting conference with God, in prayers, and meditations, ≈øhall finde in our ≈øelues, though not ≈øuddenly, yet in time, a mo≈øt heavenly change.
Q. What followes from hence?

A. The ob≈øervation of the e≈ø≈øentiall name of God; as, Lehovah, Iah, Eheie. The fir≈øt word delivers vnto vs ≈øuch an e≈ø≈øence as ever was, is, and ≈øhall be. Rev. 3.14. Ie, is a note of the Future ten≈øe; Ho, of the Pre≈øent, and Vah of the Preterperfect ten≈øe: and ≈øo is well expounded. Rev. 1.8. But ill expounded by tho≈øe, which by them would vnder≈øtand, the Trinitie, giuing the pre≈øent to the Father, pa≈øt to the ≈øonne, and to come to the Spirit. Yet it is true the Father workes of him≈øelfe, and as the pre≈øent begins time, ≈øo he the action: it is al≈øo true that the Sonne works from him, and therefore pa≈ø≈øeth on the action, as that which is pa≈øt doth time. Neyther can this be denyed but that the Spirit worketh from them both, and ≈øo fini≈øheth te action, as the future doth the poynts and periods of time. But this word is e≈ø≈øentiall, and not per≈øonall, and therefore is giuen of God to expre≈ø≈øe the e≈ø≈øence, not the per≈øons. Iah is contracted of Iehovah, not to ≈øignifie a diminute God, as if it were the diminutiue thereof: but ≈øtill for e≈ø≈øence and pre≈øent being. Neither is it applyed to Chri≈øt, humbled in the fle≈øh, as if that were the diminution of it, but it is the denomination of one and thee ≈øelfe ≈øame glorious e≈ø≈øence in all the per≈øons. Eheie, is as much as, I will be, which no
creature can peremptorily affirme. Time changeth all things, and there is none that hath the command of it, but he alone that gaue it beginning, and continuance, and to whom the account of our very houres are due, and be≈øt knowne. But I mu≈øt not lead you from Elins into the wilderne≈ø≈øe, and leauing the wells of water, trouble you with the barrenne≈ø≈øe of mans braine. Take the≈øe Texts of Scripture for confirmation, and further illu≈øtration. Exod. 3.14. and 15.2.3. P≈øal. 68.4. I≈øa. 42.8. Happy are we that wee re≈øt vpon ≈øuch a being, and may enioy all things in him, and him in all things, nothing in it ≈øelfe, ≈øo ≈øhall our ioyes neyther change nor peri≈øh: for, how ever the things them≈øelues may alter and fade, yet he in whom they are ours, is ever like him≈øelfe, con≈øtant, and everla≈øting.
Q. What followes in the ≈øecond place?

A. That God is free and voyd of all power, either to be, or be otherwi≈øe then he is. And therefore faith re≈øts vpon a mo≈øt ≈øub≈øtantiall and immutable being. Hee hath neither cau≈øes to over power him, or accidents to change him, and ≈øo he is aboue all ≈øub≈øtantiall and accidentall power. Cau≈øes prevaile in euery creature, but the Creator is voyde of them. And hereupon God is from him≈øelfe, of him≈øelfe, through him≈øelfe, and or him≈øelfe. He that is An ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ tios, without cau≈øes, is Autoon, God of him≈øelfe: yea, in vertue and power more then all cau≈øes to him≈øelfe. Goe then yee wi≈øe Idolatrous Para≈øites, and erect Shrines, and offer ≈øacrifices to your God, the world, and ≈øeeke to plea≈øe him with your ba≈øe & ≈øervile devotions: it ≈øhall be long enough ere ≈øuch religion ≈øhall make you happie: you ≈øhall at la≈øt for ≈øake tho≈øe Altars, emptie, and ≈øorrowfull; for, both you & your God are beholding to a better being then your ≈øelues. How ridiculous is it to plead for an Idollgod that hath all the cau≈øes put vpon him. What fooles will be per≈øwaded to re≈øigne vp their owne eye-≈øight, and to looke thorow ≈øuch ≈øpectacles, as very ≈øotti≈øhne≈ø≈øe doth temper for them. I will her pre≈øume to pre≈ø≈øe in with an ea≈øie determination, although it ≈øeeme to me to be no other then a plaine quarrell,
betweene ≈øtomacke, and di≈øcretion, a ≈ømall deale of wi≈øedome might decide it, e≈øpecially, con≈øidering that all things are from God, and God alone from him≈øelfe, Blu≈øh, ye Gentiles, that v≈øe a Smith, and Carpenter, ≈øo weake efficients, that they faint in drinking the ≈øtronge≈øt liquor. That make choyce of iron, bra≈ø≈øe, gold, ≈øilver, wood. &c. as matter to matte the making of a God. But aboue all let them con≈øider, whom neither the fumes of ≈øiery pa≈ø≈øion do mi≈øt, nor ≈øini≈øter re≈øpects or preiudices ≈øway downe on either ≈øide, from the pitch of iu≈øt integritie: how ≈øilly and idle a thing it is to forme a God after the image of man, bird, or be≈øt, and that without the meane≈øt life, farre from any Deitie or Divinitie, except it be by the late Ma≈øters of the Mint, in the multitude of their moderne miracles: but the Lord knowes, that the≈øe coines and ≈øtampes are farre off the pure≈øt pathes of veritie. Alas, how doe they ray and robbe God of his excellencie, whiles they robe him in the≈øe raggs of rotten relickes? But this is the very hate of heauen, and in effect, the very gate or hie way to hell, to giue our ≈øelues vnto it as our Summum Bomum, or chiefe good. Whiles Dagon ≈øtands, the Phili≈øtimes fall downe: but when Dagon was fallen before the Arke, the Phili≈øtimes ≈øtood to lift him vp. It is iu≈øt with God, that tho≈øe which want grace, ≈øhould want wit too; it is the power of ≈øuper≈øtision to turne men into tho≈øe ≈øtockes and ≈øtones, which they wor≈øhip. Methinkes their vnder≈øtandings, and wits ≈øhould haue waded further, if Dagon fall, how ≈øhall we ≈øtand by him? If he cannot helpe him≈øelfe, what ≈øhall he profit vs? Yet Idolatry and Super≈øtition are not ea≈øily put out of countenance; Dagon is vp againe, and the next morning (the fitte≈øt time for devotion) the Phili≈øtimes ha≈øten their ≈øpeed, and flocke to their Temple, to ≈øee how Dagon had re≈øted that night vnder his owne Roofe; and now behold in kindne≈ø≈øe their God is come to meeto them in the way; ≈øome peeces parted from the re≈øt ≈øalute them vpon the thre≈øhold; his head and his hands are over-runne their fellowes, to tell them, that neither his wit
nor his power could ≈øtand before the true God. And now whereas the thre≈øhold ≈øhould haue beene hollowed to the Victor; it is con≈øecrated to their beaten God. As if it had beene made more holy by his ruine, then Gods revenge. Therefore God ≈øtrikes them in their bodies, which could not feele them≈øelues ≈øtricken in their Idoll. Paine mu≈øt humble them, whom ≈øhame cannot. And now they begin to confe≈ø≈øe, that Gods hand was ≈øore vpon them, and their God. Yet they make account of confe≈ø≈øion as drunkards doe of vomiting: the Arke of the God of I≈ørael ≈øhall not abide with them. Thus wicked men vpon all occa≈øions are glad to bee rid of God, but with no patience can part with their ≈øiunes. And thus the Prophet by running through all the cau≈øes, I≈øa. 40.18. with 44.12. derides the Heathen by making their gods. And then, as if they were be≈øotted, askes them, Haue yee not knowne? Haue yee not heard? Hath it not beene told you from the beginning? Haue yee not vnder≈øtood it from the foundations of the earth? It is be that is God, which is able to ≈øit vpon he circle of the earth: ≈øtretch the heavens as a Curtains, and ≈øpread them as a Tert to dwell in.
Q. What followes from hence, that God is without all cau≈øes?

A. Fir≈øt, He is without an efficient, or beginning. Rev. 1.8. and 3.14. And from hence he is not ≈øubiect or obnoxious to the creation, or annihilation of any other, as are ll creatures; yea, the very Angels; and therefore God is ab≈øolutely independent, and ≈øupreame. And here nature and good nature may bring vs to God. Rea≈øon hath no where either bound or banke to re≈øtraine it, but at this cau≈øe, hither will it bring vs, and here will it leaue vs. I am the beginning of the creatures, ≈øayth Chri≈øt; therefore God: goe by the creatures as workes, and they will lead vs to their fir≈øt efficient and beginning. Secondly, God is without all matter; and therefore mo≈øt ≈øpirituall: the le≈ø≈øe matter, and the more forme the creatures inioy, the more ≈øpirituall it makes them. By God therefore, ≈øo pure a ≈øpirit, are all things nouri≈øhed with the onely dew of divine benediction: but this high way is ≈øo plaine, that a guide were needle≈ø≈øe.
Furthermore, God being mo≈øt ≈øpirituall, is likewi≈øe mo≈øt invi≈øible, and impalpable. Too ≈øubtile for ≈øinew or ≈øight to ≈øea≈øe vpon him. Luk. 24.39.1. Tim. 1.17. It would pre≈øent him for a furious and raving Bedlam, that ≈øhould once formalize God to his owne fancies. Againe, where matter is wanting, there common nature is wanting; for, things communicate, as they ri≈øe from ≈øome common ≈øtocke, and ≈øtemme. And becau≈øe all ≈øpecialls are contained vnder generalls, God wants that too; and therefore is properly, neither e≈ø≈øence, or being: but an Huperou≈øios, or ≈øuper ≈øub≈øtantiall being by him≈øelfe, one onely in number, neither dividing, nor devided; multiplying, or multiplyed. The wife is the husband devided, and the childe is the father multiplied. But God is neither ≈øo devided into three, neither are three ≈øo multiplied from one. He is (if I may ≈øo ≈øpeake with reverence) without all ≈øtocke or kine. Therefore when we ≈øay, e≈ø≈øence is common, and per≈øon proper, it mu≈øt be receiued with a graine of ≈øalt. For the common nature is not di≈øtributed into parts, as into per≈øons; but as common to all, ≈øo it is one individuall and ≈øingular e≈ø≈øence in them all, and that receiued of each per≈øon without parts or pa≈ø≈øions; for, matter is the ground of both, and where that is wanting, they are not to bee found. I ≈øtay the longer vpon the≈øe Negatiues, becau≈øe we re not loo≈øely & lightly to ≈ølide over the things of God, as if they were vulgar, and triviall, like our owne. Thus farre you haue ≈øeene God, out of the rode and reach of the efficient, and matter: ≈øee him now voyd of forme and end; for in them likewi≈øe con≈øi≈øts power to be. The forme in going and comming is the cau≈øe of all generation and corruption; God therefore being without it, is incorruptible, and therefore a God immortall and everla≈øting. P≈øal. 102.26.27. Iam. 1.17.1. Tim. 1.17. A choice and refined peece of high Quinte≈ø≈øence of wit is that of Papi≈øts in their breaden god, which yet never Church could di≈øtill out of her braines, or a≈øpire vnto, be≈øides their owne. What generation and corruption doe they make of the everla≈øting
bread of heauen? Here perhaps might wee finde ≈øtuffe enough (I will not ≈øay to lade an Argo≈øie) but to over lade any mans wit in the world to reply vnto. It ≈øhall ≈øuffice vs to thinke of God as God, and man as man. Chri≈øt in heaven, and Chri≈øt in the Sacrament. Now if wee adde further, without both matter and forme together, then is God neither the whole, nor the member of any thing, or any wayes to be di≈øtributed or defined; I meane with perfect definition; becau≈øe he hath no e≈ø≈øence diver≈øe from him≈øelfe, and therefore the definition, and that which it defines, are all one: ≈øo, that in God Thees and Theiotees, God and the God-head are all one. La≈øtly, hauing neither matter, nor forme, he wants all terms and limitations of e≈ø≈øence, and therefore as mo≈øt ≈øimple, ≈øo mo≈øt infinite in being. For end, God is endle≈ø≈øe, being neither for any other, or hauing any other better then him≈øelfe, and therefore the chiefe good, and by communication our good, and ≈øo to be de≈øired aboue all. Math. 19.17. P≈øal. 63.7.11 and 73.25. and 18.1.2. How ea≈øie is it now for Chri≈øtians to in≈øult over worldlings, that thinke them≈øelues worthy of enuie? and to turne off their darling with a ≈øcornefull repul≈øe? What if it make vs the Devils proffer, All the≈øe will I giue you: Can wee not returne S. Peters an≈øwere, Thy ≈øiluer and gold peri≈øh with thee? He alone that is cau≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe, ≈øhall cau≈øe mee the happine≈ø≈øe I expect, looke, and long for.
Q. What followes from hence, that God is without accidents?

A. That he is both Apo≈øes, without quantitie, and Apoios without qualitie. In regard of the fir≈øt, hee is neither augmented nor dimini≈øhed; of the ≈øecond, neither altered nor changed. Euen to your old age I am he, and euen to heare haires will I carry you. I≈øa. 46.4. I am the Lord, I change not: therefore yee ≈øonnes of Iacob are not con≈øumed. Mal. 3.6. By this I ≈øee that all things here below are as farre from ≈øinceritie, as continuance, if they were ≈øweete, as the ioyes aboue, yet how ≈øhould their ficklene≈ø≈øe coole our delights, and make vs e≈øteeme the≈øe drams of honey lo≈øt in pounds of gall, and guile? We laugh at their choice that are in loue
with the deformed; and what a face is this we now dove vpon? See if our ≈øinnes, cares, and cro≈ø≈øes haue not like a filthy morphew over-≈øpread it; and made it loath≈øome (in compari≈øon of the beautie of the Creator) to all iudicious eyes. I marvaile then that we ≈øhould thus loue, what woe cannot hold, and for a ≈øhadow of a ≈ømoake, and a dreame of a ≈øhadow leaue him, who≈øe light is neither variable, nor ≈øhadowed with turning. Iam. 1.17. Here then, if wee will be wi≈øe Marchants, thri≈øtie and happie v≈øurers, let vs part with that which wee can nor keepe, that we may gaine him whom wee cannot loo≈øe. The≈øe cottages of ours haue beene ruinous a long time, and the wor≈øe for their accidents, and yet like fooles wee haue not thought of their fall. Lord giue mee grace to leane vpon thee, then ≈øhall my fall be ea≈øie, and my re≈øt endle≈ø≈øe. Oh, thou which art out of the power of others, over power mee to the obedience of thy ≈øelfe.
Q. What will follow from Gods e≈ø≈øence in the la≈øt place?

A. That God is one mo≈øt pure and meere act; that is, his being and action are all one thing. For as his e≈ø≈øence is ab≈øolute, ≈øo is his working. There is never a creature but hee worketh by qualities, and ≈øo his act is fir≈øt in the power of them. The fire warmes not without heat, neither doth man vnder≈øtand without rea≈øon: a Bird might as ea≈øily flee without wings, and fire a≈øcend without lightne≈ø≈øe, as the creature produce his actions without facultie and power thereunto. And hereupon it followeth, that pa≈ø≈øion and re≈øi≈øtence are incident to all his workes. The very Deuils ≈øuffer, and are re≈øi≈øted of God, and how ≈øoever their motion is too ≈øwift to be ≈øtricken, or ≈ølayed by corporall in≈øtruments, yet God is quicke enough for them, to make them both feele and feare the dint of his ≈øword. God therefore being ≈øo ab≈øolute an act, mu≈øt needs haue his being and doing all one. Iob. 5.17. My father worketh hitherto, and I worke, which ≈øhewes, that Gods act is eternall; and ≈øo creation as an act is from God, hath no beginning, as a pa≈ø≈øion in the creature, is mea≈øured by time. In regard of the fir≈øt wee call
him a pure and meere act. In regard of the ≈øecond, omnipotent, being able to make nothing as well as ≈øome thing, feele his worke which before could not be perceiued. And therefore omnipotencie, or Almightie power is not giuen to God in regard of him≈øelfe, but his creatures, which may feele that hand which before was vnfelt. Againe, Gods being and act being all one thing, hee mu≈øt needs doe all things by his e≈ø≈øence, which is purely one. Hence God is the Archetype, or fir≈øt draught of euery eminent act. In which re≈øpect it mu≈øt needs be of ≈øoueraigne v≈øe for the di≈øcouering and reforming of what≈øoeuer error time hath ≈øoyled his actions withall. How are defaced copies, and di≈ø≈øigured pictures better amended, then by reducing them to their originall? If the pipe fayle, goe wee not to the head? O that his acts were ≈øet as a frontlet betweene the eyes, & as a ≈øeale vpon the hearts of all his followers. Ought not all our actions to be as branches of this root? Surely, this is the cleare head-≈øpring of all other en≈øuing brookes; and as little ≈øtreames empty them≈øelues into great rivers; and they againe into the Sea; ≈øo mu≈øt all runne to this maine. Venerable it is for the very antiquitie of it. Con≈øidering therefore what price men doe ≈øet vpon old copies, coynes, and ≈øtatues;Ignat: ad Marian: Ca≈ø≈øob. and that none will pa≈ø≈øe by a chry≈øtall fountaine, bearing ≈øome auncient name or date, but will ta≈øte thereof, though no thir≈øt provokes him; I could not well pa≈ø≈øe over this leafe without ≈øome le≈ø≈øon for mine owne learning. If any haue pa≈ø≈øed a longer way, with more happy fruit of ob≈øervation, I de≈øire hee would not ≈øpare in ≈øome part to report the excellency of this travell. But to keepe me within the ≈øphere of my profe≈ø≈øion. He that is ≈øo pure an act, mu≈øt needs bee without all pa≈ø≈øion, and re≈øi≈øtence. A pure act cannot ≈øuffer,Iob 9.4 Rom. 9.19. becau≈øe it wants that power which ≈øhould ≈øubmit it to another; neither can it be re≈øi≈øted, for that which is over-powered, ≈øuffers in re≈øi≈øting, which to a meere act is impo≈ø≈øible. And whereas God ≈øayes, Amos. 2.13. I am pre≈ø≈øed vnder you, as a Cart is pre≈ø≈øed that s full of ≈øbeaues: His meaning is, that their ≈øinne
was ≈øo intollerable and waightie, that it was time to ea≈øe him≈øelfe of it by due puni≈øhment,Amos. 2.14.15.16. not ≈øuffering the ≈øwift to e≈øcape by flight, or the ≈øtrong by force, as the next ver≈øes ≈øhew. O then the mi≈øery of all tho≈øe that will needs be rich with iniury, and grow great by being con≈øcious of ≈øecret evils. Wealth and honour without God, when they are at the be≈øt, are ≈øcarce our friends: but at the wor≈øt, our tormentors. Alas, alas, how ill agrees a gay coat, and a fe≈øtred heart? What availes an high title with an hell in the ≈øoule? The≈øe are they that mu≈øt ≈øuffer. Sinne owes them a ≈øpite, and will pay them home when they lea≈øt thinke of it, yea, when they are lea≈øt able to beare it. I will therefore preferre all the afflictions of Gods I≈øreal, Heb. 11.25. before the≈øe plea≈øures of AEgypt; and choo≈øe rather to eat the lambe Chri≈øt, with the≈øe ≈øowre herbes, then all the≈øe fle≈øh-pots of ≈øinne. Let me be mi≈øerable, ≈øo I be not guilty, and rather abound with ≈øorrow then ≈øinne: ≈øo ≈øhall the con≈øuming fire that no water can quench, or violence oppo≈øe, haue mercy vpon me.Heb. 12.29: He is liberall, that I liue; but he ≈øhall bee munificent, in bringing a poore wretch from all mi≈øeries to ta≈øte of the full cup of his glory. Hitherto we haue but heard of God by way of Negation, denying of him all the imperfections of the creatures: Now, wee are to ≈øpeake of him by way of Affirmation, giuing him the mo≈øt eminent and excellent perfections of his owne workes. The Schooles haue layd vs downe a three-fold way of knowing God. As the negation of imperfections, the affirmation of perfections, and the cau≈øation of great workes. The two fir≈øt we follow in Gods ≈øufficiency, the la≈øt wee leaue as proper to the efficiency.

div.head: CHAPTER V. Of the Attributes of the E≈ø≈øence.

p.hi: Que≈øtion.
BVt how ≈øhall God be apprehended of vs, ≈øeeing he is ≈øimply one?

div.p: An≈øwere.

In that he hath made him≈øelfe many attributes. It is fit that the obiect and the vnder≈øtanding be proportionable to it ≈øelfe, an infinite vnder≈øtanding is capable of an infinite obiect, and ≈øo God onely vnder≈øtands him≈øelfe. Now becau≈øe man cannot apprehend God by one act of vnder≈øtanding, the ≈øimplicitie of his face and e≈ø≈øence is layd open by the multiplicitie of his backe-parts, and attributes. So God reuealed him≈øelfe to Mo≈øes, when he proclaimed his glorious Name: The Lord, the Lord, ≈øtrong, gracious, and mercifull, Exod. 34.6. &c. And ≈øo Mo≈øes him≈øelfe publi≈øhed Gods name: A≈øcribe yee greatne≈ø≈øe to our God, he is arocke, is worke is perfect: Deut. 32.3.4. all his wayes are iudgement: a God of truth, and without iniquitie, iu≈øt and right is he. Preiudice is a great enemy to truth, and makes the mind vncapable of it. Hence it comes to pa≈ø≈øe, that mo≈øt men de≈øpaire of any knowledge of God, and ≈øo fall into Athei≈øme, or el≈øe they will fa≈øhion God to ≈øome forme of their owne, whether of an humane body, or of admirable light; or if their mindes haue any other more likely, and plea≈øing image; and ≈øo become Idolaters with their owne conceits. In matters therefore of ≈øo great con≈øequence, I will fir≈øt lay a ≈øure ground, and then beleeue, though I can argue no further; and will hold the conclu≈øion, in ≈øpight of all premi≈ø≈øes. He that teacheth God vpon the warrant of his owne braine, layes the brands together without tongues, and is ≈øure (at lea≈øt) to burne his owne fingers. I will therefore beware how I ≈øayle vpon this Sea without Compa≈ø≈øe.
Q. What are Gods Attributes?

A. That one mo≈øt pure God, diver≈øely apprchended. Hoare O I≈ørael, Deut. 6.4. And 10.17. the Lord thy God is one, great, mightie, terrible, &c. Faith, which is the divine Logick of Gods ≈øpirit, re≈øts vpon te≈øtimony aboue all Arguments, and ≈øo takes God barely on his word, without any further di≈øcour≈øe: yet by the way of vnder≈øtanding, which apprehends the knowledge of things by Arguments, di≈øtinct from the things, and among≈øt them≈øelues, Faith is ≈øo farre content that Rea≈øon ≈øhew the way, in making the Attributes diver≈øe from the e≈ø≈øence, and among≈øt them≈øelues; but checks rea≈øon when it would make them oppo≈øite, or really to be di≈øtingui≈øhed. It is aboue the Art of rea≈øon to teach the ≈øubiect and all his attributes to be one in nature; and yet thus farre it may agree with rea≈øon, to make them diver≈øe. So that by faith and the way of ≈øanctified rea≈øon, wee come to apprehend him that is ≈øimply one. Mans rea≈øon in matter of faith, as fire in the fir≈øt degree of her a≈øcent may be a flame, next ≈ømoake, and then nothing. The light may be good, if like fooles-fire wee tru≈øt it not too long. Faith ≈øtands like an auncient Pyramid; which the le≈ø≈øe it growes to a mans eye, the neerer it reaches to heauen. Whereas rea≈øon for the mo≈øt part, like A≈øtronomie begins in Nature, ends in Magicke. If it may haue the whole handling of divinitie, it will make it ridiculous before it leaue it. Logicke, the Heraldry of all Arts, and the be≈øt array of indgement, is in the mo≈øt exact knowledge of God, either a skilful ignorance, or a wild knowledge. Almo≈øt as good di≈øcour≈øe to brute bea≈øts, of the depth of Phylo≈øophy, as to meere carnall men of the my≈øteries of Divinitie. He that will beleeue no more, then he conceiues by rea≈øon, can never be a Chri≈øtian; or he a Logician, that will a≈ø≈øent without rea≈øon. And ≈øeeing God hath made the ≈øoule as the lampe of the body, and rea≈øon as the lampe of the ≈øoule; Religion of Rea≈øon, and Faith of Religion: Let vs v≈øe all the≈øe lights without confu≈øion, and let not one trip vp the heeles of the other, according to the dexteritie of humane policy. In
divine things what we may, wee mu≈øt conceiue, the re≈øt beleeue and wonder. Not the curious head, but the credulous and plaine heart, is accepted with God. Wee will bolt out by rea≈øon, what may helpe faith, not confound it. In briefe, to open a little crevi≈øe of further light, and giue a little more glimp≈øe to the poynt, let the in≈øuing con≈øectaries be well marked and ob≈øerved.
Q. What followes from hence?

A. That the attributes differ not really from his e≈ø≈øence, or betweene them≈øelues, but onely in re≈øpect of our vnder≈øtanding: Hence they are his e≈ø≈øence. I am that I am, Exod. 3.14. teacheth an Ocean of Divinitie: where the attribute is, I am, as well as the ≈øubiect, and ≈øo nothing is giuen to God that is le≈ø≈øe then him≈øelfe. God is mercifull, and his mercy is him≈øelfe. Loe, with this word, I am, wee may happily wade out of tho≈øe deepes, whereof our conceits can finde no bottome. A little further, here ≈øhall wee not like Pagans wor≈øhipping the Sunne, hold our hands to the Glo-worme in ≈øtead of a coale for heat.
Q. What then ob≈øerue you in the ≈øecond place?

A. That all his attributes are giuen vnto him, both in the ab≈øtract, and concret; as God is mercifull, or God is mercy it ≈øelfe; To haue life, and be life: to be in the light, Ioh. 5.26. With 14.6. 1. Ioh. 1.5.7. 1. Ioh. 4.7.8. and the light: loue to come from God, and be God are all one. Thinke of him, as one, who≈øe wi≈øedome is his iu≈øtice, who≈øe iu≈øtice is his power, who≈øe power is his mercy; and who≈øe wi≈øedome, iu≈øtice; power, and mercy, are him≈øelfe. Good without qualitie, great without quantitie, everla≈øting without time, pre≈øent every where without place, containing all things without extent. The≈øe things are not to bee weighed at the common beame of cu≈øtome and opinion, but at the golden ≈øtandard of Gods Sanctuary.Iob. 28.1.2. Siluer hath his veine, and Gold his mine where it is found, iron is taken out of the earth, and bra≈ø≈øe moulten out of the ≈øtones, but the place of this wi≈øedome is not to be found in the land of the liuing. Faint not in this knowledge, neither be weary of well-doing: for though in rowing this ve≈ø≈øell vpon ≈øo maine an ocean,
the windes blow, and cro≈ø≈øe Seas rage, yet God our mo≈øt skilfull Pilote, can ≈øtraight ≈øend an Halcyon to let vs on ≈øhoare.
Q. What learne we in the third place?

A. That his Attributes are not in him by participation, imperfectly, but at the fir≈øt hand, and by them≈øelues mo≈øt perfectly. God needs to borrow from none that which hee meanes to be≈øtow vpon vs, but being rich in grace, giues vs of his owne.Gen. 17.1. P≈øal. 36.9. Rom. 11.3. Ephe≈ø. 1.7. As one Diamond fa≈øhions another; ≈øo is this ≈øequele wrought out of the former; for, hee that is goodne≈ø≈øe it ≈øelfe, receiues none from others. That mans face is hatcht all over with impudence, that dare arrogate the lea≈øt good to him≈øelfe. It is vertue that will alwayes cleere her way as ≈øhee goes; but vice will be ever behind hand with it ≈øelfe. I know that God requires of our debts, a reckoning, not payment. And I beleeue heauen to be the ea≈øie≈øt purcha≈øe, for wee are the richer for the di≈øbur≈øing.
Q. What followes in the fourth place?

A. That all his attributes are in him in the highe≈øt degree, and can no wayes be intended, or remitted, though in regard of the obiect about which they are exerci≈øed, they may le≈ø≈øe or more appeare. P≈øal. 125.4.5. Rom. 9.13. For as fire burneth not in dry wood and greene wood alike; ≈øo, Gods grace is not to euery per≈øon in the ≈øame mea≈øure. His abundance is infinite; and therefore cannot admit decrea≈øe. Take a drop out of the Sea, and the water will be ≈øo much the le≈ø≈øe: but here the very flouds of Gods bountie, running all abroad, doe nothing le≈ø≈øen his ≈øtore. If wee receiue ≈øparingly, it is not for want either of plentie in him, or liberalitie to vs, but for very want of capacitie in our ≈øelues: even as they that come to the riuer, to draw water, receiue ≈øo much as their ve≈ø≈øell will hold.P≈øal. 81.19. Open thy mouth wide (≈øayth God) and I will fill it. And here the Rule in nature holds, That all cau≈øes doe worke according to the di≈øpo≈øition of the ≈øubiect: Saue with this caution, that God can di≈øpo≈øe of the ≈øubiect as he plea≈øeth, for the holding of his mercy. Happine≈ø≈øe and mi≈øery, are Antipodes, and God can bring them into another world,
that walke in the kingdome of darkne≈ø≈øe. O pitty not inferior to plenty, & loue towards di≈øtre≈ø≈øed ≈øinners, no le≈ø≈øe then infinite. A degree doth either extend the quantitie, as great, greater, the greate≈øt; or intend the qualitie, as good, better, the be≈øt: and God is a degree aboue the Superlatiue, as, greatne≈ø≈øe, or goodne≈ø≈øe it ≈øelfe. God is Great. P≈øal. 77.13. Greater. Iob 33.12. Greate≈øt. P≈øal. 95.3. Greatne≈ø≈øe it ≈øelfe. P≈øal. 145.3. Good. P≈øal. 106.1. Better. P≈øal. 108.9. Be≈øt. Phil. 1.23. Goodne≈ø≈øe it ≈øelfe. Math. 19.17.Gen. 15.1. To Abraham God is a reward, a great reward, yea, an exceeding great reward. I ≈øee it is difficult to avoyd varietie, I will not bee curious in traver≈øing opinions. I ≈øtudie for ≈øimple truth, as one that will not lead you out of the rode way, to ≈øhew you the turnings.
Q. May there any thing yet follow in the fift place?

A. Yes, That all the Attributes of God are equall betweene them≈øelues, though they appeare not ≈øo to euery man. Exod. 34.5.6. P≈øal. 103.8. Ezek. 18.25.29. Slow to anger much in mercy. If I were dumbe, the≈øe ≈øweete meditations would make me finde a tongue. If it be low water, the mill may ≈øtand ≈øtill, but ≈øuch abundance of heartie thoughts will ≈øet the wheeles on going. Q. Is there yet any thing that may further be learned from the definition of Gods Attributes?

A. This yet remaineth, that all the attributes are in him together, though they appeare not together in his creatures. Rom. 1.20. Act. 17.17. Luk. 10.21. Some appeare in creation, ≈øome in corruption, ≈øome in redemption. Iu≈øtice and mercy are as ab≈øolute in God, as wi≈øedome and power, though they appeare not to vs, before the application
of Chri≈øt to the Church, where prede≈øtination may mo≈øt ≈øafely be handled.Ier. 31.3. I haue loued thee with an euerla≈øting loue. Therefore with louing kindne≈ø≈øe haue I drawne thee. This life I count as a throng in a narrow pa≈ø≈øage: he that is fir≈øt out, finds ea≈øe, he in the middle wor≈øt hemmed in with troubles, the hindmo≈øt that driues both out before him, though not ≈øuffering wrong, hath his part in doing it. Oathes ≈øtriue for number with words; ≈øcoffes with oaths, vaine ≈øpeeches with both. I beleeue the de≈øtiny of all my ≈øorrowes is written in heauen by a wi≈øe and eternall decree, and that no evils either come by chance, or are let loo≈øe to light where they li≈øt, and therefore it ≈øhall content mee, that the faithfull God that hath ordained, moderates them. And here Ica≈øt Anchor.

A. Two,Exod. 3.13. which ≈øhew either what he is, or who he is. Mo≈øes de≈øires to know what is his name; and Pharaoh will know who he is,Exod. 5.2. before he will let I≈ørael goe. To the fir≈øt que≈øtion God gaue a ≈øhort an≈øwere, I am. To the ≈øecond he made a large reply, till Pharaoh was compelled to an≈øwere him≈øelfe,
the Lord is righteous. Exod. 9.22. When we de≈øire to be acquainted with ≈øome great Per≈øonage, wee v≈øually inquire, who, or what is ≈øuch a Per≈øon, euen thir≈øting till wee heare his name, or titles: So, Faith cannot be ≈øati≈øfied without ≈øome knowledge of the nature, or properties of God.2. Tim. 1.12. And mu≈øt be inquiring whom or what ≈øhe hath beleeued. And here I know it will be farre more ea≈øie to fill the belly of faith, then the eye of rea≈øon. That faith may therefore be as the elbow for a heauy Soule to leane on, wee will vnder prop it with both the≈øe pillars. I know that as the Sea receiueth all ≈øtreames, and yet hath proper water in farre greater abundance: ≈øo, in God there is a confluence of the perfections of all creatures, and yet his owne perfection doth infinitely exceed them. Wee are to meddle with the fir≈øt, with the pre≈øence whereof, all the powers of the minde ≈øhall be filled; all the ≈øen≈øes of the body ≈øhall be ≈øatiated: in ≈øo much as they ≈øhall, neither in de≈øire ≈øeeke, nor in hope a≈øpire, nor in imagination faine any greater plea≈øure.
Q. What is God?

A. God is a ≈øpirit, hauing life in him≈øelfe, or of him≈øelfe. He is (as wee haue heard) both being and Act;Ioh. 4.24. With 5.26. 2. Cor. 3.17. now wee ≈øee both in our definition, not that hee is compounded of them, but expre≈ø≈øed by them. In euery creature there is a compo≈øition of matter and forme, out of which it hath his e≈ø≈øence and action: ≈øo in God, ≈øpirit is as the matter, life as the forme; I ≈øay expre≈ø≈øing, not compounding his nature. And the rea≈øon is liuely, for God mu≈øt be the mo≈øt excellent nature, and the mo≈øt eminent act. Spirit is the pure≈øt nature, and life the quicke≈øt act. Ob≈øerue but in nature, and you ≈øhall find, that much matter and little forme make things gro≈ø≈øe and corporall: much forme and little matter fine and ≈øpirituall. Earth is more gro≈ø≈øe then water; water then ayre; ayre then fire; bodies then ≈øoules; men then Angels; Angels then God. There is no creature free from matter, for then ≈øhould it be as ≈øpirituall as God. He onely is without matter, and therefore mo≈øt ≈øpirituall; and con≈øequently mo≈øt actiue, as if he were all forme.
Hence he is ≈øtiled the liuing God. Ier. 10.10. 1. Tim. 4.10. Deut. 32.40. Iudg. 8.19. Ruth. 3.13. Ezek. 33.11. Dan. 4.37. by who≈øe life wee are to ≈øweare as hauing mo≈øt intelligence of the truth, and greate≈øt power to puni≈øh the liar. Being a ≈øpirit hee mu≈øt needs be ≈øtrong and ≈øubtile to enter where he will; being life it ≈øelfe he mu≈øt needs quicken and quiet all de≈øires and appetites.Act. 17.28. Ioh. 1.4. And 5.21.26. Alas, then how mi≈øerable are all tho≈øe that want this God, or haue prouoked him by their ≈øinnes? As one that floateth, halfe choaked and wearied in the midde≈øt of the Sea, cea≈øeth not to wre≈øtle with the waues, to ca≈øt forth his hands euery way, although he gra≈øpeth nothing, but thinne and weake water, which continually deceiueth his paines; ≈øo, they that both ≈øwim and ≈øinke in this depth of death, ≈øhall alwayes ≈øtriue and ≈øtruggle therewith, although they neither finde nor hope for any helpe. O deadly life: O immortall death; if the paine were no greater then the ≈øtinging of Ants, or of Fleas, eternitie were enough to make it intolerable.Ioh. 5.21.24. 2 Cor. 4.11. Gal. 2.19.20. Lord quicken me from this death, and make me by faith to pa≈ø≈øe from it vnto life purpo≈øed and promi≈øed in thine owne beloued. Happie are all they that beleeue, and in beleeuing ≈øerue this ≈øpirit of life in ≈øpirit and truth, Ioh. 4.24. Luk. 1.75. all the dayes of their life.
Q. What are the attributes that ≈øhew vs who he is?

A. His e≈ø≈øentiall properties. And here the field is large for the de≈øcribing of God Simonides being asked of Hiero the King, what God was, demanded a dayes re≈øpite, then two dayes, afterwards three: and being asked the rea≈øon, an≈øwered, that the longer he thought what God ≈øhould bee, the le≈ø≈øe he vnder≈øtood of him. And another heathen ≈øaid, It is hard to find a God; Plato. but to vnder≈øtand him impo≈ø≈øible. No wonder, the≈øe men had but the light of Nature, yet thus farre they aymed right,Qu√≤ enim prius eo notius natur√¢. and ≈øhot neere, that God the mo≈øt intelligible was lea≈øt vnder≈øtood of vs; and that the infinite vnder≈øtanding was not within the compa≈ø≈øe and fadome of the finite; but in helping that default by their owne imaginations, went them≈øelues exceeding wide, and came not neere the marke: which I a≈øcribe not to any defect
of eye ≈øight in tho≈øe ≈øharpe ≈øighted Eagles of Nature, but onely to the want of fixed contemplations in the book of the world, and more e≈øpecially their vtter ignorance of the word of God. Wee therefore that enioy the ≈øacred Scriptures may ≈øee farre further into this my≈øtery. Remembring alwayes, that Divinitie as the Mi≈øtre≈ø≈øe taketh vpon her to direct her hand-mayd, and that the Bible is the be≈øt man of coun≈øell, for the greate≈øt Clarke in the world, containing more then all the Divines of the Heathen ever ≈øaw the ≈øhadow of. All which will be≈øt appeare by the opening of this rich Cabinet of Gods Attributes, and viewing the ≈øeverall Iewels in it, by this torch-light, or rather Sunne of the little world. And it ≈øhould be a ≈øhame for Chri≈øtians, if it were not better knowne of them then Lip≈øius his Bee-hiue, or Machiavels Spider-web; about which many wits, like a Dor, end their flights in a Dung-hill.Rom. 3.4. Exod. 23.19. P≈øal. 46.1. With 70.5. Exod. 34.6. And here I might enter an ample harve≈øt of properties affirmatiue & negatiue, proper and figuratiue, ab≈øolute and Relatiue. But here ≈øuch properties are to be handled as appeare by them≈øelues as no wayes flowing from the e≈ø≈øence of the creatures, as all negatiue, figuratiue, and relatiue properties doe. Onely one thing I cannot but mention in admiration of Gods goodne≈ø≈øe vnto vs, which is, that God is content to take properties mo≈øt improper, as a body in re≈øpect of all the members of it, head, face, eyes, eye-lids, apple of the eye, mouth, eares, necke, hand, arme, right hand, fingers, feete, heart, bowels, &c. Dan. 7.9. Exod. 33.20.23. 2. Chron. 16.9. P≈øal. 11.4. Deut. 32.10. Io≈øh. 9.14. P≈øal. 31.2. 2. Sam. 22.9. Ier. 18.17. Act. 4.28. Exod. 6.6. and 15.6. and 31.18. P≈øal. 110.1. 1. Sam. 2.35. Ier. 31.20. So likewi≈øe a ≈øoule coupled with the body and members. I≈øa. 1.14. ≈øo the ≈øen≈øes that ri≈øe from the vnion, both inward and outward; as, memory, forgetfulne≈ø≈øe; hearing, ≈øeeing, ≈ømelling, &c. P≈øal. 136.23. I≈øa. 49.14. P≈øal. 14.2. and 5.1.2. Gen. 8.21. In briefe, he a≈ø≈øumeth the very affections and pa≈ø≈øions of the ≈øoule, as ioy, ≈øorrow, anger, zeale, Ielou≈øie, &c. Iudg. 9.13. Gen. 6.6. Rom. 1.18. Nay, yet hee
goes lower, and by the wings of birds, hornes of bea≈øts, the Sunne, the light, their very ≈øhadow, the fire, rockes, and ≈øtones he ≈øpeakes vnto vs. P≈øal. 91.4.2. Sam. 22.3. P≈øal. 84.11.1. Ioh. 1.5. P≈øal. 91.1. Deut. 4.24. P≈øal. 71.3. yea, and to goe to the lowe≈øt, by the works of mans hands, as ≈øhields, and bucklers, &c. P≈øal. 2.3. and 144.2. yet we are to vnder≈øtand, that all the≈øe are attributed vnto God improperly, and by way of his gracious condi≈øcending vnto, and ≈øympathizing with mans nature, becau≈øe being literally taken, they are derogatory vnto his eternall glory, whereunto ≈øimplicitie, and vniformitie are of ab≈øolute nece≈ø≈øitie. O Lord, doe≈øt thou ≈øpeake ≈øo familiarly vnto vs, and haue wee ≈øo little knowledge of thee? I cannot but blu≈øh to heare very Countrey-people ≈øpeake ≈øtatutes and husbandry well enough, to make their neighbours thinke them wi≈øe men: yea, to be ≈øo well skilled in Arithmeticke and rates, as they haue eloquence enough to faue their twopence. And yet (O Lord) what a world of blindne≈ø≈øe is there in conceiuing, and vnder≈øtanding of thee? O muckwormes of the world, which like the Gentiles breed of putrefaction, and Beetles fed in the dung, reli≈øhing nothing el≈øe but earthly things: thinking there is no other godline≈ø≈øe but gaine; no happine≈ø≈øe but to ≈øcrape and gather, to haue and to hold. Let them know that the trea≈øures of wickedne≈ø≈øe and wrath will goe together: and that they that make ca≈øting Nets for all fi≈øh that come, will in the end get the Devill and all: like Seruing-men, by the ≈øuper≈øcription of their livery, they tell vs, without asking, who ownes them,Rom. 6.16. and though they be not drunke, yet they are not their owne men; for, his ≈øeruants they are to whom they obey. God make vs more pliant to his will, ≈øeeing ≈øo graciou≈øly he applies him≈øelfe vnto vs.
Q. How many ≈øort of properties are there that ≈øhew God more ab≈øolutely and properly?

A. Two, either ≈øhewing how great, or what manner of God he is. P≈øal. 145.3.8. Deut. 10.17. Great is the Lord, and gracious, and mercifull, &c. Our God is the God of Gods, and Lord of Lords, a great God, mightie
and terrible. Infinitely great without quantitie, infinitely good without qualitie. Who being both the originall, and the end of all things, cannot rightly be ≈øayd to be any thing, for he mu≈øt needs be aboue all, and better then all: in regard therefore of his incomprehen≈øible nature, wee mu≈øt acknowledge, that darkene≈ø≈øe is his ≈øecret place, P≈øal. 18.11. clouds and thicke mi≈øts are round about him: yet ≈øo he hath declared him≈øelfe vnto vs, that we may know him to be mo≈øt wi≈øe in vnder≈øtanding, mo≈øt mighty in ability, and mo≈øt louing in will to ≈øuccour and ≈øaue vs. As are hiding places from the winde, and refuges from tempe≈øts, ryvers of waters to dry places, and as raine to the new mowne gra≈ø≈øe, &c. ≈øo ≈øhall we finde him our ≈øtay, if wee ≈øeeke him as we may.

p.hi: VVHat Attributes ≈øhew his Greatne≈ø≈øe?

div.p: An≈øwere.

His vnitie, in regard of quantitie di≈øcret, Infinitene≈ø≈øe and eternitie, in regard of quantitie continued: ≈øuch is his Greatne≈ø≈øe, that he is that one mo≈øt infinite and eternall. See now, that I, euen I am he, and there is no God with me; Deut. 32.39. I lift vp my hand to heauen, and ≈øay, I liue for ever. In matter of life and death there is none comparable to the Almighty; all are but cyphers, that ≈øtand for a number with him, who≈øe value and account is to be reckoned for nought. Let all proud Herods take heed, how they admit but the voyce of a God.Act 12.22.23. As no wrong can e≈øcape him; ≈øo lea≈øt of all tho≈øe which are offred to his Maie≈øty: he that made the eare, needs no intelligence of the tongue. All haue to doe with a God, that is light of hearing; men cannot whi≈øper any evill ≈øo ≈øecretly, that he ≈øhould not cry out of noy≈øe: and what
needs any other evidence, when the Iudge is the witne≈ø≈øe? And though ≈øome ≈øinnes doe not ever looke the ≈øame way they moue; yet this ≈øingle eyed God can ea≈øily di≈øtingui≈øh betwixt the vi≈øor of actions, and the face: he therefore cannot want honour and patronage, that ≈øeekes the honour of this God.
Q. What is Gods Vnitie?

A. Whereby he being one in e≈ø≈øence, is al≈øo one in number. Vnto thee it was ≈øhewed, Deut. 4.35. Mar. 12.32. 1. Cor. 8.4.5.6. that thou mighte≈øt know, that the Lord he is God; there is none el≈øe be≈øide him. Thou ha≈øt ≈øaid the truth: for there is one God, and there is no other but he. Though many are called Gods, yet to vs there is but one God. Hence it followeth that we need not be di≈øtracted in the wor≈øhip of this our God. Let him carry vs which way hee will, make the pa≈ø≈øages never ≈øo trouble≈øome and perillous, yet the ≈øame hand that makes them hard will make them ≈øure, and if we be faithfull to him, he will ma≈øter all difficulties for vs. O God as wee haue tru≈øted thee with the beginning, ≈øo will wee tru≈øt thee with the fini≈øhing of our glory. And though never ≈øo many or maine hinderances of our ≈øaluation offer them≈øelues, and after all our hopes, threaten to defeat vs, yet faithfull art thou that ha≈øt promi≈øed, which wilt al≈øo doe it. For how ≈øhould≈øt thou that art one in number and e≈ø≈øence, be otherwi≈øe then thy ≈øelfe. All things doe turne vpon this poynt, and ha≈øten to this center: if it were not for vnitie, multiplicitie would de≈øtroy it ≈øelfe. Nature will runne out of it ≈øelfe to doe homage to this vniforme creator. What ayled thee O Sea, that thou fledde≈øt, and thou Iordan, that thou wa≈øt driuen backe? yee mountaines that yee leaped like Rammes, and yee little hills like Lombes? Surely, the earth trembled at thy pre≈øence O Lord; at the pre≈øence of the God of Iacob. It is naturall for the pre≈øervation of vnitie, for waight it ≈øelfe to a≈øcend: how ob≈øervant therefore ought all creatures be to him that made them? Alas, how could the rebellious Canaanites ≈øtand out again≈øt him, or his people, who the Seas and rivers gaue way vnto? With what ioy might Gods people trample vpon the dry channel
of Iordan, ≈øeeing behind them, Aegypt, the Sea, and wilderne≈ø≈øe overcome, and before them the promi≈øed land ≈øo ready to entertaine them, that the very waters being glad of their comming, ranne backe to welcome them into Canaan? O Lord, if thus thou be one, that all mu≈øt yeeld, how great is this vnitie, making and comprehending all others? What a rowe of creatures follow thee, and what an Army doe≈øt thou lead? In ≈øpite of all Athei≈øts, vnitie will Mar≈øhall all vnder thy colours; and let them die by Mar≈øhall law that dare once breake this ranke, and rebelliou≈øly ≈øet them≈øelues again≈øt thee. There were no numbers if thou wert not fir≈øt, and if there be many, thou art a God: No A thei≈øt in the world ≈øhall be able to phillip off this authoritie with di≈ødaine. God is the fir≈øt, becau≈øe in nature one is before two, and mu≈øt begin in the order of computation. Account the times, and tell mee who hath multiplied them? Thinke on the creatures, and ≈øhew me their beginning. I deeme, all dayes and deeds in their ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, will either proue nature a God, or a God of nature. And if euery grape mu≈øt haue his bu≈øh, and each ≈øu≈øpition his prevention, let the Athei≈øt take this an≈øwere. Nature is res nata, a thing bred and borne of, or by another. Who is then this grand Parent of Nature? Your owne Poets haue told you, wee are his off-≈øpring. Act. 17.28. The head of nature is God, who of his owne will, of nothing begate all things: I ≈øay of his will, not of him≈øelfe; for, ≈øo ≈øhould he and all his creatures be ≈øimply one. And ≈øo wee ≈øhould need no other reckoning, the number would be ≈øoone told. But he mu≈øt be ≈øedulous that will learne this ≈øecret, and by telling a multitude, or an heape of vnities, finde out one ≈øimply fir≈øt. But why ≈øay I ≈øo, ≈øeeing two will proue one? let him then finde any number in being, and it will proue a God.
Q. What is Gods infinitene≈ø≈øe?

A. Whereby he is without all limits of e≈ø≈øence. As Gods eternitie ri≈øeth from this, that hee hath neither beginning nor ending: ≈øo his infinitene≈ø≈øe from this, that he hath neither
matter nor forme, which are the proper limites of e≈ø≈øence; as being mo≈øt e≈ø≈øentiall to euery finite being. Indeed the limitation of any cau≈øe, makes the effect finite. Gen. 1.2. the earth is ≈øaid to be voyd and without forme. It was of nothing for matter, and it was all things for forme: yet wanting both the≈øe it was finite, as hauing his beginning and ending from God, who alone ≈øits vpon the circle of it. I≈øa. 40.22. and aboue it ≈øtretcheth the heavens, inclo≈øing both, being inclo≈øed by neither. P≈øal. 147.5. The Lord is of great power, his vnder≈øtanding is infinite. And here may we ever be ≈øtriuing to perfection; and as the kine of the Phili≈øtimes, which drew the Arke of God, though they were milch, and had calues at home; the one to weaken them, the other to withdraw them: yet without turning to the right hand, or the left, they kept on their way, till they came to Beth≈øheme≈øh: ≈øo, hauing once ioyned our ≈øelues to the yoake of Chri≈øt, and drawing forward towards this infinite e≈ø≈øence, and the fruition of our bli≈ø≈øe in him, let vs chearefully beare the Arke of his Law vpon our ≈øhoulders, in the way of holine≈ø≈øe, and in ≈øpite of all hinderances, keepe on in our tract, till wee bee gotten where our everla≈øting hou≈øe and man≈øion is provided for vs, and that by the hands of this vnlimited God.
Q. What followes from hence?

A. Fir≈øt, The Immen≈øitie of God, whereby he is without all dimen≈øions, that is, of length, breadth, or thickne≈ø≈øe. Hee is higher then heaven, deeper then hell, longer then the earth, broader then the Sea, &c. Iob 11.8.9. I≈øa. 40.12. Ier. 23.23. A God at hand and a God a farre off. He that is freed from dimen≈øions, may pierce and penetrate, enter and pa≈ø≈øe whither he plea≈øeth without probabilitie, or po≈ø≈øibilitie of re≈øi≈øtence. A ≈øonne feeling the loue of his father, creepes neerer vnder his wings, or elbow: how ea≈øie is it for God to enter our ≈øtony and ≈øteely hearts, and draw them after him? They that re≈øi≈øt the holy Gho≈øt, doe it by gain-≈øaying his word, not by fru≈øtrating his worke; for hee ≈øhall conuince the world. Io. 16.8. either to conver≈øion, or confu≈øion.
The altitude of pride, longitude of power, and profunditie of policie are trampled vpon by God. Proud Bel≈øhazzar (Dan. 5.27.) was weighed and found too light; Gods wand ≈øoone found him wanting; and alas, how ea≈øily did God penetrate the hard walls of his heart, to the horrour of his whole ≈øoule, and ha≈øtning of his death? Now as a Ship in the mid≈øt of a ≈øtorme, to≈ø≈øed with tempe≈øts, and beaten on every ≈øide, with windes and waues, and dangerou≈øly driuen, not by direction of the Ma≈øter, but by the fury of vnbridled violence; ≈øo, in this extraordinary agitation, Rea≈øon, which is the Pilote, could beare no Rule; but affection and affliction, as a ≈øtorme, to≈ø≈øe and driue him to vtter de≈øpaire. Thus all the wicked, who≈øe hearts the Lord doth not pear≈øe and boare by his word, he enters by force to ≈øtirre vp that raging Sea, who≈øe waters foame nothing but mire and gravell. I≈øa. 57.20.
Q. What in the ≈øecond place may be ob≈øerued?

A. His incomprehen≈øiblene≈ø≈øe, whereby hee is without all limits of place, and from this flowes his omnipre≈øence, or vbiquitie, whereby he is wholly without and within all and euery place, no where included, no where excluded; and that without all locall motion, or mutation of place. Hee fils al places without compre≈ø≈øion, or ≈øtraitning of another, or the contraction, exten≈øion, conden≈øation, or rarefaction of him≈øelfe. A Candle may bee contracted for his light within the hand, or hatte, & extended to a whole roome. A ≈øpunge may be thru≈øt into a narrow compa≈ø≈øe, and yet by ≈øwelling fill a larger ≈øpace. But God neither moues to come into any place as doe the Angels, or ≈øtanding ≈øtill, fills it by thru≈øting out another, as liquor into a ve≈ø≈øell; or el≈øe in larging and contracting him≈øelfe like light; or by any thickning or thinning of pores, and parts, as Ice and water, &c. but purely, and ≈øimply, by his e≈ø≈øence and pre≈øence is euery where. 1. Ksng. 8.27. P≈øal. 139.7. I≈øa. 66.1. Ier. 23.23.24. Act. 17.27. By this it appeares, that no place can hinder God from doing vs good. Di≈øtance, or difficultie may be impediments to all the creatures to ≈øtay their helpe,
but God at a blu≈øh fills all places, to comfort or confound, as it plea≈øeth him. He moueth, or changeth all things, without eyther motion, or change in him≈øelfe; who is in euery place pre≈øent, in euery place intire; within all things, and contained in nothing; without all things, and ≈øu≈øtained by nothing; but containeth, ≈øu≈øtaineth, and maintaineth all things. O infinite goodne≈ø≈øe, pa≈ø≈øing all humane both ≈øearch and ≈øight; thou both fille≈øt and include≈øt all things; thou art in euery place pre≈øent, without either ≈øeat, or motion. Giue me therefore grace, that in all places I may both feare, and feele thy power.
Q. What is Gods eternitie?

A. That whereby he is before and after all, not beings: that is, not onely the world, but the very nothing of it. Rea≈øon will teach me that nothing was before the world, and that nothing may be after it: but it cannot teach mee any ≈øuch apprehen≈øion before or after God. For I cannot ≈øo much as conceiue a nothing, before an ab≈øolute being: the rea≈øon is becau≈øe nothing is apprehended by way of contrarietie to ≈øomething. P≈øal. 90.2. Before the mountaines were made, &c. God is not onely before the creature, but the making of it, and that from an everla≈øting before it, to an everla≈øting after it. P≈øal. 139.16. God ≈øees the creature in his non entitie, or nothing. I≈øa. 57.15. He inhabiteth eternitie. 1. Tim. 1.17. The King of ages. Heb. 1.2. The maker of times. The Hebrew word comes of a roote, to he hid, becau≈øe there is no knowledge where to beginne or end. Alas, how doe wee affect a thou≈øand things that cannot be effected; mi≈øerably afflicting the ≈øoule becau≈øe they are wanting. And of all things wee doe obtaine, the plea≈øure doth forth with eyther vani≈øh, or cloy; they doe no more ≈øatisfie the appetite, then ≈øalt water quencheth thir≈øt. Onely this eternall God giues it all contentment. Eternitie is eyther an admirable ble≈ø≈øing, or a mi≈øerable cur≈øe. If all the puni≈øhments of hell were no greater then the ≈øtinging of Gnatts, perpetuity is enough to make them intolerable. Oh, how grievous ≈øhall it bee to the damned, to thinke,
that after millions of ages, the ≈øhall bee ≈øo farre eyther from end, or from ea≈øe, as they were the fir≈øt day of their beginning. In life there is ≈øome ea≈øe, and in death an end: but here the wicked ≈øhall neither haue end, nor ea≈øe. So long as God ≈øhall liue, ≈øo long ≈øhall the damned die; and when he ≈øhall cea≈øe to be happy, then ≈øhall they al≈øo cea≈øe to bee mi≈øerable.
Q. What followes from hence?

A. That God is without all limites of time pa≈øt, pre≈øent, Rev. 1.8. 2. Pot. 3.8. or to come. And yet he is at all times, but without re≈øpect of time. And therefore cannot be ≈øubiect to any mutation, or alteration of time, as to be young, or old; but is an everla≈øting and immortall God before, and after all times, and in all times, for ever and ever. Iob 36.26. P≈øal. 92.7.8. and 102.26.27 I≈øa. 41.4. and 43.10.11. Ier. 10.10.1. Tim. 1.17. Some things haue no beginning, and yet an end, as Gods decrees. Some-things a beginning, and no ending, as Angels; ≈øome things both beginning and ending, as all ≈øublunary creatures: God alone hath neither beginning nor ending. All creatures haue a la≈øting: Angels an out-la≈øting; God an ever-la≈øting. O that true loue like a ≈øtrong ≈øtreame, which the further it is from this head of eternitie, would runne vnto it with greater violence. Alas, that ever ≈øo many cold windes of temptation, ≈øhould blow betwixt God and our hearts, to make our affections cooler vnto him. What dull mettall is this wee are made of? Wee haue the fountaine of felicitie and eternitie, and yet complaine of want and wearine≈ø≈øe. Doe wee freeze in the fire, and ≈øtarue at a fea≈øt? Haue wee God to enioy, and yet pine and hang downe the head? Let me die if ever I envie their happines that ioy in red and whie Cro≈ø≈øes, a vaine title, daintie di≈øhes. Gold is that which the ba≈øe≈øt elements yeelds, the mo≈øt ≈øavage Indians get; ≈øervile Apprenti≈øes worke, Midianiti≈øh Camels carry, mi≈øerable worldlings admire, covetous Iewes ≈øwallow, vnthriftie Ruffians ≈øpend. Let me haue my God, and let me never want him, till I envie them. So ≈øhall my ioyes be la≈øting, when this tran≈øitory tra≈øh
≈øhall leaue them. Goe then thou mi≈øcreant, that can take more plea≈øure in a kite, a dogge, a boune and ba≈øe companion, then in the liuing God. An Hauke becomes thy fi≈øt better then a Bible, and euery dung hill trifle, then this during Deitie. O the vn≈øavory foode of fooles, to the ta≈øte of any wi≈øe man: I can but wonder how any ≈øhould be ≈øo idle, hauing ≈øo fayre meanes to purcha≈øe better things: but I mu≈øt conclude them among≈øt Salomons fooles, who hauing a price in their hands, haue no hearts to get wi≈øedome.

div.head: CHAPTER VII. Of the diuine Qualities.
