p.hi: VVHat Attributes ≈øhew vs what manner of God he is?

div.p: An≈øwere.

A. His mo≈øt divine and excellent qualities, whereby hee acteth, or worketh. Properly God hath none; yet becau≈øe we cannot ≈øee his working by his e≈ø≈øence, he giues qualities to him≈øelfe, by which wee may vnder≈øtand his marveilous workes. P≈øal. 86.8. Among the gods there is none like thee (O God) and there is none that can doe like thy workes. P≈øal. 71.19. Thou ha≈øt done great things (O God) who is like thee. Exod. 34.6. O what an heauen may a Chri≈øtian here ≈øeele in him≈øelfe! when (after many traver≈øes of holy meditations) he may finde in his heart a feeling po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of his God. When he may walke and conver≈øe with him, and that not without an openne≈ø≈øe of heart, and familiaritie: ≈øo that when his ≈øoule hath caught fa≈øt and ≈øen≈øible holde of him in his gracious qualities, he may either pull him downe to him≈øelfe, or rather lift vp him≈øelfe to him, and can and dare ≈øecretly avouch, I know whom I haue beleeued. O then how ≈øhould we dete≈øt our blocki≈øhne≈ø≈øe and dulne≈ø≈øe which would ≈øuffer a leaden and earthy ≈øpirit, to thru≈øt it
≈øelfe betwixt vs and our actiue God; and by his darke and indige≈øted parts, eclip≈øe that light which ≈øhineth to our ≈øoules? Let me (deare God) with feare to offend, and faith to obtaine, alwayes be humble before thee, and never bee high minded, but onely in minding the≈øe things aboue.
Q. What ob≈øerue you from hence?

A. That all the former properties of greatne≈ø≈øe may be attributed to the≈øe: as his eternitie and infinitene≈ø≈øe may bee giuen to all, or any of his qualities, but not the contrary ≈øo properly, as Gods eternall wi≈øedome, infinite iu≈øtice, &c. and not his wi≈øe eternitie, or iu≈øt infinitene≈ø≈øe. P≈øal. 145.7.8. Great goodne≈ø≈øe, great mercy, and not good greatne≈ø≈øe, or mercifull greatne≈ø≈øe. For quantitie is the mea≈øure of the qualitie that acteth, and hereby we ≈øee an Ocean of mercy and goodne≈ø≈øe in God. Here then may we keepe what we haue, and get what we want, & a good ≈øoule will not more loath all other covetou≈øne≈ø≈øe, then affect this. Here alone mu≈øt we never profe≈ø≈øe to haue enough, and our care mu≈øt be, if we may increa≈øe, eyther by labouring, or begging, or v≈øury, to leaue no meanes vnattempted. Let others plea≈øe them≈øelues in the large extent of their rich mannors, or in the homage of tho≈øe whom ba≈øche≈ø≈øe of minde hath made ≈ølaues to their greatnes, or in the price and fa≈øhions of their full wardrope, or in the wanton varieties of their delicate Gardens, or in their full coffers of red and white earth; or if yet there be any other earthly thing more alluring, more precious, let them enioy it, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe it, and let it po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe them: let mee onely haue this God, and let me never want him, till I envie them. An idiot, or a childe lookes on the faire≈øt Gally-pot in the Apothecaries ≈øhop, which ≈øhall be ≈øure to haue his fir≈øt hand, though never ≈øo full of poyfonous drugs: where the iudicious choo≈øe rather the whol≈øome≈øt, led not onely by ≈øen≈øe, but skill: ≈øo ≈øilly ≈øotts and ≈øotti≈øh worldlings, are more tempted with wealth and honour (which when they come vpon be≈øt termes, are but vaine) then with the beames of that infinite beauty, which de≈øerues the be≈øt, yea, all, and a thou≈øand times more then
all. O that any thing in the world ≈øhould be re≈øpected before him, equalled with him, or loued out of him, of whom, for whom, and through whom are all things. It grieues mee to thinke, that ≈øo ≈øub≈øtantiall and ≈øuper excellent a good ≈øhould haue ≈øuch hollow ≈øervices: fie on all Rimmonites, that plead an vpright ≈øoule in a pro≈øtrate body; or that pretend a Nathaniel in the skin of a Nicodemus. Dare wee not ≈øpeake out, and without all ≈øecret halting, or halving ≈øay, God is God, and wee will follow him, for his excellency? O that ever Chri≈øtian ground ≈øhould beare any maples, hollow and fruitle≈ø≈øe; or that we ≈øhould lie ≈øo neere the bankes of the dead ≈øea, hauing faire apples, which vnder a red ≈øide containe nothing but du≈øt. For his ≈øake that is ≈øuper-e≈ø≈øentiall, become more ≈øub≈øtantiall. Remember what great account you are to pa≈ø≈øe at the la≈øt Audite before him, when all favorites, and fancie feeding-flatterers ≈øhall ≈øhrinke from vs, and nothing but our owne deeds and de≈øerts accompany vs.
Q. What ≈øecondly may we learne?

A. That the acts of the≈øe qualities differ nothing from the qualities them≈øelues, nor they from the e≈ø≈øence, or among them≈øelues, but onely in re≈øpect of our vnder≈øtanding, which doth diver≈øely apprehend them. Exod. 3.14. I am, mu≈øt ever be ob≈øerved as a rule to keepe vs from gro≈ø≈øe conceits of God. Ioh. 5.17. My father worketh hitherto, and I worke. Euery creature hath his being before his action, but in God e≈ø≈øence, facultie, vertue, and action are altogether, and the ≈øame. So that it is good re≈øting vpon him, in whom is ≈øo great perfection as to be ≈øimply one, and vertually all things. I can wonder at nothing more, then how a man can be idle; but of all other a Chri≈øtian; in ≈øo many improuements of rea≈øon, in ≈øuch ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe of knowledge, in ≈øuch varietie of contemplations, and mo≈øt happie opportunities of thoughts. Other Artizans and Schollers doe but practi≈øe, we ≈øtill learne; others runne ≈øtill in the ≈øame gyre, to wearine≈ø≈øe, to ≈øatietie, our choice is infinite: how many bu≈øie tongues cha≈øe away good houres in plea≈øant
chat, and complaine of the ha≈øt of night? And ≈øhall an ingenuous minde, or religious heart bee ≈øooner weary of talking with God, the ≈øweete≈øt of companions? Who would not wi≈øh him≈øelfe an Anachoret, ≈øecluded from the world, and pent vp in the voluntary pri≈øon-walles of his daily thoughts of God? Let vs therefore in our meditations on his back-parts, and the≈øe his mo≈øt excellent qualities, take heed how we begin our heauenly thoughts, and pro≈øecute them not. Hee that kindles a fire vnder greene wood, and leaues it, ≈øo ≈øoone as it begins but to flame, mu≈øt needs finde it cleane out, when hee would warme him≈øelfe by it: ≈øo, if we begin to thinke the≈øe thoughts, and giue over, wee cannot but loo≈øe by them, becau≈øe they are not ≈øeconded by ≈øutable proceedings. Fire in embers vn≈øtirred, glowes not, heats not the hou≈øe. Sugar in the cup vn≈øtirred, ≈øweetens not the wine. It is not a Trade, but a Trade well followed that fills the pur≈øe. It is not the hauing of land, but land well-looked too, that maintaines the man. A locke without a key, is of no v≈øe: ≈øo, there is no profit in ≈øetting our ≈øelues to meditate on God, more then of a ≈øleeping habite, if wee giue over before wee come to ≈øome i≈ø≈øue.
Q. How many ≈øorts of his qualities be there?

A. Two, faculties and vertues: the one makes able, and the other prompt to euery good worke. God by way of eminencie explaines him≈øelfe by both Num. 11.23. I≈øa. 50.2. and 59.1. God is mo≈øt able to helpe and deliuer. I≈øa. 55.7. He is ready to forgiue. Ephe≈ø. 2.4. Rich in mercy. 1. Ioh. 1.9. Iu≈øt and faithfull to forgiue. God is not onely able to forgiue, but ready and willing to performe his act. O wick and wretched man, call to thy con≈øideration (vnhappie creature) from whence thou runne≈øt, where thou art, and whereto thou ha≈øtene≈øt; the favour which thou for≈øake≈øt; the horrour wherein thou abide≈øt, and the terror whereto thou tende≈øt: ≈øhake of this ≈øloth, this ≈øleepe, this death of ≈øinne, wherein thou wallowe≈øt, and wherein thou wandere≈øt: Rai≈øe vp, row≈øe vp thy ≈øelfe from this dangerous
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
dulne≈ø≈øe, and looke vp to this God, who is able by his power, and willing for his mildne≈ø≈øe and mercy, to relieue and relea≈øe thee of thy mi≈øery. Liue not ≈øtill like the flie ≈øucking at the botches of carnall plea≈øures, when thou may≈øt bath thy ≈øelfe in this Ocean of ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe.
Q. What are Gods faculties?

A. Whereby he being mo≈øt excellent life is able to worke what≈øoever he plea≈øeth mo≈øt eminently: the be≈øt facultie mu≈øt be giuen to God; and therefore the mo≈øt perfect life, not ari≈øing from the vnion of two things, but the ≈øimple perfection of his owne nature, whereby hee liuing in him≈øelfe, doth inliuen and quicken other things. And hereby it mu≈øt follow, that God is mo≈øt actiue, wanting no abilitie for the effecting of any thing. Deut. 32.40. God in power lifts vp his hand to heaven, and ≈øayes, I liue for euer. Io≈øh. 3.10. The liuing God is knowne to be among the I≈øraelites, by his powerfull driuing out of the Canaanites. Ier. 10.10.14. Becau≈øe of his life and everla≈øting ne≈ø≈øe, the earth ≈øhall tremble, &c. Dan. 4.34. and 6.26. Ioh. 1.4. Act. 17.28. I. Pet. 1.23. Rev. 15.7. If fortie dayes raine, driuen with the tempe≈øt of Gods wrath, was ≈øufficient to de≈øtroy the whole world; what ≈øhall we e≈øteeme of the full ≈øtorme & ≈øtreame of his rage, wherein the fiery darts of his fury, ≈øhall never cea≈øe to beate vpon his enemies? He ≈øurely, that ca≈øts off this God, ca≈øts away him≈øelfe; and being the abiect of God, mu≈øt needs be the ≈øubiect of the Devill. But for his elect, and their ≈øalvation, hee ≈øhall ≈øtriue with no greater ≈øtraine in effecting their good, then we doe in the motion of our eyes.
Q. What are the kinds?

A. Vnder≈øtanding and will: the be≈øt faculties in which life doth mo≈øt eminently ≈øhew it ≈øelfe, are giuen to GOD. 1. Chron. 28.9. God vnder≈øtands the very inwards, and his will is to ca≈øt them off, that care not for him. Oh, thou which art the be≈øt vnder≈øtanding, and the pure≈øt will, poli≈øh thou the two tables of my ≈øoule, my vnder≈øtanding and my will; this of affections, the other of cogitations,
that I may both thinke and will as thou woulde≈øt haue mee. This may a≈ø≈øure mee, that not onely my actions, or words, but my ≈øecret cogitations ≈øhall be rigorou≈øly examined; even in that manner whereof the Prophet hath ≈øpoken. Seph. 1.12. the Lord ≈øhall ≈øearch Ieru≈øalem with lights, and vi≈øite the men that are frozen in their dregs, and ≈øay in their hearts, the Lord will neither doe good nor euill. Then ≈øhall all hypocrites cry out, Ah, who can dwell in the burning fire? who can abide the everla≈øting flames?
Q. What is Gods vnder≈øtanding?

A. That whereby he vnder≈øtandeth all things at once and together. And therefore his knowledge is mo≈øt certaine, and infallible, even in things mo≈øt contingent; neither needs he to bring any propo≈øition to the tribunall of a Syllogi≈øme, and there try the truth of it by di≈øcour≈øe. Manife≈øt things need no other iudgement, then the very ≈øight and ≈øound of them. Now to this intelligent God all things are layd open and naked. Heb. 4.13. Hee is no wayes to be deceiued by compo≈øition or divi≈øion, or any manner of Sophi≈øticall di≈øcour≈øe. He ≈øees all things at a blu≈øh by the infinitene≈ø≈øe of his e≈ø≈øence. 1. King. 8.39. P≈øal. 139.1.2.16. Iob 14.16.17. O thou that ha≈øt pure eyes looke vpon vs in thy Sonne, and ≈øo wee ≈øhall neither bee dazeled, nor damned. Eye ≈øeruice is a fault with men: but if wee could but ≈øerue God while he ≈øees vs, it were enough. Hee ≈øees them that will be Saints in the Church, and Ruffians in the Taverne, Tyrants in their hou≈øes, and Cheators in their ≈øhops. He ≈øees tho≈øe daintie Dames that vnder a cloke of mode≈øty and devotion, can hide their pride and fiendi≈øhne≈ø≈øe. It will not be long, ere thou wilt iudge all our ≈øecrecies with ≈øeveritie. The ≈øunne of my ≈øinnefull life hath pa≈ø≈øed the meridian, and I am now in the after-noone of my age. The night of nature will come fa≈øt vpon mee: when death (as Gods ≈øergeant) will arre≈øt my body vpon debt due vnto nature, my ≈øoule vpon tre≈øpa≈ø≈øe committed again≈øt my all-≈øeeing Creator. The one mu≈øt be bound hand and foote, and committed clo≈øe pry≈øoner to the
ground; the other arraigned in the high Court of heauen, where he that hath ≈øeene me ≈øinne, ≈øhall be both party and judge; to an≈øwere to all obiections, as well of ignorance, as of contempt. Onely this is my ≈øtay and ≈øtaffe, that hee will both forgiue and forget, yea, put him≈øelfe out of office, if I betimes judge my ≈øelfe, and repent of my evill.
Q. What as his Will?

A. That whereby he wills mo≈øt freely what is good. Exod. 33.19. P≈øal. 5.4. and 115.3. and 135.6. And here might ≈øomething be ≈øayd of diver≈øe affections attributed to God. But they will appeare better vpon the occa≈øions they manife≈øt them≈øelues, and for which they are giuen to God. And here mu≈øt wee learne our coun≈øell, and comfort. Coun≈øell to ≈øubmit to what≈øoeuer he commandeth; and comfort to admit what≈øoever he promi≈øeth. Oh, vaine ≈øtudies of men, how to walke thorow ≈øtreets all day in the ≈øhade, how to ≈øquare circles, how to ≈øalue the cele≈øtiall motions, how to correct mi≈øhapen copies, to fetch vp old words from forgetfulne≈ø≈øe, and a thou≈øand other points of idle skill; whiles the maine care of knowing Gods will is neglected. This makes the be≈øt of all the≈øe inferiour creatures, to liue in more ≈øorrow and di≈øcontentment then the wor≈øt of them; yea, that very rea≈øon wherein he excells them, & by which he might advantage his life, is abu≈øed to ≈øu≈øpicious di≈øtru≈øt of God and his will. How many haue wee found of the fowles of the ayre lying dead in our way for want of provi≈øion? they can eate, re≈øt, ≈øing, &c. onely man toyleth, careth, loatheth, and lamenteth his pre≈øent; O the coldnes of care in ca≈øting it vpon God, as if he wanted will to prouide be≈øt for them, for whom he hath prouided all things. I will ≈øo depend on my makers will, that my tru≈øt therein may not exclude my labour, and ≈øo labour, vpon my confidence thereon, as that my endevour may be voyd of vexation. Math. 10.
Q. What are Gods Vertues?

A. The qualities whereby he is ab≈øolutely good Math. 19.17. Why calle≈øt thou me good, there is none goad but God. Deut. 32.4.
He is a rocke, his worke is perfect, for all his workes are iudgement, a God of truth, and without iniquitie, iu≈øt and right is he. 2. Sam. 22.31. God mu≈øt needs haue all vertues, becau≈øe he wants no perfection. As the Ocean receiueth all ≈øtreames, and yet hath proper waters in farre greater abundance: ≈øo, in God there is a confluence of the perfections of all creatures, and yet his owne perfections doe infinitely exceed them. What are the plea≈øures of this life, to our drinking of his plea≈øures, as out of a ryver. P≈øal. 36.8. At the be≈øt they are but as beames of that ≈øunne, ≈øparkles of that fire, which mo≈øt purely and perfectly are contained in him. Yet as we haue made them, they are as a ≈ømoakie fire in cold weather, whereof the ≈ømoake is more noy≈øome, then the heat is comfortable. O giue me of that abundance which both in cau≈øe and continuance, plentie and place, ≈øo farre excells the other.
Q. What are the ≈øorts of the≈øe Vertues?

A. Two, either his intellectuall, or morall vertues. God mu≈øt haue the be≈øt vnder≈øtanding, and the be≈øt will; and therefore mu≈øt needs enioy the vertues of both. Rom. 3.4. Let God be true and euery man a liar. P≈øal. 51.4. God is iu≈øt when he ≈øpeaketh, and pure when he iudgeth; his will and vnder≈øtanding are purely good. By this our hearts (being ravi≈øhed with the loue & admiration of this light, which ≈øo brightly ≈øhineth vnto vs, as men with the Sunne, who are newly drawne from dungeon, and bottome of ba≈øene≈ø≈øe) ≈øhould readily follow him, who carrieth ≈øo faire a lampe before vs. Shall the marchant refu≈øe no adventure for hope of gaine? the hunter ≈øhrinke at no weather, for loue of game? the Souldier decline no danger, for de≈øire either of glory, or ≈øpoyle? And ≈øhall we frame to our ≈øelues either an ea≈øe in not vnder≈øtanding, or an idlene≈ø≈øe in not v≈øing the meanes, whereby we attaine both immea≈øurable and immortall glory, plea≈øure, and gaine? I know (as the proverbe is) a dead woman will haue foure to carry her forth; ≈øo we cannot ea≈øily be beaten out of our homes, to ha≈øten to this inheritance laid vp for the Saints in light.
Q. What are his intellectuall Vertues?

A. Whereby he is mo≈øt prompt in vnder≈øtanding all his purpo≈øes mo≈øt exactly, and di≈øtinctly. P≈øal. 139.4. There is not a word in my tongue but thou knowe≈øt it wholly. Rom. 11.33. and 16.27. Onely wi≈øe, and a depth of wi≈øedome and knowledge is to be found in God. Iob 21.1. Act. 15.8. 1 Ioh. 3.20. His deepe iudgement hath waded and weighed all con≈øiderations, and the way he taketh is ever be≈øt. The minde of man is weighed, as euery wind of pa≈ø≈øion dooth puffe. Lu≈øt and pride de≈øire to ≈øpend; avarice to ≈øpare; envie to detract; feare, or favour to extoll; ambition to adventure; ≈øu≈øpition to hold backe; wrath ≈øweetneth revenge with delight; deceit cloaketh it with di≈ø≈øimulation. Onely God is exact and di≈øtinct in all his enterpri≈øes?
Q. What are his morall vertues?

A. Whereby mo≈øt holily, readily, and purely he performes the act of his will. Gen. 18.15. Shall not the Iudge of all the world doe iu≈øtly? Deut. 32.4. A God of truth and without iniquitie, iu≈øt and right is he in all his wayes. According to the≈øe two heads of vertues were all things created. The whole world manife≈øteth the wi≈øedome of God, and all his intellectuall vertues. Men and Angels, his iu≈øtice and mercy, the top of all his morall vertues. But the particular handling of the≈øe vertues, we leaue to the places, where they doe mo≈øt manife≈øt them≈øelues. O my Soule thou art pent within the clay-walles of my body, and maye≈øt often looke through the grates in thy bu≈øie thoughts, when this holy God will ≈øend for thee. Surely to be di≈ø≈øolved is be≈øt of all; onely he that gaue our ≈øoules their mittimus into our bodies, mu≈øt giue them a re-delivery, with returne yee ≈øonnes of Adam. If in the interim he cro≈ø≈øe vs in our bodies, yet haue we no cau≈øe to complaine, as long as wee haue him in feeling, in faith, in earne≈øt and pledges; yea, in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion. O the madde in≈øolence of nature, that dares controll, where it were more fit to wonder. Should pre≈øumptuous clay be bold to check the potter? Me thinkes this ≈øhould ingender a very curious & advantagious warine≈ø≈øe in all our proceedings, hauing
learned by experience, the wi≈øedome and holine≈ø≈øe of our God. It is for them to murmure and mutter, that either know not God, or know him di≈øplea≈øed with them. Alas, fooli≈øh wormes, what doe wee turning againe, when hee ‚Ä¢ eads vpon vs? If we be his, why pine we at that which is good for vs, yea, be≈øt? for that mu≈øt ever bee be≈øt to vs, which he ≈øeeth be≈øt; and that he ≈øees be≈øt which he ≈øendeth. His will is the rule of his actions, and his goodne≈ø≈øe of his will. It is therefore our dutie to ≈øubmit vnto him in all things. If he ≈øtrike, the rod mu≈øt be ki≈ø≈øed in ≈øilence, and glory giuen to the hand that rules it. It is no ≈ømall part of his rare vertues, to worke our good by affliction; and therefore wee may be incouraged to re≈øt vpon him in all e≈øtates.
Q. What followes from hence?

A. Gods mo≈øt ab≈øolute happine≈ø≈øe both in action and contemplation. Whereby he is freed from all evill, abounding with all good, ≈øufficiently contenting him≈øelfe with him≈øelfe, and no wayes ≈øtanding in need of any other. 1. Tim. 1.11. and 6.15.1. Ioh. 1.5. P≈øal. 16.2. vnd 50.7. to 14. Hag. 2.8. Behold now yee ambitious ≈øpirits, how ye may truely ri≈øe to more then ever the ≈øonnes of Zebedee de≈øired to a≈øpire vnto. Waiting is the way to raigning, ≈øerue him which is thus happy, though without apparent wages: he will pay ≈øure, if ≈ølow. Liue well, and thou maye≈øt liue in expectation, as tho≈øe which after ≈øome terme of their cottage expired, are a≈ø≈øured they ≈øhall haue a marble palace built for them. O let vs thinke that the dayes and moneths pa≈ø≈øe ≈ølowly away, till then, ever looking vp to him that is the fini≈øher of our faith, and remembring that for the new heavens, our hearts mu≈øt be made new before hand. Let worldlings, like a company of idle boyes, ≈øcramble for the figges of this life; it is for wi≈øe men to take them if they fall in their bo≈øomes: who≈øe maine care is to be found acceptable in the day of the Lord. Worldly vanities (which are alwayes ther owne cut-throats, by their owne cro≈ø≈øing and contrarietie) are to be abandoned of Chri≈øtians, who ca≈øting away all weake diffidences, know how to tru≈øt
God with his owne. Waite thou on the Lord, and keepe his way, and he ≈øhall exalt thee. P≈øal. 37.34. It is he that will fulfill all the good plea≈øure of his goodne≈ø≈øe, and the worke of faith with power. 2. The≈ø≈ø. 1.11. O that hee would purge out of our minds and memories that ambition and vanitie, which ≈øo bewitches them with the loue of pompes and glories of this peri≈øhing and ending world, which in the breathing of a breath, wee may loath, loo≈øe, leaue and de≈øpi≈øe as nothing: and would graffe in them a pure and ≈øingle eye, to behold the eternall bli≈ø≈øe, which ≈øeene, breedeth loue, and loued conducts vs to heaven. Here to as high a tide as wee ≈øhall ri≈øe in our de≈øires of wealth, and well-fare, to as low an ebbe ≈øhall we fall in our hopes thereof. Seeing then we looke for better things in the heavens, let vs be diligent that we may be found of him in peace, without ≈øpot and blamele≈ø≈øe. 2. Pet. 3.14. Doe wee beleeue that all things ≈øhall be made new, and our hearts onely remaine olde? As if our ble≈ø≈øed God, intended nothing but our ≈øoules to be out of fa≈øhion. Be a≈ø≈øured, that as no man puts new wine into olde ve≈ø≈øels, no more will God put the new wine of his glory, into the olde ve≈ølels of our corruption. Looke wee therefore to him, that hath ≈øayd he will giue vs new hearts. Ezek. 11.19. And remember that all our glory begins in grace, and that God will haue none to dwell with him in happine≈ø≈øe, that will not vouch≈øafe him to dwell with them in holine≈ø≈øe. Roote out (deare God) all gall and acerbitie among≈øt brethren, and bend their hearts to charitie, that being re-vnited in the pilgrimage of this life, this country of our terre≈øtriall, bodies, wee may after our ≈øervice and cour≈øe therein accompli≈øhed, a≈øcend vnder the conduct of our Sauiour, before a≈øcended to our everla≈øting re≈øt, in the countrey of our cele≈øtiall Soules, there in ≈øocietie and vnitie of Saints and Angels, to enioy the happy vi≈øion of the all-glorious Deitie, and to ≈øing his pray≈øe for ever.

div.head: CHAPTER VIII. Of the Sub≈øi≈øtences, or three Per≈øons.
div.p: Que≈øtion.

p.hi: HItherto of the e≈ø≈øence, what are the Sub≈øi≈øtences?

div.p: An≈øwere.

That one mo≈øt pure e≈ø≈øence, with the relatiue properties. Relation addes nothing to the divine e≈ø≈øence, but re≈øpect, or mutuall affection. God with the relation of begetting is the Father, of begotten the Sonne, of proceeding the Spirit. One and the ≈øame e≈ø≈øence hath all the≈øe re≈øpects: but peradventure wee haue mi≈ø-taken our Cue; for there is not ≈øo much in the divine e≈ø≈øence as any inherent qualitie. I an≈øwere, I marvaile ≈øo learned a di≈øputer ≈øhould moote no better. Qualitie and relation are di≈øtinct predicaments. Wi≈øedome and father-hood in the ≈øame man, are not two qualities; for the one, becau≈øe a qualitie, is ≈øome thing in it ≈øelfe; but the other, becau≈øe a relatiue, is nothing without another. A father is nothing without a ≈øonne, neither is the ≈øonne in being without a father. They are mutuall beings. And yet one being may be mutually many of them; as one and the ≈øelfe ≈øame man, may be a father, a ma≈øter, and a ≈øubiect: ≈øo, one pure God may be a father, ≈øonne, and holy Gho≈øt. 1. Ioh. 5.7. Wee call them Sub≈øi≈øtences, becau≈øe by their ≈øingular, individuall, and per≈øonall properties, they ≈øub≈øi≈øt in one and the ≈øame e≈ø≈øence. Could we now but through a crevis, or lettice, ≈øee tho≈øe things which the eye of faith ≈øeeth here with open face, how would wee loath all Epicuri≈øme and Athei≈øme, in compari≈øon of our Bapti≈øme in the name of the≈øe three worthies? Had we but ta≈øted with the tip of our tongues the≈øe dainties, we would pray with Dauid even again≈øt the worlds delicates, P≈øal. 141.4. Here ≈øhall wee not haue our liues compo≈øed of ieiune
and emptie contemplations, but ≈øo full of contentment, that wee ≈øhall need to wi≈øh no other mea≈øure of plea≈øure, then to be wholly taken vp with this divine taske. Here is the exaltation of I≈øaacs delight in walking forth into the plea≈øant fields of ≈øacred meditations, on the ble≈ø≈øed Trinitie. O let our Soules haue two or three walkes a day vpon this mount Taber, and with holy Mo≈øes conuer≈øe with one God in three per≈øons, on the Horeb of both Te≈øtaments, till wee haue found out vnto our ≈øelues the pure law of life. As the≈øe three exhibite it vnto vs. And if the one bre≈øt let not downe this nouri≈øhing liquor ≈øo freely, ≈øo ea≈øily, as our ≈øtrength will beare it, then may we refre≈øh our ≈øelues with the other, and by ≈øuch a ≈ømall varietie wee ≈øhall finde them yeelde milke equally whole≈øome, equally plea≈øant to vs weake Infants and nur≈øelings. If mount Sinai, covered with darkene≈ø≈øe, tremble, the father being offended: the Go≈øpell calmes and lightens it pre≈øently, the ≈øonne hauing ≈øatisfied.Ioh. 17.3. This is eternall life, to know the father reconciled in his ≈øonne. Retire thy ≈øelfe daily into ≈øome ≈øecret place of meditation, and prayer, ≈øuch as Cornelius his leaddes, Dauids clo≈øet, &c. and thou ≈øhalt finde with Iacob the ≈øweete vi≈øion of Angels, climbing vp and downe this ≈øacred ladder, which ≈øtands betwixt heauen and earth, at the top of it is the father, the whole length of it is in the ≈øonne, and the ≈øpirit doth firmely fa≈øten vs thereunto, that ≈øo we may be tran≈øported vnto bli≈ø≈øe.
Q. What is here to be ob≈øerued?

A. The names in Scripture that expre≈ø≈øe this my≈øtery, as Elohim, and Adonai. Gen. 1.1. Mal. 1.6. Both which words being plurall, are ioyned with words of the ≈øingular number: to ≈øhew the vnitie of the per≈øons, both in e≈ø≈øence, and action. It is not for euery proflygate profe≈ø≈øor that liues as he li≈øt, to be dealing with this divinitie. The≈øe pearles are not for ≈øwine, who will laugh at ≈øuch congruitie, as makes one of three, and three of one: but hee that findes and feeles the conioyned working of the Trinitie, will adore it in vnitie, a≈øcribing to father, ≈øonne, and holy
Gho≈øt equall authoritie and power in all their workes. This (as well as the whole rule of well-liuing) belongs to the ≈øealed fountaine, the ≈øpou≈øe of Chri≈øt. A doctrine not fit to be preached in Gath & A≈økelon, to vncircumci≈øed and prophane hearts, that will turne euery good thing to their owne de≈øtruction. The Lord that hath the teaching of all hearts, make vs ready for this tran≈øcendent learning.
Q. What ≈øecondly is to be ob≈øerued?

A. That the ≈øub≈øi≈øtences, or per≈øons, being the ≈øame e≈ø≈øence, are God, and one God. Ioh. 1.1. 1. Ioh. 5.7. Cut but the hayre from the eye brow (≈øaith Augu≈øtine) and how di≈øfigured will the face looke, there is but a ≈ømall thing taken from the body, but a greater matter from the beautie: ≈øo in the≈øe honourable wayes of wi≈øedome, wee may not derogate the lea≈øt iot of Deitie or dignitie from any per≈øon.
Q. What in the third place?

A. That what≈øoeuer Attribute is giuen to the e≈ø≈øence, may ≈øo farre forth be giuen to the ≈øub≈øi≈øtences: as euery per≈øon is infinite, eternall, incomprehen≈øible, &c. Exod. 23.20. with 1. Cor. 10.9 Chri≈øt hath the ≈øame name and authoritie with his Father. Ioh. 1.1.2. and 14.1. and 21.17. Phil. 2.6. Heb. 1.3.1. Ioh. 5.20. Rev. 1.11. In all the≈øe places, the e≈ø≈øentiall Attributes of the divine nature are giuen to Chri≈øt. So likewi≈øe to the Spirit. P≈øal. 139. Act. 5.3.4. 1. Cor. 3.16. Iob 33.4. 2 Cor. 13.13. Mat. 18.19. O that we had but in vs the internall principles of faith, to re≈øt vpon the≈øe three worthies, infinitely great and gracious. This I am ≈øure, as a ≈øpring, or oyle to the wheeles of our Soules, would make them goe ≈ømoothly, and currantly. Make all other yokes light and ea≈øie. Vndoubtedly, the Pipe of Faith would here draw in ≈øo much ≈øweete ayre from the precious promi≈øes of life, that thereby wee ≈øhould be able to renue our ≈øtrength, and with chearefull ≈øpirits lift vp the wing as the Eagle, runne and not be weary, walke and not faint. What, ≈øhall idle Guls with a Pipe of Tobacco, or Cup of Sacke, (≈øilly ≈ømoakie helpes) giue life againe to their dull and deadly Spirits? And ≈øhall not the Saints and ≈øervants of three ≈øo infinite,
exhilerate and cheare their hearts, with the feeling of their new life, ≈øo mercifully begun by the father, powerfully di≈øpenced by the ≈øonne, and perfectly fini≈øhed by the ≈øpirit? Where were all this grace, if it were not ≈øtronger then any Ellebore, to evacuate the minde of all feares and griefes? It is for nature to be ≈øubiect to extremities, that is, eyther too dull in want, or wanton in fruition; but grace like a good temper is not ≈øen≈øible of alteration. O then that euery ea≈øie occa≈øion of plea≈øure, profit, or preferment, ≈øhould interrupt vs in the≈øe religious intentions, and draw vs to gaze, like children, which if a bird doe but flie in their way, ca≈øt their eye from their Booke. Nay, what a ≈øhame is it to thinke, how hardly we are drawne to learne or li≈øten to this le≈ø≈øon? As a beare to the ≈øtake, as a ≈ølaue to the mill, or a dullard to the Schoole, are wee brought to the≈øe ≈øtudies.
Q. What in the fourth place?

A. That all the three per≈øons are God of them≈øelues; for an ab≈øolute fir≈øt cannot, no not in order, be the ≈øecond, or third of any other: but a fir≈øt in all. The Sonne becau≈øe he hath his per≈øon from the Father, is a ≈øecond per≈øon, but not a ≈øecond God. Deut. 6.4. 1. Tim. 2.5. 1 Ioh. 5.7. All tho≈øe places that proue God to be one, exclude all derivation of e≈ø≈øence, for one cannot bee multiplied without number. Heb. 1.3. The ≈øonne is the image of the per≈øon, not the e≈ø≈øence; it were an ab≈øurditie to ≈øay, Chri≈øt is the image of him≈øelfe: but apt and proper the expre≈ø≈øe image of his Father. For tho he be no other thing from his Father, yet another per≈øon. Hence wee learne how to expound that ≈øpeech, very God of very God, that is, the ≈øub≈øi≈øtence of the ≈øonne is verily and truly from the ≈øub≈øi≈øtence of the father. The per≈øon begetts, not the e≈ø≈øence; for, to beget, and be begotten, are relatiues, yet the e≈ø≈øence is ab≈øolute. But Ioh 5.26. It is giuen to Chri≈øt to haue life in him≈øelfe. If life, then e≈ø≈øence, &c. I an≈øwere, Chri≈øt ≈øpeakes of life in the text by way of di≈øpen≈øation, as he was the Me≈ø≈øias, and ≈øo it is explained, ver. 27. He hath giuen him authoritie
to execute Iudgement, becau≈øe he is the ≈øonne of man. The very text makes this common to both per≈øons, to haue life in them≈øelues, which is the property of the God-head: and yet Chri≈øt hauing life in him≈øelfe as God, hath the ≈øame giuen him, as Mediator, and ≈øonne of man: but you will ≈øay, ≈øo he had power to giue him≈øelfe life, and therefore the fathers giuing re≈øpects his per≈øon as well as his office. I an≈øwere, it is true, for as the ≈øonne of man receiues ≈øub≈øi≈øtence from the ≈øonne of God, ≈øo the ≈øonne of God receiues ≈øub≈øi≈øtence from his father: Now working is according to ≈øub≈øi≈øting, therefore the life of grace, ≈øpoken of ver≈øe 25. is wrought by the humane nature of Chri≈øt, as it is ≈øu≈øtained by his per≈øon, and his per≈øon being from the father, worketh the ≈øame life from him: ≈øo then it is giuen to the ≈øonne in regard of his manner of ≈øub≈øi≈øting, to bee the di≈øpen≈øer and di≈øpo≈øer of the life of grace, whereof the father is the beginner, &c. But as God he quickeneth whom he will, v. 21. and that as he hath life in him≈øelfe. Life, will, and vnder≈øtanding are Attributes of the e≈ø≈øence, and ≈øo ≈øimply one in them all. Here may the ≈øicke finde a Phy≈øitian, the broken a balme of Gilead, the fearefull a ≈øhelter, the flyer a refuge, and the breath-le≈ø≈øe ≈øpirit a ble≈ø≈øed re≈øt. The ≈øonne of God hath wedded to him≈øelfe our humanitie, without all po≈ø≈øibilitie of devorce; the body hangs on the Cro≈ø≈øe, the ≈øoule is yeelded, the God-head is eviternally vnited to them both. And if Chri≈øt be God, and by his ≈øub≈øi≈øting & working, come ≈øo neare vs, what ≈øhould di≈ø≈øolue the eternall bonds of our heauenly coniunction with him, or the daily influences of grace from him? Here are the apples and flagons of holy con≈øolation, and it is good for the Spou≈øe to be walking into the Gardens, and eating of the≈øe fruits. Wee cannot hope to be ≈øo neare to our God, as Chri≈øt was, vnited per≈øonally: yet need wee not feare that God ≈øhould ≈øeeme more ab≈øent from vs, then hee did from his owne ≈øonne. Hee was ≈øtill one with both body and ≈øoule, when they were devided from them≈øelues; when he was ab≈øent to ≈øen≈øe, he was pre≈øent to faith; when ab≈øent in vi≈øion, yet
in vnion one and the ≈øame: ≈øo will hee bee to our ≈øoules, when they are at wor≈øt. He is ours, and we are his: if our hold ≈øeeme loo≈øened, his is not: when temptations will not let vs ≈øee him, he ≈øees vs, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth vs; onely beleeue him again≈øt ≈øen≈øe, aboue hope; and though he kill vs, yet let vs tru≈øt in him. Shiloach refre≈øheth Ieru≈øalem, Iordan Naaman, better then Abanah, and Pharphar. Cherith dried vp while Eliah dranke of it. Iacobs well was ≈øtopped vp, but this well of liuing water no drought can dimini≈øh, nor Phili≈øtimes ≈øtop vp.
Q. What followes yet in the fift place?

A. That the three per≈øons are coe≈ø≈øentiall, as hauing the ≈øame e≈ø≈øence together, and that not devided or by parts: but as (if I may ≈øo ≈øpeake with reverence) three partners in a Ship, haue not each a peece of it, but wholly, and together. Father and ≈øonne are often two di≈øtinct men, & haue a common humanitie devided by parts betweene them: but here the per≈øons di≈øtingui≈øhed by relation, are vndevided in e≈ø≈øence. And the rea≈øon is, becau≈øe the father cannot beget one le≈ø≈øe then him≈øelfe, and therefore he being infinite his ≈øonne mu≈øt likewi≈øe be infinite. And that which is infinite admits of no divi≈øion, or di≈øtribution. Now the three per≈øons being co e≈ø≈øentiall, are likewi≈øe co-equall, and co-eternall. Ioh. 5.18. Phil. 2.6. 1. Ioh. 5.7. He that walketh in the Sunne for plea≈øure, may bee tainted with the heate thereof before he retire: ≈øo they that are drawne by delight into the≈øe cogitations, may thereby take the touch of a more deepe impre≈ø≈øion. Papi≈øts (as I haue read) hauing little knowledge of our Ladies countenance & fauour, haue a≈ø≈øembled the faire≈øt Curtezans to draw the mo≈øt mode≈øt beautie of a Virgin out of the flagrancie of Harlots: ≈øo many who≈øe skill is very ≈ølender in this my≈øtery, out of their owne devotion, haue broached many ≈øtrange conceits of the Trinitie, and left them as Oracles for their followers. But wee ≈øtudy to expre≈ø≈øe the≈øe things as neere as wee can with truth of matter, and ≈øobriety of ≈øpeech; for truth findeth more ea≈øie entrance, when it commeth armed with
his owne force, and adorned with the furniture of words that may be≈øt be≈øeeme it.
Q. What ob≈øerue you in the la≈øt place from the definition?

A. That they are one in another, and with another, mutually delighting and glorifying each other. Pro. 8.22.30. Ioh. 1.1.2. and 5.20. and 10.38. and 13.31.32. and 14.10. and 17.5. The Sonne is a delight to the Father in the worke of our Redemption, Math. 12.18. and the Spirit a ioy to them both, in the worke of our ≈øanctification.Pro. 8.30.31 If the ≈øonne had not beene the fathers dayly delight, he had never reioyced in the habitable part of the earth, nor had his delights with the ≈øonnes of men. Behold, oh man, that ≈øtande≈øt in the wayes, inquiring for life, here it is, labour thou to delight in them, that are delighted in thee, and reioyce together to worke out thy ≈øaluation. Alas, how ≈øhould it pitty our hearts, to ≈øee many ≈øilly Soules runne vp and downe in the common labyrinth of error, groaping for the ≈øtrait and narrow gate of life, like the blind Sodomites after Lots doore, each man telling his dreame to his neighbour, of an imagined happine≈ø≈øe. And though they draw and drinke in iniquitie, yet will they ≈øtill dreame of drawing in the ea≈øie yoake of a Sauiour, when God wotes they were never driuen vnto it. Is this the pa≈øtime of the ble≈ø≈øed Trinitie, to ≈øport them≈øelues together in doing vs good, and ≈øhall wee be intreated (like madde men) to be good vnto our ≈øelues? O how many that never ta≈øted of the≈øe delights, yet thinke them≈øelues in skie and highe≈øt ≈øphere of happine≈ø≈øe? Alas, how many walking Gho≈øts in the ≈øhapes of liuing men, applaud them≈øelues, like ≈øwine in earthly plea≈øures? O the watery plea≈øures of Epicurean hoggs, that ≈øatiate them≈øelues with the huskes of vanity, and cry out in their madne≈ø≈øe, that they haue liued the onely ioviall and iocand life. The≈øe (like Moles in the earth) are ever ca≈øting vp, as re≈øtle≈ø≈øe in them≈øelues. Surely, he goes lightly that wants the≈øe loads; as loath to lagge in the foule≈øt weather. The Bu≈øtard by rea≈øon of his great body, and bulke of bones, when he is pur≈øued, can hardly get vpon
his wings; whereas the little Larke mounts pre≈øently aloft with ea≈øe. Oh how ≈øhould our right conceit of this delight of the Trinitie, carry our ≈øoules vpon the wing, and make them a≈øcend? Alas, ambitious mindes of ayery honour, are but ambitious of their owne de≈øtruction, who climbing the ≈ølippery hill of high preferment, mea≈øure more then their length in their dangerous downe-falls; whereas he that ≈øtands on oven-ground is as ≈øoone vp as downe. O then that the Chri≈øtian ≈øoule would ≈øay to it ≈øelfe in a word or two, how liue≈øt thou? know and con≈øider from whom thou drawe≈øt thy breath, and remember that one day led with the ble≈ø≈øed Trinitie, is better then an immortalitie of the worlds windie vanities.

div.head: CHAPTER IX. Of their Relation.
div.p: Que≈øtion.

p.hi: VVHat meane you by the relatiue properties?

div.p: An≈øwere.

Two things. Fir≈øt, that howbeit the Sub≈øi≈øtences are the ≈øame e≈ø≈øence, yet not as e≈ø≈øence: but as it is with the relatiue properties. A Scholler or a teacher is a man: but not a Scholler or a teacher as a man; for, as he in≈øtructeth he is a teacher, and as he learneth a Scholler. Which are relatiue properties. This my≈øtery cloudeth the cleare≈øt of our thoughts: yet from ≈øo many rayes, wee mu≈øt ≈øtudy to light ≈øome little torch, to quicken our owne feeble ≈øights. It ≈øhall be well if we tame our vnbridled vnder≈øtandings, and learne with Nazianzene. Orat. 40. in S. Bapti≈øm: I know not how (≈øayth he) to thinke of one, but that vpon the very in≈øtant, I ≈øhall ≈øee my ≈øelfe environed with the brightne≈ø≈øe of three; neither can I di≈øcerne the≈øe three, except at the very moment I returne vnto one.
Q. But make you any di≈øtinction betweene them and the E≈ø≈øence?

A. Yes. As betweene a man, and a Scholler, who though he be a man, yet not as a Scholler; for then ≈øhould euery man be a Scholler, becau≈øe he is a man. But indeed he is a Scholler, becau≈øe he learneth, and a man as he is compo≈øed of a body and rea≈øonable ≈øoule: ≈øo, that he is a man in one re≈øpect, and a Scholler in another. Rom. 2.21. Thou that teache≈øt another, teache≈øt thou not thy ≈øelfe. Where you ≈øee the ≈øame man is to be both ma≈øter and Scholler. I am a≈øtoni≈øhed at ≈øo many wonders as I behold en≈øtated and packeted vp in this rich Cabinet of the knowledge of GOD. They that goe downe into the deepes, they ≈øee the workes and wonders of the Lord. P≈øal. 107.23. But they that goe downe into this deepe are not like to ≈øee any thing, except they plow with his heyfer, that can read vs the darke≈øt riddles. Ioh. 14.9.10.11. Chri≈øt in this my≈øtery, applies two rules of relation, the one, concerning their mutuall knowledge, the other, their mutuall being. He that hath ≈øeene me, hath ≈øeene my Father: that is, Philip, know one and know both; if thou beleeue mee to be the ≈øonne, then mu≈øt thou beleeue my father. For it is impo≈ø≈øible to conceiue a ≈øonne without a father. Againe, I am in the father, and the father is in me: that is, our being is mutuall, if I were not his ≈øonne, he were not my father, and if he were not my father, I were not his ≈øonne. As I haue the being of a ≈øonne from my father, ≈øo hath he the being of a father from his ≈øonne. And hereupon by the nece≈ø≈øitie of relation, I am in my father, and my father is in mee. Abraham as a father is in I≈øaac, and I≈øaac as a ≈øonne is in Abraham: but becau≈øe they are al≈øo two di≈øtinct men, I≈øaac is al≈øo out of Abraham, and Abraham out of I≈øaac. But the eternall father and the ≈øonne hauing the ≈øame ≈øingular e≈ø≈øence, are per≈øonally the one with the other, and e≈ø≈øentially the one the other. Ioh. 1.1.
Q. How are they then di≈øtinct?

A. As the man and the Scholler: And here to avoyd all doubts and dangers, and that a godly appetite may finde
what to feed on, let rea≈øon ruled by Scriptures ≈øupply with the defectiue, what he either reads not, or in reading knowes not. Iob. 1.1. The word was with God, and the word was God. If God in both places be taken in the ≈øame ≈øen≈øe; then the ≈øecond per≈øon is ≈øo a concrete with the e≈ø≈øence, as in rea≈øon the e≈ø≈øence may be predicated of it; and therefore the difference is rationall, not reall: or if you will haue the argument, the e≈ø≈øence and ≈øub≈øi≈øtence are diver≈øe not oppo≈øite. They turne ≈øides not backes. The e≈ø≈øence di≈ø≈øents from the ≈øub≈øi≈øtence by rea≈øons apprehen≈øion, not natures oppo≈øition; for if they were oppo≈øite, he that is with God could not be ≈øayd to be God. So that the holy Gho≈øt reacheth vs by that phra≈øe, that the ≈øonne for manner of ≈øub≈øi≈øting is with the e≈ø≈øence, as if it were to bee conceiued clo≈øe by the ≈øide of it, as the manner of a thing is to the being of it. And againe, lea≈øt wee ≈øhould there mi≈ø-take, by putting too great a difference, as if the manner ≈øhould differ really from the thing, he addes, and the ≈øame was God. So then the difference is very little, a diver≈øitie, no reall repugnancie. They turne a≈øide our apprehen≈øion without cro≈ø≈øing, or contrarietie. If God in the fir≈øt place be taken per≈øonally, and in the ≈øecond e≈ø≈øentially, then with God, is with the father, and ≈øo they are not diver≈øe but contraries, not (if I may ≈øo ≈øpeake with reuerence) as backe to backe, but face to face. I am thy father, thou art therefore my ≈øonne: but when I ≈øay, I am thy father, therfore I am not thy ≈øonne, in this they are contrary, not in the other. And therefore wee ≈øay the properties are incommunicable. I am the begetter, therefore not the begotten. Yet if I be the begetter, thou art my begotten. P≈øal. 2.7. So then the Sub≈øi≈øtences are contraries with mutuall affection: but e≈ø≈øence and ≈øub≈øi≈øtence are diver≈øe by Logicall apprehen≈øion. Ioh. 10.30. I and my father are one. 1. Ioh. 5.7. The≈øe three are one: as relatiues or contraries they cannot be one; but as ≈øub≈øi≈øtences in the ≈øame e≈ø≈øence they are all one. I ≈øhould be thankefull to my render, if he would not ≈øuffer idlene≈ø≈øe to deuour the ≈øweete
that others ≈øweat for, or would but ≈øo much as count the≈øe labours plea≈øant as they are prepared to his hand. But I feare, as the Ia≈ø≈øians in Strabo delighted with the mu≈øique of an exqui≈øite Harper, ran all away as ≈øoone as they heard the Fi≈øh-market bell ring, ≈øaue a deafe olde man, &c. So they that ≈øeeme to be delighted with the knowledge of divine things, are ea≈øily called off by worldly imployments, and if any ≈øtay by it, they profit no more by this Doctrine, then the deafe man did by the Harpers ditties. The Mini≈øters haue ≈øome-thing to doe that breake vp the ≈øwarth, and ≈øowe it for vs. I ≈øhall de≈øire no more but godly attention, and patience, to weigh all points diligently, and with humilitie to yeeld vp their owne fancies to rea≈øon. The hot and headdie are not to be imployed in the contemplation and ≈øearch of the≈øe truthes; for, as being ≈øuddaine in their actions, they ≈øeize lightly on that which commeth fir≈øt to hand: ≈øo being ≈øtiffe in their re≈øolution, they are tran≈øported with euery preiudicate conceit, from one errour to another. Giue me therefore a con≈øtant and ≈øtable ≈øtudent, and he ≈øhall gaine by this good.
Q. Doe the≈øe relatiue properties adde any thing to the e≈ø≈øence?

A. Nothing but re≈øpect and manner of being: ≈øo that the e≈ø≈øence remaineth ≈øtill pure, or meere e≈ø≈øence. The relation of a father, ma≈øter, ≈øervant, &c. are no addition of a new e≈ø≈øence. Rom. 2.21. The learner and the teacher may bee the ≈øame man. He is a right Mauchen, or gazing ≈øtocke, that thinkes him≈øelfe a new man, becau≈øe he is a new ma≈øter. As Saul was changed to another man pre≈øently vpon his anointing, ≈øo are men vpon their advancement; and according to our ordinary Proverbe, Their good and their bloud ri≈øes together: Now it may not bee taken as it hath beene. Other fa≈øhions, fare, and furniture fit them whom favour graceth. But alas, what is relation to Greatne≈ø≈øe, where there is no alteration in goodne≈ø≈øe, the man is the ≈øame, though he haue the re≈øpect of a King.
Q. What is the ≈øecond thing meant by relatiue properties?

A. That the Sub≈øi≈øtences, or per≈øons, are di≈øtinct by them≈øelues as Relatiues. From the e≈ø≈øence (as we haue ≈øaid) they differ as diver≈øe, onely turning a≈øide a little: but among≈øt them≈øelues they differ as contraries, hauing mutuall re≈øpect; for, though the ≈øonne be the ≈øonne of the father, and the father the father of the ≈øonne: yet the father is not the ≈øonne, neither is the ≈øonne the father. So likewi≈øe the holy Gho≈øt, proceedeth from the father and the ≈øonne, yet is he neither the father, nor the ≈øonne. A father & a ≈øonne being relatiues, are contraries: yet both of them may be no more then diver≈øe to the ≈øame man that is both. Mat. 1.2. Abrahambegate I≈øaac, and I≈øaac begate Iacob, &c. I≈øaac is both father and ≈øonne. Sonne in regard of Abraham, and father in regard of Iacob. Plato told the Mu≈øitians of his time, that Phylo≈øophers could dine and ≈øup without them; how much more ca≈øie ought it to bee for Chri≈øtians to weane them≈øelues from childi≈øh rattles, and may games of carnall delights, and be merry without a Fidler? It is for Saul to driue away his ill ≈øpirit, and dumps of melancholy with Dauids Harpe: and for Caine, to ≈øtill his crying con≈øcience with building of Cities: ≈øo, for them that cannot li≈øpe a word of a better life, to feede them≈øelues, not by ≈øooping an handfull with Gideons Souldiers, but by ≈øwilling their bellies full of worldly plea≈øures, and other ≈øuch ≈øwill and ≈øwades, as they are wont to weary them≈øelues withall. The≈øe cry, the way of God is hard, and not for their medling; e≈øpecially, the≈øe maine my≈øteries, and therefore they abhorre once to thinke of the ≈øtudie of them. Indeed, as in the mo≈øt champion & plaine grounds of Religion, there are ≈øome hillockes higher then the re≈øt of their fellowes: ≈øo, in the≈øe the greate≈øt and ≈øteepe≈øt hills thereof, there is footing enough, whereby with labour and travaile, with much reading, and often prayer, wee may come to the height of them, wherein wee may ≈øee and di≈øcover ≈øo farre off the land of Canaan, and the kingdome of heaven, as may be ≈øufficient for ever to make vs happy.
Q. What followes from hence?

A. That the per≈øons cannot be one the other. The e≈ø≈øence and ≈øub≈øi≈øtence may be one the other, as the father is God, and the ≈øonne is God, and the holy Gho≈øt is God: but the father is not the ≈øonne; neither is the holy Gho≈øt, either father or ≈øonne. A ma≈øter and a man may bee the one the other: but a ma≈øter and a ≈øervant cannot be ≈øo predicated, the rea≈øon is, becau≈øe they are contraries, or really oppo≈øite: the other onely diver≈øe, and therefore may be di≈øpo≈øed affirmatiuely. Ephe≈ø. 1.3. Ble≈ø≈øed be God, the father of our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt. God and the father are one the other, the father is God, and God is the father: but as he is father of his ≈øonne, wee finde no ≈øuch di≈øpo≈øition in the Bible. Ioh. 10.30. They are ≈øayd to be one: that is, in e≈ø≈øence, will, or action, not in per≈øon; for ≈øo they are two, really di≈øtinct. I know the≈øe vocall ≈øounds are but a complement; and as an outward ca≈øe, wherein our thoughts are ≈øheathed. There is nothing wherein the want of words can wrong and grieue vs more, then in this point: here alone, as wee can adore, and not conceiue, ≈øo we can conceiue, and not vtter; yea, vtter our ≈øelues, and not be conceiued; yet, as wee may, thinke here of one ≈øub≈øtance in three ≈øub≈øi≈øtences; one e≈ø≈øence in three relations; one Iehovab begetting, begotten, proceeding; Father, Sonne, Spirit: yet ≈øo as they differ but rationally from the e≈ø≈øence, and really among≈øt them≈øelues; and in regard thereof admit the predication of the e≈ø≈øence of each per≈øon, and not of the per≈øons one of another.
Q. What may el≈øe be ob≈øerued?

A. That they are together by nature, for ≈øo are all relatiues. They are mutuall cau≈øes and effects, a thing in rea≈øon onely peculiar to this head of argumeÃÑt: as the father is the cau≈øe of his ≈øonnes relation, and ≈øo is the ≈øonne of his fathers. And on the contrary, they are effects of each others relation; and by vertue of this, they mu≈øt needs be together in nature. The cau≈øe is before his effect; and ≈øo the father begetting his ≈øonne, might ≈øeeme in nature to be before him:
but this mutuall cau≈øation, though it pervert not order, yet makes it things to be together mo≈øt naturally. The father is onely before the fonne, and ≈øpirit, in order of ≈øub≈øi≈øting, and not in nature, either of e≈ø≈øence, or ≈øub≈øi≈øtence. Pro. 8.22.30. Chri≈øt was ever with the father. Ioh. 1.1. In the beginning, without beginning, was the word with God. Heb. 1.3. The very expre≈ø≈øe image of his per≈øon; and therefore a ≈øonne by nature: for if he were a creature, he ≈øhould be a fonne by coun≈øell, as the ≈øonnes of men are ≈øaid to be. Iam. 1.18. Of his owne will begate he vs. Hee that begets by nature begets no le≈ø≈øe then him≈øelfe; as a man begets no le≈ø≈øe then a man; & euery creature brings forth his ownekind. Gen. 1.24.25. But coun≈øell and will beget ≈øuch images of them≈øelues, as be≈øt plea≈øe them: ≈øo man was by counfell made in the image of God. Gen. 1.26. Ad here the error of the Arians can no more infect the truth of the Scriptures, in the point of Chri≈øts Diuinitie, then the truth of the Scriptures can iu≈øtifie them in their wretched allegation of them. A bad worke-man may v≈øe a good in≈øtrument: and often-times a cleane napkin wipeth a foule mouth. If there were no more Scripture again≈øt them, then that one text, Iohn. 1.18. nor no more words in the whole Bible, then that one (Monogenees) onely begotten, it were ≈øufficient to confute and confound all they haue ≈øayd, and to leaue their cau≈øe de≈øperate, and without all plea, though they were neuer ≈øo hear tie patrons of their owne affections. God the father hath many ≈øonnes, and an onely ≈øonne: now this difference is made by the manner of generation or begetting; and all the world can invent no other, but nature and coun≈øell; nay, why ≈øay I invent, when the Scripture hath found it out to their hands, and left it them to ob≈øerue. By coun≈øell the father may beget many children, yea, and twi≈øe beget them, as his elect, by creation and regeneration. But by nature hee cannot beget more then one ≈øonne, and becau≈øe he is begotten by nature, hee is no le≈ø≈øe then his father, and becau≈øe no le≈ø≈øe then his father, therefore an onely ≈øonne. For if his whole image be
in one, it cannot be in two. But I ≈øee if wee breake our teeth with the≈øe hard ≈øhells, wee ≈øhall finde ≈ømall plea≈øure in the kernells; neither doe I thinke that Gods ≈øchoole is more of vnder≈øtanding then affection: both le≈ø≈øons are very needfull, very profitable; but for this age wherein there is coldne≈ø≈øe of care, e≈øpecially the latter. He that hath much skill, and no affection, may doe good to others by information of judgement; but ≈øhall neuer haue thanke, either of his owne heart, or of God, who v≈øeth not to ca≈øt away his loue on tho≈øe, of whom hee is but knowne, not loued. O Lord (≈øeeing therefore that men are but men by their vnder≈øtandings, and Chri≈øtians by their wills and affections) make me to affect my relation to thee as a father, and thy ≈øonne as a brother; and becau≈øe coun≈øell in working, followes nature in being, let me find and feele how ≈øweet it is to be placed vnder thy ≈øonne, who from thee, as thou of thy ≈øelfe, makes mee both ≈øonne and brother, and fellow heire with him≈øelfe.
Q. What followes from hence, that they are together by nature?

A. That they are onely in order one before another, according to their manner of ≈øub≈øi≈øting. As the father before the ≈øonne, and both of them before the holy Gho≈øt. Order requires, that the begetter ≈øub≈øi≈øt before the begotten, and the Spirants before the Spirit. Ioh. 15.26. I will ≈øend from the father the Comferter, even the ≈øpirit of truth. As there is an order in ≈øub≈øi≈øting, ≈øo in working. And here the well of life lies open before the godly, though their eyes often (like Agars) are not open to ≈øee it: whiles mi≈øerable worldlings haue neither water, nor eyes. And becau≈øe to Chri≈øtians there can be no comfort in their ≈øecret felicities; ≈øeeing to be happy and not to know it, is little aboue miferable; let me here fell them ≈øome of that ≈øpirituall eye≈øalue, which the Spirit commends to the Laodiceans; that they may clearely ≈øee how well they are in the true apprehen≈øion of this order. I know it to be v≈øuall with all men liuing, that they doe not much more want that which they
haue not, then that which they doe not know they haue. A≈ø≈øuredly, there is nothing, but a few ≈øcales of ignorance and infidelitie betwixt vs and our happine≈ø≈øe. It lies in a narrow compa≈ø≈øe, but ≈øoundly tru≈ø≈øed together; for it is from the Father, in the Sonne, by the Spirit to Faith. 2. Cor. 13.14. Loue from the Father, as the beginner of our happine≈ø≈øe. Grace from the Sonne, as the di≈øpen≈øer of it. And a ble≈ø≈øed & happy communion from the holy Gho≈øt, as the accompli≈øher, or fini≈øher of it. Loue, Grace, and Communion, are enough to pa≈ø≈øe the beleeuer from death to life. The father cannot manife≈øt his loue, without the grace of his ≈øonne, neither can the ≈øpirit therein communicate with vs, but as he is ≈øent from both, after both to manife≈øt the loue of the one in beginning, and the grace of the other, in di≈øpen≈øing all things needfull for our ≈øaluation. Thinke not much, that this gla≈ø≈øe of the word e≈øpies that in vs, and for vs, what our ≈øelues ≈øee not: too much neerene≈ø≈øe oft-times hindereth ≈øight: and if for the ≈øpots of our owne faces wee tru≈øt others eyes and gla≈ø≈øes, why not this truth for our perfections? wee are in heauen, and know it not. What greater happines then this, to be made partakers of the pure≈øt Loue, riche≈øt Grace, and choice≈øt Communion? Eph. 1.13.15. Our election is begunne by the will, coun≈øell, and decree of the Father; di≈øpen≈øed by the complete, and full redemption of the Sonne; fini≈øhed by the powerfull and effectuall application of the Spirit. It is not without due con≈øideration, why in the beginning of the Apo≈øtolicall Epi≈øtles, Grace and peace are wi≈øhed from the Father and the Sonne, without mention of the Spirit. I may, and will, reine the que≈øtion ≈øhorter, then they doe, that confound the per≈øons in their workes. The Spirit is ≈øent from the Father and the Sonne, to witne≈ø≈øe that grace and peace that wee haue from, and with them both. He that is from them both by in≈øpiration, is to them both with vs as lidger in execution. When good things are wi≈øhed from ≈øome per≈øons, it is requi≈øite that there be ≈øome to carry newes of their will and plea≈øure therein. The
Church of God hath the glorious Go≈øpell of life and ≈øaluation, and therein is contained all grace and peace with God: but how ≈øhall euery ≈øoule be certified, that he is intere≈ø≈øed in tho≈øe good things, except the Father and the Sonne, ≈øend the Spirit, as a witne≈ø≈øe and ≈øeale thereof vnto him in particular? Therefore Paul in all his Epi≈øtles, wi≈øhing grace and peace from Father and Sonne, not mentioning the Spirit, ob≈øerues the true order of per≈øonall ≈øub≈øi≈øting, and per≈øonall working. And therefore peace purcha≈øed by grace, whereby the Father is reconciled in his Sonne, is wi≈øhed to the Churches; the fruition whereof followeth by the worke of the ble≈ø≈øed Spirit in all that are ordained to be partakers thereof.
Q. What kind of properties are the≈øe?

A. Individuall and incommunicable, and being giuen to the Father, Sonne, and holy Gho≈øt, make three di≈øtinct per≈øons, and therefore the Church of God hath done well ≈øo to name them, though the word be not in all the Scripture, for it is a Latine word, and therefore cannot be found in the Originalls, which are Greeke and Hebrew. Thus far haue we freely dipped in this ≈øtreame, and not bin drowned; pulled many fragrant ro≈øes, and not pricked our fingers; there is one thing more that may ≈øting vs, if godly di≈øcretion ≈øerue not to ≈øever the good from the ill; yet the former le≈ø≈øons well remembred are ≈øufficient, to them that are capable of ob≈øervation, and not carele≈ø≈øe of repo≈øition, to keepe them from danger: but ≈øeeing remarkable con≈øideration put into vs by others, are as ≈øome loofe pearles, which for want of filing vpon a ≈øtring, ≈øhake out of our pockets; it ≈øhall be nece≈ø≈øary both for the getting and keeping of the trea≈øure of our vnder≈øtanding, to expre≈ø≈øe it.
Q. Are then the≈øe properties, qualities in the divine e≈ø≈øence?

A. They are relatiue affections, no inherent qualities; for, they doe no wayes change, or alter the e≈ø≈øence, but leaue it ≈øtill ≈øimply one. I know naturall rea≈øon would here ≈øend forth
di≈øtemper into our whole judgement. The ≈øtreame mu≈øt needs runne like the fountaine, and ≈øpeeds well, if at la≈øt, by many changes of ≈øoile, it can leaue an ill qualitie behind it: ≈øo, our judgement ≈øhall be well purged, if by all the≈øe pa≈ø≈øages we can ≈øo farre ma≈øter rea≈øon, that the fardle of fooli≈øh fancies may here be vnloden, and God may purely be apprehended, as he is in him≈øelfe. But what can be expected from this age, fitter to looke after Butter-flies, or Birds ne≈øts, or perhaps ≈øome gay coat of a Courtier, then this ≈øound and ≈øolide knowledge of Iehovah-Elohim? Or if any trauell this way, it is indeed like our yong travellers, who≈øe wealth is found to be in their tongues, wherein they exceed and excell their parents parrats at home, both for that they can ≈øpeake more, and know that they ≈øpeake: ≈øo our Aethiopian Chri≈øtians, white onely in the teeth, euery where el≈øe cole blacke, can ≈øpeake well of God and godline≈ø≈øe, and that is all. But God is not ≈øo learned; for, as among the three parts of the body, there is one, called Impetuous, or impul≈øiue, as the ≈øpirits, which ≈øets all on worke; or as Phy≈øitians call the Arteries in the body, Venas audaces, or micantes, from their continuall beating and working; which running along with the other veines beate & knock at euery gate and entrance, for the members to take in provi≈øion: ≈øaying (as it were) to euery part and portion, here is meate and nouri≈øhment for you: ≈øo, true religion, hauing put into vs the royall and cele≈øtiall Spirit of Faith, calls vpon all powers and parts, not to know and ≈øpeake good things, but to liue and practi≈øe them. Papi≈øts teach, that a man may, and mu≈øt both make and eate his God to his break-fa≈øt: this hard meate wee leaue for their ≈øtronger mawes: yet even here may wee begin with the ≈øpoone, and offer nothing to our weaker ≈øtomackes, but di≈øcour≈øe of ea≈øie dige≈øtion. Know God, and liue by faith, and wee ≈øhall haue him for our ever-la≈øting food.

div.head: CHAPTER X. Of their Di≈øtinction.
div.p: Que≈øtion.

p.hi: HOw are the≈øe Sub≈øi≈øtences, or per≈øons to be di≈øtingui≈øhed?

div.p: An≈øwere.

They are Father, Sonne, and holy Gho≈øt: or becau≈øe Relatiues are but two, into the relation of Father and Sonne, to the ≈øpirit, which is breathing, or ≈øending, or of the Father to the Sonne, which is begetting. (Spirantes ≈øpiritus, Gignens genitus) how ea≈øie were it to loo≈øe our ≈øelues in this Di≈øcour≈øe? How hard not to be over-whelmed with matter of wonder; and to finde, either beginning or end? Loe, with the≈øe words of relation, we are happily waded out of tho≈øe deepes, whereof our conceits can finde no bottomes, and now may wee more ≈øafely, with Peter, gird our coat about vs, and ca≈øt our ≈øelues a little into this ≈øea: onely, we mu≈øt remember, that as tho≈øe which had wont to ≈øwim onely with bladders, ≈øinke when they come fir≈øt to tru≈øt to their owne armes: ≈øo, wee may ≈øoone plunge our ≈øelues, if we ≈øuffer our owne thoughts to carry vs along in this my≈øtery. If any wonder, whether this di≈øcour≈øe can tend, let him con≈øider that of Tertullian, Ratio divina in medulla e≈øt, non in ≈øuperficie, Divinitie is more in the marrow and roote, then the rind and ≈øurface of things. It cannot be doubted, but as God is the be≈øt being, ≈øo he is the be≈øt life, and that the be≈øt life is rea≈øonable; God therefore is the be≈øt vnder≈øtanding. Suffer your ≈øelues with Abrahams Ramme, to be perplexed a while in the≈øe bryers, that you may be prepared to pre≈øent your ≈øelues for liuing ≈øacrifices, holy, and acceptable to this dreadfull Trinitie. Singula verba plena ≈øunt ≈øen≈øibus (as Hierome ≈øayd of the Booke of Iob.) As being by nature, ≈øo vnder≈øtanding by coun≈øell, is
able to conceiue and beget the image of it ≈øelfe, and from the one to the other to ≈øend a mutuall loue & liking: onely in the creatures both the≈øe are imperfect; for, nature doth generate to pre≈øerue it ≈øelfe, and vnder≈øtanding conceiues to perfect it ≈øelfe. No vnder≈øtanding by nature conceiues it ≈øelfe, and no being by coun≈øell begets it ≈øelfe. It is therefore the perfection of vnder≈øtanding naturally to conceiue it ≈øelfe: God doth both ≈øpeake, and worke in Parables, as a Father ≈øayth well: but here needs nothing be fayned to fa≈øten this truth vpon vs. It ≈øhall bee evinced by plaine demon≈øtration. The be≈øt being, and be≈øt vnder≈øtanding, mu≈øt needs conceiue the be≈øt image of it ≈øelfe; now in conceiuing it begets it, and being begotten by nature, is no le≈ø≈øe then the begetter. Man by nature begets no le≈ø≈øe then him≈øelfe: by coun≈øell hee can conceiue that which is le≈ø≈øe or greater then him≈øelfe: ≈øo the father by nature can beget no le≈ø≈øe then him≈øelfe, though by coun≈øell he conceiued and brought forth a whole world, nothing comparable to him≈øelfe in greatne≈ø≈øe, or goodne≈ø≈øe. Well, then in one ≈øimple e≈ø≈øence there is nece≈ø≈øarily a begetter and a begotten, and ≈øo we haue the ≈øub≈øi≈øtences of Father and Sonne. He is out of the danger of folly, whom a ≈øpeedie adverti≈øement leaveth wi≈øe. It is but an holy prevention, to be devout vnbidden, and to ≈øerue God vpon our owne conceits. Let vs then ≈øee how the ≈øecond my≈øtery will follow. The father in begetting his owne image, cannot but loue it naturally, and the ≈øonne in being begotten cannot but as naturally loue the begetter. And hence proceeds mutuall loue, and becau≈øe it is naturall, is no le≈ø≈øe in being then the begetter and begotten from whom it proceeds; for the begetter and begotten loue them≈øelues naturally, and therefore the Spirit is God, and a third ≈øub≈øi≈øtence in the divine nature. If the per≈øons were eyther greater or le≈ø≈øe one then another, then would this ab≈øurditie in≈øue vpon it, that neither the father could directly conceiue him≈øelfe, or father & ≈øonne equally loue them≈øelues, & con≈øequently never inioy their owne happine≈ø≈øe, which
con≈øi≈øts in the full fruition of them≈øelues. Heb. 1.3. Chri≈øt is ≈øaid to be the expre≈ø≈øe image of the fathers ≈øub≈øi≈øtence. Some tran≈ølate it, ≈øub≈øtance, or e≈ø≈øence, which will all come to one pa≈ø≈øe, if ≈øub≈øtance be taken ≈øubiectiuely, not cau≈øely; for the divine e≈ø≈øence hath eminently all the excellencies of creatures; and therefore vnder≈øtanding, which is able to conceiue, and in conceiuing to beget, which begetting is a relatiue propertie, and hence the Sub≈øi≈øtence of the Father, whereof the Sonne is the expre≈ø≈øe image. It were as we haue formerly ≈øaid, improper locution, to call him the image of the e≈ø≈øence, for that begets not, yet in that is the begetter, &c. Rom. 15.30. Gal. 5.22. Where loue is giuen to the Spirit; not onely as hee worketh it in vs, but as he is the mutuall loue both of Father and Sonne, and ≈øo is ≈øent from both of them, to te≈øtifie of their loue to vs, Rom. 5.5. O that the≈øe things in their true worth could affect vs, but alas, as in a Taverne where many Tables are ≈øeene repleni≈øhed with gue≈øts, halfe ≈øoaked, and ≈øow≈øed in wine; all the hou≈øe re≈øoundeth with laughters, cries, whoopings, and ≈øtrange noi≈øe, wherein the ≈øweete≈øt mu≈øicke in the world, is both neglected and mocked: ≈øo, our age, inchanted with rude and ridiculous pa≈øtimes, gibeth at this holy and heauenly contemplation of the ≈øacred and ble≈ø≈øed Trinitie. How many doth God ≈øuffer to liue and breath, which make the Taverne their Temple, Indian-≈ømoake their incen≈øe, Sacke their ≈øacrifice, and bla≈øphemous oathes their daily prayers: for the loue of this dreadfull Trinitie, and the deare loue of your owne ≈øoules, remember S. Pauls advi≈øe. Rom. 6.22. Being made free from ≈øinne, haue your fruit in holine≈ø≈øe, and the end thereof ≈øhall be ever-la≈øting life. But I mu≈øt make my cour≈øe more ≈øpeedie, and ha≈øten in the long way I haue to goe. Hitherto we haue had many Reaches to fetch in our way, and beene con≈øtrained to winde in by bourds, but wee are gotten off the Maine; onely the ≈øhore is ≈øtill buttre≈øt with rockes on euery hand, the Currents ≈øwift, the Shallowes many, that wee cannot make ≈øo fre≈øh a way as wee would. Haue but
the patience a while, and we ≈øhall bring thee within the view of the end of our toyle≈øome voyage. The ≈øhip that hath beene long at Sea, di≈øcouered many ≈øtrange Continents, and ryvers, ≈øtrugled through many hiddeous tempe≈øts, e≈øcaped many rockes and quick-≈øands, and at length made a rich returne, cannot but forget her irke≈øome Travell, and thinke ≈øhee is well apaid, when ≈øhee commeth within the kenne of her owne Countrey, and ≈øees the Land lye faire before her: So, hee that coa≈øts along the≈øe ≈øeverall bankes and bounds of godline≈ø≈øe, and in the Ship of the Church, is brought into the mouth of the haven of heaven, cannot but with ioy remember all the troubles and afflictions he hath indured in this world. In a word, vnder≈øtand this but as a letter of adverti≈øement from the Coa≈øt, whereby thou maye≈øt with the greater ea≈øe, reape the profit of them that haue travelled before thee.
Q. What is the relatiue propertie of the Father, and the Sonne?

A. To breath, or ≈øend forth the ≈øpirit. Ioh. 15.26. I will ≈øend from the father the Comforter, even the ≈øpirit of truth. The ≈øame is ≈øaid to proceed. Gal. 4.6. God hath ≈øent forth the ≈øpirit of his ≈øonne into your hearts. Ioh. 16.8. As the ≈øonne comes from the father to take our nature vpon him, ≈øo the ≈øpirit comes from them both, to apply Chri≈øt effectually vnto vs, and vs vnto Chri≈øt. But this comming, ≈øending, proceeding is a worke of coun≈øell, not of nature; for the Spirit by an imminent act as he comes from father & ≈øon, ≈øo he hath his re≈øidence in them both, and no creature is capable of him: but as by a tran≈øient act hee pa≈ø≈øeth the worke of Redemption to vs by application, hee is ≈øayd to come to vs, and we receiue him in graces and operations. By nature he comes from the ≈øame per≈øons, and re≈øts in them: by coun≈øell (not by command) he comes to vs, and is ≈øaid to dwell with vs, and that in ≈øpite of Satan & all his temptations. As fierce Ma≈øtiues tyed in a chaine, which although they both barke, and haue perhaps a good will to bite, yet they can make no neerer approach then the chaine
doth permit: ≈øo, that Cerberus of hell is chained vp of God, and though his malice be great to labour to enter, where he is expul≈øed, yet the ≈øpirit keepes him out by his pre≈øence, and ≈øafegards our hearts in peace, again≈øt all his mole≈øtations.
Q. What is the Father?

A. The fir≈øt per≈øon, who by nature begets his ≈øonne, who mu≈øt needs be an onely ≈øonne, becau≈øe the Father cannot haue many images of him≈øelfe. Chri≈øt is the fir≈øt begotten, Heb. 1.6. and the onely begotten. Ioh. 3.16.18. 1 Ioh. 4.9. Ioh. 1.14.18. And therefore the relation betwixt the Father and Chri≈øt, is a ≈øpeciall and peculiar re≈øpect. Heb. 1.5. I will be to him a father and he ≈øhall be to me a ≈øonne. Man was made in the image and likene≈ø≈øe of God, and of the three per≈øons, by a divine con≈øultation; but Chri≈øt is the image of his Father, or fir≈øt per≈øon, by an eternall and everla≈øting generation. Luk. 3.38. Adam is called the ≈øonne of God, which is a mo≈øt free and voluntary act of the Creator, in producing man in his owne image. This I in≈øi≈øt vpon the more, that wee may be wary in our conceits, in apprehending Gods act vpon vs, and the fathers act vpon his ≈øonne. It is happine≈ø≈øe enough for vs to come ≈øo neare God, that his onely ≈øonne may ≈øtand betwixt vs & him, and that wee may be called his brethren, by the Fathers choice of vs in him.
Q. What is the Fathers relatiue propertie?

A. To beget, and not to be begotten, and therefore he is the fir≈øt per≈øon in order. P≈øal. 2.7. Thou art my ≈øonne, this day haue I begotten thee. Heb. 1.5. The ≈øame words are repeated, to proue Chri≈øt aboue the Angels, who (Iob. 2.1.) are called the ≈øonnes of God, and therefore in another ≈øen≈øe, that is, in regard of Creation, and grace, both which they obtained by the will and coun≈øell of their Creator, who made them, and ordained them to ≈øtand in that favour, from which the reprobate Angels fell: but Chri≈øt is a naturall, and an eternall ≈øonne. Prov. 8.25. And therefore to day, is (as ≈øome Fathers expound it) put for eternitie, ≈øeeing
all times are pre≈øent to God, to whom a thou≈øand yeares are as one pre≈øent day. Or rather this day (being the day of Chri≈øts re≈øurrection, and exaltation, in which he was mightily declared to be the ≈øonne of God. Rom. 1.4.) is the manife≈øtation of that eternall generation, by which hee is preferred before all creatures. His conception and natiuitie, as he was man belong to his humiliation, which (as S. Augu≈øtine ≈øpeakes of his pa≈ø≈øion) was the ≈øleepe of his divinitie, as his death was the ≈øleepe of his humanitie. Yet as the fathers of Chalcedon ≈øay truly, ( „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ) indivi≈øibly, in≈øeparably is the God-head of the ≈øecond per≈øon with the whole humane nature, and euery part of it, ≈øtill, and for ever, one and the ≈øame per≈øon. The ≈øoule in the agony, and vpon the Cro≈ø≈øe, feeles not the pre≈øence of the God-head; the body in the graue feeles not the pre≈øence of the ≈øoule: yet vpon the third day both bodie and ≈øoule did feele the power of his divine nature, death being too weake to di≈ø≈øolue the eternall bonds of this heauenly coniunction. And therefore vpon the day of Chri≈øts re≈øurrection was there a manife≈øt declaration of the eternall generation of the ≈øecond per≈øon.
Q. What is the Sonne?

A. The ≈øecond per≈øon, begotten of his father. Ioh. 1.14. We beheld his glory, the glory of the onely begotten of the Father. Ver≈ø. 18. No man hath ≈øeene God at any time: the onely begotten ≈øonne, which is in the bo≈øome of the father, he hath declared him.
Q. What is the relatiue propertie?

A. To be begotten, and not to beget; and becau≈øe he is from the father alone, therefore the ≈øecond per≈øon in order. 1. Ioh. 4.9. God ≈øent his onely begotten ≈øonne into the world. Heb. 1.5. I will be to him a father, and he ≈øhall be to me a ≈øonne, therefore by the force of relation, he mu≈øt be begotten, no begetter: otherwi≈øe contrary things ≈øhould bee the ≈øame.
Q. What is the holy Gho≈øt?

A. The third per≈øon, proceeding from the Father and the Sonne.
Ioh. 14.26. The comforter, which is the holy Gho≈øt, whom the father will ≈øend in my name. Ioh. 15.26. When the comforter is come, whom I will ≈øend vnto you from the father, &c. Ioh. 20.22. Chri≈øt breathed on them, and ≈øaith vnto them, receiue yee the holy Gho≈øt: he that hath power to breath on his members the gifts of the holy Gho≈øt, according to his owne will and coun≈øell, hath by nature, together with his father an ineffable manner of breathing the ≈øpirit; for, as the three per≈øons worke by coun≈øell, ≈øo they ≈øub≈øi≈øt in the divine e≈ø≈øence by nature.
Q. What is the ≈øpirits relatiue propertie?

A. To proceed; and becau≈øe he is both from the Father and the Sonne, therefore, the third per≈øon in order of ≈øub≈øi≈øtence. Ioh. 15.26. even the ≈øpirit of truth, which proceedeth from the father, &c. Ioh. 16.7. It is expedient for you that I goe away: for if I goe not away, the comforter will not come vnto you: but if I depart, I will ≈øend him vnto you: till the ≈øecond per≈øon haue fully di≈øpen≈øed the worke of Redemption, the third per≈øon cannot ≈øo fully apply it: no marvaile then if the times before the death of Chri≈øt, had more weake meanes of application then now we haue, the ≈øpirit being more fully giuen. Ioh. 12.32. And I, if I be lifted vp from the earth, will draw all men vnto mee. Peter, Act. 2.41. conuerted more at one Sermon, then Chri≈øt did all his life; not becau≈øe he was the better, or more powerfull Preacher, but becau≈øe the ≈øpirit was then more fully ≈øent, both from the father and the ≈øonne, to accompli≈øh that which they had begun for the redemption, both of Iew and Gentile.
Q. What is the beleife of that which hath beene ≈øpoken?

A. I beleeue in God, who is one e≈ø≈øence, mo≈øt ≈øimple, pure, and ab≈øolute, and being e≈ø≈øentially indivi≈øible, is per≈øonally di≈øtingui≈øhed into the Father, Sonne, and holy Gho≈øt, and is therefore called, Vnitie in Trinitie, and Trinitie in Vnitie, or Vnitrinitie, and Trinunitie. How to conceiue of this in our prayers, and meditations, is both the deepe≈øt point of all Chri≈øtianitie, and the mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary: ≈øo deepe, that if wee wade into it, wee may ea≈øily drowne, never finde the bottome:
≈øo nece≈ø≈øary, that without it, our ≈øelues, our ≈øeruices are prophane, irreligious: wee are all borne Idolaters, naturally prone to fa≈øhion God to ≈øome forme of our owne. Away then with all wicked thoughts, and gro≈ø≈øe devotions; and with Iacob bury all ≈øtrange gods vnder the oake of Shechem, ere we offer to ≈øet vp Gods Altar at Bethel: & without all mentall re≈øervations, conceiue of our God purely, ≈øimply, ≈øpiritually; as of an ab≈øolute being, without forme, without matter, without compo≈øition; yea, an infinite, without all limits of thoughts. Thinke of him as not to be thought of; as one who≈øe wi≈øedome is his iu≈øtice, who≈øe iu≈øtice is his power, who≈øe power is his mercy, and all him≈øelfe. Good without qualitie, great without quantitie, everla≈øting without time, pre≈øent euery where without place, containing all things without extent. If this ≈øhall giue our devotions any light, it is well: the lea≈øt glimp≈øe of this knowledge, is worth all the full gleames of humane and earthly skill. After this weake direction, let vs ≈øtill ≈øtudy to conceiue aright, that we may pray aright; and ≈øtill pray, that we may conceiue: and meditate more and more, that we may doe both. And the father, ≈øonne, and holy Gho≈øt, direct vs, inable vs, that wee may doe all. Amen.

div.head: CHAPTER XI. Of the workes of Iehovah-Elohim in generall.
div.p: Que≈øtion.

p.hi: HItherto we haue heard of Gods ≈øufficiencie, what is his efficiencie?

div.p: An≈øwere.

That whereby he worketh all things, and all in all things. 1. Cor. 12.6. It is the ≈øame God that worketh all in all. Rom. 11.36. Of him, for him, and through him are all things. Deut. 34.4. Act. 14.17.
Q. What is here generally to be con≈øidered of vs?

A. Something concerning the e≈ø≈øence, and ≈øomething the ≈øub≈øi≈øtence. Gen. Chap. 1. to the end: the word Elohim is v≈øed aboue 30. times, and no other word for God. That vertue of vnder≈øtanding, whereby hee knoweth all truthes in the things, which as they are to come, is called pre≈øcience, or foreknowledge, and in regard of pa≈øt, pre≈øent, and to come, omni≈øcience. Ioh. 21.17. Lord, thou knowe≈øt all things, and therefore can≈øt iudge whether I ≈øpeake truely or not: for foreknowledge there is none in God properly, for to him all things are pre≈øent, yet ≈øpeaking of his indirect knowledge in reference to the creature, we terme that foreknowledge that goes before the exi≈øtence, and being of the creature.
Q. What is his ≈øapience?

A. That vertue of vnder≈øtanding, whereby he vnder≈øtandeth what≈øoeuer may follow, or en≈øue of euery thing. Iob 12.13.16. Such wi≈øedome with God that he knowes how to handle both deceiuer and deceiued, their fallacies can no wayes prevaile with him.
Q. What is his prudence?

A. Whereby he knoweth the fitte≈øt opportunitie for the di≈øpatch of all things. Gen. 15.16. The wickedne≈ø≈øe of the Amorites is not yet full. 2. Pet. 2.9. The Lord knowes how to deliuer the godly, and re≈øerue the wicked to puni≈øhment. 2. The≈ø. 1.6.7. It
is a righteous thing with God, and mo≈øt ag reeable with his prudence, in applying of rewards to recompen≈øe tribuiation to them that trouble you, and to you which are troubled, re≈øt with vs, &c.
Q. What is his art, or skill?

A. Whereby he knoweth how to effect euery thing mo≈øt skilfully. P≈øal. 104.24. In excellent wi≈øedome ha≈øt thou made all. Heb. 11.10. For he looked for a citie, which hath foundations, who≈øe builder and maker is God: the originall word is Technitees, an Artificer God hath manife≈øted great skill in the creation of the≈øe lower parts of the world: but in the third heauen, his art pa≈ø≈øeth all excellencie.
Q. Seeing his good-plea≈øure appeares la≈øt, what is it?

A. The mo≈øt free act of his will in euery thing as it plea≈øeth him. P≈øal. 115.3. Our God is in heauen, he doth what≈øoeuer he plea≈øeth. Mat. 11.26. Euen ≈øo father, for ≈øo it ≈øeemed good in thy ≈øight. Math. 20.15. Is it not lawfull for me to doe with mine owne as I li≈øt. Ephe≈ø. 1.5.9.11.
Q. How doth it re≈øpect him≈øelfe?

A. As the chiefe good. P≈øal. 36.9. For with thee is the fountaine of life: and in thy light ≈øhall we ≈øee light. Col. 3.11. Chri≈øt is all and in all. His good-plea≈øure mu≈øt needs fir≈øt re≈øpect him≈øelfe, then his creatures, becau≈øe from him as the fountaine of goodne≈ø≈øe, they haue all their goodne≈ø≈øe deriued. 1. Cor. 15.28. God is ≈øaid to be all in all.
Q. How the creatures?

A. As they beare his image, in which regard they are onely good. Gen. 1.4.10. &c. God ≈øaw it was good, that is, he ≈øo approued of his creatures, as they an≈øwered his goodne≈ø≈øe in making of them.
