Rom. 12.2. Be not conformed to this world: but be yee transformed by the renewing of your minde, that ye may proue what is that good, and acceptable and perfect will of God. Conformitie with the world plea≈øeth not the Almightie, becau≈øe it agreeth not with his image, being mightily deformed with ≈øinne. Then doth hee acknowledge vs for his, when we are changed by the ≈øpirit of ≈øanctification into that image which we lo≈øt by the fall of Adam.
Q. What learne you from thence?

A. That the good plea≈øure of God, being mo≈øt freely ≈øet vpon his creatures, is the fir≈øt and mo≈øt ab≈øolute cau≈øe of all things: and therefore he mu≈øt needs doe all that hee doth with the greate≈øt libertie of will, hauing no higher cau≈øe to checke him. Dan. 4.35. He doth according to his will in the army of heauen, and among the inhabitants of the earth: and none can ≈øtay his hand, or ≈øay vnto him, what doe≈øt thou? Ier. 18.6. Mat. 20.15. Rom. 9.18.21. 2. Sam. 16.10. I≈øa. 45.9. In all which places as God workes mo≈øt freely, ≈øo he is bound to render account to none of all his doings. Luk. 10.21. Chri≈øt Ie≈øus reioyced in the good plea≈øure of his Father, as the onely cau≈øe of revealing, or hiding the my≈øteries of mans ≈øaluation. Phil. 2.12.13. Worke out your owne ≈øaluation with feare and trembling; now lea≈øt wee ≈øhould follow the Popi≈øh dreame of free-will, that man could merit life and happine≈ø≈øe, if God would but beare halfe the charges, we are reduced to a more full cau≈øe, It is God which worketh in you both to will and to doe; we bring not ≈øo much as a will di≈øpo≈øed for our owne good: that is mo≈øt ≈ølaui≈øh till grace free it, and it is freed by the mo≈øt free cau≈øe, which is the good-plea≈øure of our God.
Q. What doe you ob≈øerue concerning Elohim, or the per≈øons?

A. Two things, their cooperation, and di≈øtinct manner of working, the one is nece≈ø≈øary in regard of this, that they haue the ≈øame e≈ø≈øence, and therefore cannot but co-worke in euery thing, the other is likewi≈øe as nece≈ø≈øary, becau≈øe each per≈øon hath his di≈øtinct manner of ≈øub≈øi≈øting. All operation flowes from their e≈ø≈øence, cooperation from their vnitie in it, and di≈øtinct manner, from the di≈øtinct manner of their ≈øub≈øi≈øting. One e≈ø≈øence, one operation, and three being one, mu≈øt needs worke in≈øeparably, and one being three, mu≈øt needs worke in a di≈øtinct manner. Gen. 1.1. In the beginning Elohim made. Gen. 2.26. Let vs make. Mat. 12.31. Bla≈øphemie is aggrevated in regard of the three per≈øons, and again≈øt the la≈øt it is made vnpardonable,
becau≈øe a ≈øinne again≈øt the Father is remitted by the action of the Sonne, who redeemes from wrath: and ≈øo is a ≈øinne again≈øt the Sonne by the worke of the Spirit, who applies the merites of Chri≈øt to euery guiltie ≈øoule: but if the ≈øin be again≈øt the holy Gho≈øt, all hope is cut off; for there is no fourth per≈øon to helpe, and the worke cannot goe backward; for, the Spirit workes neither by the Father, nor the Sonne, and ≈øo no meanes of remi≈ø≈øion is left for this ≈øinne.
Q. What is the divine co-operation?

A. Whereby the three per≈øons worke the ≈øame thing in≈øeparably. Ioh. 5.17.19.21. My father worketh hitherto, and I worke, what≈øoeuer things he doth, the ≈øame doe I, he rai≈øeth and quickneth the dead, even ≈øo doe I quicken whom I will, &c. Ioh. 1.3. Nothing was made without the ≈øonne. And here wee are to vnder≈øtand the ≈øame of the ble≈ø≈øed Spirit.
Q. What is hence to be learned?

A. That all the per≈øons worke of them≈øelues. 1. Ioh. 5.7. Three beare record, and yet they are all one in e≈ø≈øence, in re≈øpect whereof they worke from them≈øelues. To be and to act is all one in God, therefore as each per≈øon is God of him≈øelfe, ≈øo doth he worke of him≈øelfe.
Q. What will further follow from this?

A. That there is no preheminence, or dignitie in this their co-working. For as they are equall in e≈ø≈øence, ≈øo are they equall in their actions. Ioh. 14.1. Yee beleeue in God, beleeue al≈øo in mee. Ioh. 16.15. All things that the father hath are mine. Ioh. 5.18. It was no ≈øinne for Chri≈øt to make him≈øelfe equall with his father in euery worke. The ≈øame is as true of the Spirit.
Q. What is the di≈øtinct manner of working?

A. Whereby each per≈øon worketh according to the manner of his ≈øub≈øi≈øting. Hence it comes to pa≈ø≈øe, that the ≈øecond per≈øon being mentioned with the fir≈øt, it is ≈øaid, Not of him, but by him were things made: for as the ≈øonne workes from the father, ≈øo the father workes by the ≈øonne. Ioh. 1.3. Col. 1.16.17. Heb. 1.2. The like is to be vnder≈øtood of the Spirit,
who being from both, hath both to worke by him. Ioh. 16.13. and doth nothing of him≈øelfe, (I meane) as a per≈øon.
Q. What is the Fathers manner of working?

A. To worke all things by the Sonne, and the holy Gho≈øt. 1. Cor. 8.6. One God, which is the Father, of whom are all things, and we in him, and one Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, by whom are all things, and we by him. So that the fir≈øt per≈øon workes from him≈øelfe, not onely as God, but as a per≈øon, and continues his worke by his ≈øonne. Math. 10.20. Ioh. 15.26. 1. Cor. 3.10. By the Spirit the Father revealeth, teacheth, and te≈øtifieth; and the rea≈øon is, becau≈øe they are both from him, who worketh of him≈øelfe.
Q. What from hence?

A. That the originall and beginning of all things is from the Father. For he that is fir≈øt in ≈øub≈øi≈øting, mu≈øt needs be fir≈øt in working. Hence ≈øome manife≈øt notable ignorance in this point, who place the worke of the Sonne and the holy Gho≈øt, before the action of the Father, and that in the greate≈øt and weightie≈øt my≈øtery of our ≈øalvation, I meane our eternall prede≈øtination: who placing redemption and application before election, ≈øet the worke of the ≈øecond & third per≈øon before the fir≈øt; for, according to their wandering Doctrine, they teach that man is redeemed, and by faith applied to Chri≈øt, before he bee elected of God the Father. This is cleane contrary to S. Paul. Eph. 1.3. to 15. Where election, being an originall worke, is giuen to the Father, who di≈øpen≈øeth the ≈øame by his ≈øonne, and applies it by his ≈øpirit. So that the Father doth elect vs, before the Sonne redeeme vs, or the Spirit ≈øanctifie vs. Read the Bible, and you ≈øhall finde creation and election more frequently attributed to the fir≈øt per≈øon, then either the ≈øecond or the third. And our Creed teacheth vs to call the Father Creator, &c.
Q. What is the Sonnes manner of working?

A. He worketh from the Father, by the holy Gho≈øt. Ioh. 5.19. The ≈øonne can doe nothing of him≈øelfe, ≈øaue that which hee
≈øeeth the Father doe, &c. Ioh. 16.15. The Spirit ≈øhall take of mine, and ≈øhew it vnto you. And the rea≈øon is, the Sonne is from the Father, but the holy Gho≈øt is from them both.
Q. What learne wee hence?

A. That the di≈øpen≈øaetion of all things is giuen to the Sonne: as there is an entrance into euery worke, ≈øo mu≈øt there bee a proceeding in it; and the Father in all things proceeds by his Sonne, as in the revelation & declaration of his will. Ioh. 1.18. and the execution of all things in him≈øelfe, which may prepare for the worke of the ≈øpirit in vs. Ioh. 16.17. For till the Father haue done, the Sonne can doe nothing, neither is it for the Spirit to worke, vntill he take it from them both.
Q. What is the holy Gho≈øts manner of working?

A. To worke both from the Father and the Sonne. Ioh. 16.13. The Spirit ≈øhall not ≈øpeake, or doe any thing of him≈øelfe, but what≈øoeuer he ≈øhall heare from the Father and the Sonne, as the two next ver≈øes make it plaine. And the rea≈øon is that he ≈øub≈øi≈øting from them both, mu≈øt needs worke accordingly.
Q. What followes from hence?

A. That the con≈øummation of all things is giuen to the holy Gho≈øt, who ends the worke of the Father and the Sonne. Gen. 1.3. Let there be, is rather a word of con≈øummation, then commandement. The whole worke is carried by word and deed. God ≈øaid, the Father had none to ≈øpeake vnto but his Sonne: let there be, is that the word ≈øpoken might be done by the Spirit, who fini≈øheth what is ≈øpoken by both. And here we ≈øee by what kind of motion the world was made, by the lea≈øt ≈øtirring, for what is le≈ø≈øe then to effect all by a word. And yet what greater, then to effect by ≈øuch a word and ≈øpirit? Iob 26.13. The Spirit is ≈øaid to garni≈øh the worke of creation. Ioh. 14.26. and 15.26. All that the word hath ≈øaid, or Father promi≈øed, ≈øhall bee taught, te≈øtified, and remembred vnto vs by Gods ≈øpirit. Rom. 8.10.11 13.14.15.16.26. &c. A Spirit of life quickens tho≈øe mortall bodies that are redeemed by Chri≈øt, by whom they
liue againe, and are led in prayer as children of adoption, &c. 1. Cor. 12.11. All gifts and graces wee haue from the Spirit. Rom. 8.9. 1. Cor. 3.16. the Spirit is ≈øaid to dwell; for, as the Father makes choice of his hou≈øe, and the ≈øonne purcha≈øeth it, ≈øo the holy Gho≈øt takes po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, in ca≈øting out Satan and ≈øinne, and in keeping and holding the ≈øame in ≈øpite of all Satans a≈ø≈øaults. Act. 5.3. A lie again≈øt the truth, is a ≈øpeciall ≈øinne again≈øt the holy Gho≈øt, who≈øe proper worke is to te≈øtifie of the veritie he hath receiued from the Father and the Sonne. And hence it comes to pa≈ø≈øe, that ≈øinning after the knowledge of the truth is mo≈øt dangerous, becau≈øe it is oppo≈øite to the la≈øt act of God, further then which he will not goe in the addition of any new ≈øupply of grace and goodne≈ø≈øe.
Q. What may wee learne for conclu≈øion of all this?

A. That to him the worke is e≈øpecially giuen, in whom the manner of working doth mo≈øt appeare, as Creation to the Father, Redemption to the Sonne, and Sanctification to the holy Gho≈øt. This may a little be manife≈øted vnto vs out of man, who is ≈øaid to doe all things by his wit, will, and power. The fir≈øt mouer of man to action is will, then by wit and wi≈øedome he proceeds, and by his power concludes. The will workes by wit and power: wit workes from the will by power, and the power workes from them both. Will begins, wit di≈øpen≈øeth, and power doth fini≈øh the action. Onely here is the difference, that they are not alwayes able to worke in≈øeparably; for, ≈øometimes a man hath more wit then will; Agrippa, (Act. 26.28.) had more wit to be per≈øwaded to be a Chri≈øtian, then will to imbrace ≈øo dangerous a profe≈ø≈øion. Sometimes he hath more will then wit, as Peter, Mat. 16.22. Ma≈øter ≈øpare thy ≈øelfe; loue made him blind, in ≈øeeing what was fit for Chri≈øt to doe. Sometimes againe more will and wit then power, as the Devill, Mat. 4. in the temptation of our Sauiour, he ≈øhewed all his wit and will to trap our Sauiour, but he had not power thereunto: ≈øomtimes al≈øo there appeares more power then eyther wit or will, as in the Legion of vncleane Spirits, Math. 8.
who carried the whole Herd of Swine head long into the Sea. By this wee may ≈øee the in≈øeparable co-operation of the three per≈øons, as through a crevis, or lettice, a little glimmering light of their di≈øtinct manner of working. The Father wills the thing to be done, hence in Scripture will is oftner giuen to the Father then any other per≈øon. Mat. 11.26. Ephe≈ø. 1.11. Secondly, the Sonne being the wi≈øedome of the Father, di≈øpen≈øeth what the Father hath willed. And here wee v≈øually call the Sonne the wi≈øedome of the Father, and ≈øo indeed we finde him to be in our redemption. 1. Cor. 1.30. Thirdly, the holy Gho≈øt as the power of both, doth fini≈øh and con≈øummate their works; and ≈øo the Scripture ≈øtiles him the power of the Highe≈øt. Luk. 1.35. For as the Father did will that his Sonne ≈øhould take vpon him our fle≈øh, and as it was proper to the ≈øecond per≈øon to a≈ø≈øume: ≈øo the fini≈øhing of this worke in the la≈øt act of it was due to the Spirit: for as there is a naturall ≈øpirit, to vnite the body and ≈øoule together; ≈øo is there a divine ≈øpirit, equall to the worke, to vnite the divinitie, and the humanitie of Chri≈øt together. God wills that his ≈øonne a≈ø≈øume, and his ≈øonne will not a≈ø≈øume, but by the worke of the Spirit. To conclude, nothing is done, no, not in their mo≈øt di≈øtinct manner of working, but they will all haue an hand in it: what more proper to the ≈øonne of God then to take our fle≈øh, and become our wi≈øedome, righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, ≈øanctification, and redemption? And yet he can doe none of this, but from the will of his Father, and by the power of his Spirit.

div.head: CHAPTER XII. Of the Creation of things, immediately made perfect.
div.p: Que≈øtion.

p.hi: HItherto of Gods efficiencie in generall, what are the kinds?

div.p: An≈øwere.

A. Two, Creation and providence. In the one we ≈øee the orderly production of the creatures; in the other, Gods carefull admini≈øtration, and pre≈øervation of them. See for this, P≈øalme 104. Of creation to the tenth ver≈øe, of government to the 27. ver≈øe, of pre≈øervation to the end. Nehe. 9.6. Thou ha≈øt made the heauen, with all their ho≈øt, &c. Thou pre≈øorue≈øt them all, and they wor≈øhip thee in regard of their Government.
Q. What is Creation?

A. It is the fir≈øt part of Gods externall efficiencie, whereby he made the world of nothing originally good. Gen. 1.1. In the beginning God made. Heb. 11.3. of things which did not appeare. Gen. 1.3. and they were very good. P≈øal. 33.6.7.8.9. and 146.6. Ier. 10.11.12. Act. 17.24. All which places te≈øtifie of a Creator, and his power, wi≈øedome, and di≈øcretion in framing them ≈øo excellently, and that minimo motu by his word and breath.
Q. What is here generally to be ob≈øerued?

A. That becau≈øe things here originally had their beginning, therefore the Fathers manner of working doth here pruicipally appeare, to whom the originall of all things is giuen. 1. Cor. 8.6. All are ≈øaid to be of the Father; ≈øo are they of the Sonne as God, but as a per≈øon he is not the originall, for in the ≈øame place it is ≈øaid, by the ≈øonne. And ≈øo in the Creed we giue all per≈øonally to the Father, vntill wee come to the worke of redemption; and here we are to learne, that the Apo≈øta≈øie of Adam was e≈øpecially again≈øt the Father, and
therefore could not he by way of ≈øatisfaction be our Redeemer, for the per≈øon properly offended, cannot ≈øatisfie him≈øelfe by him≈øelfe, but by ≈øome other that mu≈øt come betwixt the Father and vs, and thus agrees it with the iu≈øtice of God, that we ≈øhould be reconciled by a ≈øecond per≈øon.
Q. Did God make the world all at one in≈øtant?

A. No, but in the ≈øpace of ≈øixe times 24. houres, that wee might more di≈øtinctly con≈øider all his workes. And Aquinas giues a good rule, Succe≈ø≈øiverum non ≈øimul e≈øt e≈ø≈øe & perfectio; God could haue created all at once, but in his wi≈øedome he tooke daies for it. Some glimps of rea≈øon hereof we may aime at thus; as ≈øome creatures were to begin with the fir≈øt in≈øtant of time, ≈øo ≈øome others that they might not haue their principles together, were to haue ≈øomething goe before them, hence the con≈øtancie and incon≈øtancie of Gods creatures. The third heauen, and the Angels were of nece≈ø≈øitie to be created in the fir≈øt in≈øtant, that they might haue their perfection of matter and forme together, otherwi≈øe they ≈øhould be corruptible, for what≈øoeuer is of a preexi≈øtent matter, is re≈øoluble and ≈øubiect to corruption. But that which is immediately of nothing, is perfectly compo≈øed, hath no other change, but by the ≈øame hand to returne into nothing againe. It was therefore impo≈ø≈øible for the world to want a beginning, and improbable for the creatures to be all at once, and yet ≈øome to remaine incorruptible, and others corruptible. That the worke was of ≈øixe dayes continuance, is plaine by Gen. 2.1. Exod. 20.11.
Q. How is the worke di≈øtributed?

A. Either into the adiuncts of time, as a worke of ≈øixe dayes, or into the e≈ø≈øentiall and integrall parts: as into nature con≈øtant, or incon≈øtant; or re≈øpecting the agent that gaue all, as well matter as forme, into Creation immediately perfect, or perfect by degrees. Gen. 1.1. In the beginning, or very fir≈øt moment of time, God created heauen and earth. Now by the oppo≈øite member in the di≈øtribution, largely di≈øcribed in the whole Chapter, we ≈øhall be able to vnder≈øtand
that which is in ≈øilence pa≈ø≈øed over. Earth vpon which wee now tread was made the third day, and therefore cannot be this which was made in the very beginning of the fir≈øt day: neither can this heauen be that which was made the ≈øecond day, ver. 8. It then remaines by iu≈øt con≈øequent to be the highe≈øt heauen, which at the very fir≈øt was made mo≈øt ab≈øolute and perfect. Secondly, the earth that was made at the very ≈øame in≈øtant, as a matter of all that was afterwards to be created, being all things in power, nothing in act, did from his owne center touch the third heauen in euery point and part of his out≈øide: & that of nece≈ø≈øitie, lea≈øt any vacuitie, or emptine≈ø≈øe ≈øhould haue interpo≈øed it ≈øelfe within the compa≈ø≈øe of ≈øo great a continent; nature abhorring to yeeld nothing a place within the circle of ≈øome-thing. Therefore were the≈øe two as companions and friends, immediately made of God in the very beginning of the fir≈øt day. Further, it is ≈øaid of the earth, ver. 2. that it was without forme and voyd; that is, as yet it had neither any e≈ø≈øentiall, or accidentall perfection. The Lord afterwards did forme it into the light, the expan≈øe, (improperly called the firmament) the water and the earth. The≈øe foure were mediately created of the earth, and yet for their formes immediately from God of nothing. Thus was the earth fir≈øt formed, the highe≈øt part of it mo≈øt apt to receiue light, the next ayre, the third, the forme of water, and the lowe≈øt the forme of earth. After the earth had receiued this perfection, it was filled in euery part of it with inhabitants, as aboue with ≈øtarres, & foules, below with trees, bea≈øts, and fi≈øhes, &c. But of the≈øe anone. I in≈øi≈øt here to proue by rea≈øon that which is a truth, not as yet clearely deliuered, and by many contradicted; I leaue all to cen≈øure, according to the evidence I ≈øhall giue. My meaning is not to binde any man vnto my opinion, I onely pre≈øent things, and lay them out, as it were, vpon a ≈øtall; neither is it meet I grow into choler with any man that giues me no credit, or di≈ø-likes my ware, that were to play the Pedant. Pa≈ø≈øion witne≈ø≈øeth, that it is not rea≈øon ≈øo
to doe, and he that doth any thing out of pa≈ø≈øion, cannot well doe it out of rea≈øon. Why ≈øhould any bee angry with mee, that I am not altogether of his opinion, ≈øeeing I am not angry with him, becau≈øe he is not of mine? I haue propounded for my example, S. Ierome and S. Augu≈øtine in their di≈øputations, to whom it was no matter, who gained the day, they would both winne by vnder≈øtanding their errors. But why doe I thus draw my ≈øelfe from my taske? Let truth vphold her ≈øelfe by mildne≈ø≈øe, and be promoted by patience. You haue heard that heaven and earth were made in the very in≈øtant and beginning of the fir≈øt day. That they are two oppo≈øite members in the worke of God; and therefore what is properly giuen to the one, mu≈øt not bee giuen to the other. The earth (≈øayth the Text) was without forme, and voyd; Heaven then had at the very fir≈øt his forme, and inhabitant, and therefore had the glorious Angels at the ≈øame in≈øtant created with it; other places were in time before their in-dwellers: onely the third heaven, and the Angels were concreated; and the rea≈øon is, for that their perfections were equally of nothing. It could not ≈øtand with order, after the fini≈øhing of the third heauen, and entrance made to create of matter, afterward to fall off againe, and beginne to create ≈øub≈øtances of no matter. I meane, integrally, for their whole e≈ø≈øence, otherwi≈øe, the foure formes of the elements, and ≈øoule of man were of nothing.
Q. What is the creation of things immediately made perfect?

A. Whereby he made them of nothing with their principles together, that is, their matter and forme were put together of Almightie God, not ≈øuffering the one to enter the compo≈øition before the other. Gen. 1.1. In the beginning he made, not giuing the one a beginning before the other. The ≈øame individuall time was the mea≈øure of both. Our bodies and ≈øoules may part a≈øunder, becau≈øe in creation time did ≈øeparate them, &c.
Q. What followes from hence?

A. That they are obnoxious and ≈øubiect to the motion of their owne nature onely by the power of God. No other force is able to worke vpon them, or de≈øtroy their beings. Luk. 12.31. Math. 6.19.20. 1. Tim. 6.19. The place and the life therein are both incorruptible, ≈øubiect to no alteration, change or mutation. Angels are too quicke and ready in their motion to ≈øuffer of any but God, he onely is nimble enough, to meet them, and ma≈øter them.
Q. What el≈øe?

A. That they are onely ≈øubiect, in regard of their e≈ø≈øence to creation and annihilation, that is, by the ≈øame hand they may be made nothing, as they were of nothing made ≈øomething. I≈øa. 40.15. God can takeaway his creature as ea≈øily as the winde doth a little du≈øt.
Q. What yet further may be ob≈øerued?

A. That they are in them≈øelues no wayes liable to generation, or corruption. They can neither receiue new formes, or loo≈øe their old; for that matter cannot admit of diver≈øe formes, which it ≈øelfe was never depriued of his owne. So complete is the vnion, that the matter hath not ≈øo much as the lea≈øt inclination to any other perfection, then it receiues at the fir≈øt in≈øtant, by the hand of the Creator, and excellencie of his forme. Math. 22.30. The idle que≈øtion of the Sadduces, concerning mariage in heauen, and procreation of children, is fully an≈øwered by our Sauiour, both in regard of the nature of the place, and his fir≈øt inhabitants. In the re≈øurrection of the dead, they neither marry, nor are giuen in mariage, but are as the Angels of God in beauen.
Q. When were the≈øe things created?

A. In the fir≈øt moment of time: for as they had no ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of time, for the receiuing of their e≈ø≈øentiall parts: ≈øo God tooke the very fir≈øt beginning for their creation. The ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of time being left to other creatures, of a cleane contrary nature. Angels are not ≈øimply eternall, becau≈øe they haue a beginning, & yet they are immortall, becau≈øe nature can never ≈øever their parts, or divide them
a≈øunder. Gen. 1.1. In the beginning he made the heauen, &c. Perfect for forme, and that it might not be voyd, like the earth, filled it with mo≈øt excellent inhabitants.
Q. What are the things ≈øo made?

A. The third heaven, and the Angels, Colo≈ø. 1.16. Heaven and all things therein, as thrones, dominions, principalities, powers, &c. were created of the Father by his Sonne. Angels no ≈øooner opened the eyes of their rea≈øon, then they ≈øaw them≈øelues in skie and highe≈øt ≈øphere of happine≈ø≈øe.
Q. What is the creation of the third heaven?

A. Whereby it was made perfect immediately of nothing, to be a mo≈øt excellent place, repleni≈øhed with all plea≈øures that belong to eternall happine≈ø≈øe, where his Maie≈øtie is ≈øeene face to face, and therefore aboue all other places, is called the Habitacle of holine≈ø≈øe, 2 Chron. 30.27.1. King. 8.30. Deut. 26.15. Gods hou≈øe full of excellent Man≈øions. Ioh. 14.2. Abrahams bo≈øome. Luk. 16.22. The third and highe≈øt heaven. 2. Cor. 12.2. P≈øal. 113.5. The habitation of Iehovah, where are fulne≈ø≈øe of ioy, and plea≈øures for euermore, P≈øal. 16.11. and 33.14. This onely hath the immoueable foundation. Heb. 11.10. And is as folide as ≈øtone, but cleare as Cri≈øtall. Rev. 21.11. Iob ≈øayes it is ≈øtrong and firme, as being ≈øtretched and ≈øpread out to the vtmo≈øt exten≈øion, and as tran≈øparent in brightne≈ø≈øe, as a molten looking gla≈ø≈øe. Iob 37.18. This onely is to be called Firmament, as not penetrable by any creature, whereas the other two heavens vnder it are to be pa≈ø≈øed through by the gro≈ø≈øe≈øt bodies. This heaven is without all pores, and cannot po≈ø≈øibly extend, or contract it ≈øelfe into a larger or ≈øtraiter compa≈ø≈øe: it opens to the very Angels. Gen. 28.12. Ioh. 1.51. who though they be able to penetrate all things vnder it, yet are they no more able to enter that body, then they are to pa≈ø≈øe into one anothers natures. Hence it comes to pa≈ø≈øe, that the third heaven giues way to Angels, the ≈øoules and bodies of men to enter by miracle: God making way by his power, where nature yeelds no pa≈ø≈øage. This heaven is more firme
and ≈øolide then the earth, more bright and glorious then the Sunne in his ≈øtrength, &c.
Q. What is the Creation of the Angels?

A. Whereby he created them at once and together in the third heaven, immediately of nothing, with the greate≈øt perfections of nature, to the end they might prai≈øe him together, and become his mini≈øtring Spirits, and Me≈ø≈øengers, as he ≈øhould haue occa≈øion to ≈øend them. Heb. 1.7. He made them for perfection of nature Spirits, and for office, his mo≈øt immediate Mini≈øters, and for execution, more ready then any flame of fire, ver. 14. Yea, and ≈øo prompt to mini≈øter to the heires of ≈øaluation, that they are all ready to be commanded. Iob 38.7. They are called morning Starres, by rea≈øon of their admirable brightne≈ø≈øe of nature, ≈øuch as the eye of fle≈øh cannot behold, Colo≈ø. 1.16.
Q. With what properties hath he enriched them?

A. With the greate≈øt per≈øpicuitie of rea≈øon, and acutene≈ø≈øe of wit, libertie of will, ≈øtrength and ≈øpeed of motion, that is po≈ø≈øible, or incident to created nature. Mat. 18.10. They are ≈øayd alwayes to behold the face of God: ≈øo cleare vnder≈øtandings that they quickly perceiue what God would haue done: yet of ≈øome things are they ignorant. Mar: 13.32. And what≈øoever they know is by reflection, either of Gods face vpon the gla≈ø≈øe of their mindes, or the beames of it, as they ≈øhine in the creatures; the one is by immediate revelation, the other, by inqui≈øition and di≈øcour≈øe. Eph. 3.10. 1. Pet. 1.12. It is true, that Angels ≈øee both the face of God, and the face of things, and then the face of them≈øelues; and hence it is, that they know nothing in them≈øelues, but either God reveales it, or them≈øelues doe finde it in the creatures; and by meanes hereof they learne much in beholding God, and his workes; and hauing ≈øo neere a pre≈øence with his Maie≈øty, mu≈øt needs out-≈øtrip others that are further off, I meane, in re≈øpect of divine Revelation. As for freedome of will, it was mo≈øt excellent by nature, and is now growne better by grace, and hath confirmed them for ever in glory; as for ≈øtrength and a gilitie of motion,
read the≈øe Texts, Gen. 32.2. 2 Sam. 24.16. 2 King. 19.35. Act. 1.10. and 5.19. and 12.7.8.9.10.
Q. What are their offices?

A. To celebrate the prai≈øes of God, and to execute his commands. Dan. 7.10. Thou≈øand thou≈øands mini≈øtred vnto him, and ten thou≈øand thou≈øands ≈øtood before him. Luk. 1.19. I am Gabriel that ≈øtand in the pre≈øence of God, and am ≈øent to ≈øpeake vnto thee, &c. P≈øal. 103.20. and 148. 2. Ready are the Angels, both in their attendance vpon God, and performance of his will, to his creatures. P≈øal. 91.11. I≈øa. 6.3. Rev. 7.11.12. They are as a gard to the Church.
Q. Where is their ≈øpeciall abode?

A. In the third heauen, Math. 18 10. Their Angels in heaven, Mar. 12.25. When wee ari≈øefrom the dead wee ≈øhall be as the Angels in heaven, P≈øal. 68.17. The Chariots of the Lord are twentie thou≈øand thou≈øand Angels, and the Lord is among them as in the Sanctuary of Sinai. They are the proper inhabitants of heaven, and there is of them an innumerable company. Heb. 12.22. Yet their number is not infinite, though to vs it be indefinite.
Q. Are there any degrees of Angels?
A. Yes, but to determine what, and how many is without warrant from Gods word, for ought I can finde.
Q. Doth not Scripture favour their opinion that make nine ≈øeverall orders of Angels?

A. Col. 1.16. Ephe.
‚Ä¢ 21. and 3.10. S. Paul here giueth di≈øtinct titles to the inhabitants of heauenly places. But whether hereby are ≈øignified di≈øtinct orders, offices, or gifts, it doth not appeare. And whenas it is ≈øuppo≈øed that tho≈øe nine orders are ≈øet downe by a di≈øciple of S. Paul, it is well proued, that the alledged Diony≈øius is of a far newer ≈øtamp, and ba≈øer mettall. Nor can I ≈øee how it can agree with Scripture, that the Seraphim, Cherubim, and th ‚Ä¢ ones haue never any other employment then immediate attending vpon the pre≈øence of God, whereas Heb. 1.14. the Angels are ≈øaid to be all mini≈øtring Spirits for the good of the elect. I≈øa. 6.6.

div.head: CHAPTER XIII. Of the fir≈øt matter, and foure Elements.
div.p: Que≈øtion.

p.hi: HItherto of things immediately perfected, what is the creation of tho≈øe things that were perfected by degrees?

div.p: An. It is whereby he made them of a preexi≈øtent matter, or forgoing principles. They are not immediately compo≈øed, but fir≈øt they haue a matter, and then a forme, and then their owne being, or exi≈øting. And as time di≈ø-ioynes the≈øe things, ≈øo they are ≈øubiect to change with time. Gen. 1.2. Out of the voyde and vnformed earth came all incon≈øtant and mutable creatures. 2. Pet. 3.5. The earth that now is, is ≈øayd to ≈øtand out of that Chaos, which Gen. 1.2. is called earth, water, &c. This by conver≈øion is as well the ground of confu≈øion, as of compo≈øition. Out of a confu≈øion are they compounded, and may by conver≈øion be confounded againe into it.
Q. What followeth hereupon?

A. That they are by nature returnable into their former principles, and ≈øo of a corruptible nature. 2 Pet. 3.6. The world that then was peri≈øhed, being over-flowed with the waters, that is, all that breathed. Gen. 7.22. Euery thing vnder the Sunne pa≈ø≈øeth away. Eccl. 1.4. And at the la≈øt day, the elements, with all their inhabitants ≈øhall be de≈øtroyed. 2. Pet. 3.10. As it were, a re≈øolution being made into the fir≈øt Chaos againe, as may ≈øeeme, what a hell were it for a man to be an inhabitant of that fir≈øt earth? The holy Gho≈øt te≈øtifieth, 2. Pet. 3.7. that the heavens and the earth, which are now, are kept in ≈øtore, and re≈øerved for fire and perdition of vngodly men at the la≈øt day. Good rea≈øon they ≈øhould be puni≈øhed where they ≈øinned, and with tho≈øe creatures they haue abu≈øed. A fearefull hell to haue all turned into the fir≈øt
Chaos, with an addition of the fire of Gods vengeance. As if that fir≈øt matter were then to be formed and filled with nothing but the extremities of Gods cur≈øes. At the fir≈øt it was formed, and adorned as a Palace and Paradi≈øe for man, then ≈øhall it be left as a dungeon and noy≈øome pri≈øon, for the torture and torment of all wretched and wicked per≈øons. Onely the third heauen, with the inhabitants thereof, ≈øhall then be in bli≈ø≈øe and ble≈ø≈øed felicitie.
Q. How manifold is this creation?

A. It is eyther of the elements, or the elementaries. Gen. 2.1. Heauen and earth were fini≈øhed with the ho≈øt of them. All that are placed aboue in the fire, and the ayre, or below in the waters and the earth, are elementaries, being compo≈øed out of tho≈øe foure elements, and are as the ho≈øt of this inferiour world.
Q. What is the creation of the elements?

A. Whereby he made them of a precedent matter, with their formes, immediately of nothing. That is, the matter, or earth without forme, receiued into euery part and portion of it a ≈øimple formation, without all mixture, yet ≈øo, that it was formed into foure bodies, e≈ø≈øentially di≈øtingui≈øhed, which are mo≈øt ≈øimple, as hauing nothing in them but one common matter, with foure di≈øtinct formes, immediately created of nothing: hence they are in them≈øelues the greate≈øt oppo≈øits, as fire to water, and ayre to earth. The maine oppo≈øites are fire and water, which ≈øtickle and ≈øtriue together, and are moderated and compounded by the two other. When water would quench the fire, earth ≈øteps in and helpes to abate his moy≈øture. And when fire would dry vp his moy≈øture, ayre ≈øecondeth the water, and prepares a radicall moy≈øture to feed the fire a little longer. When the coldne≈ø≈øe of water takes off the edge of heat, then ayre with his mild heat helpeth his fellow. And when fire over-ma≈øters the coldne≈ø≈øe of water, then earth checks him, and abates his fury, whence ari≈øeth all elementaries, receiuing the common matter, and formes of the elements, much abated and moderated, after their ≈øtriuing and ≈øtrugling
together, and therefore are not ≈øo vehemently oppo≈øite and contrary in them≈øelues. Gen. 1.3. Let there bee light, which was the fir≈øt ≈øimple forme that was put into the common matter, ver. 6. Let there be an expan≈øe, or ≈øpreading, which was next added to light, as his fitte≈øt neighbour, ver. 9. Let there be gatherings, or waters, which contained the third ≈øimple forme, & came as next fellow to the ayre; for ≈øo God had appointed, that by placing it betweene two great adver≈øaries, it might be a friend to both. ver. 9. Let the dry appeare, which comes lowe≈øt in ranke, and gaue the matter the fourth ≈øimple forme. Thus heat and cold, moy≈øture and drine≈ø≈øe, did runne through the fir≈øt common matter, which intertaines them all, and giues them leaue to diffu≈øe them≈øelues one into another, for further mixture and compo≈øition.
Q. But may the≈øe things be handled in Divinitie?

A. Yes, becau≈øe, wee ≈øo farre ≈øpeake of them as they concerne creation, which is proper to this Art. And our rule is this, that where Creation endeth, nature beginneth; and generation ≈øucceeds it, as in imitation of Gods fir≈øt compo≈øition. God by his omnipotent hand giues to euery thing his being, and then ≈øets it a worke, by his owne nature and vertue. Ari≈øtotle knew a fir≈øt matter, but he confe≈ø≈øeth, he had it from Plato, and he from the Aegyptians, and they from Mo≈øes. Yet he erred in many things, for want of Divinitie, beginning onely with nature, where creation had ended his worke. Fir≈øt, he was ignorant that the fir≈øt matter was of nothing. Secondly, that it ≈øtood certaine houres without a forme. Thirdly, that all the formes it receiued were immediately of nothing. Fourthly, that all this was done in time, and that there was nothing in the world eternall, but the maker of it. Gen. 1.1.2. The earth was a ≈øubiect of contrary formes, and therefore preexi≈øtent.
Q. What is that fir≈øt matter of all incon≈øtant things?
A. It was a thing which God made of nothing in the beginning of the fir≈øt day, without forme and voyd, and ≈øo by his ≈øpirit miraculou≈øly ≈øu≈øtained it for a certaine ≈øpace. Gen. 1.1.2.
Q. What followes from hence?

A. That of it ≈øelfe it is permanent, for being immediately of nothing, it hath no power to worke vpon it, but the ≈øame that made it, therefore God alone can turne it into nothing, from whence he brought it, and this is the rea≈øon why the fir≈øt matter, and foure fir≈øt formes are not re≈øolved, though all things may be re≈øolved into them. For in generation and corruption, as they begin here to take new formes, ≈øo here they leaue them againe. And death, though a privation of life, yet it hath no power to annihilate his contrary, and therefore, as nature begins where creation ends, ≈øo creation at the la≈øt day will begin againe where nature hath ended. I meane, in our re≈øurrection, euery man receiuing againe tho≈øe very peeces of the elements whereof he was made. Iob. 19.27. 2. Cor. 15.35.36.37.38. &c. the very ≈øeed that is ≈øowne, dieth and ri≈øeth againe, out of tho≈øe very elements into which nature re≈øolueth it, ≈øpringeth it againe.
Q. When was it made?

A. In the fir≈øt beginning of time, or the evening of the fir≈øt day, hence it is co-etaneall, and of the ≈øame time and age with the third heaven, and the Angels. Gen. 1.1. And the rea≈øon was, to hinder a vacuitie in the large ≈øpace and compa≈ø≈øe of that highe≈øt heaven. The parts whereof would ≈øooner haue fallen together, then haue admitted nothing to ≈øtand within their circle. For nothing, and evill, are cou≈øin germans, and equally oppo≈øed to the being of any thing, rather would perfection haue imperfection his next neighbour, if ≈øo be, it haue a being from God, then to permit nothing to lodge in his bo≈øome. And therefore what a degenerate thing is man, to admit evill for his be≈øt companion?
Q. How long was this matter voyd, and without forme?

A. All the time that darkne≈ø≈øe was vpon the face of it: Now the vici≈ø≈øitude of light and darkne≈ø≈øe makes the day and night, which as it is mo≈øt probable, were then Equinoctiall, of an equall length and ≈øize; that is, twelue houres a peece.
So then the earth, or fir≈øt matter ≈øtood in that imperfection, a whole night, or twelue houres. Gen. 1.1.2.5. involved in nothing but palpable darkene≈ø≈øe.
Q. How was it pre≈øerued all that time?
A. By the Spirit that moued vpon it, and which in ≈øtead of a forme, did cheri≈øh and fo≈øter it all that time. Gen. 1.2.
Q. What kind of creature may we tearme it to be?
A. Some-thing potentially, nothing actually. It was all things, and nothing. A matter for all, yet nothing in forme. It is called earth, and water. Gen. 1.1.2. And ≈øo it was fire and ayre, &c.
Q. What be the kinds of elements?

A. The higher and hotter which make one globe, or the lower and colder which make another. So that all the world is folded vp in three ≈øeverall globes, one comprehending another. The divine globe of the third heaven, in which God is ≈øaid to ≈øit. P≈øal. 2.4. as a place of ble≈ø≈øed re≈øt. The ≈øecond is the etheriall, or skie globe, containing tho≈øe glorious lampes, and burning torches, by who≈øe light and brightne≈ø≈øe all this inferior world is comforted; and vpon this heaven the Lord is ≈øaid to ride. P≈øal. 68.4. in regard of his ≈øwift motion and expedite manner of working. The third and inferior globe, which is but as a point to the re≈øt, is the earthie and watery ≈øphere, and the Lord is ≈øaid to ≈øit vpon the very circle of it. I≈øa. 40.22. And to ≈øhake the wicked out of it, as it were, by a canva≈øe, or as a man tumbles a thing out of his lap. Iob 38.13. Thus is God in all the globes of the world, no where included, no where excluded, he is in their circles, and vpon their circles, di≈ø-po≈øing all things as he plea≈øeth.
Q. What are the higher and hotter elements?

A. Whereby they were made with formes, more actiue and ≈øtirring; and therefore hotter and higher then the re≈øt. Hence in regard of levitie and gravitie, heaven is ≈øaid to be aboue, and earth below. Exod. 20.4. Much matter and little forme makes creatures waightie; whereupon wee ≈øee in our ≈øelues, that man-hood con≈øi≈øts not in the bulke of
the bones, but in the mettall, and ≈øpirits. So that wee may truely ≈øay, that the elements aboue, are formall, and they below materiall.
Q. What are the kinds of the more formall elements?

A. The fire, and the ayre, ≈øtiled by the holy Gho≈øt, light and expan≈øe, or (as it is called) Firmament. Gen. 1.3.6. God naming them by that which is mo≈øt ≈øen≈øible to vs, and in them mo≈øt proper, as light is to fire, exten≈øion and expan≈øion to the ayre. For ayre by rea≈øon of his moy≈øture doth more dilate, and diffu≈øe it ≈øelfe, then fire, though that be the thinner, and more ≈øubtile ≈øub≈øtance.
Q. What is the Creation of the Fire?

A. Whereby God made it in the top and highe≈øt part of the fir≈øt matter, with the mo≈øt actiue and working forme, ≈øo that it is mo≈øt hot and light; therefore in the highe≈øt roome, and becau≈øe of his ≈øhining, is called, Photi≈øticos. With ≈øuch violence is the fire deiected, that it ≈øtrikes into the bowels of the earth, and bottome of the Sea; as may well appeare by the generation of ≈øtones and fi≈øhes. Metalls, which are ingendered in the earth, ≈øhew that fire hath beene there, otherwi≈øe ≈øhould we never haue gold ≈øo purely purified, & concocted. Hence Phylo≈øophers attribute the engendring of gold to the Sunne; of ≈øilver, to Iupiter, lead, to the Moon, copper to Mars, &c. Likewi≈øe pretious ≈øtones could not be ≈øo re≈øplendent and glorious, if it were not for the worke of the light, or fire, that penetrates into their ≈øeverall places and veines. Gen. 1.3. Let there be light. Gen. 11.31. Abraham is called from Vr, of the Chaldees. The citie hath fires name, becau≈øe they wor≈øhipped it. Hence wee read [Suidas in Canopo. Ruffin. hi≈øt. eccl. l. 2. c. 26.] that the Chaldaeans challenged all other gods of the god-le≈ø≈øe Heathen, to fight with their God: an Aegyptian encountered, and overcame them thus: He cau≈øed his Canopus to be made full of holes, ≈øtopped with waxe, and filled with water being hollow in the middle. The Chaldaeans put vnder their God Vr, or fire, and the waxe melting, opened a full quiver of watery arrowes, that cooled and quenched their
devouring God, &c. 2 Cor. 4.6. God is ≈øaid to make the light ≈øhine out of darkene≈ø≈øe; that is, after the fir≈øt night hee made it of that matter which was couered with darkene≈ø≈øe.
Q. How did the light de≈øcend from aboue?

A. For three dayes, by the power of God alone, afterwards by the Sunne, Moone, and Starres, which were ≈øet of God in the element of fire. Gen. 1.4. God divided the light from the darkene≈ø≈øe, ver. 14. Let there be lights in the firmament of heaven, to devide the day from the night, &c.
Q. What is the day?

A. If we ≈øpeake truely and properly, it is the time of the Sunnes remaining aboue the Horizon, or vi≈øible part of the world. Some, whom I haue cau≈øe much to re≈øpect and reuerence, haue held opinion, that light naturally a≈øcendeth, and violently de≈øcendeth by a kinde of repercu≈ø≈øion made by the Sunnes body and motion, then accordingly haue defined the day to be the time wherein the light is turned downeward, or reflected vpon the lower parts of the world, and ≈øo by conden≈øation ≈øhineth. But others vpon more mature con≈øideration, iudge that a new devi≈øed way. For, fir≈øt, Light in its owne nature cannot be ≈øaid to a≈øcend or de≈øcend onely, but transfu≈øeth it ≈øelfe equally & ≈øpherically in all dimen≈øions from its owne center. Secondly, if the ≈øhining of the Sunne be nothing el≈øe but the beating backward of the a≈øcending beames of the whole skie, or element of fire, ≈øurely the Moone would alwayes ≈øeeme full, as the Sunne doth, being that this a≈øcending light mu≈øt needs in like maner meere with the thicke body of the Moone, and ≈øuffer repercu≈ø≈øion from it. Thirdly, though light were made vi≈øible in the maner imagined, yet the day cannot properly be defined the time, wherein the light is reflected by the Sunne vpon the lower parts of the world for this is done perpetually and ≈øo wee ≈øhould haue no night.
Q. Who gaue the name thereunto?

A. God him≈øelfe called it Iom, which ≈øignifieth Stirring, becau≈øe be made the day for man to trauaile in. P≈øal. 104.23. When the Sunne ri≈øeth man goeth forth to his worke. Gen. 1.5.
He called the light day by a Trope, putting it for the time wherein it is the cau≈øe of the day.
Q. What is night?

A. If we giue way to evident rea≈øon, and experience, we mu≈øt needs acknowledge the night to be nothing el≈øe, but the ≈øhadow of the earth, that is, the privation of light made by the earths thicke body, intercepting and cutting off the Sunnes beames. They that are of the fore≈øaid opinion, define night to be the time wherein the light returneth vpward, a≈øcending backe againe to the place where God fir≈øt created it: which is as a paradoxe, ≈øo an vndefen≈øible Tenent both for the rea≈øons aboue≈øaid, as al≈øo for that in this de≈øcription, there is no efficient, or materiall cau≈øe implyed, which ≈øhould make the light returne vpward, & a≈øcend backe againe. La≈øtly, there is no re≈øpectiue difference made of the diver≈øe parts of the Globe of the earth. Whereupon, it may be ≈øuppo≈øed, that he that made this definition, did not con≈øider the earth & heauens to be ≈øphericall, and ≈øo to make vici≈ø≈øitude of day and night in the moiety of the earth.

p.hi: How called God the Night?

div.p: A. He called it Lailah, which ≈øignifieth re≈øting, becau≈øe he made the night for man to re≈øt in.
Q. How did God order the≈øe things?
A. He appointed them to keepe their cour≈øe, making a ≈øeparation betweene them, ≈øetting them, as it were, their limites, which they might not pa≈ø≈øe. Gen. 1.4.
Q. What is this ≈øeparation?

A. The ≈øeparation betweene the day and the night is the euening, betweene the night and the day, the morning. Gen. 1.5 Euening ≈øeparates by darkene≈ø≈øe, morning by light. So that the one di≈ø-ioynes the day from the night, and the other the night from the day. Onely the fir≈øt euening ≈øeparated not, becau≈øe the light was then vncreated: yet was it of God appointed even then as apt to ≈øtand betwixt light and darkene≈ø≈øe. And thus from the euening and the morning was the fir≈øt day fini≈øhed, con≈øi≈øting of 24. houres. In the
fir≈øt evening were heaven and earth created: and in the fir≈øt morning, the light, or element of fire. The ob≈øervation of time will keepe vs from that foule confu≈øion about heaven and earth: which are ≈øo frequently expounded of the workes that followed vpon other dayes.
Q. What is the Creation of the ayre.

A. Whereby God made it in the next part of the fir≈øt matter, mo≈øt moy≈øt, and of a diffu≈øiue, or diffluent nature, ≈øpreading abroad, both for impletion and ≈øeparation. P≈øal. 104.2. He ≈øpreadeth the heavens like a curtaine: that is, the ayre, (for he had ≈øpoken of the light before) which is further called a ≈øuperior chamber, very ≈øpatious, and containes (as it were) a beame for the hanging of the clouds. For water is naturally cold, and therefore gathereth it ≈øelfe together in the middle region, and by helpe of the ayre is held vp, which maketh a partition betwixt tho≈øe waters that are congeled aboue, and that are fluide and floating below. Gen. 1.7. for the cloudes hang by vertue of cold, both in the place, and of that which is in vapours, being watery, and a≈øcending by the violence of the Sunne beames redoubled, which when they returne ≈øingle, leaue their vapours behind them, which are held by the place, till the fire & light returning di≈ø≈øolue the bands, and ≈øend them downe againe in raine, or ≈øome ≈øuch like moy≈øt Meteor. Iob 38.31. Can≈øt thou bind the ≈øweete influences of Pleiades? or loo≈øe the bands of Orion. This is nothing but the neat and cold that rules in the ayre, and earth, when the≈øe brumall, or ae≈øtivall ≈øtarres are mo≈øt to be ≈øeene in our haemi≈øphere. Orion is ≈øeene all night in the moneth of December, and ≈øo on, till the Spring, le≈ø≈øe, or more. The Pleiades begin with the Spring, and la≈øt till Autumne, when Acturus takes place. Iob. 9.9. So then as cold bindes vp all in Winter, becau≈øe of the Sunnes ab≈øence: ≈øo heat loo≈øeth againe, when the Sunne returneth in the Spring. And as below, ≈øo aboue, cold knits the clouds, and heat breakes their knots.
Q. How called he it being made?

A. By the name in Hebrew, Shamaijm, which ≈øignifies,
there be waters, ≈øealing thereby the office in deviding betwixt the two waters. Gen. 1.7.8. Hence it comes to pa≈ø≈øe that raine water is farre more fruitful to the earth then any other, becau≈øe it is not di≈ø≈øolved by the light, but it brings downe with it much ayery moy≈øture, which is fatter then leane water; and we ≈øee by experience, that one ≈øhower is better then much watering.
Q. When was it made?

A. In the ≈øecond 24. houres, God taking (as it were) a whole day for that which was equally capable of light and darkene≈ø≈øe. Gen. 1.8. So the euening and the morning were the ≈øecond day, by an equall ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of light and darkene≈ø≈øe. 2. Cor. 4.6. God in the fir≈øt day made light to ≈øhine out of darkene≈ø≈øe, when there was no capable ≈øubiect for the receiuing of it; now he ≈øtayes a whole day of 24. houres, for light and darkene≈ø≈øe to come and goe in a proper ≈øubiect. Oh then how ≈øhould we tru≈øt this God to ≈øhine in our hearts, even when we are mo≈øt vncapable?
Q. What is the creation of the colder elements?

A. Whereby he created them with formes le≈ø≈øe actiue, and therefore colder; the≈øe elements are clogged with more matter then forme, and therefore the action of them is much hindred. I≈øa. 1.2. Heare, O earth, the dulle≈øt of Gods creatures is brought to convince man of di≈øobedience, which ≈øhould be the mo≈øt forward.
Q. What are they?
A. Water and earth. Gen. 1.9. Let the waters be gathered, and let the drie appeare.
Q. What is the Creation of the water?

A. Whereby it was made in the lower part of the fir≈øt matter mo≈øt cold, and moi≈øt. His cold appeares to be greate≈øt by his gathering, and his moy≈øture in this, that it is fluide, and of a ≈øpreading nature, yet much inferior to the ayre, as may appeare by putting our hands into oyle and water, as likewi≈øe by pictures, which hold their colours the longer, for that they are laid in oyle. Now becau≈øe water ≈øooner dries vp then oyle, it is plaine, that ayre which is predominant in
oyle is moy≈øter then water. Gen. 1.9. Let the waters vnder the heaven be gathered together, this is done by the cold of them and therefore no wonder to ≈øee the Seas tumble together.
Q. How is this water devided?
A. Into the waters aboue, and the waters beneath. Gen. 1.6. And it is probable, that both the≈øe waters met together in Noahs flood. Gen. 7.20. with 11.
Q. What meane you by the waters aboue?

A. The clouds, and what≈øoeuer water is aboue in the ayre. Gen. 1.6. P≈øal. 104.3. and 148.4. For as cold gathers them below, ≈øo aboue, &c. and may very well be called Gods botels, as containing all tho≈øe gatherings. Iob 38.37.
Q. What meane you by the waters beneath?

A. The Sea, and all the waters here below. P≈øal. 33.7. Hee gathereth the waters of the Sea together, as vpon an heape, and layeth vp the depths in his trea≈øure. P≈øal. 104.6.7.8.9. Iob 26.12. and 38.8.9.10.
Q. What is the proper place of the water?

A. To be next vnder the ayre, and next aboue the earth: yet their proper place by Gods appointment is to keepe within the earth, as in a ce≈øterne, and that not by a miracle, but by a law of nature; for the word gather, comes of Kavah, and pa≈ø≈øiuely ≈øignfies a confluxe of waters. God therefore bidding the waters caue, did fir≈øt make them a Ce≈øterne in the bowels of the earth, and that was by the a≈øcent of the mountaines, and de≈øcent of the valleyes. P≈øal. 104.8.9. Hither at Gods rebuke they caue and gather them≈øelues, by their coldne≈ø≈øe, which is of a congregating nature. Hence it comes to pa≈ø≈øe, that wee haue the pure≈øt fountaines at footes of hills; and that often out of their ≈øides great ≈øtore of waters haue broken forth, to the de≈øtruction of the inhabitants. Gen. 7.11. At Noahs flood all the fountaines of the great deepe were broken vp: which may very well be vnder≈øtood of the bur≈øting of the mountaines, to let in the waters. Againe, from the Seas come all the ≈øweet Springs that run betweene the mountaines,
and water the valleyes. P≈øal. 104.10.11.12. which as it were, ≈øweating through the bodies of the huge mountaines, are purged of their ≈øaltne≈ø≈øe, and leaue behind them what they had contracted by the continuall working of the Sunne beames, and their owne agitation in to≈ø≈øing too and fro. Againe, for the fluxe and refluxe of the ≈øea, which is nothing but the ri≈øing and falling of it, the one being violent, and the other naturall, is ea≈øily vnder≈øtood by the cau≈øe of both. The fluxe, or tyde is violent, cau≈øed by the Starres, more e≈øpecially the Moone, who≈øe heat being weaker then the Sunne, hath her beames returned with greater oppo≈øition, yet prevailing, as being more actiue then water, gets vp her fumes and vapours, and with them lifts vp the water, and carrying them after her, makes the water follow her, and ≈øo they thru≈øt forward the water that is before them, vntill they be cleane gotten out of the Sea, and then the water fals againe of it owne accord, and the refluxe, or the ebbe is naturall, moy≈øture and coldnes making it runne downeward. Thus the Lord keepes the Seas in a perpetuall motion, lea≈øt by ≈øtanding they ≈øhould corrupt, to the de≈øtruction of the whole earth. It is not altogether to be neglected, which is ≈øaid of Starres, in affecting our bodies, which is not in regard of their owne influences, but their exhalations. For all the Starres worke by the heat they ca≈øt downe, which being nothing el≈øe but the element of fire, cannot of them≈øelues otherwi≈øe hurt, or heale, but according to their temper and degree of heat. As for example, Saturne ≈øends downe a weake heat, and rai≈øeth fumes from pooles of water, and dunghills, and carries them vp into the cold region of the ayre, being able to bring them no higher; and ≈øo they affect the ayre fir≈øt, and then our bodies by it with cold and drine≈ø≈øe, two enemies to life, con≈øi≈øting in heat, and moy≈øture; Ergo, they ≈øay, it is fatall to be borne vnder his regiment; and to ≈øucke, as it were, our fir≈øt breath from him. Hence fabulous Poets faine him eating a child, onely a better Starre, which they call Iupiter, by his heat and breath, as
with a ≈øtone chokes him. This Starre is brighter then the other, and more ≈øolide to ca≈øt downe his beames; hence from him comes a greater heat, and rai≈øeth vp more vapours from Meeres, which are more ≈øweet and plea≈øant, &c. Ergo, to draw our fir≈øt breath vnder ≈øuch a planet they count whole≈øome, and a progno≈øticke of good fortune. Mars, another planet, of a reddi≈øh and fiery nature, turneth downe more ≈øolide heat and fire, and inflames the fumes and vapours it rai≈øeth, and therefore they deeme ≈øuch as draw in the fir≈øt ayre, vnder ≈øuch a con≈øtellation, ≈øhall afterward proue men of a word and a blow, &c. The Sunne being of the greate≈øt ≈øtrength, is able to fetch vp vapours from the bottome of the Sea, and lowe≈øt bowels of the earth, and turne them into the nature of ayre, making them, according to their matter, plea≈øant, or pernicious. As fumes of gold and precious ≈øtones may bee cordiall; of other Mineralls, like deadly damps that Metalli≈øts often meete withall. Venus like Iupiter rai≈øeth vp vapours, which falling in the night, cheri≈øh, and nouri≈øh plants, and ≈øo is ≈øayd to be fruitfull, and the mother of of≈øpring. This I thought good to admoni≈øh all concerning the conceit of Starres, of I know not what influences; when the truth is, they are all but in≈øtruments of ≈øending downe light and fire, and according to their ≈øeverall compo≈øitions and placing in this element, ≈øend downe a greater, or le≈ø≈øer quantitie of heat, the qualitie being all one. Chri≈øt ≈øayes his locks are full of the dew of the night, ≈øhewing that the Moone hath not the ≈øame regiment over the night in regard of heat, that the Sunne hath over the day. And Phy≈øitians teach, that it is dangerous to ≈øleepe with our heads in the Moone-≈øhine, for feare of the moy≈øt di≈øtempers of the braine. And we ≈øee in the lunacie, that the franticke and madde moode followes the ≈øea≈øons of the Moone. So that ≈øome-thing is to be giuen to the Starres, and yet no more then is to be wrought by the naturall qualitie of heat.
Q. What is the Creation of the earth?

A. Whereby he made it in the lowe≈øt part of the fir≈øt matter, mo≈øt dry and cold. It is not the colde≈øt element, though it be mo≈øt remote from the fire; for, in the reflection of the Sunne-beames it is the ≈øtronge≈øt of all other, and therefore it is never the colder for the place of it. The Sunne and Starres warme not naturally in de≈øcent, for heat properly a≈øcends: now in the reflexe of the heat, the earth is mo≈øt capable, and to be made the hotte≈øt. It is therefore mo≈øt dry, and le≈ø≈øe cold then the water; as may appeare by the propertie of gathering. Gen. 1.9. Let the drie appeare.
Q. How called God the earth?

A. Erets; which ≈øignifieth, hardne≈ø≈øe, or to be trampled vpon, ≈øealing thereby the office thereof, which was to ≈øu≈øtaine the creatures that ≈øhould goe thereon. Gen. 1.10. As to be a fit habitation for man, and other creatures. P≈øal. 115 16. It is ≈øaid to haue the Sea for his foundation. P≈øal. 24.2. and 136.6. Yea, to be made out of the water, and to con≈øi≈øt in it. 2. Pet. 3.5. God would haue Iob admire at the laying of this foundation. Iob 38.3.4.5.6. El≈øe where it is ≈øayd to haue no foundation. Iob 26.7. Onely to hang in the mid≈øt of the world by the power of God immoueably. P≈øal. 93.1. and 104.5. I≈øa. 40.12. and 42.5. and 44.19. and 48.13. The truth is, the earth is made of God to re≈øt in his proper place, and hangs not by any miracle, but poy≈øeth it ≈øelfe by his owne waight; yet the a≈øcending of the earth, to make way for the Sea, ≈øeemes to lie vpon the very waters, and to be vpholden by them, and ≈øo appeared by Gods commandement from vnder them, and now to ≈øtand in them.
Q. How called God the waters beneath?

A. Iammim, Seas. Gen. 1.10. becau≈øe there was the collection of many waters, all rivers running into it. Eccl. 1.7. We ≈øee many great rivers, which at the fir≈øt ri≈øing out of ≈øome hills-≈øide, might be covered with a Bu≈øhell; which, after many miles, fill a very broad channell, and drawing neere to the Sea, doe even make a little Sea in their owne bankes. Iam ≈øignifies the we≈øt, becau≈øe the Seas flow from that way, &c.

div.head: CHAPTER XIIII. Of the Elementaries.
div.p: Que≈øtion.

p.hi: VVE haue heard of the elements, what are the elementaries?

div.p: An≈øwere.

Whereby God made them of the≈øe foure elements, by a mixture. Gen. 1.11. Let the earth bring forth, &c. This was impo≈ø≈øible without heat and moy≈øture, therefore other elements were in the compo≈øition, as may appeare by the re≈øolution of plants, out of which water and ≈øpirit is to be di≈øtilled, &c. The my≈øtery of this mixture may thus bee conceiued. Fir≈øt, water being of a running nature, is ≈øtayed by earths drine≈ø≈øe. Secondly, earth being dry in the highe≈øt degree would de≈øtroy waters moy≈øture, being not an≈øwerable to his quality in the ≈øame degree, therefore ayre comes in and takes part with water, to moderate his exce≈ø≈øiue drine≈ø≈øe. Thirdly, the coldne≈ø≈øe of water and earth together would ea≈øily extingui≈øh the heat of the ayre, except fire, the greate≈øt champion ≈øhould ≈øtep in and helpe the ayre again≈øt them both. And tho≈øe all foure being clo≈øed together, fight it out, vntill the quarrell be taken vp by euery one yeelding a little to another, and remitting their forces, vntill they all meete louingly together in the ≈øame elementary compo≈øition, which is as a compound of them all. But you will ≈øay, this is rather Generation then Creation, and therefore a foule confu≈øion to bring it among≈øt divine precepts. I an≈øwere; The action of euery creature is but an imitable gene≈øis, or corre≈øpondent work-man≈øhip to Gods: and therefore in euery thing, the fir≈øt cour≈øe is extraordinary, God ≈øhewing the creature his way of imitation. Therefore all the elementaries were made of God, though hee gaue commandement to the elements to bring them forth.
Q. How devide you the≈øe clementaries?

A. They are either animate, or inanimate, things with life, or without life: God ≈øhewing him≈øelfe by his worke, to be both life and being. Now becau≈øe God proceeds to perfection, let vs fir≈øt ≈øee the more imperfect elementaries.
Q. What are the inanimate elementaries?

A. Whereby they were made out of the elements without parts, that is, a body and a ≈øoule. I confe≈ø≈øe, ≈øome di≈øpute is about Mineralls, which containe in them excellent ≈øpirits, and are found very vivificall in cordialls: but yet this is no proper life, neither will it follow, that they haue a vegetatiue life, becau≈øe they ≈øeeme to grow; for, that is onely by addition of matter, and not a liuely exten≈øion of the ≈øame matter by a ≈øpringing life, increa≈øing to his full perfection, &c.
Q. How are they devided?

A. They are either Meteors, or Mineralls: for ≈øo it comes to pa≈ø≈øe, that the≈øe things which haue onely a body and no ≈øoule, are either of elements well ioyned together, or el≈øe of ≈øuch as hang very loo≈øely together, and are ca≈øily ≈øhaken a≈øunder: the≈øe things are pa≈ø≈øed over in ≈øilence by Mo≈øes, and might well be left out of this Art, ≈øaue onely that God doth wonderfully ≈øet forth his glory, even by the weake≈øt workes, and tho≈øe that are wor≈øt tyed together in their compo≈øition. We will therefore ≈øtay a little in the handling of them; for their knowledge ≈øhall be both plea≈øant and profitable.
Q. What are the Meteors?

A. All luch things as are mixed of the foure elements imperfectly. Gen. 1.6. Of this kinde are the waters aboue. Gen. 2.5. & the raine that de≈øcends from them. P≈øal. 148. Clouds, fire, haile, ≈ønow, winde, and vapours are called vpon to pray≈øe the Lord, becau≈øe he created them. What marvells doe we meete withall in this head of creatures? the clouds, the bottles of raine, ve≈ø≈øels as thin as the liquor which is contained in them: there they hang and moue, though
weightie with their burden. The≈øe the Lord maketh one while as ≈øome ayery Seas to hold water: another while as ≈øome ayery Furnaces, whence he ≈øcattereth his ≈øudden fires vnto all the parts of the earth, a≈øtoni≈øhing the world with the fearefull noyies of the thunders eruption: out of the mid≈øt of the waters aboue he fetcheth fire, and hard ≈øtones. Another while hee makes the clouds as ≈øteele-gla≈ø≈øes, wherein the Sunne lookes and ≈øhewes his face in the varietie of colours which he hath not; there are the ≈øtreames of light, blazing and falling Starres, fires darted vp and downe in many formes, hollow openings, and (as it were) gulfes in the skie; bright circles about the Moone, and other Planets, Snowes, Haile, &c. Here might I di≈øcour≈øe of a world of wonders, to the a≈øtoni≈øhment of the readers: but I mu≈øt remember my Art, which is to ≈øpeake of Creation, and not the generation of things; for as the one belongs to Divinitie, ≈øo the other to naturall Phylo≈øophy. And I take it that Meteors were rather generated of the foure elements, then created: though in all wee are to admire Gods hand, though we cannot ≈øearch out his action. But if God lend life, as I de≈øire fir≈øt to acquaint men more fully with the knowledge of Iehovah-Elohim; ≈øo after with their workes. And Creation, according to Mo≈øes de≈øcription, will yeeld the exacte≈øt and divine≈øt Phylo≈øophie.
Q. What is the perfect mixture?

A. Whereby the bodies of things are more clo≈øely vnited, and produced according to the predominant element, not hanging by violence out of their proper elements, but duely placed of God in their proper places, whereby the fir≈øt matter is filled and adorned. God him≈øelfe ≈øupplying that voyd and vnformed ma≈ø≈øe, with foure formes, and infinite varieties of creatures out of their compo≈øition and mixture. They which lie the lowe≈øt, and doe adorne the bowels of the earth, wee call Mineralls; and they are either Metalls, or Stones, the one hath water predominant in it, the other earth; and they are both precious, and ba≈øe, purer, or impurer. And it is to
be wondered at, that man treading vpon the≈øe Mineralls, ≈øhould not learne to contemne them. They lie furthe≈øt from heaven, and the be≈øt of them are in India, furthe≈øt from the Church. It is (as we haue ≈øaid) that which Midianiti≈øh Camels carry, that Indian ≈ølaues get, that ≈øervile Apprenti≈øes worke, that greedy Iewes ≈øwallow, worldlings admire, and Ruffians ≈øpend: and yet we cannot e≈øteem of it as the meane≈øt of Gods creatures, far inferior to a ≈øpire of gra≈ø≈øe. Adam had them in the fir≈øt Paradi≈øe. Gen. 2.11.12. In the ≈øecond we ≈øhall not need them. Iob 28.1.2.3.5.6. &c. There may you ≈øee how God hath placed them, and how we come by them. And ≈øo ≈øubiect to ≈øinne, as God made a law to haue them purified, before he would haue them v≈øed. Num. 31.22.23. &c. Hence it is abominable of the≈øe things to make Idoll gods. Ezek. 16.17. Ioel. 3.5.
Q. What are the elementaries with life?

A. Whereby they were created of a body and ≈øoule; for life is nothing but the act of the ≈øoule vpon the body: and the ≈øoule, ≈øaue onely the rea≈øonable, is compounded of the foure elements, and is nothing but the Spirits of them, or that which is mo≈øt formall and actiue in them. Hence fire and ayre are mo≈øt predominant in the≈øe ≈øpirits; for, as by extraction we haue the ≈øpirits of things taken from the ma≈ø≈øe and body, by re≈øolution of the compo≈øition: ≈øo, in the compo≈øition, tho≈øe ≈øpirits were as the ≈øoule of that liuing thing. Wine is pre≈ø≈øed from the grape, which is the fruit of a vegetable plant: and becau≈øe it carries away with it the more formall elements, and leaues the gro≈ø≈øer and more materiall behind, wee ≈øay it is generous and full of Spirits: yea, and out of this againe by Art are taken the Spirits of wine, which are very liuely, and of a quickning nature. In all plants, Ayre is mo≈øt formall; and therefore the vegetatiue life con≈øi≈øts mo≈øt in moy≈øture, and the ≈øpirit of it: but in the Sen≈øatiue and Motiue life, fire, and the ≈øpirit thereof is mo≈øt predominant. The≈øe Spirits which are the ≈øoules of Plants, and Bea≈øts, are but the band, or
tye of the rea≈øonable ≈øoule and body: hence death in man is nothing but the extingui≈øhing, or con≈øuming of the≈øe Spirits: for as this cla≈øpe vnloo≈øeth, or knot vntieth: ≈øo body and ≈øoule ≈øeparate a≈øunder. Agues they con≈øume and backe the≈øe Spirits within our bodies, and ≈øo con≈øequently kill vs: colds and watery di≈øtempers doe not ≈øo much wa≈øt as weary and tyre them, and at la≈øt extingui≈øh them as a brand in a puddle of water. Gen. 1.20.21.24.28. &c. we read of life; and Gen. 7.22. wee heare how God extingui≈øhed the ≈øame againe.
Q. What are the kinds?

A. Either ≈øuch as liue a ≈øingle life, or a compound life. Some creatures haue their Spirits, or Soules from ≈øome one element formally, others from more. As for example, all Plants liue mo≈øt by the Spirit and moy≈øture of the ayre: Starres of the fire, men and bea≈øts by both. They grow by the one, haue ≈øen≈øe and motion by the other.
Q. What is this ≈øingle life?
A. Whereby he made ≈øome creatures to line by the formall and act it ‚Ä¢ e Spirits of ≈øome one element.
Q. What are their kinds?

A. Plants and lights, the one with a growing and ≈øpringing life, the other with a ≈øtirring, or mouing life. Gen. 1.11. with 14. The fir≈øt being more imperfect (as ayre is le≈ø≈øe formall then fire) is fir≈øt handled.
Q. What is the Creation of the Plants?

A. Whereby the earth brought them forth with a≈øpringing life onely. Gen. 1.11.12.13. They were compounded of the foure elements, but the earth doth predominate, or beare rule in the body; as ayre doth in the Soule: and euery thing is placed in that element which beares greate≈øt ≈øway in the body, or materiall ≈øub≈øtance of it.
Q. How were they created?

A. According to their kinds, yeelding ≈øeed; both the le≈ø≈øer and greater: the le≈ø≈øer, as gra≈ø≈øe, herbes flowers, & ≈øhrubbes: the greater, fruitfull trees, and the re≈øt without fruit. All which the earth brought forth by the commandement of
God; and as it is the mother and breeder of them: ≈øo is it the Nur≈øe and fo≈øter-mother of them ever after. Gen. 1.14. The act of the ≈øoule in plants, is vegitation: and they haue as it were, a mouth to draw nouri≈øhment, and prepare it for the ≈øtomacke, and a kind of liuer and heart for concoction. Now this facultie to nouri≈øh, hath foure companions to waite on it. Fir≈øt, Attraction, the Spirits drawing a portion to euery part. Secondly, Retention, whereby the part keepes and holds what it hath gotten. Thirdly, Concoction, to dige≈øt and convert what it hath gotten into it ≈øelfe. Fourthly, Expul≈øion, whereby it reiecteth and electeth what≈øoeuer is ≈øuperfluous. Now the ≈øeed is an excrement of the la≈øt concoction, and therefore is from the a≈ø≈øimulation of the nouri≈øhment, which makes it like euery part. Hence from ≈øimular parts, it begets ≈øimular parts; and out of ≈øo little a part being full of Spirits, are begotten all other creatures. In ≈øeed and food con≈øi≈øts all vegitable life, and a hurt in either is dangerous, and often deadly. From nutrition proceed augmentation and generation; the one for exten≈øion of the ≈øame thing, the other, for pre≈øervation of it in others. Extention is by heat, hence females are le≈ø≈øe then males, becau≈øe their heat is le≈ø≈øe, though often they haue more moy≈øture. Generation, is by ≈øeed, which receiues from plants, and all other things, the ≈øoule and ≈øub≈øtance of euery part. Hence is it able to giue the kind that yeelds it. And therefore the Lord ≈øayes euery Plant yeelding ≈øeed after his kind. Gen. 1.12. Teaching vs thereby, that the ≈øeed vertually, and potentially, an≈øweres the creature in euery part and member of it?
Q. When were the≈øe made?

A. The ≈øame day wherein the waters and earth were created. Gen. 1.13. And ≈øo by ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of an evening and morning, was there a third day, or 24. houres. In creation of the elements, God began in the top of the matter: but in the elementaries he began in the bottome, fir≈øt creating the Mineralls, and then the Plants. For God is a God of order and ≈øo pa≈ø≈øeth on in his worke from imperfection to perfection,
I meane, where there is a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of parts, otherwi≈øe God begins with the be≈øt fir≈øt. For the Lord did not in the vniver≈øe, as men doe in building, rake fir≈øt in the earth to lay the foundation, and adde the roofe la≈øt: but he fir≈øt laid on the roofe, and la≈øt of all came to the foundation. Fir≈øt heaven, then fire, next ayre, and la≈øt of all water and earth. Yet being the God of Art, followed an exact methode in all; for being come to the earth, hee fir≈øt makes things ≈øpring, then moue, after ≈øpring moue and walke by ≈øen≈øe. La≈øtly, as an Epitome of all the re≈øt he comes to man, which growes, moues, walkes, and aboue all the re≈øt, liues by rea≈øon.
Q. What is the Creation of the lights?

A. Whereby he made them in the element of fire, with a motiue life to runne round, carrying the ≈øame ≈øide ≈øtill forward, that they may bring light vpon the earth, and ≈øeparate betweene day and night, and be for fignes and ≈øea≈øons, dayes and yeeres. Gen. 1.14.15. Iob 38.31.32.33. P≈øal. 8.2.4. P≈øal. 19.2.3.4.5.6.7. and 136.7.8.9. Ier. 31.35. Amos. 5.8. &c. Fal≈øe and fabulous Phylo≈øophie makes this doctrine a wonder, and they that bring Mo≈øes to Ari≈øtotle, laugh at this le≈ø≈øon. Starres to liue is again≈øt rea≈øon, for they are not nouri≈øhed, neither doe they increa≈øe or generate, &c. I may reply againe vpon Divines from Mo≈øes, by a probable argument they were created after liuing things, therefore they haue life, &c. Ari≈øtotles obiection is ea≈øily an≈øwered. Life con≈øi≈øting in the moy≈øture of ayre is to be nouri≈øhed; not in the ≈øpirit of fire. Animall ≈øpirits if they were not generated of the vitall, and daily re≈øtored by them, they might liue by their fiery nature, as well as ≈øtarres. Let this then be granted, that all elementarie ≈øoules, are either the formall ≈øpirits of the ayre, or fire: and then ≈øtarres hauing the one and not the other, may liue without nouri≈øhment. The influences of the Starres are as vitall as the animall ≈øpirits in man, and both comfort and beget life, &c. Againe, their motion ≈øhewes they liue, for nothing is moued from place to place without it. If God and Mo≈øes may be heard, Phylo≈øophers
≈øhall ea≈øily haue their mouthes ≈øtopped. Scripture euery where te≈øtifieth of the motion of the Starres. Which mu≈øt either be by coun≈øell, or nature, or violence, or fortune. Not by coun≈øell, for their motion is regular, and alwayes the ≈øame, and this were ≈øufficient to proue the cau≈øe next vnder God to be naturall. But the opinion is, they are moued by the externall force of Angels, as a wheele by a dog, or a Crane by walking men. I reade indeed, that the Angels are mini≈øtring ≈øpirits for the good of the elect; but no where in Gods booke, that they turne the wheeles of heaven. And againe, the light being common to good and bad, the good Angels ≈øhould mini≈øter daily, as well for reprobates as Gods elect. But to ≈øtill all cackling in this cau≈øe, let the Text cleare it ≈øelfe. Gen. 1.14.15.16.17.18. That which God ≈øaw to be good, an≈øwers Gods intention in his motion to his end. Therefore the Starres had ≈øo much by their creation, that they were able to devide, giue light, rule dayes and nights, the which they were vnable to doe without motion; God therefore gaue them a power to moue, that they might obtaine the≈øe ends; which if they ≈øhould a≈ø≈øume from any other then God, would argue the imperfection of his owne worke. It may well be thought they receiue this life in their centers, as other things doe in the circumference. For being round, heat and ≈øpirit will mo≈øt vnite them≈øelues within, as in a ≈øilver ≈øpoone, turne the hollow ≈øide to the fire, and it will be very hot. But in plaine bodies heat is receiued in a cleane contrary fa≈øhion, as in Andyrons, where they be round, are very cold, but where they be plaine, they be very hot, and will burne ≈øoone. Starres therefore are round like globes, that heat may the better center in them, and make them the more actiue and liuely in their motion. Why they ≈øhould neither a≈øcend, nor de≈øcend, is their equall temper with the place where they ≈øtay, Why they moue round, is the actiue ≈øpirit and ≈øoule that will not ≈øuffer them to re≈øt. It is ≈øaid of the Sunne. P≈øal. 19.4.5.6. that God hath ≈øet him a tabernacle, or proper place, out of
which he cannot goe, and yet he comes out of the chambers thereof, and in the ≈øtrength of his motiue ≈øpirit, reioyceth to runne his race; not tumble it as ≈øome dreame: for running a bre≈øt in the fire, hee pu≈øheth and ≈øhoueth it from him, that nothing can be hid from his heat & light. His circuit is from one end of heaven to another, and by his quicke di≈øpatch, euery day either drawes a little nearer, or goes a little farther off: not that at any time he comes nearer the earth: but by fleeting a little his chambers, he comes ≈øometime in the yeere to dwell more directly over our heads then other. He devids night and day euery 24. houres with vs, and by running from one point to another the whole yeere. And it is as naturall to the Sunne to runne a circuit euery day, as another in a whole yeere: not that he is pulled contrary wayes by two diver≈øe orbes: but that which he doth euery day in part, that hee doth wholly and completely in a yeare. Now the part and the whole may agree in the ≈øame motion; and euery dayes race is but a part of the whole yeeres cour≈øe, which the Sunne may as truely keepe in the whole, as in the parts, and that without all contrary motions. But ≈øeeing euery man will fancie his owne fiction, I leaue this without all further pro≈øecution.
Q. How many ≈øort of Starres haue we?

A. Two; The greater and the le≈ø≈øer: not for quantitie of bodie, but qualitie of light: for the originall word Meoroth, is Makers of light, Luminaries, ≈øhiners. And ≈øo the Sunne and Moone are greate≈øt, as giuing to the earth the greate≈øt quantitie of light. How great the Starres are is a coniecture and gue≈ø≈øe at the iu≈øt proportion of any one: yet they are very bigge, and it is evident that the Sunne is bigger then the earth, by the Eclip≈øes, and becau≈øe it enlightneth more then halfe the earth at once. Gen. 1.16.
Q. What are the greater?
A. The Sunne and the Moone. The≈øe two ca≈øt downe the greate≈øt light vpon the face of the earth. Gene≈øis 1.16. P≈øal. 104.19.
Q. What is the Creation of the Sunne?

A. Whereby he made it to rule the day, &c. And it is called the greater light, becau≈øe it darkens all Starres by his ≈øhining: yea, and ca≈øts light in the face of them all: hence the Moone which hath ≈øuch a changeable light, receiues her ≈øplendor from the Sunne, according to that face which is oppo≈øite to the body of the Sunne, for the one halfe of it is ever illuminated and illu≈øtrated by the ≈øame, and in receiuing and ca≈øting downe that light ≈øeemes to haue ≈øpots in her face. Gen. 1.16. P≈øal. 19.5.6.
Q What is the creation of the Moone?
A. Whereby it was made to rule the night. Gen. 1.16. Yet ≈øhee hath the a≈ø≈øi≈øtence of the Starres; for her ≈øelfe is often ab≈øent in the night.
Q. What are the le≈ø≈øer lights?

A. The Starres. Gen. 1.16. The≈øe carry downe a le≈ø≈øer quantitie of light: yet if it were not for them, our nights would be palpable darkene≈ø≈øe, which is the greate≈øt enemy to the eye; for, it is a comfortable thing to ≈øee the light. Eccl. 11.7.
Q. When were all the≈øe made?
A. In the fourth day, euening and morning ≈øucceeding as before in the compa≈ø≈øe of 24. houres. Gen. 1.19.
Q. What is the creation of things with a compound life?

A. Whereby they were made not onely with a growing and mouing life; but al≈øo with ≈øen≈øe, externall and internall, the one ≈øerving as gla≈ø≈øe windowes for the other. The fir≈øt ≈øen≈øe which is mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary, is our feeling, and is di≈øper≈øed through the whole body, excepting the bones and ≈øinewes. Bones are the ≈øu≈øtentacles of our bodies, and therefore would be painfull to vs, if they were tender of feeling. The ≈øinewes they are the organs and in≈øtruments, and carry in them the ≈øen≈øitiue ≈øpirits; and man is mo≈øt tickli≈øh where his skin is thinne≈øt. With the tips of the fingers, Phy≈øitians feele their patients, as being mo≈øt ≈øen≈øible of the pul≈øes motion. The tangible obiects are heat, cold, drought and moy≈øture principally: ≈øecondarily, the qualities that hence
ari≈øe. Ta≈øt is next, which is a kind of feeling, for both mu≈øt haue their obiects pre≈øent. Now it is made by the pa≈ø≈øing down of the ≈øen≈øitiue ≈øpirit from the brain to the tongue, &c. Sight is made by conveiance of ≈øen≈øitiue ≈øpirits to the eyes, where they are met with the light without that fir≈øt comes to the watery humor, which is as lead to a looking gla≈ø≈øe, that ≈øtayes the light, then it comes to the gla≈ø≈øie humor, and there is gathered together, then it comes to the cry≈øtaline, or cleare≈øt humor, and is carried vp vnto the braine, by the ≈øen≈øitiue ≈øpirit that meetes it. Hence Hippocrates ≈øaies, that the≈øe ≈øen≈øitiue Spirits are a drie brightne≈ø≈øe, and that is, becau≈øe fire is here predominant, as wee may ≈øee by a blow vpon the eye, the Spirits redoubled, are made vi≈øible as fire. Tho≈øe that haue the brighte≈øt eyes, as Catts, &c. ≈øee better in darkene≈ø≈øe then other creatures, and wor≈øe in the light; becau≈øe the greater light darkens the le≈ø≈øer. Hearing is a fourth ≈øen≈øe, and meets with the noy≈øe in the eares, there it centers: for noy≈øe is made by a circle in the ayre, not much vnlike vnto that which wee ≈øee in the water when wee ca≈øt a ≈øtone into it. Hence it comes to pa≈ø≈øe as many as ≈øtand within the circle or circumference of the ≈øound made in the ayre, heare it; and the rea≈øon is, becau≈øe any point or center within the circle of the ≈øound, is potentially in euery part of it, & one point is enough to bring it to our eares: yet we cannot ≈øee ≈øo; for, when we but looke at a thing that is round, wee cannot ≈øee it all at once. But I mu≈øt not play the Phylo≈øopher too much; it is my de≈øire, that God for his workes may haue the due glory. Smelling is the la≈øt ≈øen≈øe, and ≈øerues wonderfully to refre≈øh the braine. The inward ≈øen≈øes that looke through the≈øe outward, are fancie, cogitation, and memory: and they are a little re≈øemblance of rea≈øon, which comes in the la≈øt place.
