For fancie hath in it a kind of invention, cogitation of iudgement, and memory of methode. And this is the ≈øen≈øatiue life, wherein God ≈øhewes his owne act more eminently.
Q. How many ≈øorts of creatures liue by ≈øen≈øe?

A. Two; either ≈øuch as liue by it onely, or haue be≈øide all the≈øe a rea≈øonable life. This onely pa≈ø≈øeth Elements both formall and materiall, yet the fine≈øt Spirits ≈øerue to knit it with the re≈øt, and ≈øo wee handle that life among≈øt Elementaries, otherwi≈øe it is angelicall, and purely of nothing by the power of the Creator.
Q. How many kinds haue we of the fir≈øt life?
A. Either fi≈øhes and foules, or bea≈øts. All which were made according to their kinds, and were mightily to increa≈øe, through Gods ble≈ø≈øing, and to fill their places with daily of-≈øpring.
Q. What is the creation of the fi≈øhes?
A. Whereby the Lord cau≈øed the waters to bring them forth in abundance, wherein al≈øo they increa≈øe and multiplie, and repleni≈øh the waters. Gen. 1.20.21.22. Iob 40.20. & 41.1.
Q. What is the creation of the fowles?
A. Whereby he made them to flie in the ayre, and to multiplie vpon the earth. Gen. 1.20.
Q. When were the fi≈øh and fowle made?

A. In the ≈øift day, or 24. houres. Gen, 1.23. The≈øe were more imperfect then the bea≈øts of the field, and therefore conclude a dayes worke by them≈øelues, God willing vs to take notice, how exact he was in a≈øcending vp to mans perfection.
Q. What is the creation of the bea≈øts?

A. Whereby he cau≈øed the earth to bring them forth after their kinds; and they are either walkers, or creepers: walkers, cattell and bea≈øts, that is, wild and tame creatures. Gen. 1.24.25. Thus God formed and filled that fir≈øt matter, and prepared it as an habitation for man: who though hee came naked out of the wombe of the earth, was even then ≈øo rich, that all things were his, heaven was his roofe, earth his floare, the Sea his pond, the Sunne & Moone his torches, all creatures his va≈ø≈øalls. They that looke into ≈øome great Pond, may ≈øee the bankes full, though they ≈øee not the ≈øeverall
≈øprings whence the water ri≈øeth: ≈øo wee may eye the world, but can never come to ≈øee the excellencie of it, much more of the maker him≈øelfe. Kings erect not cottages, but ≈øet forth their magnificence in ≈øumptuous buildings: ≈øo God hath made a world, to ≈øhew his admirable glory. And if the lowe≈øt pauement of that third heaven be ≈øo glorious, what ≈øhall wee finde within? Who would thinke, that all the≈øe ≈øhould be made for one, and that one, well-neere the lea≈øt of all? Sure I am, the la≈øt: with him therefore, let vs conclude this worke of Creation.

div.p: Question.

p.hi: VVHat is the creation of things with a rea≈øonable life?

div.p: An≈øwere.

Whereby he made them of a body and ≈øoule immortall. Gen. 1.26. Other creatures were made by a ≈øimple command; Man not without a divine con≈øultation: Others at once; Man he did fir≈øt forme, then in≈øpire: others in ≈øeverall ≈øhapes, like to none but them≈øelues; Man after his owne image: others with qualities fit for ≈øeruice; Man for dominion. His bodie and ≈øoule are both immortall; for, death is an enemie. 1. Cor. 15.26. And therefore no con≈øequent of nature, but a companion of ≈øinne: yet this is true, that euery elementary is corruptible, and re≈øoluble; and ≈øo is the body of man, being taken out of the du≈øt: but as it was made a companion of an immortall ≈øoule, immediately made of nothing, ≈øo is it fit, that it ≈øhould be aboue its own nature elevated, to be one, though not per vim contactus, yet per vnionem per≈øonae, immortall and eternall. Almighty God after he had drawne the large, and reall map of the world, abridged it into this little table of Man, as Dioptron
Microco≈ømicum, which alone con≈øi≈øts of heaven and earth, ≈øoule and body. In his ≈øoule is the nature of Angels, though not ≈øo exten≈øiue and actiue, as wee may ≈øee in a little and great man, &c. In his bodie are the foure elements, the Meteors and Mineralls, as may appeare both by vapours and fumes, and ≈øpirits. He liues the life of a Plant, he hath the ≈øen≈øes of bea≈øts; and aboue all, the addition of rea≈øon. His body is more exqui≈øitely made then any other, as may appeare by the nakedne≈ø≈øe of it. For others that are clothed with feathers, and haires, &c. ≈øhew that they are fuller of excrements. The Lord brought him vpon the ≈øtage fully prepared, that he might be both an actor and a ≈øpectator. He had a body, with hands for action, and an head for contemplation.
Q. How did God create him?

A. In his owne likene≈ø≈øe and image. Gen. 1.26. Colo≈ø. 3.10. And it is ≈øo called, becau≈øe man was furni≈øhed in euery point, to re≈øemble the wi≈øedome, holine≈ø≈øe, and righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe of God, not onely in this frame and perfection of body and ≈øoule, but al≈øo by his actions, and government of the creatures: and this was naturall vnto man. The Papi≈øts thinke, that this image was ≈øupernaturall; but vntruely, ≈øeeing it was of his created perfection, hauing the greate≈øt excellencies of all things here below. For an image is a ≈øpeciall kinde of ≈øimilitude, and ≈øo man after a more ≈øpeciall ≈øort, then all other creatures, re≈øembles the maie≈øtie of his Creator, even (as it were) a ≈øtature, or image of him: yet mu≈øt we take heed of the error of the Authropomorphoi and Papi≈øts, who metamorphize God into the ≈øhape of a Man, old and auncient. For the likene≈ø≈øe ≈øtands not in hauing a body and ≈øoule, but in the hability of both to worke an≈øwerably to the righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe and holine≈ø≈øe of God. And image, be≈øide ≈øimilitude, which is the generall, containes two things more, expre≈ø≈øion, and repre≈øentation. Fir≈øt it mu≈øt either be expre≈ø≈øed by another thing, or el≈øe exemplarily formed to ≈øuch a patterne and pattent, and as it were, the very copie and countenance of it. Hence one

And in Plinie, Diglath, or Diglito, another arme, is the ≈øame with Hiddekel, both ≈øignifying the ≈øame thing, viz. an arrow for the ≈øwiftne≈ø≈øe of the water; and this is the ≈øame with Tigris, now called Tegil. So that by all this, it is mo≈øt probable, that the Garden did lie betwixt Euphrates and Tigris. Furthermore, Plinie writes, that (as it were) a fi≈øh-pond, or Mar≈øh, in compa≈ø≈øe about an Acre of ground, burnes continually, which may not without probability be thought to be≈øome remembrance of that flaming ≈øword, which turned euery way to keepe man from the tree of life. Gen. 3.24. God in iu≈øt judgement, turning the place into a≈øhes, & a burning poole, as he afterwards did Sodome, another Eden of the world. By this appeares the folly of Papi≈øts, that thought this Garden was not drowned in the flood, and that Enoch and Elias liue in it, &c. Oh happy man, if hee had but knowne his owne happine≈ø≈øe, when he fir≈øt opened his eyes, he ≈øaw haven aboue him, and a flouri≈øhing earth vnder him, and him≈øelfe placed in the very Paradi≈øe and Palace of the world. But this is cleane wa≈øhed away, and over turned in the iu≈øt judgement of God. Yet read the excellent de≈øcription of it and let the lo≈ø≈øe of it provoke vs to ≈øeeke after a better. Gen. 2.8.9.10.11.12.13.14.
Q. Why did God thus place man in a Garden?

A. That man being appointed of God, as Lord deputie vnder him, might there ≈øerue him more freely, keepe his Court, haue nece≈ø≈øary imployment, both in dre≈ø≈øing and keeping the Garden. Gen. 2.15. It was one of Adams faults, to ≈øuffer the ≈øerpent to come into it. Another, to forget his dutie to God; for, the very trees did not onely affoord him worke for his hands, but in≈øtruction for his heart. There he ≈øaw two Sacraments in the very mid≈øt of the re≈øt of the trees, grow before him as mo≈øt eminent teachers of him. Gen. 2.9. The greater ≈øhame to offend God, who had ≈øo hedged him in on all ≈øides, that by a word of his mouth he might haue
rebuked the Serpent, and by the lea≈øt ca≈øt of his eye beene confirmed in dutie and diligence. But ble≈ø≈øed be God that we haue a better tree of life before our eyes; not a tree for triall, but for confirmation of being happie, in de≈øpight of Satan, of which we may eate and liue.
Q. Of what kinds was man created?

A. Male, and female. Gen. 1.27. The Male immediately for his body of the foure Elements. Gen. 2.7. The female for her body of one of his ribs, man being ca≈øt into a deepe ≈øleepe. Gen. 2.21. Man had better loo≈øe a peece of him≈øelfe, then mi≈ø≈øe a good wife. Yet the Lord would not paine him in ≈øending him a meete helper; as for their Soules they were equally in≈øpired, that they might both be partakers of the ≈øame happine≈ø≈øe. Gen. 1.27. For the image they were both equall.
Q. Why did God make her?

A. God ≈øaw that it was not good for man to be alone, and among the re≈øt of the creatures, there was none fit to be his companion. Gen. 2.18.20. That there might therefore be wanting to him no comfortable thing, God thought it needfull, that he ≈øhould haue ≈øuch an helper as might ≈øatisfie his de≈øires, and giue him by his divine benediction, a fruitfull of≈øpring. Gen. 1.28. Mal. 2.15. All that man ≈øaw immediately after his creation, were fit to be his ≈øervants, none his companions; and the ≈øame God that found the want ≈øupplies it. Rather then man ≈øhall want a comfort, God will begin a new creation, not out of the earth, mans fir≈øt matter, or out of other creatures, his ≈øervants: but out of him≈øelfe for dearne≈ø≈øe, for equalitie, and that neither of the head nor foote, but the ≈øide, ≈øhewing her place, which is to ≈øtand next to her husband, neither as his drudge in being ba≈øely governed, nor as his wanton in crowing over him. Furthermore, God con≈øults not with man to make him happie. As he was ignorant while him≈øelfe was made, ≈øo ≈øhall he not know while a ≈øecond ≈øelfe is made out of him. Both that the comfort might be greater then was expected, as al≈øo, that he might not vpbraid his wife with any great
dependance, or obligation, he neither willing the worke, nor ≈øuffering any paine to haue it done. The rib can challenge no more of her, then the earth can of him. They are both made equall debters to God, who alone tooke care, that they might both be happie in him, and by him.
Q. What did God with her being made?

A. He brought her to man, and ioyned her in marriage with him, who acknowledgeth her to be fle≈øh of his fle≈øh, and bone of his bone; This ≈øheweth how exqui≈øite knowledge he had from God. If God had giuen him her name, or the names of other creatures, it had not beene ≈øo great a pray≈øe of Adams memory to recall them, as it was now of his judgement (at fir≈øt ≈øight) to impo≈øe them. Gen. 2.23. Shee ≈øhall be called Woman, becau≈øe ≈øhe was taken out of Man. So piercing was the eye of his rea≈øon, that he ≈øaw the in≈øide of all the creatures at fir≈øt blu≈øh, and by his perfect knowledge, he fitted their names to their di≈øpo≈øitions; whereas we ≈øilly ≈øolves, his ignorant po≈øteritie, ≈øee but their skins ever ≈øince, and forget their very names, when we are told them. Furthermore, he receiued her thankefully to be his wife, and e≈øtabli≈øhed that law of matrimony concerning co-habitation, Therefore ≈øhall man leaue his father and mother, and cleane to his wife, and they ≈øhall be one fle≈øh. Gen. 2.22.23.24.
Q. How were man and woman perfect, whiles they were both naked?

A. They then needed no clothing, for yet there was nothing whereof they needed to be a≈øhamed, nor any externall thing wherby they might be anoyed, which are the proper ends of apparell. viz. to hide our ≈øhame, and defend vs from externall danger of weather, and weakne≈ø≈øe. Gen. 2.25.
Q. When were they created?

A. Together with the bea≈øts on the ≈øixt day. Gen. 1.31. Thus God leaues them to their con≈øcionable obedience, the only way to entaile a comfortable pro≈øperitie vpon them≈øelues, and their ≈øeed after them, if their ≈øinnes ≈øtrip them not of all their hopes.

div.head: CHAPTER XVI. Of Gods Providence.
div.p: Que≈øtion.

p.hi: HItherto of the Creation; What is Gods Providence?

div.p: An≈øwere.

It is that part of Gods efficiencie, whereby he provideth for all his creatures, even to the lea≈øt circum≈øtance, that haue his being. P≈øal. 104.24. with 27. As he hath made them in excellent wi≈øedome, ≈øo in the ≈øame wi≈øedome he provides for them. Providence is not to over-≈øee, or ouer-looke his workes, but to worke, and haue an efficiencie in all things. Permi≈ø≈øion, to the creature, is not a ce≈ø≈øation to the Creator: but the Lord workes his owne will by euery permi≈ø≈øion. Providence is to minde the creature, God never forgetting the workes of his owne hands. Hence God may be ≈øaid to be the ≈øoule of the world, not informing it e≈ø≈øentially as a peece of any creature, but by his efficiencie in euery thing. Math. 10.29.30. Luke. 12.6.7. That which Mathew ≈øpeakes of the falling of a Sparrow, Luke interprets by not forgetting. In regard of Providence all things are done by rea≈øon, not of the creatures, for thereof they are ignorant, therefore by God. The falling of a Sparrow is a propo≈øition, and that is made of arguments, which are cau≈øe and effect, all which is rea≈øon, not of the Sparrow, nor of men & Angels, for they onely analy≈øe it, by ≈øeeing it done; therefore of God alone who makes that rea≈øon to hang together, in the very fall of a Sparrow, or hayre of our heads. And here come many errors to be touched. Fir≈øt, the error of nece≈ø≈øitie, which is, that all things fall out by a fatall de≈øtinie. There is a certaintie in all things; for, the coun≈øell of God is infallible, but no nece≈ø≈øary cau≈øe; ≈øeeing the≈øe two in rea≈øon are oppo≈øed. Secondly, ≈øome goe as wide
on the other ≈øide, that would haue all things governed by fortune and chance: as if ignorance in vs, were to bee preferred before knowledge and coun≈øell in God A flocke of ≈øheepe ≈øtands not in more need of a Shep-herd, then the worke doth of God. Thirdly, others hold a Providence in the great and waightie affayres of the world, but none in the le≈ø≈øer, and ba≈øer workes. As if it were not as honorable for God to rule the lea≈øt, as to make them. A ≈øpire of gra≈ø≈øe was his creature, and it growes not but by his Providence. Fourthly, the Providence in Lots is not rightly vnder≈øtood, It is as ca≈øuall for a lot to fall, as an haire from the head: and yet the Providence is not equall; for, be≈øide the rea≈øon it hath from God in the cau≈øe and effect, ≈øo di≈øpo≈øed by him, It hath another in the conclu≈øion, that by ≈øuch a fall, ≈øuch a thing ≈øhall be determined, which is ≈øometimes miraculous, ≈øometimes ordinary, but alwayes the conclu≈øion of God. Seeing then both the rea≈øon in the propo≈øition and event is Gods, and not mans, it is ≈øoberly to be v≈øed, and not vpon euery ≈øleight occa≈øion. Chance may bev≈øed in recreation, for ca≈øualty is to vs in all things inevitable: but not determining chance, for that is at our libertie, and may follow our con≈øultation. A lot and fortune, differ as the generall, and ≈øpeciall; the generall is incident to all our actions, and pa≈ø≈øing our rea≈øon, is ordered by God: the ≈øpeciall is incident to tho≈øe things which are warranted vs of God, when we take a ca≈øuall thing and applie it by Gods providence to determine ≈øome event. The fir≈øt is naturall, and ordered by that providence, which guides nature to his end, and ≈øometimes in wi≈øedome lets it mi≈ø≈øe his end, which is chance, falling be≈øide the ≈øcope of the ≈øecond mouer, though it hit with the fir≈øt. The other is divine, as being a te≈øtimony giuen by God, in the re≈øolution of lome doubt. And here it may well be demanded, whether the Lot being a divine te≈øtimony, would like a divine Oracle, ever conclude the ≈øame truth? I an≈øwere, the Lot is ever infallible in the conclu≈øion, becau≈øe the rea≈øon is Gods, and ought not to be iterated, for that makes God
a lier; calling into que≈øtion, whether the Lot conclude by the Providence of God or no. Yet I ≈øay, in ≈øinnefull iterations, where the Lot is ordinary, and not extraordinary, that in the next fall of the Lot, fortune may change, and differ from the fir≈øt, & yet the conclu≈øion in both be Gods, and that as his divine te≈øtimony. But you will ≈øay then Gods Oracle is vncertaine, and he may contradict him≈øelfe. I an≈øwere. No. For they are both truthes, ≈øo determined by the Providence of God, and the latter may bee a puni≈øhment of mans infidelitie, for di≈øtru≈øting God in the former. A lot is a cau≈øe by fortune, and therefore mu≈øt be referred to ≈øome cau≈øe by coun≈øell; not to men, for then might they make by the Lot what conclu≈øions they plea≈øed; therefore to God, who by his owne coun≈øell makes ≈øuch a conclu≈øion in ≈øo ca≈øuall an accident. Furthermore, it followes not becau≈øe the matter of Lots is indifferent, that therefore it may indifferently be v≈øed in recreation; for, it is the forme & the matter that giues the e≈øpeciall e≈ø≈øence. Things that are ≈øimply good, or ≈øimply evill, are not to be determined by Lots, for ≈øo may wee imbrace good for evill, and evill for good. It mu≈øt be of a midle nature to both. Hence it is vnlawfull to choo≈øe two Magi≈øtrates by Lot, if both be not equally capable of the place; for ≈øo ≈øhall the Common-wealth be wronged by in≈øufficiencie. Fiftly, this reproues them that exclude actiue providence from the workes of darkne≈ø≈øe; I know no providence which acts not, the Sunne can worke in a ≈øtinking puddle, or filthy dung-hill, and yet ≈øtill be pure. True it is, God permits things, when he doth not with≈øtand their actions: but to ≈øay he permits, not hauing any hand in the worke, is to deny his providence, &c. And here is excellent comfort to all Gods children, that their afflictions are not let loo≈øe at randum; but come from an Almightie power, guided by a mo≈øt wi≈øe providence, and tempered with a fatherly loue. This cannot but blunt the edge of all evils, to con≈øider that a divine hand is in them all. Savage creatures will be ≈ømitten by their keepers, when they are ready to teare
≈øtrangers in peeces: & ≈øhall I ≈øtruggle with him that made and moderates the world, when he ≈øtrikes me? Either mu≈øt I blame the fir≈øt mouer, or di≈øcharge the meanes, though the men may be iu≈øtly blamed. I know the agent, what≈øoever may be the fault of the in≈øtrument. The dying theefe pardons the executioner, and exclaimes on his vniu≈øt judge, or malicious accu≈øers. But I will neither be a foole, nor a rebell, either ignorant whence my cro≈ø≈øes come, or impatient, knowing them to be from my God. He hath ≈øtinted all my mi≈øeries, and weighed out euery dram of my ≈øorrowes, and the very powers of hell ≈øhall not be able to ca≈øt in one ≈øcruple more then he hath allotted for me.
Q. How is Providence confidered in regard of the Agent?

A. It is ordinary, or extraordinary. God provides for his creatures, either by meanes, or by miracles. Wee plow, we ≈øow, reape, thre≈øh, grind, bake, &c. God can skip over all the≈øe meanes, and multiply a few loaues to feed many thou≈øands. Math. 14.17. and make Corne grow without tillage. I≈øa. 37.30. God hath leaue to leape the meanes, and whereas one bu≈øhell of Corne by ≈øowing may multiply ten, ten, twentie; twentie, an hundred, and an hundred, a thou≈øand, God can ≈øend all this at once, and multiply one loafe to as great a quantitie of bread, as may be made of a thou≈øand bu≈øhels. Sheepe, Wool, Wool-men, Spinners, Weavers, &c. for the making of cloth, and cloth for garments. God can doe all this at a leape, and giue cloth and ≈øhooes, & make them la≈øt fortie yeares without all change. Deut. 29.5. And giue them bread that did never come from the earth. ver. 6. He can make Sunne and Moone ≈øtand ≈øtill, cleare the eyes with clay, ≈øaue and helpe with many, few, or none. Io≈øh. 10.12.13. Ioh. 9.6. 1. Sam. 14.6. 2. Chron. 14.11. Hence wee learne that our extremities, are Gods be≈øt opportunities.
Q. What is Gods ordinary Providence?

A. Whereby he provideth by ordinary meanes. P≈øal. 147.8.9.
He covereth the heaven with clouds, and prepareth raine for the earth, and maketh the gra≈ø≈øe to grow vpon the mountaines: which giueth to bea≈øts their food, and to the young Ravens that cry. P≈øal. 104. ver≈ø. 10. to the end. Math. 6.26. Gen. 45.7. Act. 14.17. Lev. 26.26. Math. 4.4. And here comes to be detected the Devils ≈øophi≈øtrie, ca≈øt thy ≈øelfe headlong vpon God, and v≈øe no meanes. And the Divinitie of the vulgar ≈øort, is to be learned in the beginning, and end of their ≈øalvation, negligent of the middle. Gods decree, and their finall e≈øtate, mu≈øt hang together without meanes; men would be ≈øaued by ≈øitting ≈øtill, and thinke it is enough, that they are either elected, or reiected. What is this but to eate the Corne out of the eare, nay, to fami≈øh, becau≈øe we will not abide the labour to grind, or to knead it; Sure I am, God is come to vs in a mo≈øt wonderfull manner; his Sonne is become as low as our ≈øelues, and though now returned whence he came, yet his word and ≈øpirit are ever pre≈øent, and there is nothing wanting, but a will to learne. Yet this ≈øhall be my conclu≈øion, that if meanes were wanting, I might looke for miracles. And faith can re≈øt vpon God, as all ≈øufficient in both.
Q. What is Gods extraordinary Providence?

A. Whereby he provideth extraordinarily, and by miracles: and that either again≈øt nature, or be≈øide nature, or aboue nature. As to cau≈øe the light de≈øcend without Starres. Gen. 1.4. To devide the red Sea. Exod. 14.21. To ≈øaue the three men in the hot fiery furnace. Dan. 3. To devide Iordan. Io≈øh. 3.15. To in≈øpire the Apo≈øtles. Act. 2.11. Yea, the very making of lice, was Gods extraordinary finger. Exod. 8.19. What el≈øe ≈øhould haue guided that vntamed and vntaught teame, 1. Sam. 6.12. in as right a path toward I≈ørael, as their teachers could haue gone, ≈øaue an hand aboue nature? What el≈øe ≈øhould over-rule brute creatures, to preferre a forced carriage vnto a naturall burden at home, ≈øaue a divine conduct? Little can wee, by the beginning of any action, gue≈ø≈øe a Gods intention in the conclu≈øion: yet by this may wee be premoni≈øhed to
depend vpon him in all our affayres, and that with hope of good ≈øucce≈ø≈øes. Set faith a worke in any difficultie to make the motion, and wee ≈øhall be ≈øure to ≈øpeed, eyther the one way or the other.
Q. What is a Miracle?

A. It is a worke aboue nature, and all ordinary meanes; as the rai≈øing of Lazarus. Ioh. 11.43.44. It is for the mo≈øt part a vi≈øible ≈øigne, to manife≈øt the power of God. Mat. 11.4.5. and 15.31. Ioh. 20.30. And this is proper to God. Ioh. 9.16. If this man were not of God, he could not doe ≈øuch Miracles.
Q. Wherein is the Providence of God ≈øeene?

A. In the con≈øervation, and gubernation of all things. God made nothing pre≈øently to de≈øtroy it, but re≈øerues euery thing for further v≈øe of his glory and ≈øervice. Mat. 10.25. Two ≈øparrows, ≈øcarce worth a farthing, are pre≈øerved, and governed according to Gods will; yea, the very hayres of our heads are ordered by his providence. This mind, or forminding of the creatures, is, that their beings be pre≈øerved, and their actions governed. We ≈øtand not vpon our owne feete, for when God permits vs to goe alone, like children, wee get many knocks, and fall fowlly, becau≈øe we tru≈øt too much to the broken reede of our owne freewill.
Q. What is the con≈øervation of the Creatures?

A. Whereby he keepeth and continueth the creatures in their being and kinds. Iob 12.14. P≈øal. 36.8.9. and 44.3. P≈øal. 104. and 105. and 106. and 147.10.11. If God de≈øtroy, none can deliver, and if he pre≈øerue, none can kill. It differs from government thus; that is, to guide to the end, this to keepe it for that end. Rom. 9.17. with Exod. 9.16. God kept Pharaoh for his end.
Q. Wherein ≈øtands it?

A. In the pre≈øervation of their e≈ø≈øence, and forces, or faculties: and that both vniver≈øall and ≈øingular. P≈øal. 65.2. P≈øal. 104.27.28.29. and 136.25. and 147.9. Math. 6.26.30. It is God that keepes that cau≈øes and qualities in good temper,
or changeth them from a bad condition to a good, and from a good to a better; or pre≈øerues them by ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, one generation ≈øucceeding another; or keepes them in ≈øtate, as all the Starres which this day ≈øtand firme, as vpon the day of their Creation. P≈øal. 65.6. I≈øa. 49.5. Ier. 1.5. Eccl. 1.4.5.6.7. Pre≈øervation is as the perpetuation of Gods creation, and as the continuation of it by ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, or a permanent ≈øtation. Iob 10.8.9.10.11. and 31.15. The change and alteration of the creatures condition, is from God, whether it be good, or evill. P≈øal. 76. ver≈ø. 5.6.7.9.12. and 104.29.30. and 107.34.35. and 113.7.8.9. Al≈øo their permanent ≈øtanding in their auncient e≈øtate, as Starres, Mountaines, Waters, and Earth, P≈øal. 65.6.7. Eccl. 1.4. And all this extends it ≈øelfe, even to the lea≈øt of Gods creatures, ≈øparrowes, hayres, teares, and euery ≈øickne≈ø≈øe. Math. 6.30. and 10.29.30. P≈øal. 56.8. and 68.20. and 113.6. and 146.8. Exod. 23.25. I≈øa. 19.22. Now God pre≈øerues vniver≈øalls by generation and propagation, ≈øingulars by food and nouri≈øhment, &c. As al≈øo by keeping them from violence.

p.hi: What is government?

div.p: A. Whereby he governeth all things to their end. P≈øal. 104.19. Pro. 16.4. Rom. 11.36. God made all things for an end, he pre≈øerues them to it, and by government guides them in the way. All things are compo≈øed, betwixt a beginning and an ending, and God is both. Rev. 1.8. As they are of him, ≈øo likewi≈øe without him would they returne againe to nothing, he therefore pre≈øerues them, and becau≈øe they are for him, he guides and governes them all to the ends he hath appointed them. And yet this is done by ≈øeverall rules he giues them all. A man makes a Pen, and then writes with it, it may well be ≈øaid, that the Pen writes, and the maker writes: ≈øo, God made all, and framed them by his wi≈øedome, and the very Art of God ≈øtill remaining in his creatures, teacheth them all obedience to the hand that goes with them.
Q. What are the kinds?

A. Two common, and ≈øpeciall: the one is as the Common-law in a kingdome, the other, as the municipall, or priviledged lawes of Corporations. The one is the law of Nature, whereby all creatures are governed, the other, of Divinitie, whereby men and Angels are ordered to an eternall e≈øtate. P≈øal. 8.1.3.4.5.6. &c. Excellent in all, but pa≈ø≈øing excellencie in men and Angels. P≈øal. 19.1.2.3. &c. The line and language of the heauens, teacheth Gods government, but ver≈ø. 7. the law of life exceeds all other perfection. P≈øal. 139.14. Marveilous are Gods workes, but aboue all, fearefull and wonderfull is man, both in his making and moderating.
Q. What is the common government?

A. Whereby he governeth all things by a common cour≈øe, or vniver≈øall law. P≈øal. 10.1.19. The Sunne knoweth his going downe. And here come in tho≈øe excellent in≈øtincts of nature, wherein creatures ≈øhew the rea≈øon of their government, to be more in God then them≈øelues. The Ant, or Pi≈ømire prepares her meat in the Summer. Prov. 30.25. And yet ≈øhee knowes nothing but the pre≈øent: furthermore, ≈øhe bites the little grains ≈øhe gathereth at both ends, lea≈øt it ≈øhould grow in her ≈øtore-hou≈øe. What rea≈øon in the world of this, and many more in the brute creatures can be given, but that the great law-giuer is the agent of the≈øe things? &c.
Q. What it Gods ≈øpeciall government?

A. Whereby he governeth ≈øome ≈øpeciall creatures vnto an eternall e≈øtate, as Angels and men. Prov. 16.4. Almightie God hath two ≈øorts of vertues, to manife≈øt in his creation and providence. Fir≈øt, intellectuall; Secondly, morall. No creatures but men and Angels are capable of the latter. The manifold works of God ≈øhew his excellent wi≈øedome, or the vertues of vnder≈øtanding. P≈øal. 104.24. Onely men & Angels can ≈øhew forth his Iu≈øtice & Mercy, the vertues of his will. For this end he created them, and by a ≈øpeciall law governes them thereunto, and that which is done by
law will iu≈øtifie it ≈øelfe again≈øt all exceptions. Prov. 15.3.
Q. How manifold was that eternall e≈øtate?
A. Two-fold; either of happine≈ø≈øe, or mi≈øery. Rom. 9.18. He hath mercy on whom he will, and whom he will he hardneth. Be a≈ø≈øured, the Lord will be as vnblameable in the one, as in the other.
Q. Whence doth this felicitie, or infelicitie acrew to the rea≈øonable creatures?

A. By the good plea≈øure, or di≈øplea≈øure of Almightie God. It was po≈ø≈øible for men and Angels to plea≈øe God, and be happy; and al≈øo po≈ø≈øible to di≈øplea≈øe him, and be mi≈øerable. And both the≈øe were to be acted by the law; for, it is the law that makes vs ble≈ø≈øed, or cur≈øed; and man might ≈øo handle the matter, that he might act whether part he plea≈øed, and yet his de≈øtruction come from him≈øelfe, though in life the law ≈øhould haue beene a principall agent. A che≈øt is made for linnen, or other clothes, and it is combu≈øtible: but the burning of it comes not from the Carpenters Art, &c. So man is mutable, and ≈øubiect to fall; yet his falling no wayes ari≈øeth from his Creator. Gen. 2.17. and 3.7.
Q. What is here to be con≈øidered?

A. Mans fearefull apo≈øta≈øie, and happie Ana≈øta≈øie: his fall, and returne to God. Providence fir≈øt governes man in his aver≈øion from God, and this is of all; ≈øecondly, in his conver≈øion againe, and this is of ≈øome. Gal. 3.22. The Scripture concludes all vnder ≈øinne, that the promi≈øe of Chri≈øt might be to beleeuers. Rom. 11.32. Luk. 1.78.79.

p.hi: VVHat is the Apo≈øta≈øie?

div.p: An≈øwere.

That fall of the Creature from the government of God, or his obedience therevnto, in ≈øo much that as now he ≈øtandeth, he cannot plea≈øe God, but di≈øplea≈øe him continually. Gen. 3.6. and 6.5. I≈øa. 59.2. Gal. 3.10. Marke where man fell, not in his con≈øervation, for his being and action are continued: but government, his action ≈øwarving from the line of Gods law, and it was nothing, but (as it were) the turning of the wheele the contrary way, ≈øo that now the whole man is exorbitant in his cour≈øes, and altogether oppo≈øite to his government: like Iobs wild A≈ø≈øe in the de≈øert, or as Amos his Hor≈øe that will runne vpon the rockes. Amos 6.12.
Q. Of whom was this Apo≈øta≈øie?

A. Of ≈øome Angels, and of all men in the fir≈øt man. Iud: ver. 6. Gen. 3.6. Rom. 3.10. Ioh. 8.44. angels and men were governed in their fir≈øt fall, God ≈øending the one to try the other. Man was to try the Angels, whether they would at Gods command mini≈øter for his good; and they againe man, whether he would li≈øten more to Gods law, or their rebellion.
Q. What are the things to be ob≈øerved in this Apo≈øta≈øie?

A. The transgre≈ø≈øion and the propagation of it. Rom. 5.12. By one man ≈øinne entred into the world. Here is the head or ≈øpring, one man, the ≈øtreame or flood, ≈øinne, the channell, entred, the ≈øea or Ocean into which it fell, the world. Rom. 5.18.19.
Q. What is the tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion?

A. The eating of the forbidden fruit of the tree of knowledge, of
good and evill. Gen. 2.17. which was a great offence, both in regard of God, his law, and Sacrament. He was bound to loue God aboue all; who gaue him the v≈øe of all trees, onely he forbids him this, even as he loued him not to eate thereof. Againe, the rule of good and evill was the whole law of mans life. And therefore here was not a partiall, but an vniver≈øall breach of all the branches of obedience. And la≈øtly, he in contempt of God, and his goodne≈ø≈øe, plucked off the ≈øeale of the covenant, for God placed that tree with the other in the very mid≈øt of the Garden, as a vi≈øible ≈øigne and Sacrament of his obedience. Man was changeably good, and therefore as he was to haue a Sacrament, to ≈øeale his con≈øtant e≈øtate in goodne≈ø≈øe, if he per≈øi≈øted and continued in the loue of God, which was the tree of life: ≈øo, on the contrary, if he ≈øhould leaue off to ≈øerue God, then ≈øhould he haue ≈øealed vnto him the a≈ø≈øurance of his change from good to evill; and this was by the tree of the knowledge of good and evill. Thus it plea≈øed God to deale with man, either in regard of obedience, or di≈øobedience. Ble≈ø≈øed be God, wee haue a better tree of life, to ≈øeale our perfect obedience in another: and two Sacraments to put vs out of all danger of death: God ≈øealing our ≈øalvation for his owne names ≈øake.
Q. What things are to be ob≈øerved therein?

A. Two; The cau≈øes thereof, and the effects. Gen. 2.17. Ezek. 18.2. Rom. 6.23. Sinne and death are as in ≈øeparable in the cau≈øe, as fire and burning; death is a nece≈ø≈øary con≈øequent of ≈øuch a cau≈øe.
Q. How many ≈øorts of cau≈øes be there?

A. Two, the one, blameable and guiltie, the other, blamele≈ø≈øe and guiltle≈ø≈øe. The law and ≈øinne, as well s the law and obedience worke together, though in a di≈øtinct manner; for, of obedience the law is the principall cau≈øe, but of ≈øinne an accidentall, as working be≈øide his owne ≈øcope and maine drift, which is to ≈øavour nothing but life, and al≈øo as a contrary to ≈øinne; hence a ≈øinner ≈øtands in violent oppo≈øition to the law, and they ≈øtriue the more, becau≈øe the
one is readie to hinder the others act; as bankes, or flood-gates ≈øtaying the ≈øtreame, make it either bur≈øt them downe, or el≈øe ≈øwell over them: and doe we not ≈øee how all ≈øuch as are bent vpon any villany, are more exa≈øperated by di≈ø≈øwa≈øion, then if they were let alone? Pharaoh is better to I≈ørael, whiles they willingly obey, then when Mo≈øes and Aaron come to preach their deliuerance; then as a bea≈øt he turnes madde with baiting. And ≈øo all the Martyrs ≈øhould haue had the Heathen Emperours better tutors then tyrants, if they had not provoked them by oppo≈øition of their wickedne≈ø≈øe. Nay, doe we not ≈øee how the be≈øt mindes, when they are troubled, yeeld incon≈øiderate motions; as water that is violently ≈øtirred, ≈øends vp bubbles? Rom. 7.11.11.13.
Q. How many be the cau≈øes blameable?

A. Two; The principall, and mini≈øteriall: the Devill a chiefe agent in mans apo≈øta≈øie, abu≈øed the Serpent, and the woman, as his in≈øtruments, to ≈øeduce man. Gen. 3.2. Cor. 11.3. Satans policie was to take the ≈øubtill Serpent, and ≈øimple Woman, to defeat man of his happine≈ø≈øe, as now he doth the Ie≈øuites, and females, to draw men to Antichri≈øt.
Q. What are the principall cau≈øes?

A. The Devill, and Man: though Eue was fir≈øt in the motion, yet was Adam principall in the action; for he is fir≈øt called to the barre, to an≈øwere the tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion. Gen. 3.9. 1. Tim. 2.13.14. Fir≈øt, he was the head of his wife, and therefore it was his ≈øinne, that he gaue her no better in≈øtruction. Secondly, the Covenant of life was made principally with him, and therefore it is ≈øaid, that when he had eaten, both their eyes were open. Gen. 3.7. She did eate before her husband, and ≈øinned per≈øonally: but when he did eate with her, then they both ≈øaw, that they, and all their po≈øteritie were accur≈øed. Thirdly, It is probable, that Adam ≈øtood by all the time of the di≈øputation, and therefore his ≈øinne was the greater, that he rebuked not the Serpent, and re≈øcued his wife from all ≈øuch ≈øugge≈øtions: or if he was ab≈øent, (whereof the Text makes no mention)
then ≈øhould he ≈øhew him≈øelfe a weaker ve≈ø≈øell then his wife, who had all the bad Angels (in one craftie bea≈øt) to ≈øet vpon her: whereas he had onely one weake woman in his pure≈øt integritie to overthrow him. Neither could his affection then to his wife be ≈øo prepo≈øterous, as are now of corrupt naturali≈øts, who are blinded in loue. His loue to his wife was created pure, and therefore except his iudgement had beene fir≈øt perverted, as it was in his wife, he could not ≈øo ea≈øily haue con≈øented, of meere affection to his wife. I cannot beleeue, but that the Devils in the Serpent, did as well tempt Adam as Eue, though fir≈øt they began with her, as a further meanes of inticing him. The text ≈øayes not, that Eue went to ≈øeeke her husband; but that ≈øhee tooke, and gaue to her husband with her, &c. Gene≈øis 3.6.
Q. How were the Devils the cau≈øe of it?

A. They were by creation good, and appointed of God to be mans keepers, yet of their owne accord, and free will they di≈ødained and contemned their ≈øtanding with God. Iud. ver. 6. and became proud, rebellious, and abominable lyers, and bla≈øphemers of God, and of malice and hatred of man, became ≈øeducers and murtherers of him. Ioh. 4.44. It may well be di≈øputed, whether the Angels were Apo≈øtataes in heaven, or Paradi≈øe. If I may ≈øhew my iudgement, and leaue it as a probable opinion, it is this. The third heaven is a place of puritie, and ab≈øolute felicitie, and therfore cannot for a moment, or in≈øtant of time, be the ≈øubiect of any pollution, or mi≈øery. If ≈øinne had ever beene in heaven, the place ≈øhould haue beene polluted by it. The very earth was ≈øtained with the ≈øinne of his proper inhabitant: and ≈øo ≈øhould heaven, if the proper and peculiar inhabitants had there ≈øinned: but ≈øuch was the wi≈øe providence of Almightie God, that at once he would giue a iu≈øt occa≈øion of triall, of the Angels in their obedience, and ≈øaue heaven from all polution, which he then, and now, and ever pre≈øerues mo≈øt pure for his elect, both Angels and men. The occa≈øion was giuen in their mini≈øtration to man, not the celebration of Gods
glory in heauen, that they might ≈øee more fitting their place then the other: but ≈øhall wee the mo≈øt excellent of Gods creatures, ≈øtoop ≈øo low as to become mans ≈øervants, and ≈øubiect our ≈øelues to ourinferiours, &c? Let vs thinke of a cour≈øe to ≈øubvert his e≈øtate, and bring him out of grace and favour with his creator; ≈øo ≈øhall we according to our excellencie, Lord it over him. So that here might very well be a conioyned Apo≈øta≈øie in the ruine of them both. O ble≈ø≈øed God, how farre is thy decree from all ≈øtaine of ≈øin, and yet how full of Mercy and Iu≈øtice? Thou would≈øt not try all thy Angels, ≈øome thou kept≈øt at home, whiles others fell in mini≈øtring abroad. And all this, that thy ≈øonne might be exalted, neither Angel or man ever prevailing without him. Rev. 12.6.7. They that fight vnder this head; are all ≈øaued; if they warre vnder their owne power they cannot but peri≈øh. The good angels were but lookers on till a Me≈ø≈øias was promi≈øed, and then are they all mini≈øtering ≈øpirits for the good of their fellow heires of ≈øalvation. Heb. 1.14. Who can ≈øay blacke is the eye of Gods providence, intending to glorifie his Iu≈øtice in the condemnation of ≈øome Angels, and ≈øome men, when he might haue executed all? Let vs all ≈øing with the ≈øweet Singer of I≈ørael. P≈øal. 119.137. Righteous art thou, O Lord, and vpright are thy iudgement.
Q. How was man a cau≈øe thereof?

A. By the abu≈øe of Gods law, and his owne free will, being ≈øeduced by Satan, and induced into ≈øinne by the ≈øtrength of his temptation, ≈øubtiltie of his ≈øugge≈øtion, and is owne free reception of both, voluntarily harkning thereunto, contrary to Gods commandement, when being a≈ø≈øi≈øted thereby, he might ea≈øily haue re≈øi≈øted the ≈øame. Gen. 3.6. Man was made a mo≈øt free beginner of his owne action, neither did God withdraw, or with-hold any nece≈ø≈øary grace from him; he gaue him ≈øufficient not to ≈øinne, neither was he bound to giue him ≈øo much as he might prevent, and prevaile over euery violent temptation god might haue kept Satan from him, or in the combat haue giuen him the conque≈øt: but it was Gods
meaning to try him with the grace of his Creation: that now he may ≈øee the greater loue of his Creator, in putting him vnder a ≈øecond Adam, who prevailed again≈øt Satan, and in whom all the elect ≈øhall be ≈øure of victory. Hence learne, that ≈øince the fall, in the hardning of Reprobates, as in Pharaoh, God neither withdrawes grace, for he had none; nor with-holds it, for he is not bound to giue it: Chri≈øt is onely a head and fountaine of ≈øauing grace, for his elect Angels and men.
Q. What were the in≈øtrumentall cau≈øes?

A. The Serpent, and the Woman. Gen. 3.1. The Devill to further his temptation, v≈øed vi≈øible in≈øtruments, and plotted by the ≈øubtiltie of the one, and ≈øimplicitie of the other, the woefull down fall of Adam, and all his po≈øteritie. All the Legions of the reprobate Devils entred into one bea≈øt, to conferre with the woman, and by the Poitho and Suada of that viperous tongue, crept into the bo≈øome of Eue, as it were, by all the topicke places in Logicke, figures of Rethoricke, and other engines of guile & deceit, till they had brought her into a fooles Paradi≈øe, with the lo≈ø≈øe of the earthly, and hazzard of the heauenly.
Q. What is the vnblameable cau≈øe?

A. The commandement of God, for had there beene no law there had beene no tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion. Rom. 7.7. Gal. 3.22. And here comes in the act of Gods providence in the apo≈øta≈øie of Angels and men. A law is giuen, by which God will haue them both ruled, but of this they make no account; for it is the very fir≈øt thing they begin to conte≈øt withall, and at length by plaine deniall oppo≈øeit. The law was giuen to moue man to his dutie, even as that Spirit in Ezekiel moued the wheeles. Ezek. 1.21. The law was ≈øpirituall. Rom. 7.14. And placed in the very heart of man, and was of a divine nature, to haue drawne man to good; but the ≈øpirit of Satan enters to graple with the law, and turne the wheele of the minde in a cleane contrary cour≈øe to Gods will: the law re≈øi≈øts, but man for≈øakes his mouer, and is
turned of Satan the bie way; and ≈øo the good law of God becomes the ≈øavour of death vnto death. 2. Cor. 2.16. And that by an oppo≈øite motion to his owne nature. The tree was a ≈øeale, both of good and e ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , and the fruit ta≈øted could leaue a tang of death behind it. The law was as able to guide to death, as life; to life by his free motion, to death by his oppo≈øition. He that runnes again≈øt a wall, or a tree, is throwne backe againe by violence, and brui≈øed in peeces by his ownefall and folly: or by this compari≈øon may you ≈øee the worke of the law, by ca≈øting Angels and men into hell. An earthen pitcher is da≈øhed by a fooli≈øh and furious hand again≈øt an hard ≈øtone wall: that the wall breaketh it, is not the fault of the wall, but rather a commendation; all the evill is in the ha≈øtie hand that ra≈øhly hurles it again≈øt ≈øo apparent a death and danger: ≈øo wilfull and witle≈ø≈øe man by the ≈øugge≈øtion of Satan in the ≈øerpent and woman, takes him≈øelfe, and of his owne free accord flings, or rather flies in the very face of the law, and by it is mi≈øerably ≈øtricken in peeces Doe we not now ≈øee how the law makes him ≈øhiver and ≈øhake, even as a vanqui≈øhed enemie vnder the hands of his Conquerour, and how he ≈øeeks to ea≈øe him≈øelfe of ≈øuch a governour? He might as well haue knocked his head again≈øt the ≈øtone-walles, as his wits to fru≈øtrate the power of the law within him. A ≈øilly ≈øhift to ≈øtop a little torrent with ≈øodds and turfs, will it not breake over with roaring? A fooli≈øh fancy to ≈øtanch bleeding, by ≈øtopping our no≈øthrils, will it not breake out at the mouth, or runne downe the throat into the ≈øtomacke? A man may with many piles of greene wood ≈ømoother and ≈øuffocate the fire for a ≈øea≈øon, but when the moy≈øture is ma≈øtered, the fury of the burning will be more fearefull, and the flames and fla≈øhes, more dreadfull to behold. Alas, alas, how doth euery ≈øinner pile vp the fagots of his future fire, and warme the worme in his owne bo≈øome, that ≈øhall gnaw for ever? Con≈øcience ≈øhall reade him a lecture euery day, becau≈øe he would not heare the lecture of the law for his eternall good. Rom. 7.10.11.12.
Q. What followes from hence?

A. That as the law was the cau≈øe of ≈øinne by accident, ≈øo was God, and no otherwi≈øe. Here was no omnipotencie to con≈øtraine man to fulfill the will of his creator; here was a law to re≈øtraine him from ≈øinne, and di≈øtre≈ø≈øe him in committing it, yea, and thru≈øt him head-long into all out-rage, being once oppo≈øed by man. Let men rot in their ≈øinnes, and they will die quietly: but ≈øtirre them by the liuely word, and ≈øinne will reviue. Rom. 7.9. and either kill wor≈øe by impenitencie, or be more happily killed by repentance. Mud in a gla≈ø≈øe, when it is ≈øhaken, runnes all over that which before ≈øeemed pure and cry≈øtall. The poy≈øon of the ≈ønake, whiles he is benummed with cold beareth no danger, but warme him, and he will hi≈ø≈øe and ≈øting. The Sea in calme weather is as ≈øtill and quiet as any river; but let the windes once blow and blu≈øter, and you ≈øhall ≈øee nothing but raging, ≈øtorming, and foaming out mire and dirt. Ho≈ø. 2.1. When I would haue healed I≈ørael; namely by admonitions and rebukes of the word, then the iniquitie of Ephraim was di≈øcovered, &c. The law had an intent to ≈øaue man; but man would not hearken thereunto, ≈øo that his perdition was of him≈øelfe.
Q. What ≈øecondly may be learned?

A. That God was no bare permitting, or for≈øaking cau≈øe, but a working cau≈øe, even in the fall of man. Gen. 3.1. It is Satans fir≈øt on-≈øet, hath God ≈øaid ye ≈øhall not eate, &c. Like an earewig did he wrigle in by ≈øophi≈øticating the holy law of God; for he knew well enough he could not get in except he did driue that out, which was not done, but by a mightie wre≈øtling, and wreathing on both ≈øides. And Gods worke was fir≈øt to hold out Satan, then in contempt to thru≈øt man vpon his adver≈øary, when he left him to cleaue vnto a lyer. 1. Sam. 2.30. They that de≈øpi≈øe me ≈øhall be lightly e≈øteemed. God in an holy indignation might well reiect them that had ≈øo ≈øhamefully reiected him; and (as it were) even pu≈øh man vpon the pikes of his owne puni≈øhment. It was no ioy to God, to ≈øee his beloued creature, ≈øo vilely
to ca≈øt away him≈øelfe; and yet God intended, & wrought it without all blame, not as an author, or fautour of mans finne, but as a judge, ca≈øting him in his owne act, and taking revenge vpon him for his ≈øinne.
Q. What will follow in the third place?

A. How God wrought in mans fall, yea, and from all eternitie, for Gods act began before mans. And this is ≈øafely to be done by our anatomie, or re≈øolution of Gods compo≈øition in this worke. Fir≈øt, God did it by his law, and ≈øpeciall government of man. Secondly, as he did it, ≈øo had he power to doe it, and ≈øuch a power, as neither Devils nor men are able to re≈øi≈øt. Man might re≈øi≈øt the law. Math. 23.37. but not the power, by which the law worketh; for man, not the law, ≈øhall ≈øuffer for the irruption, and breach of it. The law will be ≈øure, one way, or another, to make his part good, with the mo≈øt ma≈øterle≈ø≈øe mon≈øters. Thirdly, as God did it, and could doe it, ≈øo he decreed it to be done, and omnipotencie and efficiencie, are but two executours, no compo≈øors of Gods decree, and therefore it ≈øhall ≈øtand infallible in the greate≈øt contingencie. It was po≈ø≈øible for man to fall, or not to fall, and his act was contingent, ≈øo true that it might haue beene fal≈øe, yet the decree was as certaine before as after the event, ≈øeeing all things are pre≈øent to God, when they are ab≈øent to vs. Fourthly, as he decreed it, ≈øo it was done by coun≈øell. Ephe. 1.11. both in the ≈øcope, and plot. God had an end in mans fall, neitheir was it otherwi≈øe executed then him≈øelfe had plotted it. The Devils, and our fir≈øt parents, together with the Serpent, time, and place, could never haue ≈øo met together, except God had ≈øet it downe, ≈øo will I haue it acted, even to euery circum≈øtance. Fiftly, It ≈øeemed good to his wi≈øedome ≈øo to haue it done, and no otherwi≈øe. Pharaoh deales wi≈øely by ≈øinning. Exod. 1.10. but God is wi≈øe in decreeing how Pharaoh ≈øhall ≈øinne. Sixtly, that which is done by the wi≈øedome of God, is good and iu≈øt. Hence ≈øinne, oppo≈øite to all good, and the enemie of iu≈øtice, was both good & iu≈øt, not in it ≈øelfe, but as God decreed it to be a meanes
of his glory, which it is not by his owne nature, for God is cli≈øhonoured by it: but by accident, as God can bring light out of darkene≈ø≈øe, good out of evill, and life out of death. Therefore as God did it, it was no ≈øinne, euery cau≈øe is to be examined by his manner of working. Man ≈øinnes by coun≈øell, and God by coun≈øell orders it ≈øo to be done, and in doing workes as much as he willed. La≈øtly, as it was good and iu≈øt, ≈øo God willed it, but as ≈øimply evill, he willed it not, but did hate the being of it. P≈øal. 5.4. Will is the highe≈øt ≈øtep we mu≈øt ≈øtand vpon, and thus may we goe downeward, by the ≈øame ≈øtaires we came vp. God did will nothing but that which was good and iu≈øt, and ≈øo it ≈øeemed good to his wi≈øedome, by coun≈øell to decree it, and by his power to effect it.

Blame, and then guilt and puni≈øhment. Man was blameworthy, for eating again≈øt the expre≈ø≈øe commandement of his God, then was he made guiltie of all the debt and danger that the law contained, and by puni≈øhment to ≈øuffer, or ≈øatisfie what≈øoeuer the law could challenge at our hands. Rom. 5.12. One man ≈øinnes, there is the blame, by it entrance is giuen to death, there is our guilt, that we haue ≈øo intangled our ≈øelues in the ≈ønares of ≈øinne and death, and it runnes over all, there is the puni≈øhment.

Both originall, and actuall. Adams tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion turned the Chariot of the ≈øoule cleane out of the tract of good, ≈øo that now it is impo≈ø≈øible he ≈øhould ever get into his way againe. Small ≈øinnes are like to ≈ølips, and ≈ølidings, whereby men fall and hurt them≈øelues, but great ≈øinnes are like downefalls, which wound, lame, di≈ø-ioynt, or breake ≈øome member, &c. Mans fir≈øt ≈øinne was a mi≈øerable downe-fall, for it did wound and wa≈øt the whole man, and made him euery way vnable to ≈øtirre hand or foot, to plea≈øe God. Gal. 6.1. See how the fir≈øt ≈øinne put all out of ioynt, and di≈øplaced the whole image of God. Fir≈øt, man neglected his ordinary calling, when carele≈øly he ≈øuffered the Serpent to enter. Thirdly, his eye wandered, when he ≈øaw that to be de≈øired, which was ≈øo plainely forbidden. Fourthly, his feeling was perverted, touching where it was ≈øure to be tainted. Fiftly, he ta≈øted with delight, that which he ≈øhould haue ≈øpit out, as bitter, and poy≈øonfull. Sixtly, his ≈ømelling, which is ≈øet over the mouth to giue intelligence to it, whether our meat be ≈øweet or no, was here trecherous to the palate, in ≈øuffering it to ≈øwallow downe ≈øo ≈øtincking a mor≈øell. Thus the fiue ≈øen≈øes were as Cinqueports for temptations, where ≈øinne began fir≈øt to trafficke, and at length, Satan became Lieutenant of them all, and by them not long after gained cu≈øtome-tribute of Soules. From all the≈øe wheeles running wrong, Satan creepes neerer the Soule, and gots po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of all the interior ≈øen≈øes. While the Crocodile ≈øleepes with open mouth, the Indian Ratt ≈øhoots him≈øelfe into his belly, and gnawes his gutts in ≈øunder; ≈øo entred mi≈øchiefe at the open gates of this ≈øecuritie. Now the fancy begins plau≈øible inventions, here is a tree for wi≈øedome, the cogitation takes it for a truth, and the memory hath forgotten both the loue, and law of God. Vnder≈øtanding thus blinded with ≈øen≈øe, never calls this ≈øophi≈øtry to her tribunall, but taking one argument for another, teacheth the will to conclude ami≈ø≈øe, and ≈øo the Devill is imbraced for God, and man being thus ≈øubverted, ≈øinned, being condemned of him≈øelfe. Tit. 3.11. And by this di≈øobedience are we all made ≈øinners, both actually and originally. Rom. 5.19.
Q. What is originall ≈øinne?

A. An exorbitation, or ≈øwarning of the whole man, both inwardly in him≈øelfe, and outwardly in the government of the creatures. P≈øal. 51.5. Rom. 3.10. and 5.12.18.19. and 7.24. and 8.5. Thirdly, It is not a ≈øleeping habite, but an inward act, ever ≈øtirring in man, as doth the fir≈øt act of the ≈øoule, which is never quiet, Fourthly, in this inward motion, it hath alwayes an inclination to evill. Fiftly, It mo≈øt e≈øpecially po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth the will; and therefore by the auncients, is called concupi≈øcence, which is the wills motion, where now all ≈øinne beginnes, and by a kinde of imperious command, drawes all other wheeles about with it. By this ≈øinne, the whole man is in evill, and whole evill is in man, as the Chaos had the ≈øeeds of all creatures, onely wanted the ≈øpirits motion, to bring forth: ≈øo this wants nothing but Satans heat to hatch even Cockatrices, and ≈øuch like poy≈øoned mon≈øters.

A. That mans wit and will are exorbitant, and therefore he hath no freedome of will to any good, that is, that may be plea≈øing vnto God, but wholly is carryed vnto evill. Ioh. 8.34.35. Without the principle of life, it is impo≈ø≈øible to liue, therefore originall ≈øinne being in the place of originall righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, and now no new principle of faith as yet infu≈øed, man is euery wayes di≈ø-inabled to liue well; liue he may, and that freely; but it mu≈øt be in ≈øinning. The Chariot of the ≈øoule is cleane carried out of the way of holine≈ø≈øe, and man runnes quite be≈øide the line of the law. Without mee (≈øayes Chri≈øt) you can doe nothing; no, not thinke any thing, ≈øayth Paul. Alas, what can they doe that are not lame, but dead in ≈øinnes? Eph. 2.1. The fir≈øt bond is broken, and therefore God and man are parted, as really and truely, in regard of ≈øpirituall life, as when the naturall ≈øpirits
are extingui≈øht, body and ≈øoule flie a≈øunder. By the influence of Gods Spirit alone, mu≈øt a new life be created in vs, that was not, and not ≈øome former life excited: yea, further, wee are not pre-di≈øpo≈øed, and prepared of our ≈øelues, for the receiuing of it. As there is no vacuitie in nature, no more is there ≈øpiritually. Euery ve≈ø≈øell is full; if not of liquor, yet of ayre: and ≈øo is the heart of man; though (by nature) it is empty of grace, yet it is full of hypocri≈øie, and iniquitie: neither can it be filled with grace, except it be emptied of the≈øe evill qualities: and as in a ve≈ø≈øell, ≈øo much water as goes in, ≈øo much ayre goes out: ≈øo in the narrow mouth'd ve≈ø≈øell of the heart, ≈øo much grace as comes in by drops, ≈øo much ≈øinne is expelled, and the fir≈øt expul≈øion is violent, man not co-working at all; for he is imformed (as it were) with ≈øinne, and is contrary to the worke of grace, the very wi≈øedome of his fle≈øh is enmitie, not ≈øecret, but publicke, in re≈øi≈øtance: neither doth, nor can ≈øubiect it ≈øelfe. Rom. 8.7. One hupota≈ø≈øetai, ou dunatai, two words that cut the very throat of our free-will, It ≈øubiects not, there is re≈øi≈øtance, and where there is re≈øi≈øtance, there is contrarietie; and contraries ≈øuffer violence of one another. And the corrupt will is turned againe to God by violence; I ≈øay not the will, for that is a ≈øubiect of both, and pa≈ø≈øiue in conver≈øion, ≈øuffering grace by violence to ca≈øt out ≈øinne. As farre as it oppo≈øeth by corruption, ≈øo farre is it con≈øtrained to yeeld by grace; and in the fir≈øt motion will not-≈øubiect, nay, becau≈øe of ≈øinne cannot: but the wheele once turned againe by grace, is as ready to doe well, as ever it was to doe evill. Onely Lord, I know, that by rea≈øon of this oppo≈øition, my ≈øoule will take a long time to emptie and fill, and that the be≈øt ve≈ø≈øell cannot be quite full, while it is in the body; becau≈øe there will be ≈øtill the≈øe remainders of corruption. Though I mu≈øt not be impatient of Gods delay, yet will I never re≈øt coÃÑtent with any mea≈øure of grace in this world: but will euery day endevour to haue one drop or another added to my ≈ømall quantitie: ≈øo ≈øhall my la≈øt day fill vp
my ve≈ø≈øell to the brim.
Q. What is actuall ≈øinne?

A. The continuall iarring of man vpon outward obiects, by rea≈øon of this naturall exorbitation. An in≈øtrument put out of tune, is di≈ø≈øonant in all harmonies. Rom. 3.13.14.15.16.17.18. Throat, tongue, mouth, feete, actions, &c. are all without Gods feare. Rom. 1.29.30. P≈øal. 50.16.17.18.19.20. P≈øal. 10.4. and 14.1. Hainous crimes, neither ≈øparing God nor man. P≈øal. 10.6.11.13. and 40.13. and 74.8. I≈øa. 28.15. Math. 12.24. Luk. 12.19.45. and 18.11.12. 1 Cor. 2.14. Gal. 5.17. Secondly, God directeth ≈øinners evermore to his glory, they ≈øhall honour him when they thinke lea≈øt of it. They ≈øcarce find an Inne to baite in, before they be baited out againe with mi≈ø-rule: onely that light of Gods loue, and countenance, that ≈øhines into an holy heart is con≈øtant, like that of the Sunne, which keepes due times, and varies not his cour≈øe, for any of the≈øe ≈øublunary occa≈øions: yet ble≈ø≈øed be God, who re≈øtraines the plots and practi≈øes of the wicked for the good of his elect.
Q. What are the degrees of this ≈øinne?

A. It may be greater, or le≈ø≈øer, in re≈øpect of whom, or against
whom it is committed, likewi≈øe in re≈øpect of the matter, manner, or mea≈øure of working it, as whether it be done of knowledge, or ignorance, of infirmitie, or ≈øtubbornne≈ø≈øe, or with an high hand. Iam. 1.14. A wicked obiect brings in ≈øugge≈øtion, ≈øugge≈øtion delight, delight con≈øent, con≈øent practi≈øe, practi≈øe cu≈øtome, cu≈øtome ob≈øtinacy, ob≈øtinacy hardne≈ø≈øe of heart, and that a reprobate mind. 1 Tim 1.13. Rom. 2.5. & 1.28. Ier. 5.3. Lu≈øt is le≈ø≈øe then adultery, ha≈øty anger is le≈ø≈øe then Racha, and that then foole. Math. 5.22. The ≈øinne of a Iew, is greater then of a Pagan, of a teacher then a ≈øcholler, Rom. 2.18.20.21. He that knowes Gods will and doth it not, is to be beaten with more ≈øtripes then one that is meerely ignorant. Luk. 12.47. A profe≈ø≈øors ≈øinne is greater then the ≈øinne of a prophane man. Againe, it is a le≈ø≈øe ≈øinne to ≈øtrike a common man then a Con≈øtable, a Con≈øtable then a Iu≈øtice of peace, a Iu≈øtice of peace then a Iudge, a Iudge then a Prince, a Prince then to put out the hand again≈øt God. It is a greater vnkindne≈ø≈øe for a ≈øonne to offend his father, then another man, &c. Habituall ≈øinnes are wor≈øe then actuall, and a railing habite is wor≈øe then a ≈ølip, or error of the tongue. Here may a que≈øtion be demanded, whether the ≈øinnes of the fir≈øt Table, or the ≈øecond are greater? An≈øwere; compare per≈øon with per≈øon, and then euery ≈øinne again≈øt God is more vile then again≈øt my neighbour: but other circum≈øtances may aggravate, and make a ≈øinne greater in the ≈øecond Table then the fir≈øt. Q. How many ≈øorts be there of actuall ≈øinnes?

A. Two; the ≈øinnes of commi≈ø≈øion, and the ≈øinnes of omi≈ø≈øion. Ier. 2.13. And man doth v≈øually omit good, before he

div.p: Que≈øtion.

p.hi: VVHat is Death?

A deprivation and lo≈ø≈øe of life, with a fearefull ≈øubiection to the mi≈øery of this life, and the life to come. Gen. 2.17. Rom. 6.23. And what newes can be better then this, that God ≈øends for me, to make me more happie, then my cra≈øie carca≈øe will ≈øuffer me to be, till it be mended, and ca≈øt in a better mould. Q. What things are to be confidered in death?

A. The inchoation and beginning, or the perfection and end. The beginning of any act is part of it, and when man ≈øets his hand to any thing, he is doing it. If there had beene any act of ≈øpirituall life, man had liued, and God had beene well plea≈øed, and his life had beene immutable: ≈øo on the contrary, when man begins to die, he is a dying, and God ≈øayes in the very day that thou eate≈øt, or ≈øinne≈øt, thou ≈øhalt die. A. Two; The fir≈øt and the ≈øecond. The ≈øoule dyes the fir≈øt death, by ≈øympathie with the bodie, and the bodie dies the ≈øecond death, by ≈øympathie with the ≈øoule. Math. 10.28. Rev. 2.11. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, that is called the ≈øecond death, becau≈øe the extremitie of it is to begin after the end and perfection of the fir≈øt.
Q. What is the fir≈øt death?

Q. What is the beginning hereof?

A. The lo≈ø≈øe of the good things of the body, as the ≈øen≈øe of nakedne≈ø≈øe, of maie≈øtie, (whence comes ≈øhame) of comeline≈ø≈øe and beautie, as al≈øo of health, whence man is expo≈øed to wearine≈ø≈øe, dangers, ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, and a daily dying. A. Subiection to the mi≈øeries which come by the lo≈ø≈øe of externall good things, as fir≈øt of ≈øuch things, wherewith the life of man was honoured, as the lo≈ø≈øe of friend≈øhip, honour, rule over the creatures, eiection, or ca≈øting out of paradi≈øe, with an interdiction, or forbidding of vs to enter by the Cherubius. weedes, and ≈øtep mother of wheate) his cloathing eyther clogging nature, in keeping it too hot; or over-little, leauing it to the annoyance of the ayre, and to ≈øtarue as well with cleanline≈ø≈øe of apparell, as cleanene≈ø≈øe of teeth: and la≈øtly, euery calling ≈øubiect to calamitie, and goods lea≈øt good when mo≈øt need; and we cannot but conclude, that all the≈øe together were great ha≈øtners of his death: but aboue all, ≈øeeing now in ≈øtead of a ble≈ø≈øing, Gods cur≈øe was carried withall, and could be no le≈ø≈øe then a devouring canker, or wartwort in all his actions and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions. A. The going out of the Spirits, whereby the Soule departeth from the body, and the body afterwards is returned and re≈øolved into the earth, and other elements, whence it was taken. Gen. 3.19. Eccl. 12.7. Here then is nothing but improvidence, that addes terror vnto this death. Let vs but thinke of it, and wee ≈øhall not feare it. Doe wee not ≈øee, that even Beares and Tigres ≈øeeme not terrible to tho≈øe that liue with them? how may wee ≈øee their keepers ≈øport with them, when the beholders dare ≈øcarce tru≈øt their chaine? Let vs then be acquainted with this death, and we ≈øhall be the better able to looke vpon his grimme countenance. I am a≈øhamed of this weake re≈øolution, that we ≈øhould extoll death in his ab≈øence, and be ≈øo fearefull in his pre≈øence. Often in our ≈øpeculations haue wee freely di≈øcour≈øed of ≈øuch a friend, and now, that hee is come to our beds ≈øide, and hath drawne the Curtaines, and takes vs by the hand, and offers vs his ≈øervice, wee ≈øhrinke inward, and by the palene≈ø≈øe of our faces, and wildne≈ø≈øe of our eyes, wee bewray an amazement at the pre≈øence of ≈øuch a gue≈øt. Our ≈øinne hath made it bitter, and thy mercy hath made it better then life Good Phy≈øitians when they apply their Leeches, ≈øcoure them with ≈øalt and nettles, and when their corrupt bloud is voyded, imploy them to the health of their Patients. This E≈øau in ≈øtead of frownes, ≈øhall meet vs with ki≈ø≈øes, and although wee receiue a blow from his rough hand, yet the very ≈øtripe and ≈øtroke ≈øhall be healing. I will therefore never grieue to tread in the ≈øteps of my Sauiour to glory. I know, my la≈øt enemy, by his goodne≈ø≈øe, ≈øhall be my fir≈øt friend in my pa≈ø≈øage to another world.
Q. What is the ≈øecond death?

A. The ≈øubiection of man to the mi≈øeries of the world to come. Rom. 2.5. An heaping of wrath again≈øt the day of wrath. The little ≈øparke of immortality, and beame of Gods eternity, through ≈øinne, of an inualuable ble≈ø≈øing, becomes an intollerable cur≈øe, ≈øubiecting of vs to the mi≈øeries of another life: Oh, that we could feele this as well as the other, and vpon the fir≈øt groanes ≈øeeke for ea≈øe. What mad man will purcha≈øe this crackling of thornes (≈øuch is the worldlings ioy) with eternall ≈øhrieking, and torment? But it is no marvaile, ≈øeeing onely wi≈øe men ≈øeeke for remedies before their di≈øea≈øe: ≈øen≈øible patients, when they begin to complaine: as for fooles they will doe it, too late. Oh that wee could weepe on earth, that wee might laugh in heauen. Who would not be content to deferre his ioy a little, that it may be perpetuall, and infinite? Better that wee ≈øhould weepe with men, and laugh with Angels, then fleering with worldlings, and iolly ones, to gna≈øh and howle with Devils.
Q. What are the beginnings thereof?
Q. What is the perfection of it?

A. An eiection, or eternall ≈øeparation from the face of God, and an iniection, or ca≈øting of the Soule immediately after the fir≈øt death into hell, where there is an increa≈øing of ≈øinne, but more truely of torment, their ≈øinnes being turned into ≈øorrows, and they then finding no plea≈øure in evill; for ≈øinne being the greate≈øt mi≈øery, and mo≈øt oppo≈øite to good, cannot but be the principall part of their torment. Furthermore, a re≈øervation of the body in the graue, as in a dungeon, again≈øt the di≈ø≈øolution of the world by fire, and day of judgement, when after the re≈øurrection, both body and ≈øoule, meeting together againe, ≈øhall be ca≈øt into hell fire, where there is both an increa≈øe of ≈øinne, of the gnawing worme of con≈øcience, and torment, and from hence weeping, wayling, and gna≈øhing of teeth. Weeping is the expre≈ø≈øion of ≈øorrow, and ≈øorrow cooles the heart, and cold makes the teeth to chatter, ≈øo that their torment and mi≈øery ≈øhall be intollerable. Sinne ≈øhall increa≈øe the worme of con≈øcience and con≈øcience ≈øhall make all to ≈øympathize with it in ≈øorrow, and ≈øorrow ≈øhall be angmented by fire and cold, ≈øuch paines ≈øhall the damned indure in hell, as never eye ≈øaw, nor eare heard, nor can po≈ø≈øibly enter into the heart of man. I≈øa. 30.33. Math. 13.40.42. & 25.41. 2 The≈ø. 1.9. Rev. 20.14. The Papi≈øts neare adioyning to hell make three places more, as Limbus, of the Fathers before Chri≈øt, of Infants before Bapti≈øme, and of Purgatory for ≈øatisfaction. As a Caldron hath brimmes, and a bottome; ≈øo hell is the bottome of the Caldron, Purgatory is the middle, and the Fathers, and Infants were in the brimme. Wee ≈øay in all ≈øcalding and fiery in≈øtruments, the greate≈øt heat is in the top: but this ≈øeething Caldron,
though it did hemme in the Fathers, like the gard of a gowne, yet was it full of plea≈øure vnto them, onely infants being in the next border, had neither paine nor plea≈øure. Here is a rale of Limbus, without either welt or gard yet ≈øo plaine and palpable an error, that it confutes & confounds it ≈øelfe. God, his law, mans life, his recompence, ≈øocietie, and Sauiour, doe all exclaime again≈øt ≈øuch dreames of Limbus, and Purgatory. Fir≈øt, God deales with all mankind, either in iu≈øtice, or mercy. Secondly, his law is either broken, or kept; and of ≈øacrifices for all ≈øinnes and ≈øinners, there are none appointed for the dead. The law then whom it ca≈øts in this world, it condemnes in the world to come without redemption; and God is iu≈øt in the highe≈øt degree, and therefore takes no expiation out of his ≈øonne, and if he once admit it in his ≈øonne, he is like wi≈øe mercifull in the highe≈øt degree, and therefore ≈øends none to Purgatory or Limbus, whom he ever meanes to recall backe againe. All that po≈øteritie that was to proceed from Adam by ordinary propagation, as it ≈øhould haue had happine≈ø≈øe, if he had ≈øtood, ≈øo is it made obnoxious to all his mi≈øeries, he falling. By a rule in nature he begets children, and by a rule in divinitie he begets them ≈øinfull, and yet both naturall. It was in mans nature to doe well for him≈øelfe, and others: and ≈øo by con≈øequent, to doe evill, and convey the ≈øame to all his heires; for as naturall ≈øpirits runne along in the bloud, and are apt for generation: ≈øo originall righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, as a more divine ≈øpirit, runnes along with the whole frame, to frame it in others: now that being lo≈øt, a wor≈øe ≈øpirit of evill hauing taken vp the roome of the fir≈øt, formes men according to a ≈øinfull image. Q. By what right is ≈øinne propagated?

A. By all kinds of right; fir≈øt by the law of Nations; for Adam was a Prince of all his po≈øteritie, who covenanted with God for vs, and for him≈øelfe, for the performance of obedience, and therefore he breaking, wee brake. He was

He went as a common ≈øuretie for vs all, and on him was all our credite repo≈øed, and he was betru≈øted of God with the e≈øtate of vs all. Secondly, we haue it by the law of inheritance, he was our father, and we were his ≈øonnes, hee the roote, and we the branches, and therefore were to participate with him in all his e≈øtate. Doe we not ≈øee how children are left in good, or bad ca≈øe by their parents, and of meere relation they become their lawful heires and ≈øucce≈ø≈øors? Thirdly, by the law of divine Iu≈øtice, the perfection whereof cannot pardon the lea≈øt ≈øinne without ≈øatisfaction to euery farthing, as al≈øo by the infinitene≈ø≈øe of it that extends it ≈øelfe to euery guiltie per≈øon, and by rea≈øon of the violation of the law, and di≈øhonour of the law-giuer, deales mo≈øt ≈øtrictly and preci≈øely with euery ≈øinner. A. A. A iu≈øt imputation of the fir≈øt tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion, as al≈øo of the
fault, guilt, and puni≈øhment, and that both in ≈øinne and death. Rom. 5.12. 1 Cor. 15.21.
Q. How is originall ≈øinne propagated?
A. By our next parents, and ≈øo a≈øcending to Adam him≈øelfe. It is impo≈ø≈øible to bring a cleane thing out of filthine≈ø≈øe. Gen. 5.3. Iob 14.4.

A. In the ma≈ø≈øe and lumpe; other wi≈øe in kind euery mans actuall ≈øinne is his owne. Ezek 18.20.
Q. How death?

A. Seed and food are the principles of our life, in procreation and pre≈øervation: the fir≈øt we haue from our parents, which is deadly, as poy≈øoned with ≈øinne: the other comes from our ≈øelues, being ignorant of what ≈øhould bee good for our bodies; but be≈øide the fir≈øt death, there is a conveyance of the ≈øecond, we being borne the children of wrath; for Gods di≈øplea≈øure was kindled as well again≈øt Adams po≈øteritie, as Adam him≈øelfe.
