Thirdly, as ≈øhe was a companion with him in the ≈øame ≈øinne: they did both eate, ≈øinne, and ≈øee it at the ≈øame time. Gene≈øis 3.6.7.
Q. Was propagation then from them both?

A. Yes, immediately from them both, as their children were begotten by the mutuall knowledge of the one the other. Gen. 4.1. and 5.3. Hence Chri≈øt was not borne ≈øinnefull, becau≈øe of the holy Gho≈øts ≈øeparation, not onely of the ≈øeed of Mary, but likewi≈øe of Mary from Io≈øeph. Mary her ≈øelfe could not be without ≈øinne, becau≈øe propagated; this is onely the priviledge of her ≈øonne, who of vnholy ≈øeed by the ≈øecret operation of the Spirit, and ≈øeparation of a part
from the whole, tooke that which was mo≈øt pure and holy.

div.head: CHAPTER XXII. Of Redemption.
div.p: Que≈øtion.
HItherto of mans Apo≈øta≈øie, what is mans Ana≈øta≈øie, or returne to God againe?

An≈øw. It is the ioyfull reduction, or bringing of man againe into favour with God. Rom. 5.8.9.10. 1 The≈ø≈ø. 5.9. Here we need not doubt vnder Chri≈øt, without feare of premunire, or offence to the crowne and dignitie of the iu≈øtice of God, to affirme of faith in the merites of our Saviour, that its Gods ≈øtrong arme and power, to the enliuing and ≈øauing of euery ≈øoule. So that now with a Non ob≈øtante, we may looke vp to God in Chri≈øt, and without the law of workes, receiue a better e≈øtate by the Go≈øpell then ever we inioyed.
Q. What are the parts of our ri≈øing againe?

A. Two; Redemption, and application. Ioh. 3.14. There is a lifting vp of Chri≈øt on his Cro≈ø≈øe, and a beleeuing in him for life. ver. 16. Gods loue in giuing his ≈øonne for vs, and then application of him by the Spirit.
Q. What is Redemption?

A. A ≈øatisfaction made vnto the in≈øtice of God for man by a Redeemer. Rom. 3.24.25.26. And here comes in the ≈øpeciall worke of the ≈øecond per≈øon: thus farre wee haue gone with the Fathers worke, both in Creation & Providence; and now in a ≈øpeciall manner the Sonne doth manife≈øt him≈øelfe; for the Father can goe no further without him.

p.hi: How is it wrought?

div.p:
A. By a Mediator, who doth intercede betwixt God and
man: the Father is offended, and cannot be reconciled without ≈øome mediation. All was made vnholy when the fir≈øt Adam ≈øinned; It is the ≈øecond Adam that mu≈øt rectifie all; Mo≈øes the ≈øervant built the hou≈øe with a partition wall in the mid≈øt. Eph. 2.24. Chri≈øt the ≈øonne pulled downe that Screene, and ca≈øt all into one, bringing both Iew and Gentile into favour with God. The worke therefore is more properly a mediation then a redemption; or, a redemption by mediation. 1 Tim. 2.5.
Q. Who is the Mediator?

A. Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, both God and man, who ye≈øterday, to day, and for ever, is the Saviour of mankinde. They that were ye≈øterday, yea, from the worlds beginning, were ≈øaued by him alone, ≈øo they that liue to day, or ≈øhall come afterwards into the world, doe all expect for ≈øalvation by him. Heb. 13.8. He redeemes, becau≈øe we are captiues; he mediates, becau≈øe there is a controver≈øie betwixt God and vs, and that continually, becau≈øe Gods wrath would ever be breaking forth, except our Mediator ≈øtood in the gap for vs.
Q. Why is Chri≈øt called Ie≈øus?

A. Becau≈øe the end of his mediation was to bring vs to ≈øaluation. Mo≈øes brings the people into the wilderne≈ø≈øe: but Io≈øhna, a type of Chri≈øt, into Canaan. Mo≈øes dies in the de≈øert, and ≈øees not the promi≈øed land: ≈øhewing plainely, that the law can lead vs into de≈øolation, but Chri≈øt, and the Go≈øpell mu≈øt bring vs out of it. Zerubbabel, a Captaine of Gods people, and a type of the law, carries them out of captivitie: ≈øo the law, when it ≈øayth, Doe and liue, ≈øhewes plainely, how man may be ≈øaued: but Io≈øhua a prie≈øt, or ≈øacrificer, mu≈øt be ioyned with him, or el≈øe in Canaan it ≈øelfe, the people were to be ca≈øt out againe. The≈øe were liuely types of Chri≈øt, by whom alone wee are brought to heaven, and confirmed in the happine≈ø≈øe of it. Math. 1.21. 1 Tim. 2.5.6.
Q. Why Chri≈øt?

A. As Ie≈øus is the proper name; ≈øo this is the name of his office,
and it ≈øignifies, his anointing. Kings, Prie≈øts, and Prophets were all anointed, as types of Chri≈øt to come. Henee the name Me≈ø≈øias; in whom the materiall anointing cea≈øeth, he receiued the thing ≈øignified by it aboue all his fellowes. P≈øal. 45.7. Luk. 4.18. Act. 4.27. and 10.38. Heb. 1.9. 1 King. 19.1. Lev. 8.12. 1 King. 19.16. Both the Te≈øtaments tell vs of Chri≈øt bequeathed, and teach vs, that hee was that Chri≈øt, that is de≈øcribed in both: hence in the old Te≈øtament, we haue Prie≈øtly, Princely, and Propheticall Bookes: ≈øo in the new, the Go≈øpels are regall, ≈øhewing that Chri≈øt was that King of the Iewes. The Epi≈øtles are more ≈øacerdoticall, beginning for the mo≈øt part with prayers and ≈øupplications. And the Revelation of Saint Iohn, is meerely Propheticall. And all the≈øe are nece≈ø≈øary in Chri≈øt, to make him a complete Saviour: we ≈øtand in need of them all, and of their daily exerci≈øe.
Q. Why ≈øhould Chri≈øt be a Prophet?
A. That he might reveale vnto man the will of his Father, and be the onely Doctor of the Church. Luk. 4.18. Chri≈øt was anointed to preach the Go≈øpell. Deut. 18.15.18. Math. 21.11. Luk. 7.16.
Q. Why a Prie≈øt?

A. That he might make a full ationement with the Father for man, and reconcile vs daily vnto him, both by his expiation and interce≈ø≈øion. Math. 20.28. Luk. 4.18. 1 Ioh. 2.2. & 4.10. P≈øal. 110.4. Zech. 6.13. Heb. 5.6. & 7.3.
Q. Why a King?

A. That he might rule and governe them, whom as a Prophet he had taught, and as a Prie≈øt he had reconciled to his Father, ≈øubduing his and their enemies, and procuring them peace and pro≈øperitie continually. P≈øal. 2.6. Math. 21.5. Rev. 17.14. & 19.16.
Q. Why God and man?

A. That he might redeeme vs by paying a price ≈øufficient: as likewi≈øe being Mediator, he might communicate with both natures, which were by him to be reconciled; that being inferior to his Father as touching his manhood, and
≈øuperior to man as touching his God-head, he might the better bring both together againe. Gal. 3.20. Phil. 2.6.7. 1 Tim. 2.5. Heb. 8.6. and 9.15. and 12.24. Hence in Hebrew, the name Immanuel, and in Greeke, Theanthroopos. I≈øa. 7.14. God-man, or God with vs, and in our fle≈øh.
Q. What is here to be ob≈øerved?
A. Two things; The di≈øtinction of the≈øe two natures, and their per≈øonall vnion. Io. 1.1. The word was God. v. 14 The word was made fle≈øh. Truely God, truely man, and yet but one Mediator.
Q. What is the di≈øtinction?

A. Whereby the two natures remaine di≈øtinct in him, both in them≈øelues, and their properties. Math. 28.20. Vbiquitie is proper to the divinitie of Chri≈øt, and not his humanitie. Ioh. 16.7. Ab≈øence proper to the humane nature. 1 Tim. 3.16. God manife≈øted in the fle≈øh, not confounded with it. 1 Pet. 1.18. Dying and quickning are proper to the di≈øtinct natures of Chri≈øt. Yet this we are to vnder≈øtand, that there is a tropicall communion of properties, in regard of the whole, wherein the≈øe parts are vnited, as God dies, that is, he that is both God and man. The people thought, Chri≈øt did contradict him≈øelfe, and the Scriptures. Ioh. 12.35. Me≈ø≈øias abideth for ever, and thou ≈øaye≈øt, he dieth, &c. Both the≈øe are true, Me≈ø≈øias liueth when he dieth, and dyeth when he liueth. There was never a ≈øeparation of his two natures, though body and ≈øoule parted for a while. Wee mu≈øt therefore hold, that neither the God-head is at any time changed into the manhood, nor yet the manhood into the God-head. Luk. 24.39. 1 Pet. 4.1. Furthermore, we are to learne, that Chri≈øts humane nature is like vnto ours in all things, but in ≈øinne, and manner of ≈øub≈øi≈øting. Phil. 1.7.8. Heb. 2.17. and 4.15.
Q. What is the per≈øonall vnion of the≈øe two natures?

A. Whereby the nature a≈ø≈øuming, and nature a≈ø≈øumed make one Me≈ø≈øias, or Mediator betwixt God and man: the nature a≈ø≈øuming, is infinite, and his action is incomprehen≈øible; yet this we may ≈øafely affirme, that the ≈øecond per≈øon in
Trinitie immediately a≈ø≈øumes, and then the God-head: ≈øo that our fle≈øh is fir≈øt taken by a per≈øon, and hence our nature a≈ø≈øumed, is without all per≈øonall ≈øub≈øi≈øtence in it ≈øelfe, and is in≈øeparably conioyned with the divine nature, and doth wholly ≈øub≈øi≈øt, that is, the whole manhood ≈øub≈øi≈øts in the whole God-head; for whole God is in heauen, & whole God is on earth, becau≈øe the divine nature hath no parts, and ≈øo our fle≈øh is not in a part of the God-head, but wholly in the whole. And yet not euery where with the whole. For the a≈ø≈øumption is not by way of exten≈øion, as a forme extends his matter: but of ineffable vnion, humane nature hauing no ≈øtanding of it ≈øelfe, but by the divine nature. It is locally circum≈øcribed, as hauing quantitie, and con≈øi≈øts as a finite thing within the limites of e≈ø≈øence, being truely compounded of matter, and forme. And yet it hath neither parts, nor pa≈ø≈øions, e≈ø≈øence, or accidents, which are not a≈ø≈øumed vnto the divine nature: when body and ≈øoule were a≈øunder, and locally in diver≈øe places, then were both of them in≈øeparably knit vnto the God-head. Ioh. 1.14. Colo≈ø. 2.9. The Papi≈øts ≈øay, Chri≈øt was Mediator according to his humane nature, which is contrary to this per≈øonall vnion; for, as the per≈øon a≈ø≈øuming, giues the nature a≈ø≈øumed ≈øub≈øi≈øtence, ≈øo action, and it is not able to doe any thing without it. Therefore according to both natures, Chri≈øt redeemes, and the worke is not to be devided. Furthermore, we ≈øay the ≈øecond per≈øon a≈ø≈øumes, not the fir≈øt, for he is principally offended; not the third, for he is to te≈øtifie of the reconciliation: yet ≈øuch is the vnion that wee come by it, both to the Father, and the Spirit. For immediately the ≈øecond per≈øon a≈ø≈øumes, then the Deitie, and hauing fellow≈øhip with that, wee haue it al≈øo with the Father and Spirit. Now if the divine nature ≈øhould fir≈øt a≈ø≈øume, then would the action be the Fathers; or if the Spirit, then ≈øhould the Father haue two Sonnes, &c.

div.head: CHAPTER XXIII. Of Chri≈øts humiliation.
div.p: Que≈øtion.

p.hi: VVHat are the parts of Redemption?

div.p: An≈øwere.

Two; His humiliation, and his exaltation. P≈øal. 110.7. I≈øa. 53.12. Rom. 8.34. Eph. 4.9.10. Phil. 2.8.9. And the rea≈øon is giuen by S. Luke, chap. 24.26. Chri≈øt mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øitie, both ≈øuffer, and be glorified, &c.
Q. What is his humiliation?

A. Whereby he was made ≈øubiect to the iu≈øtice of God, to performe what≈øoever the ≈øame might require for the redemption of man. Rom. 10.4. Gal. 4.4. Heb. 7.22. Chri≈øt became our Suretie, and ≈øo bound him≈øelfe to pay all our debts. Papi≈øts ≈øay, Chri≈øt is a Mediator betweene him≈øelfe, and vs; but they are ignorant, how a ≈øinne may more peculiarly be again≈øt one per≈øon, then another; as the manhood it ≈øelfe is more properly vnited to the ≈øecond per≈øon, then any other. Chri≈øt doth principally mediate betwixt the Father and man; and yet the ju≈øtice of the whole Deitie, and con≈øequently of euery per≈øon is ≈øatisfied.
Q. What did the iu≈øtice of God require?

A. Two things; Satisfaction for the tre≈øpa≈ø≈øe, or payment of the forfaiture, and righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe an≈øwerable to the law, for the payment of the principall. The one frees vs from death; the other, brings vs to life. By the fir≈øt wee are made no ≈øinners, by the ≈øecond wee are made iu≈øt. The law ≈øtands ≈øtill in force for death, and life, ≈øinne and die, is by Chri≈øts death ≈øatisfied, doe and liue, is by his life fulfilled. Dan. 9.24. Chri≈øt reconciles to God by ≈øuffering, and of enemies makes vs friends: but wee neither de≈øerue, nor can iu≈øtly
de≈øire any thing, vntill he bring his owne righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe for vs. Rom. 4.25.
Q. Wherein con≈øi≈øts all this?

A. In the conformitie of him≈øelfe, both for him≈øelfe, and vs, to he image of God, and the law, its performing perfect obedience thereunto, as al≈øo in vnder going for his ≈øuch death and dolors as were requi≈øite. As Adam was made in the image of God, and bound to keepe the law for him≈øelfe, and vs: ≈øo Chri≈øt mu≈øt be conformed in nature to Gods image, and in all his actions to his Pathers will. He is holy and iu≈øt, both for vs, and him≈øelfe; but his ≈øufferings are onely for vs, and not him≈øelfe. And here two que≈øtions ari≈øe; fir≈øt, whether his originall righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, and actiue obedience, were onely for him≈øelfe, his pa≈ø≈øiue onely for vs, and ≈øufficient for our ≈øaluation; It may be obiected, by his bloud we are ≈øaued, &c. An≈ø: Here a part is put for the whole; for, we are ≈øaued as well by his life, as by his death, and they are both of them, both actiue and pa≈ø≈øiue. Chri≈øt ≈øuffered in being concelued, and he was no looner made man, & made vnder the law, but he began to pay for vs; for, as Adam dyed as ≈øoone as he had ≈øinned ≈øo Chri≈øt ≈øuffered as ≈øoone as he became our ≈øuretie; therefore his whole life & death are for vs, and our payment. He that dies by the law is not acquitted, or iu≈øtified, but condemned. He that makes fal≈øe Lature may be pardoned, or puni≈øhed, but not iu≈øtified. Euery law acquits, when men are found to haue done nothing again≈øt it: but it moreouer rewards, when ≈øubiects are found to performe the vtmo≈øt required by it. Chri≈øt therefore is to ≈øuffer and ≈øatisfie; but that will not iu≈øtifie vs, except further be found in him, that he hath done nothing again≈øt the law, nay, al≈øo that he hath to the height and ful mea≈øure fulfilled it. We haue need both of originall and actuall righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe to bring vs to heauen, and out of him it is not to befound. The ≈øecond controuer≈øie is about the ≈øecond death, which is the puni≈øhment of the damned, and therefore not fit for Chri≈øt to ≈øuffer. Concerning this we acknowledge that Chri≈øt did not, neither could truely, and properly ≈øuffer the ≈øecond death, which is a ca≈øting out and bani≈øhment from ble≈ø≈øedne≈ø≈øe, and the
fauour of God. God forbid that any Chri≈øtian ≈øhould haue ≈øuch a thought of our Lord Chri≈øt, who euer ≈øince his conception was „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , and could not be other for any moment of time. He and his Father were neuer ≈øeparated in loue and affection; becau≈øe Chri≈øt, even in vnder going of this, obeyed his Father: yet were they for a time ≈øeparated in apprehen≈øion, and repre≈øentation, God puni≈øhing his Sonne iu≈øtly for vs, in as much as he ≈øtood in our ≈øtead. Whiles Chri≈øt ≈øuffered bodily dolors he neuer complained. I≈øa. 53.7. No thornes, no nailes, fetcht bloud from him with ≈øo much paine, as his owne thoughts, My ≈øoule is heauie, &c. My God why ha≈øt thou for≈øaken me? Oh, what man, or Angell can conceiue the taking of that heart, that without all outward violence, meerely, out of extremitie of his owne pa≈ø≈øion, bled, through the fle≈øh and skin, not ≈øome faint dew, but ≈øolide drops of bloud. If I bee asked, how the ≈øonne of God (very God) who≈øe humane ≈øoule was euer hypo≈øtatically & in≈øeparably vnited to the Godhead, could be ca≈øt vpon ≈øo fearefull an obiect, and bereft of the fruition of heauenly ioy? I an≈øwere, that the cau≈øe of this was „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , the re≈øting of the Deity from actuall and comfortable influence, into the humanitie, or the holding in for a time the beames of that glorious divine light, a kinde of veyle being drawne betweene them, not of reall ≈øeparation, for that is impo≈ø≈øible, but of actuall interpo≈øition, or imputation of the cur≈øed e≈øtate of tho≈øe, whom he was fir≈øt to repre≈øent, and then to redeeme by ≈øuch performance for them. Hereto we mu≈øt adde how his ≈øufferings were aggravated by his fulne≈ø≈øe of knowledge, and want of comfort. He did not ≈øhut his eyes, when he drunke the bitter and dreggi≈øh cup of his Cro≈ø≈øe. We read of Theodorus, a Martyr, that when he had hanged tenne houres vpon theracke for Religion, his ioynts di≈øtended, and di≈øtorted, &c. felt no paine at all, becau≈øe be was comforted by an Angel, who in the forme of a yong man wiped off his ≈øweat with a cleane to well, and powred coole water upon his racked limbes, &c. But Chri≈øt when he ≈øuffered found none to comfort him, no, none to pittie him. Not
an Angell dare be ≈øeene to looke out of the windowes of heaven to relieue him, whiles the Father will ≈ømite him. And ≈øurely, if Chri≈øt had not here wre≈øtled for vs, his other death vpon the Cro≈ø≈øe had never ≈øaved vs from the wrath of God torments of Devils, and fire of hell. His conformitie with God in holine≈ø≈øe, is expre≈ø≈øed. Luk. 1.35. in obedience. Ioh. 5.30. Rom. 5.19. and 10.4. In ≈øuffering. Phil. 2.8. Heb. 5.8. Math. 26.37. Mark. 14.34. Luk. 22.44. Math. 27.46. And that it was both actiue and pa≈ø≈øiue, is plaine, by the eating of the pa≈øchall Lambe. Exod. 12. with ≈øweet bread, and ≈øowre hearbs.
Q. How many parts are there of his humiliation?

A. Two; His life and death: there is nothing in the whole hi≈øtory of Chri≈øts life and death, but it makes for vs, all our liuing and dying, ≈øeruing for no better v≈øe, but to make vs mi≈øerable. Phil. 2.7.8. Ioh. 10.11. and 18.37. He did liue to beare witne≈ø≈øe to the truth of ≈øalvation, and died to ≈øeale it with his bloud. Heb. 9.16.17.18.
Q. What was his life?

A. His willing vnder-going of the mi≈øeries of this life for vs, and the full ≈øanctification of ours in all points; from the ≈øeparation of the ≈øeed, to the ≈øeparation of his Soule, he liued for vs, and our good. He begins to liue where we begin to die, that is, in the mothers wombe, and to ≈øanctifie vs, where we begin to be vncleane. Heb. 2.14.15.16.17.18.
Q. What are the parts of his life?

A. His being in the mothers wombe, and his being out of it. Our originall is polluted by propagation, and our whole life by an evill conver≈øation, he mu≈øt therefore beginne to clean≈øe and cleare the fountaine, and make all the ≈øtreames ≈øweet by his pa≈ø≈øage thorow them. Luk. 2.6.7.
Q. What are the parts of his life, being yet in his mothers wombe?

A. His conception, and nativitie. Wee are polluted in both, our very warming is a di≈øpo≈øing of vs to a ≈øinfull conception and birth. P≈øal. 51.1. Chri≈øt therefore mu≈øt be both
conceiued and borne for vs. I≈øa. 7.14. Luk. 1.31.32.33. Math. 1.18.
Q. What is his conception?

A. Whereby he was made of the ≈øeed of the Virgin, taken out of the re≈øt of the ma≈ø≈øe, and ≈øanctified by the holy Gho≈øt, after that ≈øhe was betrothed vnto Ie≈øeph, and before they came together. The conception is without generation, that there might be no conveyance of originall ≈øinne vnto Chri≈øt, and by ≈øeparation in the Virgin, that Chri≈øt might be borne of holy ≈øeed. Ier. 31.22. Luk. 27.34.35.
Q. How was his ≈øoule created and adorned?

A. Immediately of nothing, and infu≈øed with great perfection, but not ≈øo ab≈øolute, as that it receiued no after increa≈øe of knowledge, and wi≈øedome. Luk. 2.40.52. He increa≈øed as well with God as man; and therefore he receiued not all at once, to manife≈øt afterwards, as need required. He by his actions did merite vnto him≈øelfe a further augmentation of gifts.
Q. What is his nativitie, or birth?

A. Whereby he was borne of the Virgin Mary, who was of the hou≈øe of Dauid. Hence Chri≈øt is the Sonne of the ten Fathers of all the world, more e≈øpecially, of Abraham and Dauid, being peculiar types of Chri≈øt. Abraham had the promi≈øe renued vnto him, by calling him out of Chaldea into Canaan, a type of heaven, where Circumci≈øion, a badge of ≈øeparation was in≈øtituted, & the Church brought more particularly into one Nation, that the line & lineage of the Me≈ø≈øias might the better be knowne; afterwards it comes to Dauid, who≈øe kingdome was made a more peculiar type of Chri≈øt. Furthermore, Mary was heire of the kingdome of the Iewes, hence Chri≈øt was borne King of the lewes. Mat. 2.2. the Wi≈øe men aske for a borne King, not for Herod the v≈øurper. Againe, ≈øhee was to marry with one of the kindred, to pre≈øerue the ≈øeed of Dauid, and therefore ≈øhee was betrothed to Io≈øeph by name, and one of the ≈øame familie, but not as yet married vnto him: ≈øo that Chri≈øt was both by nature, and law, lawfull heire of
the kingdome, though he never came the ordinary way. Math. 1. ver. 1. to the end. The Genealogie is devided into three ≈øeverall foureteene generations; becau≈øe of a threefold change of government. Fir≈øt, in the Patriarkes. Secondly, in the Kings. Thirdly, in the Dukes. The Regall began with Dauid, and ended in Ieconias. Ier. 22.30. And ≈øo from Salomons po≈øteritie was tran≈ølated to the po≈øteritie of Nathan. Ezek. 21.26. And the Crowne changed into a Diademe, which had a threefold over-turne before it came to the right heire. Ezek. 21.27. Fir≈øt, in the Maccabees. Secondly, in the Prie≈øts. Thirdly, in Herod. In all this time Dauids po≈øteritie liued in private, and Chri≈øt found the Scepter cleane gone. Whiles the fooli≈øh lewes gloried in their Temple, the Lord de≈øtroyed it, to ≈øhew them, that it was not an earthly but a ≈øpirituall Temple, that he regarded; and remoued the government from Dauid, and from Iudah to Leui, and then to a very ≈øtranger, an Edomite, checking them very often, before his birth, for their vaine conceit, both of Church and Common-wealth. And yet it ≈øeemes Chri≈øt had ≈øome con≈øanguinitie, both with the Princely and Prie≈øtly progenie. Luk. 1.36. he came to ≈øaue of all ≈øorts of men, and therefore ≈øpread farre in his race. That law Num. 36.7. did not limit the Tribe of Levi. Exod. 6.23. 1 Chron. 22.11.
Q. What is the hi≈øtory of his life, being out of his mothers wombe?

A. It is either his priuate, or publicke life. This was ≈øhadowed out in the Leuites, who might not mini≈øter at the Altar, till they were thirtie yeares old. Num. 4.3. At twentie yeares, the I≈øraelites might goe to warre: but greater maturitie is required in Gods mini≈øters, who ≈øerue publickly at his Altar. And our ble≈ø≈øed Sauiour, who would fulfil euery type, mini≈øtred not till he was thirtie yeere old. Luk. 3.23. yet all the time of his private life, he liued for vs, even to ≈øanctifie vnto vs, as well our dayes ≈øpent in private as publicke.
Q. What are the parts of his private life?

A. His infancie, and time of ≈øubiection to his parents, both needfull for vs, ≈øeeing wee offend God being Children, as well as in the yeares of di≈øcretion. Infants are no innocents before God, but even then provokers of GODS wrath, though they haue not wit to ≈øinne with ≈øo high an hand again≈øt God as others. Luk. 2.7.51.
Q. What is revealed concerning his infancie?

A. His Circumci≈øion, oblation, and flight into Aegypt. As a Iew he was to vnder-goe the Ceremonies that belonged vnto them, yea, and to put an end vnto them. He was circumci≈øed in his private life, liuing then as a Iew; baptized at his entrance into his publicke, becau≈øe he did then put forth him≈øelfe more openly to be the Me≈ø≈øias of the whole world. Luk. 2.21.22.23.24.
Q. What is meant by his Circumci≈øion?

A. He was circumci≈øed, not becau≈øe he needed that him≈øelfe, as if corruption had beene in him, which mu≈øt be cut off by mortification: but for that he was to fulfill the righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe thereof, and put an end to all ceremonies, and to ≈øhew that the force of that Sacrament, which did ≈øcale vnto the Fathers their reconciliation with God depended on him, and that in him was found, that which ought to be in euery circumci≈øed per≈øon, a pure and an vndefiled heart. Luk. 2.21. It was not onely a ≈øeale, or ≈øigne of righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, but al≈øo a bond, or obligation of fulfilling the law. Rom. 4.11. with Rom. 2.25. Gal. 5.3. Chri≈øt therefore being circumci≈øed, bound him≈øelfe to keepe the law, both for vs and him≈øelfe. This importable yoke was layd vpon his necke. Act. 15.10. 2 Cor. 5.21. Hence, at his circumci≈øion he had his name Ie≈øus, for by binding him≈øelfe to the law, he ≈øaued vs. Act. 4.12. There were two that had this name in the old Te≈øtament, the one, a Magi≈øtrate, the other, a mini≈øter. And the fir≈øt had his name changed when he was ≈øent as a ≈øpie into Canaan. Num. 15.16 from O≈øhea to Ieho≈øhua. From let God ≈øaue, to God ≈øhall ≈øaue. Vnder the law (which brings vs, as it were, into a wilderne≈ø≈øe) we may de≈øire, wi≈øh, and pray, that there
were a Saviour; but vnder the Go≈øpell, wee are ≈øure of ≈øalvation, and that our Ieho≈øhua hath bound him≈øelfe to fulfill all righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe for vs.
Q. What is meant by his offering?

A. It was to ≈øhew, that he indeed was the fir≈øt borne that was to be dedicated to the Lord, whereof all others were but types. Luk. 2.22.23.24. Lev. 21.1.2.3.4.5. &c. is ≈øet downe both the ≈øeparation and purification of women. The one, in regard of originall ≈øinne, the other, in regard of actuall. The Ma≈ø≈øe ≈øeparates from God, and yet when the forgiuene≈ø≈øe of that is ≈øealed by circumci≈øion, yet ≈øtill remaines a daily purification. After the Leper was wa≈øhed, he was to ≈øhaue off his hayre, ≈øhewing how the ≈øuperfluities of ≈øinne were daily to be purged away. Furthermore, becau≈øe the female was more moy≈øt then the male, there was a longer time pre≈øcribed for the one, then the other. The ≈øeparation for a male was ≈øeven dayes, for a female foureteene. The purification for a man child, thirtie three dayes for the woman, ≈øixtie ≈øixe. Now Mary needed neither of the≈øe, for Chri≈øt was borne free from all ≈øinne, both originall and actuall, he was the holy of holies. Dan. 9.24. yet becau≈øe he was our Suretie, his mother was ≈øeparated ≈øeven dayes, and he was circumci≈øed the eighth, and when ≈øhe had accompli≈øhed thirtie-three dayes of purification, he was pre≈øented vnto God, all this was to ≈øhew that her ≈øeed tooke vpon him all our debt, and was content that his Father ≈øhould impute vnto him, both our originall and actuall ≈øinne, and that by him wee ≈øhould be purified from both. Rom. 7.18. That which dwells in vs is laid vpon him: his offering was a paire of turtles, to ≈øhew that innocency that was in him, and ought to be in his Church. He offered not the Lambe, becau≈øe the ≈øub≈øtance being there, the ≈øhadow was to vani≈øh; as al≈øo that he became poore for our ≈øakes. Againe, he was pre≈øented, as the fir≈øt borne, to ≈øanctifie all others, and pre≈øerue them aliue. Exod. 12.29. Aegypts fir≈øt borne was ≈ømitten, becau≈øe they wanted the blood of the Lambe. And as types of Chri≈øt ever after, the fir≈øt
borne were either con≈øecrated, or redeemed. Exod. 13.15. Num. 3.12. Of bea≈øts, onely the vncleane were redeemed, the re≈øt ≈øacrificed. Num. 18.15. And of men, God would haue all redeemed. Chri≈øt therefore in all con≈øecrations was typified, as the price of euery mans redemption, being before God vncleane; yea, the very ≈øtrength of man. Gen 49 3. could not ≈øtand out with the wrath of God; but for this that Chri≈øt hath ran≈øomed it. Math. 20.28. Ioh. 17.19. Furthermore, the fir≈øt borne had a right aboue all the re≈øt. Deut. 21.17. And they were to depend vpon their elder brother. Gen. 25.31. and 27.36. and 49.3. Hence Chri≈øt Math. 1.15. Luk. 2.7. is called that fir≈øt borne, and Rom. 8.29. among≈øt many brethren. Yea, ≈øets him aboue Kings, P≈øal. 89.27. Nay, the very Angels. Heb. 1.6. P≈øal. 97.7. And he alone by right may aske for the ends of the earth to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe them. P≈øal. 2.8. he is heire of all. Heb. 1.2. and hath power to make vs ≈øonnes. Ioh. 1.12. and fellow-heires with him≈øelfe. Rom. 8.17.
Q. What is meant by his flight into Aegypt?

A. That he might therein al≈øo fulfill the type and prophecie of God, in calling his ≈øonne out of Aegypt; and that therein wee might learne, how he was to de≈øcend into ≈øpirituall Aegypt, to beare our labours and ≈øtripes, and bring vs out of thraldome and bondage into ≈øpirituall Canaan. Math. 2.13.14. I≈ørael was borne in Canaan, went downe into Aegypt, and came backe againe triumphantly. They went downe voluntarily and freely, but returned by force of Armes: ≈øo we that were the ≈øonnes of God by Creation, and placed in Paradi≈øe, left our ≈øtanding with God freely, and went downe into the kingdome of darkene≈ø≈øe, and are brought backe againe by the infinite power of God in Chri≈øt. Exod. 4.22. I≈ørael was not Gods ≈øonne by nature but grace; therefore mu≈øt the naturall ≈øonne of God enter into the Aegypt of this world, to reduce poore Captiues to their auncient liberties. I≈ørael was in Aegypt in the time of her infancie; Adam went downe too vpon the day of his Creation, or not long after, and therefore Chri≈øt to an≈øwere both, went
downe being an Infant. Againe, Chri≈øt after many admirable te≈øtimonies of his royall birth, will fall backe againe into wonderfull ob≈øcuritie, to ≈øhew plainely, how our pride was to be expiated. And here Mo≈øes is a liuely type of Chri≈øt. Mo≈øes by flight e≈øcaped Pharaohs rage, and returned againe when they were dead that ≈øought his life, and became a deliuerer: So, Chri≈øt e≈øcaped the butchery of Herod, came backe againe when his enemies were dead, and became I≈øraels happy deliuerer. His infancy was mo≈øt ≈øpent in Aegypt, as being our mo≈øt vnprofitable time; but his education mu≈øt be in Canaan: but not as a King in Ieru≈øalem, P≈øal. 110.2. or Bethlehem, Dauids citie. Mic. 5.2. but in greater ob≈øcuritie, befitting his humiliation, in Nazaret, a place both ba≈øe and wicked. Ioh. 7.52. with 1.46. Hence he was called a Nazarite, by which name the Devils di≈øgraced him. Mar. 1.24. Scribes and Phari≈øees reiected him. Ioh. 7.52. Act. 6.14. and the Iewes ≈øcorned him. Math. 26.71. Ioh. 18.5.7. and 19.19. And yet holy Angels, that better knew the my≈øtery, did adore him in it. Mar. 16.6. And vnder it was he preached. Act. 2.22. and 4.10. And the godly beleeued in him. Mar. 10.47. Neyther is our Saviour a≈øhamed of it in his glory. Act. 22.8. The rea≈øon of the name is abundantly te≈øtified of by the Prophets. Nazer, or Nezer, is an ornament giuen to the Nazarites, hie Prie≈øt, & Princes, whereby they are di≈øtingui≈øhed from the vulgar. Nazarites that gaue them≈øelues to God by vow, had the bu≈øh of their hayre called Nezer, Num. 6.7.8. The high Prie≈øt had Nezer vpon his head. Exod. 29.6. And as the former were holy to the Lord as long as they kept on their lock, ≈øo was holine≈ø≈øe written vpon this, Exod. 39.30. And the very oyle that did con≈øeerate it, is called Nezer, Lev. 21.12. So the Crowne vpon the Kings head is called by the ≈øame name. 2 Sam. 1.10. 2 King. 11.12. P≈øal. 89.39. Chri≈øt therefore being called a Nazarite, is ≈øeparate from all others, as mo≈øt holy, and is our true Prince and Prie≈øt, P≈øal. 2.2.6. and 110.4. Furthermore, he is called a Nazarite, as was Io≈øeph, Gen. 49.26.
Deut. 33.16. that is, one ≈øeparate to be a pre≈øerver of his brethren. Io≈øeph was a long time ob≈øcured, before hee was brought forth to feed the fami≈øhed: ≈øo, Chri≈øt did lie hid a long time in this citie, before he ≈øteps forth to his publicke function. On Chri≈øt ≈øhall Nezer flouri≈øh. P≈øal. 132.18. Samp≈øon, who≈øe haire was faire and ≈øtrong, Iudg. 13.25. and who liuing, and dying, devoured his enemies, is a royall type of Chri≈øt. Luk. 11.22. But Nezer thus taken, is with Zam; it is al≈øo written with Zade, which ≈øignifies a branch, and ≈øo indeed Chri≈øt is called, I≈øa. 11.1. Al≈øo Zemach, which ≈øignifies the ≈øame, Ier. 23.5. and 33.14. Zech. 6.12. and 3.8. I≈øa. 4.2. In the tribe of Nephtali, was there a Citie called Hazar, or Enhazar, Io≈øh. 19.37. And by contraction Nazar, from whence Nazareth might be deriued, a Citie of ≈øprigs and branches: that place in Io≈øhua called Cinereth, afterwards was called Genezar, or Ge-nezareth, the valley of branches: ≈øo Chri≈øt being the true branch of Dauid, would grow in this Citie, and afterwards put forth him≈øelfe as our Me≈ø≈øias. By all this we ≈øee, that eyther place, or per≈øons giues vs an apt rea≈øon of this derivation, as ≈øufficeth to fulfill the Prophecie.
Q. What is written of the time of his life, wherein he liued ≈øubiect to his Parents?
A. Two things; fir≈øt, his di≈øpute with the Doctors at Ieru≈øalem, when he was twelue yeeres old: ≈øecondly, his labouring with his hands. Luk. 2.42.49.51.
Q. What is meant by his di≈øpute with the Doctors?

A. It was (as it were) the giuing notice before hand of his publicke calling, and that he was the true Rabbi, or Doctor that come from God. Luk. 2.46.47. The children of the Iewes had a double education, fir≈øt, at home, Exod. 12.26. Deut. 4.10. and 6.7. ≈øecond, in the Schooles, 1 Sam. 10.5.10. 2 King. 2.3. and 4.38. Act. 22.3. 2 Tim. 3.15. Chri≈øt at home did both teach, and was taught. Luk. 2.49. to ≈øanctifie our private education, and in≈øtruction; but for the more exact teaching, Chri≈øt had none. Ioh. 7.15. Mar. 6.2. to ≈øhew, that he needed not to learne of man, and yet hee
entred into the Schoole at twelue yeeres, both to ≈øanctifie that profe≈ø≈øion, as likewi≈øe to ≈øhew him≈øelfe to be the great Doctor that was ≈øhortly to come into the world; and had no need to learne of any other. Iohn 1 18, and 7.16.
Q. What meant his labouring with his hands?

A. That he might al≈øo beare our cur≈øe, who were with the ≈øweat of our browes to eate our bread. Gen. 3.19. The word, ≈øubiect to his parents, Luk. 2.51. ≈øignifies, to be ordered, and governed by another in outward Arts, and Sciences. Math. 13.55. with Mar. 6.3. He was not onely the Carpenters ≈øonne, but the Carpenter, and therefore ver≈øe 2. they were offended at him. He was neither brought vp in the Temple, as was Samuel; nor among the Phari≈øees, as was Paul at the feet of Gamaliel; neither in the wilderne≈ø≈øe among≈øt the E≈ø≈øees, &c. All which might haue gained him ≈øome authoritie among≈øt his owne; but with Io≈øeph a Carpenter, in a mo≈øt ob≈øcure village. All this might well ≈øhew his humilitie for our good, as likewi≈øe ≈øhew vs that the builder of the world, Heb. 1.2. and 11.10. was now come to repaire the decayes of it, and even to ≈øanctifie vnto vs the meane≈øt trade and calling in the world. Furthermore, be≈øide bodily labour for the ≈øpace of eight-teene yeares, Chri≈øt did wonderfully increa≈øe, Luk. 2.52. with 40. Ioh. 1.14. and by rea≈øon of the Hypo≈øtaticall vnion, had all fulne≈ø≈øe dwelling in him. Cel. 2.9. yet this hid it ≈øelfe for a time, 2 Cor. 8.9. Phil. 2.7.8. So that que≈øtion is iu≈øtly moued, whether there was a reall increa≈øe of wi≈øedome, ≈øtature, and grace, or onely an apparent and vi≈øible declaration of that which was in Chri≈øt from his very fir≈øt ≈øub≈øi≈øting, and being in our fle≈øh? The auncient Diuines lea≈øt they ≈øhould derogate from the hypo≈øtaticall vnion, thought the increa≈øe to be in outward effects, no inward habites. Yet body and ≈øoule, being finite receiued according to mea≈øure, and manner: and as the one increa≈øed in quantitie, ≈øo the other in qualitie; the wi≈øedome of the Soule, as the ≈øtature of the body, receiuing a daily augmentation.
He is ≈øayd to grow inwardly as well as outwardly, and to learne by his owne actions, Heb. 5.8. And we know that frequent actions require habites, or at lea≈øt, a further perfection of infu≈øed gifts and graces; and que≈øtionle≈ø≈øe, all this time of eight-teene yeares labour, he according to the increa≈øe of grace, became gracious in his calling; for the Text ≈øaith, both with God and men he manife≈øted a wonderfull thriuing in goodne≈ø≈øe.
Q. What is his publicke life?

A. Wherein he more publickly declared him≈øelfe to be that Me≈ø≈øias, which was ≈øo long before expected and looked for. He had hither to beene hid in the chips; but now being poli≈øhed and perfitted, he comes forth and provokes the adver≈øarie to ≈øet vpon him. Mar. 1.9. Math. 3.13. Luk. 3.21.30.
Q. What the parts thereof?

A. His initiation, cour≈øe, and conclu≈øion; his ingre≈ø≈øe, progre≈ø≈øe, and egre≈ø≈øe. Chri≈øt doth not abruptly ≈øet vpon the cour≈øe of his calling, but makes an excellent preparation vnto it. Act. 1.22.
Q. What is to be con≈øidered in his very entrance?
A. His Bapti≈øme, with his temptation and fa≈øting. Math. 3.13. and 4.1. Mar. 1.12. Luk. 4.1.

p.hi: What is meant by his Bapti≈øme?

div.p: A. He was baptized as he was circumci≈øed, not for any need he had thereof in him≈øelfe, who needed no wa≈øhing, but to ≈øanctifie our Bapti≈øme, and to ≈øhew both by his circumci≈øion and bapti≈øme, that he was the band and knot of both Couenants, the end of the old and beginning of the new. Luk. 3.21. When all the people were baptized, Chri≈øt al≈øo was baptized, ≈øo hee had many witne≈ø≈øes; he was baptized in Iorden, for there the people pa≈ø≈øed over into Canaan. Io≈øh. 3.17. And now was he come that gaue pa≈ø≈øage into heauen, &c.
Q. What is meant by his fa≈øting?

A. His holy preparation to his after temptation; wee by eating ≈øurfeited of ≈øinne, and he will beginne to cure vs with ab≈øtinence; our ≈øuper fluitie, by his fortie dayes emptines,
according to the old rule; Hunger cures the di≈øea≈øes of gluttonie. His cour≈øe of cure was wonderfull, not by giuing vs receits, but by taking our receits for vs, &c. Math. 4.2.
Q What is the meaning of his temptation?

That whereas the fir≈øt Adam encountring with the Devill was overcome: ≈øo the ≈øecond oppo≈øing him≈øelfe to the conflict, might overcome him for vs, and wee through him in our fights, Mat. 4.1. to 13. All the while Chri≈øt lay ≈øtill in his Fathers ≈øhop, and medled onely with the Carpenters chips, the Devill troubled him not; but now that he is declared the Sonne of God, & ≈øolemnly inve≈øted into the office of Mediator≈øhip, and goes about to di≈ø-throne him, and to ca≈øt him out of his kingdome, now he bends all his forces again≈øt him. The two Purgatories of a Chri≈øtian, are Repentance and Temptation, and wee are no ≈øooner come out of the one, but we mu≈øt looke to enter into the other. If we haue pa≈ø≈øed the waters of Repentance, wee mu≈øt looke to be ca≈øt into the fire of Temptation. No ≈øooner is I≈ørael out of Aegypt, then Pharaoh pur≈øues them, and if he be drowned, yet will the Amalekites vexe them: yet here is our comfort, that Chri≈øt hath borne the heat of the day, and that wee in him ≈øhall be able to hold out the re≈øt of the conflict.
Q. What is meant by his publicke cour≈øe?

A. A diligent teaching by his forerunner Iohn Bapti≈øt, him≈øelfe, and his Di≈øciples, as al≈øo a continuall working of miracles, that he might bring the Iewes to an acknowledgement of God, and him≈øelfe, being ≈øent from God. Ioh. 1.6.7. Luk. 4.15. Ioh. 2.23. Math. 10.7.8. Luk. 10.9. Act. 2.22.

p.hi: What is the fini≈øhing thereof?

div.p:
A. His pa≈ø≈øion, and crucifying, ≈øo the Creed concludes his life by a generall & particular; Pa≈ø≈øion is generall to both, yet as the ca≈øe ≈øtood, Pa≈ø≈øion is limited to Pilate, Crucifying is left indifferent, as well to expre≈ø≈øe Gods hand vpon him, and power of darkne≈ø≈øe, as of his other per≈øecutors: but the truth is, pa≈ø≈øion and action runne along from the one end to the other of his humiliation. Pa≈ø≈øion is, as the
ca≈øe ≈øtands betwixt God and Chri≈øt, and Chri≈øt and his per≈øecutors: action, as betweene God and vs, and vs and Chri≈øt. Chri≈øt is a patient as he ≈øuffers for vs at the hands of his Father, devils, and men; and an agent as he becomes our Suretie, and reconciles vs to God. P≈øal. 69.4. He re≈øtored that which he tooke not away. Act. 2.23. & 4.27.
Q. Keeping then the generall and particular tearme, what is his pa≈ø≈øion?
A. His ≈øuffering vnder Pontius Pilate, with the re≈øt of his per≈øecuters, who brought him vpon the ≈øtage, that God might puni≈øh him for our ≈øakes. Act. 4.27.28.
Q. What is hereto be con≈øidered?
A. His preparation vnto death, and expo≈øing of him into the hands of the wicked. Math. 26.2.17.36.47.
Q. What is the preparation?
A. Whereby Chri≈øt being to giue his la≈øt farewell vnto nature, prepares and makes ready him≈øelfe for death. Luk. 22.15.

p.hi: Wherein con≈øi≈øts it?

div.p: A. In the eating of the Pa≈ø≈øeover, and his agonie in the Garden, he begins his Pa≈ø≈øion with the Pa≈ø≈øeover; for the Pa≈øchall Lambe was a more particular type of his ≈øuffering, and from that time the Devill began to worke in Iudas, and the Iewes, and it was the fitte≈øt, becau≈øe at ≈øuch publicke times, malefactors were executed, that all might the better know the ≈øinne and be in≈øtructed, &c. This the high Prie≈øt and his followers, thought to be a very convenient time to let the people know Chri≈øts bla≈øphemie, as al≈øo to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe his Doctrine, ≈øo much by them dete≈øted. Math. 26.20.36.
Q. What is meant by Chri≈øts keeping of the Pa≈ø≈øeover?

A. That he was the Lambe ≈øignified in the Pa≈ø≈øeover, and that now was the time wherein he was al≈øo to put an end to the ≈øame by him≈øelfe, and therefore in place thereof he in≈øtituted the Sacrament of his la≈øt Supper. Luk. 22.14.15.16.17.18.19.20.
Q. What is meant by his Agonie?

A. His grieuous conflict with him≈øelfe about the vnder-going of his Pa≈ø≈øion, when in the Garden he ≈øweating drops of bloud,
cryed vnto his Father once and againe, that if it were po≈ø≈øible, the cup might pa≈ø≈øe from him, and in the end he was heard and comforted, Math. 26.36. Luk. 24.42.43.44. Heb. 5.7.
Q. What is his expo≈øing vnto iudgement?

A. The la≈øt act of his humiliation, wherein he was to vndergoe the greate≈øt penaltie for our ≈øinne, at the hands of ≈øinners them≈øelues; and therefore is put in Scripture for the whole worke of our Redemption. The Iewes choo≈øe a time wherein they might put our ble≈ø≈øed Saviour to the greate≈øt ≈øhame; a time of the greate≈øt frequence, and concour≈øe of all Iewes and Pro≈øelytes: an holy time, when they ≈øhould receiue the figure, they reiect the ≈øub≈øtance: when they ≈øhould kill and eate the Sacramentall Lambe, in faith, in thankfulne≈ø≈øe, they hill the Lambe of God, our true Pa≈ø≈øeover, in crueltie and contempt, &c. I≈øa. 53.3.
Q. What are the degrees of this his expo≈øing vnto iudgement?

A. The fir≈øt is his apprehen≈øion in the Garden, by Iudas, and a company of armed men, ≈øent from the chiefe Prie≈øts and Elders of the people, Math. 26.47. Luk. 22.47. Ioh. 18.3. Adam began our mi≈øery in a Garden, and there will Chri≈øt begin to ≈øuffer for vs. It is probable, that it was one of Salomons Gardens, the plea≈øures whereof he ≈øanctified by paines, and fulfilled the type of comming to his Garden. Can. 5.1.
Q. Why was Chri≈øt thus apprehended?

A. That he being in our ≈øtead, might vnder goe the greater contumelie and reproach, de≈øerved by vs; for they came with billes and ≈øtaues to take him, as if he had beene the greate≈øt Malefactor that ever was. Math. 26.55.
Q. What is the ≈øecond degree?

A. His arraignment before the Eccle≈øia≈øticall and politicke Magi≈øtrate, as if he had broken all lawes, and de≈øerued puni≈øhment at euery judgement ≈øeat. And all this was done to ≈øhew vs what wretches wee were in Gods ≈øight, and how he ≈øhould haue proceeded again≈øt vs, who by meanes of his Sonne are pardoned, that wee might never ≈øee our iu≈øt condemnation, otherwi≈øe then wee ≈øee it acted in our
Suretie, he was po≈øted from Caiaphas to Pilate, from Pilate to Herod, and backe againe from Herod to Pilate, by whom he was both iu≈øtified and condemned. God running along with the whole Tragedie, and ≈øhewing plainely by Iudge Pilate, that Chri≈øt was not to die for him≈øelfe, but for vs, the iu≈øt ≈øuffering for the vniu≈øt, Mat. 26.57. and 27. 2. Luk. 23.7.8. Math. 27.4.19.24.
Q. What was the third degree?

A. The mo≈øt mi≈øerable deri≈øion and whipping of him that ever was heard tell off; he was to encounter both paine and ≈øcorne for vs. An ingenuous and noble nature, can wor≈øe brooke this then the other; any thing rather then di≈ødainfulne≈ø≈øe, & imperious in ≈øultation: e≈øpecially, from ≈øo ba≈øe enemies. The Iewes, the Souldiers, yea, the very theeues flouted and taunted him, and triumph over his mi≈øery; his blood cannot ≈øatisfie them, without his reproch. Math. 26.67.68. and 27.28.29.30.31. Oh, that wee could imitate the Iewes in their cu≈øtome concerning evill doers; they had ever ≈øome malefactor brought forth to them in their great Fea≈øt, which they di≈ømi≈ø≈øed with di≈øgrace; ≈øo it ≈øhould bee the happie≈øt peece of our triumph and ≈øolemnitie, if wee could bring forth that wicked prophanene≈ø≈øe, wherewith wee haue di≈øhonoured God, and blemi≈øht his Go≈øpell, to be ≈øcourged, and ≈øent away with all holy indignitie. See thy Sauiour ≈øcourged and beaten for thee, and ≈øee if thou can≈øt finde in thy heart to fauour, or cheeri≈øh the lea≈øt ≈øinne.
Q. What is his crucifying?

A. After all the≈øe abu≈øes he is put to the mo≈øt accur≈øed death of the Cro≈ø≈øe, a kind of puni≈øhment ioyntly with the other, inflicted vpon none but ≈øuch as were offenders in the highe≈øt degree, and euery one was held mo≈øt accur≈øed that ≈øo died, to ≈øhew, that he ≈øuffered for offenders of the greate≈øt ≈øtaine and ≈øtraine, and ≈øo to beare our cur≈øe vpon him. Phil. 2.8. Gal. 3.12.13. Deut. 21.23.
Q. Did he ≈øuffer onely the≈øe outward afflictions?

A. He ≈øuffered the≈øe as iudgements for ≈øinne; therefore were
they ≈øo much the more bitter; and whiles he was on the cro≈ø≈øe tho≈øe three houres of darkene≈ø≈øe, he was a≈ø≈øayled with all the powers of darkene≈ø≈øe, ≈øo that he felt in his ≈øoule and body vnvtterable angui≈øhes, even the effects or apprehen≈øion of the mo≈øt feareful wrath of God, ≈øo that it made him cry out, My God, my God, &c. and when that was over, as hauing felt therein the mo≈øt bitter paines of all his ≈øufferings, he ≈øaid it was fini≈øhed. Math. 27.45.46. Ioh. 19.30.
Q. What might this meane?

A. That he was for the time reputed as one ≈øeparated from God, which is the ≈øecond death; for as the fir≈øt death is the reparation of the ≈øoule from the body, the beginning of our naturall life: ≈øo the ≈øecond death is the ≈øeparation of both body and ≈øoule from God, the beginning of that ≈øpirituall life. I≈øa. 53.4.5.6.10. Chri≈øt was never a ≈øtranger to the life of God. Eph. 4.18. and yet his Father did for a ≈øpace ≈øeeme to e≈øtrange him≈øelfe to his Sonne. Oh, beloued Saints of God, let vs, with that Di≈øciple, follow him a far off; and pa≈ø≈øing over all his contemptuous v≈øage in the way, ≈øee him thus brought to his Cro≈ø≈øe, and ≈øtill the further wee looke, the more wonders ≈øhall wee behold. Euery thing addes to his ignominy of ≈øuffering, and triumph of over-comming. It was not done in a corner, as Paul ≈øaith to Fe≈øtus, but in Ieru≈øalem, the eye, the heart of the world; and that without the gates; in Calvary, among the ≈øtinking bones of execrable Malefactors. Before, the glory of the place bred ≈øhame; now, the vilene≈ø≈øe of it. Not a circum≈øtance, but argues the wonderfull humiliation of our Sauiour, and ≈øtill his paine and ≈øcorne increa≈øed till all was fini≈øhed.
Q. Hitherto of his life; what is his death?

A. The expiration, and deliuering vp of his ≈øoule into the hands of his Father. Math. 27.50. Luk. 23.46. Ioh. 19.30. When he had fini≈øhed all, and indured mo≈øt exqui≈øite torments, he him≈øelfe without all violence gaue vp the Gho≈øt. For he both cryed with a lowd voyce, and bowed the head immediately before he yeelded his la≈øt breath; whereas in
mans death the ≈øpirits fir≈øt faint and tyre, and the head fals downe when they are expired: but Chri≈øt being full of ≈øpirit, able to hold vp his head, bends the ≈øame downe-ward of his owne accord, and then dies. Oh, yee ≈øinners, behold, Chri≈øts head thus humbly bowed downe in a gracious re≈øpect to you; his armes are ≈øtretched out louingly to embrace you; yea, his precious ≈øide is open to receiue you, there is no more accu≈øation, iudgement, death, hell for you: all the≈øe are no more to you, then if they were not, if yee can beleeue, who ≈øhall condemne? It is Chri≈øt which is dead. Rom. 8.34. I know euery man is ready to reach forth his hand to this dole of grace, and would be angry to be beaten from this doore of mercy; ≈øurely, there is no want in this Mo≈ø≈øias, looke that the want be not in thy ≈øelfe: hee hath fini≈øhed, but thou beleeue≈øt not, thou repente≈øt not, all is in vaine to thee; for all the≈øe, thou mai≈øt be condemned. What ever Chri≈øt is, what art thou? Here is the doubt: Chri≈øt is a good ≈øhepherd, and giues his life for his ≈øheepe: But what is this to thee, that art ≈øecure, prophane, impenitent, thou art a wolfe, or a goat. Chri≈øts ≈øheepe heare his voyce, but thou art a rebell to his law, and therefore can≈øt not hearken to his Go≈øpell for mercie, &c.
Q. What is his death to vs?

A. Chri≈øt was willingly content to indure the ≈øeparation of his body and ≈øoule for a time, which is the fir≈øt death, that hee might take away what≈øoeuer is iudgement therein, and ≈øanctifie the ≈øame vnto vs. 1. Cor. 15.55.56.57. Wee were the authors of this death, and our Saviour did alter it, our di≈øobedience made it bitter, his mercy hath made it not to be evill vnto vs. Oh, my Saviour, how halt thou perfumed and ≈øoftened this bed of my graue by dying? How can it grieue mee to tread in thy ≈øteps to glory? The wor≈øt peece of the horror of this death is the graue, and that part which is corrupted feeles it not; the other, which is free from corruption, feeles an abundant recompence, and forefees a ioyfull reparation. Wee carry heauen and earth wrapt vp in one
compound; it is but re≈øtitution, when each part returnes homeward.
Q. What followed his death?

A. His buriall, and abiding in the graue, to the end, that hee might ≈øweeten the ≈øame for vs; and whereas it was by rea≈øon of ≈øinne, a dungeon, to re≈øerue the guiltie body again≈øt the day of judgement, it is through him become (as it were) a perfumed bed for the elect, again≈øt the day of Re≈øurrection. Math 27.59.60. Luk. 23.53. I≈øa. 57.2. Buriall comes of burning, an auncient cu≈øtome of burning bodies, and then pre≈øerving their a≈øhes in a pitcher in the earth. Hence it may be that the Auncients to prevent an ab≈øurd conceit of this kind of Funerall concerning Chri≈øts body, whereof not a bone was to be broken, or wa≈øted, added de≈øcending into hell, to ≈øhew, that Chri≈øt was not burned, but buried, by going downe into Sheol: but it is not for mee to determine the doubt, I leaue it to riper judgements. One thing more I adde, that buriall is ≈øometimes taken for preparation of a body for the graue. Math. 26.12. This ≈øhee did to bury me, &c. Chri≈øt died, was embalmed, and then interred.

div.head: CHAPTER XXIIII. Of Chri≈øts Exaltation.
div.p: Que≈øtion.

p.hi: HItherto of his humiliation; What is his Exaltation?

div.p: An≈øwere.

It is his victory and triumph over his and our enemies, the Devill, ≈øinne, and death, with the world, and what≈øoever el≈øe might cro≈ø≈øe the felicitie of the Saints. Eph. 4.8.9.10. Phil. 2.9.10. It was the ≈øtrange≈øt and ≈øtronge≈øt receit of all the re≈øt, by dying to vanqui≈øh death. 1 The≈ø≈ø. 5.10. Wee need no more, wee can goe no further; there can bee no more Phy≈øicke of the former kinde: there are cordials after this purgation of death, of his re≈øurrection and a≈øcen≈øion; no more penall receits. By his bloud wee haue Redemption. Eph. 1.7. Iu≈øtification, Rom. 3.24. Reconciliation, Colo≈ø. 1.20. Sanctification, 1 Pet. 1.2. Entrance into glory, Heb. 10.19. Woe were to vs if Chri≈øt had left but one mite of ≈øatisfaction vpon our ≈øcore, to bee di≈øcharged by our ≈øelues: and woe be to them that derogate from him to arrogate to them≈øelues, and would faine botch vp his ≈øufferings, with their owne ≈øuperfluities: hee would not off the Cro≈ø≈øe till all was done, and then hauing fini≈øhed, he went on with a ≈øecond worke, to build vp a perfect way to heauen vpon this foundation, and from the graue to his throne in heauen, he chalked out for vs the everla≈øting way.
Q. Wherein doth the glory of his victory and triumph con≈øi≈øt?

A. Fir≈øt, in the depo≈øition and laying a≈øide of all infirmities. Secondly, in his a≈ø≈øumption and taking vp of all perfections, both of body and ≈øoule. His body was now no more to die but to receiue cele≈øtiall perfection. His ≈øoule had nothing withheld from it, no truth from his vnder≈øtanding, no goodne≈ø≈øe
from his will: vpon earth hee was ignorant of ≈øomething, which now is perfectly revealed vnto him, he now knowes the day of judgement, and by his God-head hath euery thing revealed vnto his man-hood that is fit for the government of his Church, though he be ab≈øent from vs both in body and ≈øoule, that which neither Saint nor Angell can heare, he heares, and puts vp all petitions to his Father. His minde is ignorant of nothing for the manner and mea≈øure of a mo≈øt perfect created vnder≈øtanding, and his will is perfected with the greate≈øt perfections of vertues that are incident to any creature; ≈øo that hee is both in ≈øoule and body far more glorious then any other creature is, or can be, and made Lord of all. Heb. 12.4. The manhood of Chri≈øt is not the ≈øonne of God by adoption, or creation, but per≈øonall vnion, and ≈øo hath no other relation to the Father of ≈øonne-≈øhip, but the ≈øame with the God-head; this exalts him highly in glory, and there is as much difference betwixt the ≈øonne of God and other creatures, as betweene a King and his meane≈øt ≈øubiect, and as one Starre differeth from another in glory, 1 Cor. 15.41. and the Sunne farre exceeds all the re≈øt: ≈øo in heauen ≈øhall Chri≈øt appeare more glorious then any other Saint or Angel. Rev. 21.23. I≈øa. 60.19. and ≈øhall be as ea≈øily knowne from the re≈øt, as the Sunne is from all other Starres, &c.
Q. Hitherto of his glory in generall; what are the particular degrees thereof?

A. The fir≈øt is his re≈øurrection the third day, when as his ≈øoule and body, by the power of his God-head (never ≈øeparated from either) were brought together againe, and ≈øo ro≈øe againe, and appeared to his Di≈øciples for the ≈øpace of fortie dayes. And this is the earne≈øt of our Re≈øurrection, ≈øo that wee ≈øhall al≈øo ri≈øe by the power and vertue of his Re≈øurrection, not vnto judgement, but life everla≈øting. This is fir≈øt confirmed by the Angels to men, Math. 28.5.6.7. Mar. 16 6.7. Luk. 24.4.5.6. Secondly, by his owne apparitions vnto them. Math. 28.9.17. Mar. 16.9 12.14. Luk. 24.15.36, Ioh. 20.14.19.26. and 21.1. Act. 1.2.3.
1 Cor. 15.4.5.6.7.8.9. Thirdly, by the keepers of the Sepulcher, Math. 28.11. Fourthly, by his Apo≈øtles, Act. 2.24.32. La≈øtly, by the inward te≈øtimony of the Spirit, in the hearts of the elect, Ioh. 15.26. The power by which he ro≈øe is expre≈ø≈øed, 2 Cor. 13.4. 1 Pet. 3.18. His immortalitie, Rom. 6.9.10. dominion. Rom. 14.9. Godhead, Rom. 1.4. The fruit of it to vs, fir≈øt, in our iu≈øtification, Rom. 4.25. Secondly, our ≈øanctification, and glorification, Rom. 6.4.5.8.9.10.11.12.13. 2 Cor. 5.15. Eph. 2.4.5. Colo≈ø 2.12.13. and 3.1.2.3.4.5. 1 Pet. 1.3.4. 1 The≈ø≈ø. 4.14. &c.
Q. What is the ≈øecond degree thereof?

A. His a≈øcen≈øion into Heauen, by the vertue of his God-head from Mount Olivet, in the ≈øight of his Di≈øciples. Where he began his pa≈ø≈øion, there he beginnes his a≈øcen≈øion, to teach vs how from deiection, wee ≈øhall be brought to our exaltation; as al≈øo to teach vs, that becau≈øe hee is our head, and is already advanced into heauen, thither al≈øo mu≈øt the body follow him. And therefore he is gone before to prepare a place for vs. Mar. 16.19. Luk. 24.50. Act. 1.9.12. Heb. 10.9.20 Ioh. 14.2.
Q. What is the third degree?

A. His ≈øitting at the right hand of God the Father, where we haue his advocation, and interce≈ø≈øion for vs, and need to acknowledge no other Ma≈øter of reque≈øts in heaven, but one, Ie≈øus Chri≈øt our Mediator. Here good prayers never come weeping home: In him I am ≈øure I ≈øhall receiue, eyther what I aske, or what I ≈øhould aske. I cannot be ≈øo happie, as not to need him, and I know I ≈øhall never be ≈øo mi≈øerable, that he will contemne mee, if I come as a poore ≈øuter, with my petition vnto him. Rom. 8.34. Heb. 9.24. 1 Ioh. 2.1. 1 Pet. 3.22. Rev. 3.7. Furthermore, by Chri≈øts ≈øitting at his Fathers right hand, wee are to vnder≈øtand two things: fir≈øt, the returne of the divine nature, as it were (the worke of humiliation being fini≈øhed) to his former glory. Chri≈øt for a time ob≈øcured the excellencie of his Godhead, Phil. 2.6.7.8.9. vnder the vaile of our fle≈øh, but now
the Curtaine is drawne againe, & the divine nature, which ≈øeemed to ≈øleepe in the humane, is awaked, to worke wonders openly, for the good of the elect, and even breakes forth as the Sunne doth from vnder a cloud, hauing expelied all the mi≈øts of his humiliation, Secondly, as there is but a rever≈øion of the divine nature, ≈øo this is an exaltation of the humane, to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe that glory and excellency which before it had not, P≈øal. 2.6. and 110.1. Dan. 7.13.14. Act. 5.30.31. Heb. 2.9. and 8.1.2. and 9.24. Thus might Steuen ≈øee Chri≈øt in a mo≈øt glorious manner, aboue all other in heaven. Act. 7.55.56.
Q. What benefit redoundeth thereby to vs?

A. Vn≈øpeakeable, for while our head is ≈øo highly magnified, and made Lord of all, wee know that he will rule all for the be≈øt, and that no good thing ≈øhall be wanting to them that are his, yea, that our ≈øinnes which wee cannot but commit, whiles the old man dwelleth in vs, ≈øhall not preiudice our happine≈ø≈øe, ≈øeeing he ≈øitteth at the right hand of our Father, to be our interce≈ø≈øour and governour.
Q. What is the fourth and la≈øt degree?

A. His glorious returne from heaven to iudgement, both of the quicke and dead, which is his ≈øecond comming into the world with great glory and maie≈øtie, to the confu≈øion of them that would not haue him rule over them, and the vn≈øpeakeable good of his owne; for it is he that iudgeth, and who ≈øhall condemne them? and hereupon is the full worke of Redemption giuen to the Sonne. Math. 24.30. Ioh. 14.3. Act. 1.11. 1 The≈ø≈ø. 4.16. and 2. Epi≈øt: chap. 1. ver. 7.8. Iud. ver. 14.15. Phil. 3.20.

div.head: CHAPTER XXV. Of the Spirits application to the Church.
div.p: Que≈øtion.

p.hi: HItherto of Redemption; what is the application thereof?

div.p: An≈øwere.

The making of that ours, which the Lord of life hath done for vs. The purcha≈øe of our peace was paid at once, yet mu≈øt it be ≈øeverally reckoned to euery ≈øoule whom it ≈øhall benefit. If we haue not an hand to take what Chri≈øts hand doth either hold, or offer, what is ≈øufficient in him, cannot bee effectuall to vs. Wee haue no peace without reconciliation; no reconciliation, without remi≈ø≈øion; no remi≈ø≈øion, without ≈øatisfaction; no ≈øatisfaction without infinite merite; no infinite merit without Chri≈øt, no Chri≈øt without faith. By this wee are intere≈ø≈øed in all that either God the Father hath promi≈øed, or Chri≈øt his ≈øonne hath performed. Con≈øcience mu≈øt play the hone≈øt ≈øervant, and take his ma≈øters part, not daring to be ≈øo kinde to the ≈øinner, as to be vnfaithfull to his maker. It mu≈øt not looke ≈øtraight vpon him, till he by the eye of faith be able to looke ≈øtraight vpon God. Hence it will ≈øuffer no man to bee friends with him≈øelfe, till hee be a friend with God: now by faith in Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, of enemies wee become friends, yea, ≈øonnes, and as ≈øonnes may expect, and challenge, not onely in this life carefull provi≈øion, and ≈øafe protection; but in the life to come ≈øalvation, and fruition of an everla≈øting patrimony, Mark. 16.16. Luk. 24.45.46. Ioh. 3.3.14.15.16.18.19. Ephe≈ø. 3.17.
Q. To which of the three per≈øons is this worke mo≈øt properly a≈øcribed?

A. To the holy Gho≈øt: the Father mo≈øt properly carries the worke to Redemption, and then the Sonne goes on with it ≈øo begun to Application, and then the Spirit fini≈øheth the worke ≈øo di≈øpenced by the ≈øecond per≈øon. Ioh. 14.17.18.26. and 15.26.27. and 16.7.8.9.10.11. Chri≈øt left not his Church comfortle≈ø≈øe, but even increa≈øed her ioyes by the pre≈øence of his Spirit. When he let fall the ≈øhowers of ≈øpirituall operation (after his departure) vpon the Iewes, Act. 2.41. there were at one Sermon three thou≈øand ≈øoules added to the Church; a great increa≈øe, none ≈øuch in Chri≈øts time. Why? Was Peter the better Preacher? Nay, never man ≈øpake as he ≈øpake, for God gaue him the Spirit not by mea≈øure. Ioh. 3.34. and 7.46. But now the ≈øpirit was giuen plentifully to the hearers, which before was either re≈øtrained, or ≈øparingly imparted. Eph. 1.13. The word, faith, and the Spirit, worke all together, for the applying of Chri≈øt vnto ≈øalvation.
Q. To whom is Chri≈øt applied?

A. To the Church, which is the proper ≈øubiect of Redemption. They that make Chri≈øt an vniver≈øall Mediator, and the Spirit a generall agent in applying to all, and yet the Father but a ≈øpeciall elector of ≈øome, ≈øhew them≈øelues ignorant of the manner of the co-operation of the ≈øacred Trinitie. For as the Father beginnes by election, ≈øo the Sonne goes on by Redemption, and the Spirit fini≈øheth the worke by application: ≈øo that application is as ≈øpeciall as election, Ioh. 17.9.10.11. As the Father redeemes his owne by Chri≈øt: ≈øo he keepes them by the Spirit. Eph. 5.25. He gaue him≈øelfe onely for his Church, ver≈ø. 26.27. and the ≈øame he doth pre≈øent holy to his Father, by the worke of his Spirit.
Q. What is the Church?
