div.p: Q. What are the kinds as they concerne man?

A. Election, which is Gods gracious decree in Chri≈øt, Ephe≈ø. 1.4. to ≈øet free ≈øome men from the mi≈øery of the generall lap≈øe, and to bring them infallibly to ≈øalvation, for the ≈øetting forth of his abundant mercy, Rom. 9.11.16.23. And Reprobation, which is his preterition, or pa≈ø≈øing by ≈øome men, and leauing them in the generall corruption of the fall, without effectuall meanes of recovery and ≈øalvation, for the manife≈øtation of his vncontroulable ju≈øtice. Rom. 9.18.21.22.
Que≈øtion.

p.hi: VVHat meane you by this delineation and de≈øcription of Election.

div.p: An≈øwere.

That wee ≈øhould not fixe our eyes vpon the odious and offen≈øiue name of Reprobation, but delight our ≈øelues the more with the ≈øweet and comfortable in≈øpection of our Election, wherein were ≈øhall finde the ≈øacred Trinitie to haue beene more deepely then in the other, and not to be ≈øo much plea≈øed in plaguing men for finne as to ≈øaue them out of it. Reprobation, being an internall effect, and ever ≈øleeping in the bo≈øome of him that never ≈øleepeth (I meane an imminent, no tran≈øient effect) mu≈øt needs be from God and in God yet the execution of it is no wayes ≈øo large in God, as that decree of life and ≈øalvation. Shewing plainely, that God is farre more affected with the life and happine≈ø≈øe of his creatures, then their death and mi≈øery. Election is from the Father, in the Sonne, by the Spirit to faith, which workes not any life in vs, or for vs, but onely receiues it at the bountifull hands of Almightie God. Oh, let vs not ≈øo much wrangle and wra≈øtle concerning Reprobation, but with delectation, recreate our ≈øelues with this divine worke of our Election. This ca≈øts it ≈øelfe into a large compa≈ø≈øe, whereas in the other, God contracts his hand, and giues man leaue to mi≈øchiefe him≈øelfe. And although our Reprobation be from God, yet our condemnation is from our ≈øelues. The ≈øtrait and ≈øtraight line to heauen lies in this compa≈ø≈øe, that it is from the Father by the inchoation of decree, in the Sonne by the di≈øpen≈øation of meanes, by the holy Gho≈øt for con≈øummation of tho≈øe meanes, and to faith for the in≈øtrument of application.
Q. How is the Church devided?
A. It is either militant vpon earth, or triumphant in heauen.

This di≈øtribution is of the Church, eyther in re≈øpect of the members, or of their condition. Members, as ≈øome are on earth, others in heauen. Condition, as our fighting overcomming. In this world our application is but inchoatiue, in the world to come it ≈øhall be plenary. Here with ≈øtrife
again≈øt ≈øinne and Satan, hereafter ≈øhall bee our glory and triumph. We can ≈øee no more palmes then cro≈ø≈øes, if there were no re≈øi≈øtence, our Chri≈øtian vertue would not appeare. There is but one pa≈ø≈øage, and that a ≈øtrait one, and if with much pre≈ø≈øure wee can get through, and leaue our ≈øuperfluous ragges as torne from vs in the crowd, wee are happy. God would haue heauen narrow and hard in the entrance, that after our paine, our glory might be the ≈øweeter. One peece of iron cannot be ≈øouldred and fa≈øtned to another, vnle≈ø≈øe both bee made red hot, and beaten together: ≈øo, Chri≈øt and his Church, the whole body, and the members cannot ≈øo ≈øoundly be affected each to other, vnle≈ø≈øe both haue experience of the like mi≈øery, Rom. 8.17. this frayes many from being the Lords, who though they would be glad of the crowne, yet ≈øtand trembling at the Cro≈ø≈øe. It is Satans policie to driue vs from our military profe≈ø≈øion, by the difficultie of our Chri≈øtian ware fare; like as ≈øome in ho≈øpitall Savages, make fearefull delu≈øions by Sorcery, vpon the ≈øhore, to fright Strangers from landing, &c. But wee are not to bee di≈ømayed, ≈øeeing God hath made the militant e≈øtate of the Church a degree vnto the triumphant. It is a graduall, no ≈øpecificall di≈øtinction, to ≈øay the church is militant or triumphant. Eph. 6.11.12.13. Heb. 12.22.23.
Q. What is the militant Church?

A. It is the number of all tho≈øe that are applied vnto Chri≈øt by faith. Here were mu≈øt liue by faith, after wee ≈øhall come to the fruition of Chri≈øt by ≈øight. Ephe≈ø. 6.16. Heb. 11.1. 2 Cor. 3.18. and 4.17.18. 1 Cor. 13.12.13. This Church con≈øi≈øts onely of men, not as yet freed from the burden of the fle≈øh; and that is the rea≈øon, why the worke of the Lord goes ≈øo ≈ølowly forward, and makes many ≈øit ≈øtill with their hands foulded in their bo≈øomes, and wi≈øh they knew how to be rid of time, and ≈øo become mi≈øerable loo≈øers of good houres, and good parts, and the very hope of future reward, becau≈øe they will not ≈øtriue with them≈øelues. Happy are tho≈øe per≈øecutions that driue vs to this hold, and like
an old beaten Hare, weary of long cha≈øing, returne vs to this home, to die in this borrough.
Q. Is the number of the≈øe alwayes alike?

A. No, but ≈øometimes greater, and ≈øometimes le≈ø≈øer, and its invi≈øible in regard of faith, yet euery faithfull man may know him≈øelfe, and ≈øo may a man that hath the ≈øpirit of di≈øcerning, judge of another to his comfort; for faith in both is to be knowne by his fruits, &c. 1. Tim. 1.12. Heb. 6.9.
Q. How ≈øhall a man doe in this ca≈øe?

A. By his care to walke according to the rule of godline≈ø≈øe, he ≈øhall procure a comfortable te≈øtimony to his owns Soule, and confirme others in the way of Religion. Act. 24.16. 2 Cor. 1.12. Heb. 13.18. Tit. 3.8.
Q. Is the Church militant by it ≈øelfe in the world?

A. No; it is mingled with tares and chaffe: and as God left the accur≈øed Cananites to be as prickes and thornes to his auncient people: ≈øo ≈øtill will he haue his deare ones to bee exerci≈øed with the wicked of this world, that their graces may more fully be knowne, and them≈øelues wained from the weari≈øome world. Hence it mu≈øt needs be great folly to leaue vi≈øible Congregations, becau≈øe they are pe≈øtered with the prophane of the world; there is no man that will ca≈øt away the gold, or corne, becau≈øe it is mingled with his offall: but will be≈øtow ≈øome labour on the fanne, fire, or furnace. God hath left meanes to purge his Church of prophane per≈øons, though he will haue ≈øome tares to try his Children, and keepe them in awe of his maie≈øtie, nay, make them labour the more to proue their election. If all were good, who would feare to goe to hell? But ≈øeeing we may be Chri≈øtians, and not elect, it will make vs more diligent to ≈øtudie for true holine≈ø≈øe. And knowing that many ≈øhall be damned with the water of Bapti≈øme in their faces, and Church in their mouthes, It will teach Gods Saints in ≈øpite of all hypocri≈øie, to worke out their ≈øalvation with feare and trembling. Phil. 2.12. Our ble≈ø≈øed Saviour out of the very feares of damnation, hath fetched the ≈øafe≈øt ≈øecuritie
of ≈øalvation; oh that we could out of this ≈øecuritie, as ea≈øily fetch the feare of his maie≈øtie. Math. 13.24.25.47. 1 Cor. 5.10.11.12.13.
Q. What are the≈øe tares and chaffe?

A. Such in the Church as haue but the name of Chri≈øtians, and yet are together with the Church in this world; and ≈øo are called improperly by the name of the Church. Vi≈øibilitie, Profe≈ø≈øion, congregation, &c. doe as well belong to the tares as the wheate, the Reprobate as the elect, and therefore are but accidents of the Church, yea, ≈øuch adherents as are ≈øeparable from the Church: and therefore Papi≈øts and Separati≈øts doe ill in teaching them to belong ≈øo e≈ø≈øentially to it. Math. 13.49.50. Rom. 9.6.7. 1 Ioh. 2.19. Ioh. 6.70.71.
Q. How is the Church militant with the tares di≈øtributed?

A. Into Congregations, as great Armies into le≈ø≈øer bands. It is impo≈ø≈øible for all to heare one Pa≈øtor, and therefore mu≈øt the governed be ranked vnder diver≈øe teachers, that all may heare and learne. 1 The≈ø. 2.14. Eph. 4.11.12.13.
Q. What is here to be con≈øidered?

A. The government of the Congregations, which is an order of ruling and obeying in the outward communion of the Saints. Our ≈øanctification is not wrought all at once, but by degrees, and the Churches mu≈øt beget children vnto God; and therefore there mu≈øt be an holy ordering of the people to bring this worke to pa≈ø≈øe. Againe, a law is nece≈ø≈øary to keepe corruption vnder, and if there were no power to re≈øtraine evils, this field of God would runne all into thi≈øtles. This worke mu≈øt be continuall, or el≈øe grace ≈øpeedeth not. Like as the body from a ≈øetled and habituall di≈øtemper, mu≈øt be recovered by long dyets; and ≈øo much the rather, for that none can intermit this care without relap≈øes: ≈øo in regard of our old Apo≈øta≈øie, to keepe the heart in vre with God, is the highe≈øt taske of a Chri≈øtian. Good motions are not frequent: but aboue all the con≈øtancy of a good di≈øpo≈øition is mo≈øt rare and hard. God knowing this
leaues his Church an order of policy to keepe vnder corruption, and advance grace. And it were an happy thing, if Gods Mini≈øters could be as happy as Trade≈ømen; for a Carpenter in the morning ≈øhall finde his worke as he left it the evening before: but Gods Mini≈øters are often to begin againe, and like Wyer-drawers are faine to goe forward, by going backward. Hence they haue power to binde and loo≈øe, loo≈øe and binde; God by them a≈ø≈øaying all meanes to ≈øaue ≈øome. Paul reioyced to ≈øee the good order of the Church, Colo≈ø. 2.5. And commended this point to Timothy, who was to ≈øucceed him in the government of Gods hou≈øe, 1 Tim. 3.15.
Q. What are the parts and members of Congregations?

A. They are eyther the Governours, or Governed: In the militant Church, God hath ≈øet Captaines to teach, and Souldiers to learne, and both faithfully to wage warie again≈øt the enemy. Eph. 4.11.12. and 6.10.11.
Q. What are the Governours?

A. They are tho≈øe that are appointed of God for the looking to the Congregations, over which they are ≈øet, for the edification thereof. Act. 20.28. 1 Pet. 5.1.2.3.4. The≈øe are called Gods right foote, Rev. 10.2. and are to lead the way. Hence it is the error of the Separation, in the con≈øtitution and reformation of Churches, to ≈øet the left legge before the right. God hath ever con≈øtituted and planted Churches by his Mini≈øters, and reformed them both by Magi≈øtrates and Mini≈øters. It is v≈øurpation in the people to adventure vpon either, they are to reforme them≈øelues; but Churches, and their government is referred of God to the Pa≈øtour, and the Prince.
Q. Wherein ≈øtands the power of the Pa≈øtours over the people?

A. In the power of the Keyes; whereby they are able to open, or ≈øhut heauen, bind, or loo≈øe ≈øinners, Math. 16.19. and 18.17.18. 1 Cor. 5.4.5. Yet wee are to vnder≈øtand, that the principall authoritie is in Chri≈øt, the mini≈øtery in men, 2 Cor. 5.18.19.20. Rev. 3.7.
Q. What is binding?
A. That authoritie whereby they might correct a brother that ≈øhould walke inordinately, 1 Cor. 5.5.
Q. What degrees were to be v≈øed therein?

A. Fir≈øt, Admonition, and that was done privately by a brother which ≈øhould finde him walking inordinately, whom if he did heare, it was to goe no further: but if hee would not heare him, then the party admoni≈øhing, was to take two or three more for witne≈ø≈øes, and to admoni≈øh him before them, and if he would not hearken to all the≈øe, they were to tell the Governours, who al≈øo did admoni≈øh him. Math. 18.15.16.17.18.19.20.
Q. What was the ≈øecond degree?

A. If Admonition would not prevaile with the offender, then proceeded the Governours to ≈øu≈øpen≈øion, and ≈øo did bind the delinquent from comming to the holy Communion; and if this ≈øu≈øpen≈øion prevailed not, then followed the excommunication of him, and it was al≈øo either the greater, or the le≈ø≈øer; the Church ≈øtill v≈øing moderation; fir≈øt, therefore the le≈ø≈øer was v≈øed, whiles there was any hope of reclaiming the party offending, then the greater, when his ca≈øe was de≈øperate. 1 Cor. 5.4. 1 Tim. 1.20. Tit. 3.10. Gal. 1.8. Rom. 9.3. 1 Cor. 16.22.
Q. What is ab≈øolution?

A. A receiuing againe of the offender into the Church vpon his true repentance, 2 Cor. 2.6.10. God would not haue them to peri≈øh that repent of their former evils, but to be comforted of their brethren, lea≈øt over much ≈øorrow ≈øhould ≈øwallow them vp. 2 Cor. 2.7.11. In ≈øchooles it is nece≈ø≈øary, not onely that precepts be taught, but that the practi≈øe of them be vrged, and the diligent incouraged: ≈øo in the Church it is needfull that men be not onely in≈øtructed, but pre≈ø≈øed and ≈øtrained to a holy life; for, not the hearers of the law, but the doors ≈øhall be ≈øaued.
Q. How many ≈øort of Governors are in the Church?

A. Two; The principall, and the mini≈øteriall. This government is ≈øpirituall, and concernes the Soule, and therefore
there mu≈øt be a teaching of the heart as well as the eare; here is need of in≈øpiration with in≈øtruction. 1 Cor. 3.6. P≈øal. 63.1. and 143.10.11. Cant. 4.15.
Q. Who are the principall Governours?

A. The Father, the Sonne, and the holy Gho≈øt. The father is the chiefe agent in the Church; for, no man commeth to the Sonne, except the Father draw him. Ioh. 6.44. And none can come vnto the Father, but by the Sonne Ioh. 14.16. Neither can any ≈øay that Ie≈øus is his Lord, but by the Spirit. 1 Cor. 12.3. or that he is Gods child by free adoption. Rom. 8.16. The Church is one with Chri≈øt, as he is one with his Father. Ioh. 17.21.22.23. not in nature, but in the worke of our Redemption.
Q. What are the Mini≈øters?

A. Such as are appointed of the principall to be labourers together with them in this worke, 1 Cor. 3.9. They are called vnder-rowers. Luk. 1.2. becau≈øe vnder Chri≈øt the Ma≈øter Pilote, they helpe forward the ≈øhip of the Church, towards the haven of heaven. Men that are ≈øubiect to the ≈øame pa≈ø≈øions with vs, are fitte≈øt to deale for vs. Exod. 20.19. Iam. 5.17. Thus we ≈øee how God is alone in the principall worke, and principall in the mini≈øteriall. And though he parts labour with his ≈øervants, yet not po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion. It is enough for the labourer, if he haue his hire, his penny: men doe not v≈øe to devide their ground with the plow man, or their hou≈øe with the Ma≈øon. He that hath the Bride, is the Bridegroome. Ioh. 3.29. ≈øo is not he that prepareth, and pre≈øenteth her. 2 Cor. 11.2. ≈øo is not he that ≈øtandeth by, and reioyceth to heare the Bridegroomes voyce. All the Apo≈øtles call them≈øelues ≈øervants, not Lords of Gods inheritance. Rom. 1.1. 1 Pet. 5.3. Mo≈øes as a ≈øervant in his Lords hou≈øe, Chri≈øt as the ≈øonne over his owne hou≈øe, Heb. 3.5.6. Church-men are the Churches, and not the Church theirs, that the Church with them, may bee Chri≈øts, and hee Gods.
Q. How are the Mini≈øters devided?

A. They are either ordinary, or extraordinary. Such were
the times wherein the Church had need of extraordinary teaching, that the truth of Religion might depend vpon God, and not the devices of men; and here the Lord had re≈øpect vnto his Maie≈øtie and excellencie; and therefore did immediately communicate him≈øelfe with a few, lea≈øt over-much familiaritie ≈øhould breed contempt, both of him≈øelfe, and his ordinances. No Prince will ≈øpeake to euery man, but keepe ≈øtate with his ≈øubiects, that they may reverence him the more. Eph. 4.11.
Q. What were the extraordinary?

A. Such as were immediately called of God. All arts are the wi≈øedome of God, and by creation might bee read in the creatures; but this art of Divinitie by ≈øin is blotted out, and therefore is to bee learned by immediate revelation. Hence God extraordinarily calleth ≈øome, and reveales his will to them, that they may reveale it to others. Exod. 4.15.16. And this God hath done many wayes, generally, either externally, or internally. Externally by voyce, without vi≈øion. Act. 9.4. or by both together, Chri≈øt for a time a≈ø≈øuming the ≈øhape of men and Angels. Gen. 18.9.13.17.33. and 19.2. Internally, either awaking by in≈øpiration, or ≈øleeping by inward dreames and vi≈øions. Gen. 15.12.13. &c. Math. 2.12.13. Act. 2.4.17. Sleepe reacheth not to the rea≈øonable Soule, and God may conferre with man, when both his internall and externall ≈øen≈øes are locked vp. He is able to informe the Soule immediately, without all v≈øe of the body, and by a divine vi≈øion let man ≈øee his will, though his rea≈øon was never informed thereof by his eare, or any outward word. So God can informe the inward ≈øen≈øes without the outward, and by a dreame let a man ≈øee that which was never within the ≈øuppo≈øition of any ≈øen≈øe. So God can ≈øhew vnto the outward ≈øen≈øes, obiects without naturall light, or colour. Rev. 1.10.12. He ≈øaw and heard in an exta≈øie. His eye and his eare were ≈øpiritually taken vp with revelations; not as the Prophets of the wicked Spirit, when they are ≈øaid to be Deo pleni, full of God, behauing them≈øelues like mad-men: but quiet and
calme, vnder≈øtanding well what they did, God fir≈øt certifying their vnder≈øtandings, after their wills, and ≈øo inclining them to ≈øpeake and liue accordingly; the other knew not what they ≈øaid, as being po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Spirit of darkene≈ø≈øe. And this extraordinary revelation, ≈øhews the immortalitie of the ≈øoule, being able to conferre with God even without the body. 2 Cor. 12.2. Wee receiue all our knowledge by our outward ≈øen≈øes, Rom. 10.17. which conuey things to the inward, and they informe our rea≈øon: but God can invert the order, and beginne fir≈øt with our rea≈øon, and by that informe our inward ≈øen≈øes in dreames, and then by them our outward, &c.
Q. What are the ordinary Governours?

A. Such as are called by the Church, where there is try all of their gifts, election of their per≈øons, and con≈øecration of them in office. The two fir≈øt were ≈øupplied by the third in all tho≈øe whom the Apo≈øtles ordained; for they by impo≈øition of hands gaue gifts, and therefore ≈øuch were not tryed by the learned, ≈øeeing they had no gifts for ≈øuch callings, before hands were impo≈øed by the Apo≈øtles. Hence it followes, that the new Te≈øtament ≈øpeaking of no other con≈øecration of Mini≈øters, but by the Apo≈øtles, ≈øpeakes nothing of examinations, or elections. Men then had not ordinary gifts; for they receiued them together with other ornaments, by the hands of the Apo≈øtles: that place Act. 14.22. is abu≈øed, even again≈øt Grammaticall con≈øtruction, by tho≈øe that would draw it to election before ordination, and that by the ≈øuffragies of the people; for the Nominatiue ca≈øe to the Verbe, mu≈øt needs be Paul and Barnabas, they therefore and not the people were agents in that bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and made Mini≈øters of ≈øuch as they found fit for gifts, whom God with an ordinary calling, extraordinarily gifted. Wee reade Act. 19.6.7. of 12. made Mini≈øters, which before had not heard, whether there was an holy Gho≈øt, yea, or no: who≈øe power immediately they felt, after Paul had impo≈øed his hands. So that wee may ≈øafely conclude, that ordination is more e≈ø≈øentiall to
mini≈øtry, then popular election: and yet in after-times the people were not reiected, for the liking, or di≈øliking of their Pa≈øtours, vntill they became factious, and patrons of ≈øchi≈ømes, or at lea≈øt-wi≈øe abetters of the wor≈øe, and ≈øo made them≈øelues vnworthy of their voyces. I would faine know of any ≈øtrict defender of the peoples choice, whether it were better in point of ≈øchi≈øme, or here≈øie, to leaue them to their owne libertie, or to haue them re≈øtrained? If they be left in ≈øuch ea≈øes to them≈øelues, then ≈øhall the Church of God be de≈øtroyed. As for example, in the times of Ariani≈øme, whiles the people had libertie, they would choo≈øe no Pa≈øtours but Arians. It ≈øhall ever be ob≈øerved, that in ≈øiding and factious divi≈øions, the wor≈øt are for the mo≈øt part ≈øtronge≈øt, &c. So that election is to be moderated by the di≈øcretion of the civill Magi≈øtrate, or faithfull Pa≈øtours. But ordination and con≈øecration hath ≈øtill gone in his cour≈øe, and Mini≈øters are to make Mini≈øters, and not the people. Gal. 1.1. Some are called immediately of God, and by God, as Apo≈øtles, ≈øome of God by man, as, Timothie, Titus, &c. Some of men, and by men, as the Prophets of Browni≈øts, and therefore none of Gods. This is the Tenent of truth, that the fir≈øt cour≈øe of Mini≈øtry hath ever bin extraordinary, the ≈øecond hath ever gone on in an order, as from one government to another, and never hath Mini≈øtry begun at the people. We deny not that we are Mini≈øters by Rome, but we affirme, wee are not the Mini≈øters of Rome. Wee are of God by them; and they may as truely be in≈øtruments of our Mini≈øtery, as of our Bapti≈øme. For as Ezek. 16.20. the Iewes did beget children vnto God, but con≈øecrate them to Molech: ≈øo Papi≈øts may beget both a people, and Pa≈øtor for God; but till they ≈øeparate, they are both con≈øecrated vnto Antichri≈øt. And here let all take notice, how Separati≈øts gnaw vpon this bone, and ≈øucke in nothing but the bloud of their owne iawes.
Q. What were the Governed?

A. All tho≈øe in the Congregations, which were ≈øubiected to their lawfull Pa≈øters, Act. 20.28. 1 The≈ø≈ø. 5.12. Heb. 13.7.17.
It is for Korah, and his confederates to ri≈øe vp again≈øt Mo≈øes and Aaron, becau≈øe they are lift vp aboue the Congregation. Num. 16.3.
Q. Of how many ought a Congregation to con≈øi≈øt?

A. Of ≈øo many as may conveniently meete together in one place, for the publicke exerci≈øes of Religion. The ≈øeverall portions are left to the di≈øcretion of our Governors, and ≈øo far forth a Pari≈øh is humane: yet the Congregation it ≈øelfe is Gods ordinance, who would haue it gouerned, according to his owne lawes. 1 Cor. 5.4. The flocke is Chri≈øts, the fold is le≈ø≈øer or greater, as the Governours judge it fit and convenient.
Q. What if ≈øome members of more Congregations meete together, to con≈øult of ≈øome matters?

A. Then it is called a Councell; for ≈øingle Congregations are the weake≈øt parts of the Church, and therefore haue need of neighbour helpe, Act. 15. The Separation teach, that euery Congregation is ab≈øolute in it ≈øelfe, and that a≈ø≈øembling of Councels is voluntary, &c. which if it be true, then the guiltie, or infected Congregation cannot be cited to appeare. Iudicium redditur in invitum, for pars rea, is in law pars fugiens, the party pre≈øumed to come thither again≈øt his will. &c. Poeticall, the ≈øix following from the beginning of Iob to E≈øay. Propheticall, the three great Prophets, with the twelue le≈ø≈øer, and Daniel. The Apocrypha is ≈øhut out of the di≈øtribution, both by the Iewes, and our Saviour, and therefore is not of equall authoritie with the bookes we haue mentioned. God made the Iewes faithfull regi≈øters of the old Te≈øtament; and they were ≈øo curious, lea≈øt a letter ≈øhould be lo≈øt, that they kept them by count: and therefore would never haue beene ≈øo negligent in the Apocrypha writing if ever they had beene committed of God vnto them, by their extraordinary governours. As in notorious Burglaries, a hat, gloue, or fword is often left behind, for di≈øcovery: ≈øo, in the≈øe (though more hone≈øt) ≈øome errors haue e≈øcaped, to di≈øcover the Authors.
Q. Who were their ordinary Governours?

A. The ≈øupreame was the high Prie≈øt, the inferior were the Prie≈øts, Levites, and Rulers of their Synogogues. Lev. 8. Num. 3. Act. 13.15. Order hath ever beene for the cu≈øtodie of divine things, and confu≈øion for their ruine.
Q. What is the Church among all people?

A. The Catholicke Church, gathered out of all people, where we haue the Me≈ø≈øias exhibited in the fle≈øh, in whom the law and the Prophets are yea, and Amen. Mo≈øes branded ≈øome creatures with vncleanne≈ø≈øe; he that hath redeemed his children from morall impuritie, redeemes his creatures from legall: what ≈øhould S. Peters great ≈øheet, let downe by foure corners, teach vs, but that all creatures through the foure corners of the world, are cleane and holy? And that God is no re≈øpecter of per≈øons, but in euery nation, he that feareth him, and worketh righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, is accepted with him. Act. 10.34.35. Gal. 4.27.
Q. How are the Congregations thereof called?

A. They are called Churches; the name of the whole being put for the part; and Chri≈øt doth it to di≈øtingui≈øh his
Churches of the Go≈øpell, from the prophane and wicked Synagogues of the Iewes. Math. 18.17. He ≈øayes not, tell it the Synagogue, but the Church, &c. They therefore levell ami≈ø≈øe, that lay the line of their government by this deceitfull ≈øquare.
Q. Who were the extraordinary Governours of this Church?

A. Iohn Bapti≈øt, the forerunner of Chri≈øt, Chri≈øt him≈øelfe, his Apo≈øtles, ≈øeventie Di≈øciples, Evangeli≈øts, and Prophets; whereof ≈øome did write the bookes of the new Te≈øtament in the Greeke tongue; which are either Hi≈øtoricall, as the Go≈øpells of Mathew, Marke, Luke, and Iohn; or diver≈øe excellent Epi≈øtles, as of Paul to the Romanes, Corinthians 2. Galathians, Ephe≈øians, Philippians, Colo≈ø≈øians, The≈ø≈øalonians 2. Timothy 2. Titus, Philomon, Hebrewes, Epi≈øtle of Iames, of Peter 2. Iohn 3. Iude; or la≈øtly, the Propheticall booke of the Revelation.
Q. Who were the ordinary Governours?

A. The Doctors and Pa≈øtours. Eph. 4.11. which may be di≈øtributed into Bi≈øhops, Elders, and Deacons. As for the fir≈øt, if time and place be accidents of a calling, and the very e≈ø≈øence lie in relation betwixt the caller and the called. Timothy and Titus were ordinary teachers; for to an extraordinary Governour, an extraordinary caller is required. It cannot be denied, but that both Timothy and Titus did a long time wait vpon the Apo≈øtles, and were ≈øent from place to place, though ≈øetled at the la≈øt. If going from place to place make an Euangeli≈øt, then they were both of them Evangeli≈øts: but I beleeue all the Pa≈øtours and Doctours of the Church were at the Apo≈øtles command, and ≈øent too and fro as there was need. 2 Tim. 3.10.12.20. &c. wee heare of Cre≈øcens, Titus, Tychicus, Trophimus, &c. ≈øent diver≈øe wayes by the Apo≈øtle Paul, &c. And therefore it is not enough from the place, to ≈øay, ≈øuch a one was an Evangeli≈øt, except it be further prooued, that he had an extraordinary calling. That Timothy is bidden to doe the worke of an Euangeli≈øt, it is a dubious terme, for an Evangeli≈øt,
is either put for a writer of the Go≈øpels, and ≈øo ≈øome Apo≈øtles are Evangeli≈øts; or for an officer, and ≈øo ≈øuch as were extraordinarily called to plant Churches, Act. 8. but had no power to ordaine them Pa≈øtours, are called Evangeli≈øts, Act. 21.8. And of this ≈øort might be many of the ≈øeventie Di≈øciples: or la≈øtly, for Preachers; for the Go≈øpell (with which the name is coniugated) is the obiect of all three. The fir≈øt write it for the edification of the Church, the ≈øecond preach it, and worke miracles, to confirme it for the plantation of the Church; and the third preach it too, for the further watering of that ≈øeed which others haue ≈øowne before them, and in this ≈øen≈øe is Timothy bidden to doe the worke of an Evangeli≈øt, as the next words expound it, make thy mini≈øtery fully knowne. And it is out of doubt, that Timothy was called of God by man, which to me is an ordinary calling. And that Timothy and Titus (as Bi≈øhops properly ≈øo called) had a ≈øuperintendencie, and coerciue power of juri≈ødiction over Elders, Mini≈øters, or Preachers it is evident to me out of the≈øe places, 1 Tim. 1.3.5.19. 2 Tim. 2.14. Tit. 1.5.11.13. The Elders are from the originall, called Pre≈øbyteri, which turned into Engli≈øh, is called Prie≈øts, the mo≈øt current and pa≈ø≈øable title, had not Ma≈ø≈øe-mongers made it infamous, in the eares of ≈øuch people, as are not acute enough to devide betweene a fit title, and a corrupting abu≈øe. Thus much for the name. As for the office of Elders (taken for Eccle≈øia≈øticall Governours) I find none de≈øcribed, but by ≈øeeding of the flocke, which makes mee conclude, they were all Pa≈øtours. As for that place. 1 Tim. 5.17. all the que≈øtion is about the compari≈øon, whether gifts, or offices be compared together. The originall hath it thus, Elders ruling well are worthy of double honour, e≈øpecially, labouring in the word and doctrine: now it is a rule in the Greeke tongue, that participles are to be turned into rea≈øons of the things they explaine; as ruling becau≈øe they rule, and labouring becau≈øe they labour, &c. The ≈øen≈øe then may be thus rendred, without all rending of the compari≈øon. Elders are to be reompenced with honour and
maintenance; fir≈øt, becau≈øe they rule; ≈øecondly, becau≈øe they preach. Fir≈øt, they goe before their flocke in holy practi≈øe of di≈øcipline, vpon them≈øelues and others; ≈øecondly, they continually pre≈ø≈øe them by precepts in painfull preaching. Now that the people may e≈øpecially ≈øee wherein they are to be honoured, it is in this, that they are labourious di≈øpen≈øers and di≈øpo≈øers of heauenly doctrine. Therefore with the Scriptures, I ≈øay that the ordinary teachers, and Governours of the Chri≈øtian Churches, were Pa≈øtours and Doctors, and that copulatiuely, and not ≈øegregatiuely, as in Apo≈øtles, Prophets, and Evangeli≈øts.
Q. What is the Church triumphant?

A. The number of all tho≈øe that are applied vnto Chri≈øt by ≈øight. After faith and ≈øight, followes freedome and fruition. This Church con≈øi≈øts of holy Spirits, both Angels and men, the ≈øoules of the Saints departed, are receiued vp into glory, and after the re≈øurrection, the militant Church both in body and ≈øoule ≈øhall be of the Triumphant, in the full fruition of all bli≈ø≈øe and happine≈ø≈øe. Gal. 4.26. Heb. 12.22.23.24. Iob. 14.2.3. Heb. 11.10.16.26. &c. As tho≈øe therefore that haue ta≈øted of ≈øome delicate di≈øh, finde other plaine di≈øhes but vnplea≈øant; ≈øo it fareth with all tho≈øe which haue once ta≈øted of heauenly things, they cannot but contemne the be≈øt worldly plea≈øures. As therefore ≈øome daintie gue≈øt, knowing there is ≈øome plea≈øant fare to come, will re≈øerue his appetite for it: ≈øo mu≈øt not we ≈øuffer our ≈øelues to be cloyed with the cour≈øe dyet of the world, but keepe our de≈øires for the ioyes to come. And if worldlings find ≈øo much plea≈øure on earth, as to thinke it worth the account of their heauen; becau≈øe they ≈øee ≈øuch a Sunne to enlighten it, ≈øuch an heauen to wall it about, ≈øuch ≈øweet fruits and flowers to adorne it, ≈øuch varietie of creatures, for the commodious v≈øe of it, and yet onely provided for mortalitie, and chiefely po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the makers enemies: what then mu≈øt heaven needs be, that is provided for God him≈øelfe, and his be≈øt friends? If the out ≈øide be ≈øo glorious, what ≈øhall be within? How can it be le≈ø≈øe in worth,
≈øeeing God is aboue his creatures, and Gods friends better then his enemies? I will therefore not onely be content, but de≈øirous to be di≈ø≈øolved.

div.head: CHAPTER XXVI. Of the Spirits application by Faith.
div.p: Que≈øtion.

p.hi: HItherto of the ≈øubiect of Application; what are the parts?

div.p: An≈øwere.

Preparation, and the infu≈øion of faith. Such is the nature of man, that before he can receiue a true iu≈øtifying faith, hee mu≈øt (as it were) be broken in peeces by the law. Ier. 23.9. The word of God is both the hammer to breake our hard hearts, and a fire to heat, melt, mollifie, and di≈ø≈øolue them into the teares of godly ≈øorrow. A rocke may tremble, and an iron ve≈ø≈øell by violent ≈øtroakes may be broken in peeces, and yet ≈øtill retaine their hardne≈ø≈øe, onely the ≈øweet and plea≈øant fire of grace mu≈øt ≈øoften them againe. It is the bloud of the Lambe that mu≈øt melt the Adamant, and the Sunne-≈øhine of Gods loue in Chri≈øt, that mu≈øt thaw the ice of our hearts. Rom. 8.15. we are to be led from the feare of ≈ølaues, through the feare of penitents, to the feare of ≈øonnes: and indeed one of the≈øe makes way for another; and though perfect loue thru≈øt out feare, yet mu≈øt feare bring in that perfect loue; as a Needle, or Bri≈øtle drawes in the thred after it, or as the potion brings health. The compunction of feare (≈øaith Gregory) fits the minde for the compunction of loue. P≈øal. 2.11. We are bidden to reioyce in God with trembling. If Samuel had not made the people to quake at Gods thunder and raine, hee ≈øhould never haue brought them ≈øo to haue ioyed in the following Sunne-≈øhine. 1 Sam. 12.18.19. &c. Ho≈øtile feare through the power of God, may be initiall to the filiall. And whereas
that ca≈øts both the eyes vpon the puni≈øhment, God can make it ca≈øt the one eye off the iudgement, and fixe the other on the partie offended: ≈øo Samuel teacheth I≈ørael. 1 Sam. 20.20. with 24. Feare not the thunder, but feare him that ≈øent it. If ever wee will ≈øtoope, the iudgements of God will bring vs on our knees.
Q. What is the preparation?

A. A fitting vs for our being in Chri≈øt; for wee being branches of the wild Oliue, mu≈øt be made ready for our being in the true Oliue, before wee can be grafted into it. Rom. 11.17.24. Ioh. 15.5.6.7. The convexe, or outbowed ≈øide of a ve≈ø≈øell will hold nothing; it mu≈øt be the hollow and depre≈ø≈øed part, that is capable of any liquor. The broken & contrite ≈øpirit makes way for Gods grace. P≈øal. 51.17. Sweetly Bernard, God poures not the oyle of his mercy, ≈øaue into a broken ve≈ø≈øell; for indeed whole ve≈ø≈øels, are full ve≈ø≈øels: and ≈øo this precious oyle would runne over, and be ≈øpilt on the ground. Oh, if wee were ≈øo humbled with the varieties of Gods iudgements as wee ought, how ≈øavory would his coun≈øels be? How precious and welcome would his feare be to our trembling hearts? Whereas now our ≈øtubborne ≈øen≈øele≈øne≈ø≈øe fru≈øtrates all the threatnings and executions of God.
Q. When is this done?

A. In the acceptable time, and day of ≈øaluation, in the which the Lord plea≈øeth to bring into act his purpo≈øe of ≈øalvation, in gathering his owne out of the world, and that ≈øooner, or later, as it plea≈øeth him Wee may not mend the pace of God, or ≈øpurre on his decree; yet mu≈øt we be diligent in the meanes, vntill God ble≈ø≈øe them for this end. Every man hath power to goe to Church, heare the word, and be pre≈øent at all outward ≈øeruices, and the neglect of this hinders many, in re≈øpect of better ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, though not of Gods decree. Wee therefore are guiltie of our owne time ill husbanded, though God will not worke before his owne day. Luk. 19.42. Rom. 13.11. 2 Cor. 6.2.
Q. What are the parts of this preparation?

A. Fir≈øt, the cutting of vs, as it were, from the wild Oliue tree. Secondly, a paring, and fitting of vs to be put into the true Oliue tree. Rom. 11.24. The Gentiles were cut out of the Oliue tree, which is wild by nature, and contrary to nature grafted into a good Oliue tree, &c. Wee that grow wild in wickedne≈ø≈øe, want grace to ≈øeeke Chri≈øt, and being contrary to his vertues, are vnapt to ioyne with him, without a great preparation. Tell the prophane per≈øon in the mid≈øt of all his iollitie and revels, of devotion, pietie, or iudgements, and he will turne you off with the Athenian que≈øtion, What doth this babler ≈øay? Tell the woman of Samaria Ioh. 4. of the water of life, and ≈øhee will mocke at it, till Chri≈øt ≈øit as iudge in her con≈øcience, and pinch her with that clo≈øe imputation of adultery: there is no ≈øowing, Ier. 4. till the hard and clottie fallow ground be ≈øubdued by the Plough: the vnhumbled ≈øinner is as vnfit for Gods in≈øtruction, as an vnbroken Colt for the ≈øaddle. Our Gallants cannot be ≈øtayed from their Gallop, till God touch their Soules with ≈øome terrour, ca≈øt their bodies on their beds of ≈øicknes, turne their fooles feathers into kerchiefes, then when they ≈øee their faces grow pale, their eyes ≈øunke in their heads, their hands ≈øhaking, their breath ≈øhort, their fle≈øh con≈øumed, you ≈øhall haue them ea≈øie to be talkt withall, now, or el≈øe never will they learne with old Eli, to ≈øay, ≈øpeake Lord, for thy ≈øervants heare. Thus wee ≈øee it is good ≈øtriking when the iron is hot; there is no fi≈øhing ≈øo good, as in the≈øe troubled waters. Now it is good ≈øtriking, whom God hath ≈øtricken; for con≈øcience is a nice and ≈øullen thing, and if it be not taken at fit times and moodes, there will be no medling with it.
Q. What meane you by this cutting of vs from the wild Oliue?

A. Two things; fir≈øt, a violent pulling of vs out of the corruption of nature, or a cutting (as it were) by the knife of the law of an vnregenerate man from his ≈øecurity, wherin
he ≈øleepeth, he not ≈øo much as dreaming of any ≈øuch thing. P≈øal. 119.70. Their heart is as fat as grea≈øe: but I delight in thy law. Shewing by the oppo≈øition, that it is onely the leane heart, pined and pinched with ≈øpirituall famine, that can feele any delight in God: nothing more vn≈øavory to a ≈øen≈øele≈ø≈øe, brawny heart, then Chri≈øts bloud; no more reli≈øh feeles, or findes he in it, then in a dry chip. Nay, he never complaines of his mi≈øery; a man being dead neuer bemoanes the intollerable paines of the Stone, who if hee were aliue, would te≈øtifie his griefe by groanes, for the grating paine, and gripes he continually feeleth. Secondly, as there is a violent evul≈øion; ≈øo as violent attraction to Chri≈øt for ea≈øe, man at the fir≈øt plainely refu≈øing it: the hunted bea≈øt flies to his den; the pur≈øued malefactor to the hornes of the Altar, or Citie of Refuge. Pauls mi≈øery Rom. 7.24. driues him to Gods mercy; The I≈øraelites are driuen into their Chambers by the de≈øtroying Angell; Balaam is made to leane backe by the naked ≈øword; Agur to run to Ithiel and Vcal, that is, Chri≈øt. Pro. 30.1.2.3. When he is confounded with his owne bruiti≈øhne≈ø≈øe. God mu≈øt let loo≈øe his law, ≈øinne, con≈øcience, and Satan to bait vs, and kindle hell fires in our Soules, before wee will be driuen to ≈øeeke to Chri≈øt. Paul and Silas came not out of pri≈øon, without a greater earth-quake, then poore ≈øinners from Satans hold, with an heart-quake. How violently did Satan driue Saul to per≈øecute; and did not Chri≈øt as violently ≈øend him backe againe by a contrary winde, that blew him off his hor≈øe, & ≈ømote him downe, as dead, to the ground? As Lot was driuen out of Sodome, with fire and brim≈øtone about his eares; or as the venturous child is terrified from fire & water, the carefull Father holding him by the heeles over both: ≈øo God by the ≈øowre ≈øauce of a guiltie con≈øcience, lets the ≈øinner ≈øee what it is to fall to the ≈øweet meat of ≈øinne, and eate thereof vnto ≈øurfeit. Davids broken bones, and brui≈øed con≈øcience, will tell him of his plea≈øure in murther and adultery, and what he gaines by his ≈øilence. P≈øal. 32.3.
Q. How are wee pared and trimmed for our putting into Chri≈øt?

A. By our humiliation for ≈øinne; God takes advantage of our feares; for hauing ≈øtopped the way of ≈øinne with feare, he labours to tyre and weary the ≈øinner with ≈øorrow, and according to that golden ≈øentence of that Samian wi≈øe man, that bids vs lay weight vpon the loden, lades the offender with his burden, vntill he be weary of it, and could wi≈øh with all his heart, he were rid of it. Oh, how acceptable is the fountaine of liuing waters to the cha≈øed Hart, panting, and braying? So how welcome is redemption to the thir≈øtie Con≈øcience, ≈øcorched with the ≈øen≈øe of Gods wrath? The traytor laid on the blocke will be ≈øen≈øible enough of his Soueraignes mercy in pardoning, and farre more apprehen≈øiue of it, then when he was fir≈øt attached. And yet for all this, ≈øinners doe but wilder them≈øelues in humiliation, except God ≈øtill draw them on vntill they be ingrafted into Chri≈øt. Humane helps here prevaile nothing; merriments haue no more power to quiet con≈øcience, then holy-water and charmes to coniure the Devill; Popi≈øh pardons, pilgrimages, ≈øhrifts, whips, are ≈øilly ≈øhifts to ea≈øe the bleeding wounds of ≈øorrowful ≈øoules. He that drinkes water, or leapes into a poole, to coole his fever, fiers him≈øelfe the more, though he feele ≈øome ea≈øe for the pre≈øent: his torment will never cea≈øe till he both find Chri≈øt, and be found of him. Heb. 9.14. Iam. 4.9.10.
Q. How is this wrought?

A. God giueth the ≈øinner to ≈øee by the law his ≈øinne, and the puni≈øhment of it, and that by the detection happily of ≈øome one ≈øinne and that many times none of the greate≈øt, lea≈øt he ≈øhould be pre≈øently ≈øwallowed vp of de≈øpaire; yet by that one makes him ≈øu≈øpect the re≈øt. 1 Sam. 12.19. That one ≈øinne in asking of a King, brought them to confe≈ø≈øe all. Furthermore, the detection of one ≈øinne, and ≈øu≈øpition of all the re≈øt, with their iu≈øt de≈øert, driues them to compunction, and a pricking of heart, which is greater or le≈ø≈øer, and carries with it diver≈øe Symptomes, and
≈øen≈øible pa≈ø≈øions of griefe. All are not handled alike, ≈øome haue greater fits then others, and are but (as it were) ≈øprinkled in this Bapti≈øme, wherein others haue beene dou≈øed over head and eares. Some ≈øip of this cup, others drinke the very dregges. Tho≈øe converts, Act. 2. had ≈øome grudgings and prickes of con≈øcience, but yet they had none of Iobs and Dauids fits. Mathew at his fir≈øt conver≈øion, ≈øeemes to entertaine Chri≈øt with a fea≈øt, and ≈øo did Lydia the Apo≈øtles. It is here as in a Womans travell; none travell without paine, yet ≈øome like tho≈øe Hebrew women, Exod. 1. prevent the Mid-wife, and are quicker in di≈øpatch then many others. Some ≈øores we ≈øee are let out with the pricke of a pin, others are ≈øearched to the bottome with the Surgeons launce. Vi≈øcous and gluttonous humours mu≈øt haue a ≈øtronger purge, then ≈øuch as flow of them≈øelues. A hard knot mu≈øt haue a hard wedge, when the Axe alone is able to poli≈øh other peeces of timber. Neither is it alwayes ≈øinne that brings the greatne≈ø≈øe of this agony vpon penitents; but ≈øometimes further imployment of ≈øuch per≈øons in more worthy ≈øervices. The higher the building, the deeper the foundation, which is not ≈øo requi≈øite in the ruder pyles, &c. This detection of ≈øinne, workes a ≈øeque≈øtration from their former cour≈øes, and makes them loath them≈øelues; for God ≈øtops the way of ≈øinners by feares, tyres and wearies them by ≈øorrow, and turnes them by hatred; and when they begin to ≈øee how the controver≈øie is betwixt God and them≈øelues, they fall from the very ≈øen≈øe of their mi≈øery, to de≈øpaire of helpe in them≈øelues, or any other worldly thing, and ≈øubmit them≈øelues to be di≈øpo≈øed of as God ≈øhall plea≈øe. Thus by the law are they brought to ≈øee, they want Chri≈øt, but without faith they cannot looke vp to him, and therefore faith is infu≈øed, by which the ≈øoule may be comforted. The law is common in this worke, both to the elect and reprobate: yet this preparation is peculiar and proper to ≈øuch as God hath cho≈øen. No birth without travell, and yet ≈øome children are killed with the paines of the labour: ≈øo God hath none borne his
but they come forth at this ≈øtrait pa≈ø≈øage, onely the reprobate want ≈øtrength to bring forth, and therefore peri≈øh in de≈øpaire. The law brings them both to this conclu≈øion, and ends ever in de≈øpaire, onely the cho≈øen of God finde mercy, Ho≈ø. 14.4. With thee the fatherle≈ø≈øe ≈øhall finde mercie; God will haue vs brought into the ≈øtraits of poore de≈øolate ≈øhiftle≈ø≈øe Orphanes, before he thinkes vs fit for his mercie. And the deeper wee goe in the ≈øen≈øe of our mi≈øery, the ≈øweeter ≈øhall wee finde the ≈øen≈øe of Gods mercy. Iob 33.19. to 25. Math. 5.4. and 11.28. Chri≈øt (Ioh. 16.) promi≈øeth the Comforter, and the fir≈øt ground that hee ≈øhall lay of our comfort, ≈øhall be to convince our con≈øciences; conviction of ≈øinne, goes before our conviction of righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, Hab. 3.16. The Prophet ≈øheweth, how his peace was wrought out of trouble. P≈øal. 126.5. Wee mu≈øt ≈øow in teares before wee can reape in ioy. And wee care not if wee may haue a dry harve≈øt, after a wet ≈øeed time. And thus farre haue wee ≈øhewed the preparation; now let vs ≈øee the compo≈øition of grace.
Q. What is the infu≈øion of faith?

A. Q. What are the degrees thereof?

A. The fir≈øt is in a≈ø≈øurance of our election, and the loue of God, never to be violated, or broken off againe, and that is by our effectuall vocation, iu≈øtification, and ≈øanctification; then for the time of this life, the vndoubted per≈øwa≈øion of faith, which makes tho≈øe things extant, or pre≈øent, that are hoped for, and giues vs vndoubted evidence of tho≈øe things which are not ≈øeene. Heb. 11.1. And hereupon a certaine and infallible hope and expectation of the fruition of tho≈øe good things which are prepared for Gods elect, ≈øuch indeed as the eye hath not ≈øeene, nor ≈øo much as the eare heard, nor that which is mo≈øt, entred into the heart and thought of man. La≈øtly, the fruition it ≈øelfe, of glory, and life everla≈øting. Rev. 7.14.15.16.17. and 21.3.4. In vi≈øion, fruition, and perfection of holine≈ø≈øe. Math. 22.30. How ≈øhould this make vs to conquer our impatience, and to ≈øwallow downe the mi≈øeries of this life? O blinder then Beetles; the Marchant refu≈øeth no adventure, for hope of gaine; the hunter ≈øhrinketh at no weather, for loue of game; the Souldier declineth no danger, for de≈øire, either of glory, or ≈øpoyle; and ≈øhall we frame to our ≈øelues, either an ea≈øe in not vnder≈øtanding, or an idlene≈ø≈øe in not v≈øing tho≈øe things, which will be a meanes to vs, not onely to avoyd intollerable and endle≈ø≈øe paines, but to attaine both immea≈øurable and immortall glory, plea≈øure, and gaine? Doe we not know what the≈øe tearmes doe import, death, iudgement, hell? or whom they doe concerne? or how neere they are vnto our neckes? Will wee like mi≈øcreants, thinke, hell is not ≈øo hot, nor ≈øinne ≈øo heavy, nor the Devill ≈øo blacke, nor God ≈øo vnmercifull, as the Preachers ≈øay? So that as our ≈øeruice mu≈øt be grounded vpon our faith, ≈øo mu≈øt our faith be reduced to ≈øeruice. For ≈øhame, what are wee, and where is our emulation? which is the girdle of truth. Eph. 6.14. Thinke thy ≈øelfe but a loo≈øe man as long as thou wante≈øt it, & thy graces, never ≈øo excellent, will be ≈øhaken off with a ≈øtorme, as loo≈øe garments with the wind. Obedience, if wee re≈øpect Gods iu≈øtice, ought to be perfect, yet it is ≈øo farre perfect in vs, as it is wrought in vs by the ≈øpirit and faith; wherein properly there is no imperfection; for it is the oppo≈øition of corruption, that makes faith little. The ≈øpirit, faith, and man are all agents in well doing, and man de≈øerues the lea≈øt pray≈øe; for he is beholding to the Spirit and faith, if he receiue any reward of his workes: I wonder at Papi≈øts, that they ≈øhould make tho≈øe workes mo≈øt meritorious, which are mo≈øt remote from the fountaine of well-doing. Q. Wherein ≈øtands our obedience?

A. Either in ob≈øervation of the law, invocation of God, or celebration of Sacraments. Faith makes vs euery way dutifull to our Maker. It moues vs to ≈øeeke him in all his ordinances, and mo≈øt willingly ≈øubmit vnto his lawes, devoutly to ≈øue vnto him in our prayers, and holily to receiue the pledge of his loue. Math. 28.19.20. They that for want of faith become weake in doing, will ≈øoone become weary
of well-doing. Dead work is ≈øoone giuen over for want of this life.
Q. What is the Law?
A. The rule of all good, and condemner of all evill. Here alone may we try our actions, how acceptable they are vnto God. I≈øa. 8.20.
Q. Doth God require of man obedience thereunto?

A. Man was to performe it by the law of creation; for, God made him able to doe it, and made his covenant with him for him≈øelfe, and his heires, vpon the promi≈øe of life, for the keeping of it, and threatning death, if he ≈øhould breake it, and ≈øealed the ≈øame with two Sacraments. The one, of the tree of life; the other, of the knowledge of good and evill. Gen. 2.9.17. Lev. 18 5. Rom. 10.5.
Q. How had man this law by creation?
