It is therefore by the doctrine of our Church, no ≈øigne ≈øealing grace: but as that Altar, Io≈øh. 22.27. was a witne≈ø≈øe betwixt party and party; ≈øo this betwixt the Childe and the Congregation; for the Mini≈øter baptizing in the name of the Trinitie, ≈øayes I baptize: but in that action the phra≈øe is altered; and hee ≈øayes in the name of the Congregation wee receiue, ≈øhewing that as God by Bapti≈øme admits the Childe into fellow≈øhip with him≈øelfe: ≈øo they the Infant into the ≈øame communion of the Cro≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øt with them≈øelues, that is, they gladly te≈øtifie, that they are not a≈øhamed of any ignominies, or reproches for their Saviours ≈øake. And I would to God, that ≈øo Chri≈øtian an expo≈øition could ≈øtay our brethren for going vp again≈øt vs in Battell. A ≈øecond Que≈øtion may be, whether Chri≈øt as man may be pictured? I an≈øwere; that ≈øubiect that is to be adored, is not to be painted; for it can no wayes be ≈øet forth as civill, and ≈øo wee cannot haue an image of Chri≈øt (as he is to be adored) for civill or hi≈øtoricall v≈øe. Wee are flatly forbidden the very making of an image of God, and whole Chri≈øt being to be adored as God, we are not onely forbidden to wor≈øhip his image, but al≈øo to make it. If any by the ≈øubtiltie of their wits can ab≈øtract Chri≈øts man hood from his Godhead, or wor≈øhip from either of them both, I ≈øhall not oppo≈øe the keeping of an image of Chri≈øt, as of the greate≈øt Benefactor that ever came into the world: but my braine is too dull to devide in this ca≈øe; and therefore from the
precept, Than ≈øhalt not make, that is, of the proper ≈øubiect of Religion, ≈øuch as was expre≈ø≈øed in the fir≈øt Commandement, any image. If it were of Religion it ≈øelfe, the precept could not be ≈øo generall; for the making of an image of God is morally a ≈øinne, I meane, in the very nature of the thing it ≈øelfe, and admits no di≈øpen≈øation, nay, God him≈øelfe, though he tooke libertie in his wor≈øhip to expre≈ø≈øe it by images; yet never did fie goe about to paint out him≈øelfe in any ≈øimilitude. Deut. 4.12. Yee heard the voyee of words, but ≈øaw no ≈øimilitude, onely yee heard a voyce; this is the way to ≈øhew his nature, which no other image can doe. And therefore I may conclude, that Chri≈øt as he is to be adored, ≈øo he is not to be painted, &c. The third que≈øtion is, whether things indifferent, abu≈øed, may againe be v≈øed in the wor≈øhip of God, e≈øpecially, if their fir≈øt in≈øtitution haue beene ≈øuper≈øtitious? I an≈øwere; they may. Iudg. 6.25.26. Baals bullock with Baals wood is ≈øacrificed to God by Gideon. His Altar is throwne downe, fir≈øt will God haue him cut the very throat of Idolatry, and when once Gods dete≈øtation, and their danger is cea≈øed, then may the good creatures of God, prophened to Idolatry, be imployed to the holy ≈øervice of their makes. Ioh. 2.6. The fixe water pots were ≈øuper≈øtitiou≈øly abu≈øed, for private purification, whereas God had onely inioyned it for the Temple: yet our Sauiour v≈øed both the pots and water, ≈øee the holy working of a miracle, &c. yet this rule mu≈øt ever be ob≈øerued, that things indifferent when they become ≈øcandalous and offen≈øiue, are to be foreborne. The Iewi≈øh Ceremonies were retained in the Church of God as things in different after the di≈ø≈øolution of their nece≈ø≈øary v≈øe. But when they became hurtfull and offen≈øiue to Gods Church, they were reiected by the Apo≈øtles. Methinkes the≈øe foure propo≈øitions ≈øhould quiet any man, con≈øcience in this ≈øubiect, which hath in all times cau≈øed ≈øuch trouble to Gods Church. Fir≈øt, that the Church of God hath power to retaine things indifferent. Secondly, that the ≈øame Church (as it ought) hath power to remoue
them when they proue ≈øcand aloua and offen≈øiue. Thirdly, that this power is to be exerci≈øed by our Governours, and not by private men. Fourthly, that private men ≈øinne not in the retaining of them, they cannot be taxed, or touched with that which is none of theirs; for God requires reformation of none, but ≈øuch as haue receiued iniunctions from him.
Q. What is the Law concerning the right v≈øage of Gods wor≈øhip?

A. It either hath re≈øpect to reverence in doing it, or diligence in learning it. As wee are to avoyd all contempt of the glorious name of God, ≈øo are wee to neglect no time to learne his will. Wee are to wor≈øhip him with all reverence, e≈øpecially vpon his owne ≈øolemne day. To whom is the account of our dayes, either more due, or better knowne, then to God? All the dayes are his, who gaue time a beginning & continuance; yet ≈øome he hath made ours, not to command, but to v≈øe. In none may wee forget him: in ≈øome wee mu≈øt forget all, be≈øides him. I≈øa. 56.2.4.6. and 58.13.
Q. What is the precept concerning the reverent wor≈øhip of God?

A. The third Commandement. Exod. 20.7. Thou ≈øhalt not take the name of the Lord thy God in vaine, &c. By name we are to vnder≈øtand any thing by which Almightie God is made knowne vnto vs, as his nature, attributes, word, and workes.
Q. What is here commanded?
A. All reuerence po≈ø≈øible to be ≈øhewed in the wor≈øhip of God, or in ≈øpeaking of God and his holine≈ø≈øe, I≈øa. 48.11. Ier. 4.2.
Q. What is here forbidden?

A. All kind of prophanene≈ø≈øe, and light e≈øteeme of God and goodne≈ø≈øe. Ho≈ø. 4.2. The Iewes haue a conceit, that the ≈øinne of that I≈øraelite which was ≈øtoned for bla≈øphemy, was onely this, that he named that ineffable name of foure letters, Iehovah, Shall their feare keepe them from once
mentioning the dreadfull name of God, and ≈øhall not our feare keepe vs from abu≈øing it? Dur≈øt wee ≈øo boldly ≈øinne God in the face, if wee feared him? Surely, if any feare of him ≈øtood before our eyes, wee dur≈øt not dally with his name, or at our plea≈øure teare him in peeces. Wee mu≈øt needs de≈øpi≈øe his per≈øon, who≈øe name we contemne.
Q. What is the law of our diligent learning to wor≈øhip God?
A. The fourth Commandement. Exod. 20. S. 9.10.11. Remember the Sabboth day to keepe it holy.
Q. What is here commanded?

A. The ≈øetting apart of the ≈øeventh day to the ≈øervice of God, as like wife all diligence in learning to know his will. He that will needs be his owne Scholler, hath commonly a foole to his Ma≈øter. It is dangerous medling with the things of God according to our owne appoiatments. How perplext, and in how manifolde mindes are men, as tho≈øe that are encountred with diver≈øe wayes, and know not which to take, in this poynt of the Sabboth? It ≈øhall be well, if ≈øome change not their ma≈øter, as they ≈øeeme to haue changed their livery in their ≈øervice on this day. All our thoughts and vitall ≈øpirits are too little in remembring the ≈øanctification of it. True it is that the ≈øub≈øtance of the Sabboth con≈øi≈øteth not in houres, but in holine≈ø≈øe, not in a naturall day, but the ≈øanctification of it; and therefore the alteration of the time, is no mutation, or change in the e≈ø≈øence of the fourth Commandement, but onely in the accident of it. Time, as other naturall things, is ≈øeparate and ≈øet apart for holy v≈øe. All time is Gods by creation, and waites vpon the creature, and his actions: but the ≈øeventh part of time is to be his by the holy ob≈øervation of it. And here a iourney to Dama≈øcus were happily vnder-taken, to meet with ≈øome good Annanias, that might cau≈øe to fall tho≈øe ≈øcales of ignorance, where with wee are blinded in a fallacie of compo≈øition and divi≈øion; thinking the Sabboth to be abrogated, becau≈øe the time is changed from a ≈øeventh day to a fir≈øt day. Truth is great and prevaileth; for I ≈øee no
greater change in this, then if the Sacrament ≈øhould bee celebrated with one kinde of water, or bread, and not with another. For naturall things in both are elevated aboue them≈øelues to ≈øupernaturall ends. Time therefore is as morall in the fourth Commandement, as bread, wine, or water evangelicall in the Sacraments. Fir≈øt, the di≈øtribution of time proues the ≈øeventh part con≈øecrated to God. Exod. 20.9. And let him take heed that ≈øacrilegiou≈øly ≈øleales it from God. I am re≈øolved (like Surgeans and Phy≈øitians) rather to force a bitter pill, or ≈ømarting ≈øalue, then ≈øuffer a patient to peri≈øh. With what face can≈øt thou ≈øay (O wretched Soule) not ≈øixe dayes will I labour, but al≈øo play and plea≈øe my ≈øelfe vpon the ≈øeventh? Secondly, the order and ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of parts, will proue, either the fir≈øt, or ≈øeventh part of time to be Gods. The whole is ≈øeven, and of the≈øe God mu≈øt haue a part, and if it be neither the fir≈øt nor the la≈øt, it will be in two weekes; for either from the fir≈øt to the la≈øt is a ≈øeventh day, or from the la≈øt to the fir≈øt: and therefore as the Logicke in the di≈øtribution, ≈øo the Arithmetick in the number, proues Gods vncontroulable wi≈øedome in the removall of the Sabboth from the la≈øt member to the fir≈øt. Divines call (or rather mi≈øcall) the Sabboth, the eight day; for eight is no part of ≈øeven: onely in ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of time the next day after the ≈øeventh is the eight, but this is not con≈øiderable in the precept: which commands one of ≈øeven, and not one of eight. Thirdly, the end of this ≈øeparation is holine≈ø≈øe, and re≈øt: that a part of our time ≈øhould ≈øolemnly be imployed for the ≈øanctification of the whole, is as rea≈øonable as the authour, who doth all things in waight and mea≈øure. Againe, by holine≈ø≈øe wee are to enter into our perpetuall re≈øt; and therefore it is requi≈øite, that a part of time ≈øhould be a Sabboth here, becau≈øe wee looke for an everla≈øting Sabboth hereafter, and that all our time ≈øhall be turned into an holy re≈øt, from ≈øinne and ≈øorrow. Heb. 4.11. As God the Father re≈øted after his workes of creation, and commanded the creature to imitate him therein: ≈øo God the Sonne after his workes
of Redemption, fini≈øhed in his humiliation, re≈øted in heaven. And Dauid tells vs, P≈øal. 118.24. that even Chri≈øt being refu≈øed in his humiliation, and made the head ≈øtone of the corner in his exaltation, brought to pa≈ø≈øe a marvellous worke in our eyes, and thereupon concludes, This is the day which the Lord hath made: wee will retoyce and be glad in it. This day of Chri≈øts re≈øurrection excells all other, and ≈øo is iu≈øtly our Sabboth, and kept by vs as a pledge of our re≈øurrection, and entrance into glory. Fourthly, the lawgiuer is fayd to ≈øpeake all the≈øe words, Exod. 20.1. Even the≈øe ten words. Deut. 4.13. and therefore let them looke to it that dare make them nine. Good Surgeans and Phy≈øitians loue their patients, when they are cruell to their di≈øea≈øes. I cannot but count it a damnable errour, to detract one word from ten. They were all giuen equally in fire, and in fire ≈øhall equally be required. They were all written in tables of ≈øtone, becau≈øe they were fir≈øt written in the tables of our hearts, which as then lo≈øt all, like letters written in water, and are now as hard to receiue againe, as the very ≈øtones: the ceremoniall Law was better remembred then the morall: and of all the moralls, this hath the memento, men naturally being mo≈øt oppo≈øite vnto it. Oft times that which wee know not through our ≈øloth, the ≈øame by teares is made knowne vnto vs. And an afflicted mind certainly findeth out a fault committed; and the guilt which ≈øhe remembreth not in ≈øecuritie, ≈øhee clearely perceiueth being troubled. He that findes and feeles his owne dulne≈ø≈øe on this day, will judge the breach greater then of a ceremony. La≈øtly, holine≈ø≈øe is the ≈øub≈øtance of the precept; and that is as morall in the ≈øolemne wor≈øhip of God, as the hauing of a God, or wor≈øhipping of him with reverence. But if pietie could not prevaile, me thinkes policie ≈øhould, men needing no teachers to be negligent in their duties. To conclude the point, this fir≈øt day of the weeke is according to creation, for mea≈øure and manner. And that is from evening to evening, or from darkene≈ø≈øe to darkene≈ø≈øe. Gen. 1.5.
Q. What is here forbidden?

A. The imployment of the day to any other v≈øe, to the hinderance of any holy exerci≈øe. Pietie is no Ceremony, and in that we are as ≈øtrictly bound to the ob≈øervation of it as ever were the Iewes, wherein wee doe not Iudaize, but moralize in true holine≈ø≈øe. I≈øa. 58.13.
Q. What is the law concerning the loue of our neighbours?

A. That wee doe to them, as wee would they ≈øhould doe to vs. Mark. 12.31. Math. 7.12. The loue of man begins at our ≈øelues, and as we in loue are ready to doe all good to our ≈øelues, and prevent all hurt: ≈øo mu≈øt wee from the ≈øame fountaine, be in readine≈ø≈øe to helpe our neighbour: how ill doth any man de≈øerue to haue an Occan of mercy powred on him, that will not let one drop of it fall vpon his brother, &c?
Q. Where is this commanded?

A. As the former in the fir≈øt table; ≈øo this in the ≈øecond, and our loue of man, is the declaration of our loue of God. 1 Ioh. 4.20. He that loueth not his brother, whom he hath ≈øeene, how can he loue God whom he never ≈øaw? The Devill, when he cannot bring a man, who hath knowne God, to confront and de≈øpi≈øe him directly, he entreth him with this politicke traine; fir≈øt, makes him bold to trample downe his image, and then at length brings him to de≈øpi≈øe God.
Q. How doth the ≈øecond table concerne our neighbour?

A. It con≈øi≈øts either in the ob≈øervation of due order, or pre≈øervation of him and his. Honour is the fir≈øt fruit of loue, and then pre≈øervation of the life and good things of him whom wee honour. If wee mu≈øt loue our neighbours as our ≈øelues, then mu≈øt wee keepe the ≈øame order with them, that wee would haue kept with our ≈øelues. It is bred in the nature of man, either to wi≈øh there were no authoritie, or none aboue him≈øelfe.
Q. What is the law concerning due re≈øpect?

A. The fift, or the fir≈øt Commandement of the ≈øecond
Table. Exod. 20.12. Hononr thy father and mother, &c. Where wee are commanded, all due re≈øpect to our ≈øuperiours, inferiours, equalls, in what condition, ≈øoever, and forbidden all neglect of dutie in this kinde Lev. 19.3. Colo≈ø. 3.20. Luk. 2.51. Ephe≈ø. 6.5. 1 Pet. 2.18. 1 Tim. 6.1. Rom. 15.1.
Q. What is the law of pre≈øervation?

A. It is eyther in the pre≈øervation of life, or the good things thereof. If wee giue to all due honour, wee will haue re≈øpect to life aboue all other things, neither will we be negligent of tho≈øe things wherewith God him≈øelfe hath honoured the liues of men.
Q. What is the law concerning life?

A. The ≈øixt Commandement. Exod. 20.13. Thou ≈øhalt not kill. Where is commanded, what≈øoeuer may conduce to the pre≈øervation of life, and forbidden what≈øoever may preiudice the ≈øame vnlawfully. Deut. 24.14. Ephe≈ø. 4.32. 1 Ioh. 3.5. And here appeares the vertue of fortitude.
Q. What are the good things of life?

A. They eyther concerne the body, or the goods and good name of man, or the whole man; for the la≈øt Commandement teacheth vs to doe our duty in all mo≈øt freely, without either ≈øtop or ≈øtay: here mu≈øt be no if, or and. If concupi≈øcence make any re≈øi≈øtence, wee faile in the worke of our loue.
Q. What is the law concerning cha≈øtitie?

A. The ≈øeventh Commandement, or the third of the ≈øecond Table. Exod. 20.14. Thou ≈øhick not commit adultery. Where cha≈øtie, in thought, word, and deed is commanded, and all kind of vncleanene≈ø≈øe what≈øoeuer forbidden. Pro. 6.13. Ier. 5.8. Math. 7.27. 1 Cor. 6.9. Gal. 5.19. 2 Pet. 2.14. and here appearrs the vertue of Temperance.
Q. What is the law of riches?

A. The eight Commandement. 20.15. Thou ≈øhalt not ≈øteale: where all vprightne≈ø≈øe in dealing is commanded; and all corrupt and fal≈øe traffique and trading or any other
deccitfull cour≈øe forbidden. Prov. 20.14. Mic. 2.2. Zach. 5.4. Io≈øh. 7.21. 1 The≈ø≈ø. 4.6. Ephe≈ø. 4.28. 2 Pet. 2.14. And here appeares the vertue of ju≈øtice & common equitie; for we are to hold that what men hold not in the con≈øi≈øtory of God, they may and mu≈øt hold in the commonpleas of men. The child of God in regard of dominiumis gratificum, may be ≈øayd to haue all things, when he po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth nothing; heire of the world, when he is poorer then Iob. Yet may he not by this his ≈øpirituall right, take the goods which the wor≈øt in the world ownes by a civill and humane right.
Q. What is the law of fame in pre≈øeruing the good name of our brother?

A. The ninth Commandement. Exod. 20.16. Thon ≈øhalt not beare fal≈øe witne≈ø≈øe again≈øt thy neighbour: where wee are commanded, that wee circum≈øpectly, and in due time giue our te≈øtimony for the truth, and are for bidden all ≈øpeeches that may harme the truth, by lying again≈øt it. And here is commanded the vertue of prudence. Portitnde pre≈øerues life, temperance cha≈øtitie, ju≈øtice our goods, and prudence our good name: ≈øo that in the≈øe foure Commandements, are contained the foure tardinall vertues. 1 Sam. 23.19. Prov. 17.25. and 29.11. Lec. 19.17. I≈øa. 5.20. Rom. 1.29. Iam. 3.17. Rev. 22.15.
Q. What is the law of the whole man in regard of de≈øire and appetite?

A. The tenth Commandement, Exed. 20.17. Thou ≈øhalt not covet, &c. There is a naturall appetite of meate and drinke, and likewi≈øe a rea≈øonable de≈øire of things good or bad. Here then we are commanded to loue our neighbour without all re≈øi≈øtence of conoupi≈øcence; for if concupi≈øcence re≈øi≈øt never ≈øo little the pure loue of man wee ≈øinne. Here any language, or looke of lu≈øt is a ≈øinne. Carnall ≈øugge≈øtion, delectation without con≈øent are here condemned. The Devils iniection of a temptation, if wee re≈øi≈øt not is this euill concupi≈øcence. Originall ≈øinne is forbidden in euery Commandement, and here the not re≈øi≈øting of the
lea≈øt ≈øtirring, or motion ofit. That is the fire that is ever burning within vs, and here the not quenching of the flames is judged of God. Here the thoughts of the head, lu≈øts of the heart, deeds of the hand are all reproued, if they turne never ≈øo little from the line of the law. And this is that precept that pre≈ø≈øeth mo≈øt the heart and con≈øcience, and lets vs ≈øee how farre wee are from our created perfection; for Adam in his innocency was made able to performe obedience without all inward or outward re≈øi≈øtence: but wee his ≈øonnes finde re≈øi≈øtence inwardly, in regard of our will and affections, outwardly, in regard of the temper of our bodies, temptations of Satan, lewd company, idlene≈ø≈øe, &c. Furthermore, be≈øide all this wee are commanded by this precept to be content with our owne e≈øtate, and reioyce at the pro≈øperitie of others, and forbidden all grudging and repining at their good and wel-fare. Heb. 13.5. Phil. 4.11. 1 Tim. 6.6. Iam. 5.9. Too many thinke, there is no ≈øuch law that requires a man to bee ≈øo ≈øtrait laced, as not to dare to looke awry. Phari≈øees fume and chafe, and aske, what needs all this adoe, as if it were not enough to keepe the law in their hands, but their very thoughts mu≈øt be bound vp with it. The covetous man thinkes it no matter to be greazed in his fi≈øt with a bribe, to remit but a little of the rigor of a good con≈øcience. Well, here is a rule that layes things hard to our charge, that if wee re≈øi≈øt not the very fir≈øt motions to ≈øinne, wee make our ≈øelues guiltie before God, and lyable to his iu≈øt wrath, &c.

div.head: CHAPTER II. Of holy and heauenly Prayer.
div.p: Que≈øtion.

p.hi: HItherto of obedience to the Law; What is Prayer?

div.p: An≈øwere.
It is an affectionate mouing of God, with things agreeable to his will. Rom. 8.27, and 10.14. Iam. 1.5.6. and 4.3. 1 Ioh. 2.1. and 5.14.
Q. How ought it to be performed?

A. With all comely ge≈øture, in re≈øpect of that mightie Maie≈øtie whom we moue, and our owne ba≈øene≈ø≈øe who doe moue, and that with ardent affection, according to the nature of the thing we moue for. Ho≈ø. 14.2. Gen. 18.27.
Q. How is Prayer diflingui≈øhed?
A. It is either mentall, or vocall; for the Lord vnder≈øtands the language of the heart, as well as of the tongue, Rom. 8.27. Math. 6.8.
Q. What is mentall Prayer?

A. It is a moving of God without a voyce, with the inward affections of the heart and ≈øoule. Exod. 14.15. Mo≈øes cryed to God when he ≈øpake never a word, and hereupon our ≈øighes, ≈øobbes, and groanes are good prayers. Rom. 8.26. Nay, it is fit that the heart ≈øhould pray a long time before the mouth: full ve≈ø≈øels doe not pre≈øently run at the fir≈øt piercing, neither doth the fle≈øh that is deepely wounded, bleed pre≈øently: the heart that is truely touched with ≈øinne and mi≈øery, is not able vpon the ≈øudden to vent it ≈øelfe; for; as great throngs of people, pre≈ø≈øing out at ≈øome narrow pa≈ø≈øage, ≈øticke fa≈øt, and cannot goe forward but very ≈ølowly: ≈øo the abundance of matter in the heart, wanting words, is ≈øtreighted in comming forth, and often
a broken heart, di≈øchargeth it ≈øelfe in broken prayers. And yet the harmony of ≈øuch prayers is mo≈øt ≈øweet and plea≈øant to God; nay, ≈øometimes contraries, as the interlacing of di≈øcords, graceth this mu≈øicke.
Q. What is vecall Prayer?

A. When according to the nature of the thing we moue for, wee labour to expre≈ø≈øe our ≈øelues in words, that the tongue may be the true interpreter of our prayers, and that the breath in which they are vttered, like pillars of ≈ømoaks perfumed with Myrrh and Incen≈øe, and with all the chiefe ≈øpices. Cant. 3.6. may come vp before God, as the prayers and almes of Cornelius. Act. 10.4. Otherwi≈øe our words will be but like the Aegyptian flc≈øh pots, reeking out the hot vapours of the ≈øtrong ≈ømelling Onions and Garlike of our owne corruptions. If our prayers be not mentall before they be vocall, they ≈øpeed not: Ezekias 2 King. 19.4. bids I≈øaiah lift vp his prayer to God, that is, pray heartily. Lu≈øly beggars that flouri≈øh in their Rhetoricke, moue ≈ømall compa≈ø≈øion in the pa≈ø≈øenger; if they were hunger bitten, their hearts would teach them another dialect. The guilty theefe pleading for his life, goes not about to entertaine the Iudges eares with quaint phra≈øes, and fine words, but hee ≈øtudies to ≈øhew the pa≈ø≈øion and affection of his heart. Carnall eloquence ≈øhews ≈ømall repentance; and affectation of Rhetoricke, is without all affection in prayer. Too many ≈øavour in their words more like the golden ≈øockets of the holy lights, blazing in ≈øpeculations, then the bowles of the Altar full of the liquor of heauenly devotion. Such haue more words then matter in their prayers: but humbled ≈øuters haue more matter then words, & ever de≈øire to fit thier words according to their matter. This makes the heart like the pots in Zech. 14.20. ≈øend vp ≈øweet fumes of contrition, righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, thanke≈øgiuing, into the no≈øtrils of God, that he may ≈ømell a ≈øavour of re≈øt from vs; wee a ≈øavour of peace and life from him. That which was ≈øaid of Maries Spicknard, wherewith ≈øhe anointed Chri≈øt, that the whole Hou≈øe was filled with the ≈øavour of the oyntment.
Ioh. 12.3. The ≈øame may be ≈øaid of the≈øe plea≈øant perfumes of our religious prayers, that they are fragrant to God and men: and the rea≈øon is, becau≈øe Chri≈øt by a liuely faith, lyes as a bundle of Myrrh betweene the brea≈øts of euery Chri≈øtian, and that he him≈øelfe in regard of the graces of Gods ≈øpirit is as an Orchard. Can. 4.13. of Pomegranates, with plea≈øant fruits, as Cypres, Spicknard, Saffron, &c. and all the chiefe Spices of the Marchant. And in this ≈øen≈øe, the voyce of the Church is mo≈øt ≈øweet in prayer. Can. 2.14. On the contrary, if our hearts be like Ezechiels bloudy pots. Ezek. 24.6. that boile with the ≈øcum and ru≈øt of lu≈øt, revenge, ambition, wanton pampering of the fle≈øh in painted faces, prodigall gari≈øhne≈ø≈øe, mon≈øtrous di≈øgui≈øedne≈ø≈øe, &c. bringing in all exce≈ø≈øe in our re≈øpects to our ≈øelues, and content with all defects in our re≈øpects to God, wee may well ≈øay, death is in ≈øuch a pot, and that the ≈øacrifice thereof is more noy≈øome to God then any caryon. Never did the fiue Cities of the plaines ≈øend vp ≈øuch poy≈øonous vapours to God, as the prayers of a corrupt and polluted per≈øon, and God being not able to abide the≈øe ill ≈øents, ≈øends downe vpon ≈øuch, a counter-poy≈øon of fire and brim≈øtone. Oh, then let not this pot of the heart that ≈øhould boile the≈øe ≈øweet ≈øacrifices of prayer, either be dry for want of the liquor of grace, or grow ru≈øty for want of daily v≈øe, but let them be full of liquor and meat; ≈øo the fle≈øh-pots of the≈øe ≈øacrifices, erunt ≈øicut aromata, ≈øhall be as perfumes in the bowles of incen≈øe. Zech. 14.20. I know ≈øome are very ≈øhort in prayer for want of matter and affection: but this will make vs ≈øhort and pithy for the abundance of matter and affection. Prayer con≈øi≈øts not more in fragore quam fervore, more in contention of voyce, then in intention of heart.
Q. How is vocall prayer di≈øtingui≈øhed?

A. It is either in pro≈øe, or meeter, ≈øung, or ≈øaid: And hereupon it followes, that the Liturgie of the Church may be not onely in ≈øet forme of prayers, but al≈øo in dimen≈øion of words, for meeter is the mea≈øure of words and ≈øyllables.
Let therefore the doting & dizie headed Browni≈øts, either confe≈ø≈øe P≈øalmes, hymnes, and ≈øpirituall ≈øongs to be no parts of divine wor≈øhip, or el≈øe that prayer may be in a ≈øet forme: but they can on the ≈øudden both ≈øing and ≈øay; yet in their dotage they haue taken paines to bring Davids P≈øalmes into an Engli≈øh meeter, and v≈øe them when they meet, notwith≈øtanding, they reiect their owne practi≈øe, and will not pray in any ≈øet forme of words, as if ≈øinging as well as ≈øaying, were not praying. Colo≈ø. 3.16. Ephe≈ø. 5.19. But our ca≈øe is never the wor≈øe, for that the Lords prayer beares part with vs in this baffling of theirs.
Q. How mu≈øt all the≈øe be done?
A. Seriou≈øly in the ≈øpirit. Rom. 8.26. Colo≈ø. 3.16. It mu≈øt be done with grace in our hearts to the Lord.
Q. How is vocall prayer, deliuered either in pro≈øe or meeter, di≈øtingui≈øhed?
A. It is either publicke, or private; In the Church, Familie, or Chamber. Act. 10.2.9. and 14.23. Zech. 12.11.12.13.14.
Q. What is publicke Prayer?

A. That which is performed to God in the publicke place of his wor≈øhip, and in the publicke meeting of the Congregation; where the Pa≈øtour is to goe before in a liuely voyce, and the people to follow after in minde and heart; and in the conclu≈øion, to ≈øay, Amen, to te≈øtifie their con≈øent, and de≈øire to be heard. Deut. 27.14. to the end.
Q. What is private Prayer?

A. It is euery where, and in all places, and at all times, where either more are gathered together, and then one is to goe before, and the re≈øt follow in con≈øent as before; or el≈øe one by him≈øelfe alone, which may pray only in mind, or al≈øo with his voyce; and this againe may be more ≈øolemne and accu≈øtomed, or a ≈øhort ejaculation, &c. 1 Tim. 2.8. Math. 18.19. Ion. 2.1. Exod. 14.15. Zach. 12.13.
Q. To whom are wee to pray?

A. To the Father, Sonne, and holy Spirit, and to them alone. P≈øal. 50.15. Rom. 10.14. Wee are onely to call vpon
them, in whom wee are to beleeue, and that is onely in God. I beleeue in God, not in any creature, for that is bla≈øpheme. Neither is there in all the prayers of the Bible any other mentioned, to whom wee are to ≈øue but God alone. If any ≈øhall demand, whether he may direct his prayer to one per≈øon of three; the an≈øwere is, he may doe it ≈øafely, and with comfort. What need we feare, while we haue our Sauiour for our patterne: Oh, my Father, if it be po≈ø≈øible, let this cup pa≈ø≈øe. And Paul euery where, both in thankes and reque≈øts, bowes the knees to the Father, &c. yet mu≈øt this be done with due care of wor≈øhipping all in one. Exclude the other, while we fixe our heares vpon one, our prayers will be ≈øinne; retaine all and mention one, wee offend not. None of them doth ought for vs, without all. It is a true rule of Divines, all their externall workes are common: to ≈øollicite one therefore and not all, were iniurious.
Q. Hitherto of Prayers generall affections; What are the kinds?
A. Prayer is either ≈øimple, or compound. Sometimes we are all ≈øuites vnto God, another time all thankes; and ≈øomtimes againe wee ioyne all together. 1 Tim. 2.1.
Q. Whas is ≈øimple Prayer?
A. Where Prayer is of one nature onely. Eph. 1.3. Ble≈ø≈øed be God. ver. 2. Grace be to you, &c.
Q. How manifold?
A. It is either Petition, or thanke≈øgiuing. Either wee reque≈øt ≈øome thing at Gods hands, or ble≈ø≈øe him for the receipt of it.
Q. What is Petition?
A. When by prayer we craue any thing of God, according to his will. Math. 26.39. Iam. 1.6. 1 Ioh. 2.1.
Q. What may fall out here≈øometimes?
A. Making of vowes, which is a ≈øolemne promi≈øe made to God, with mature deliberation of things lawfull, and po≈ø≈øible, &c. P≈øal. 76.11.
Q. How many ≈øorts of Petitions are there?

A. Two; either a crauing of ≈øome things to be done
for vs, or an entreating that ≈øome thing may be avoyded by vs, or remoued from vs. Eph. 6.18. Heb. 5.7.
Q. What is the crauing of ≈øomething to be done for vs?
A. Our petitions to God, to be≈øtow good ble≈ø≈øings vpon vs; where we are to labour to haue a true ≈øen≈øe of the want of the≈øe ble≈ø≈øings. P≈øal. 119.17.18.
Q. Wherein con≈øi≈øts it?

A. Either in good things that concerne God, or our ≈øelues: the fir≈øt wee mu≈øt de≈øire infinitely, as the end of our thoughts, the other, with moderation, as meanes to helpe vs to that good. No man de≈øires meate, or medicine infinitely, but for health, wee never thinke wee haue enough of it: ≈øo God and his goodne≈ø≈øe mu≈øt be ≈øought without mea≈øure, but the things of this life in a meane, as meanes of a better kingdome. Math. 6.33.
Q. What concerning God?

A. Our ≈øanctification of his name, the comming of his kingdome, and performance of his will: fir≈øt, wee pray that God may be glorified by vs; and ≈øecondly, wee pray that the meanes of his glory may be ≈øanctified vnto vs. Math. 6.9.10.
Q. What concerning Man?
A. All things convenient and nece≈ø≈øary for him in his condition, that both him≈øelfe may line by Gods ble≈ø≈øing, and others by him, &c. Math. 6.11. Eph. 4.28.
Q. What are the things we intreat to be remoued from vs?

A. Sinne and mi≈øery: Where we are to make v≈øe of that holy exerci≈øe of fa≈øting, which is to ab≈øtaine from Gods creatures for a time, to te≈øtifie our humiliation before his Maie≈øtie. Iocl. 2.15.
Q. What is our deprecation for the pardon of our ≈øinne?

A. It is our intreating of God to forgiue them, and that he will never lay them to our charge; Remi≈ø≈øion is an action of God the Father, whereby for the merites of his Sonne applied by his ≈øpirit, he accounts ≈øinne as no ≈øinne, or, as if it had never beene committed, I≈øa. 38.17 and 44.22.
Ier. 31.34. and 50.20. Mic. 7.19. Math. 6.12. Colo≈ø. 1.14 1 Ioh. 1.7.
Q. What is our deprecation in regard of mi≈øeries?

A. That the Lord would deliuer vs out of all temptations, and other afflictions and calamities, which if we con≈øider them as they are ≈øent of God, then our entreating is in Lamentation; if as they are inflicted by the wicked. It is a Complaint. P≈øal. 35. and 69. In both which P≈øalmes, Dauid lamenteth for the wicked and complaineth of their ingratitude to God. Ier. 9.19.20.
Q. What is thanke≈øgiuing?

A. An heartie acknowied gement of Gods mercies be≈øtowed on vs, yeelding him due prai≈øe, and a≈øcribing vnto him, kingdome, power, and glory for ever, Amen. P≈øal. 29.2.9. and 66.2.3. and 96.6.7. Luk. 1.68. Eph. 1.3. Col. 3.17. 1 Tim. 2.1.
Q. What is a compound Prayer?

A. A prayer con≈øi≈øting of all, or ≈øome of the≈øe ≈øimples. 1 Tim. 2.1. I exhort, that ≈øupplications, prayers, interce≈ø≈øions, and giuing of thankes be made for all men. As faith is the Conduit cocke, that watereth all the herbes and flowers that grow in the Garden of obedience; ≈øo prayer is the me≈ø≈øenger that knockes at heauen gates, for the ≈øhowers and dewes of heauenly benediction, to make all thriue and pro≈øper. Oh, that euery ≈øoule whiles it is fea≈øting and banqueting with God by faith, as E≈øter with Aha≈øuero≈øh, could bethinke it ≈øelfe, what ≈øuites it hath to him, or what trouble ≈øome enemie it would be rid off, ≈øuppo≈øe it to be ≈øome potent Haman of pride, &c. How ≈øoone ≈øhould it be executed and crucified before our eyes, if wee could but make our complaint to our be≈øt beloued? or if wee find we haue more need to petition for our≈øelues, then deprecate again≈øt others, then let vs duely con≈øider what grace wee want, ana make our ≈øuite to God, as Ach≈øah to Caleb, and wee ≈øhall haue giuen vs the plentifull ≈øprings of grace, both aboue and beneath. And that we may doe all the≈øe, the Lord powere
vpon vs the ≈øpirit of grace and ≈øupplication, and that we may cheerefully looke vp to him whom we haue pierced with our ≈øinnes, &c. Zech. 12.10.

div.head: CHAPTER III. Of the Sacraments.
div.p: Que≈øtion.

p.hi: HItherto of Prayer; What is the celebration of a Sacrament?

div.p: An≈øwere.

An act of faith, whereby according to Gods in≈øtitution, wee celebrate the Sacraments or dained of God by the reciprocall action of godly giuing and taking. 1 Cor. 11.23.24.25.26. Hence the Lords Supper is called a Communion, God communicating to vs by giuing, wee with him by receiuing. 1 Cor. 10.16.
Q. What is a Sacrament?

A. It is a divine te≈øtimony, wherein externall ≈øen≈øible things, by a ≈øolemne right, are ≈øeparated from common v≈øe, to ≈øignifie, ≈øeale, and repre≈øent vnto the faithfull, a≈ø≈øurance of life in Chri≈øt Ie≈øus. Rom. 4.11. Circumci≈øion is ≈øayd to be a ≈øigne and ≈øeale of righteou≈øue≈ø≈øe by faith. A ≈øigne in regard of the thing fignified, a ≈øeale in regard of the covenant made betwixt God and man; of righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe not our owne, but that of Chri≈øt, both actiue and pa≈ø≈øiue; for all the wayes of God are iu≈øt and true, and therefore no imperfect righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe can be ≈øealed in Gods contracts, and treaties with men by faith, for that as the in≈øtrument makes the righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øt ours by imputation.
Q. How many parts, or members be there in a Sacrament?

A. Two; The outward and ≈øen≈øible ≈øigne, and the inward and ≈øpirituall grace; for as man con≈øi≈øts of a body and ≈øoule, and that nothing ordinarily comes to the ≈øoule but by the body, Almightie God conde≈øcending to our weakne≈ø≈øe, hath ordained outward teachers, to convey knowledge and comfort to the inward man. Math. 26.26. This is my body. If bread, and the body of Chri≈øtwere not two di≈øtinct parts of a Sacrament, the Sacrament it ≈øelfe ≈øhould be lame and imperfect, both in rea≈øon and religion: In rea≈øon, becau≈øe the relation betwixt the ≈øigne and the thing ≈øignified ≈øhould be taken away, the one being pre≈øent without the other, as a reall pre≈øence of fle≈øh, without a reall pre≈øence of bread; and ≈øo the teacher of the outward man being remoued, God is ≈øo farre in the Sacrament aboue our capacitie, that it is incredible to beleeue either the thing, or the power of God in ≈øuch a conver≈øion; for it were vnrea≈øonable to turne a peece of bread into a glorified body, or a glorified body into an omni-pre≈øent God. A Sacrament is the plaine≈øt part of Divinitie, and commeth lowe≈øt both to our nece≈ø≈øitie and capacitie: yet Papi≈øts elevateit aboue all Divinitie, and make it ob≈øcure aboue mea≈øure. Secondly, it is again≈øt rea≈øon in proper ≈øpeech to call a member the whole, and to ≈øay the body of Chri≈øt is the whole intyre and perfect Sacrament. If they ≈øay it is but a part, then let them ≈øhew vs the other, the bread being vani≈øhed away, and remaining no more in his ≈øub≈øtance. Thirdly, it is again≈øt Divinitie and Religion, to thinke any part of it to be corporall food; for it is the rule of the will, and con≈øequently of the whole man; and ≈øo is a ≈øpirituall teacher, though it be helped by ≈øen≈øible meanes to convey it ≈øelfe into the ≈øoule, and therefore Chri≈øt in the Sacrament profiteth not, except he be eaten by faith. A reprobate may receiue bread; but the ≈øigne, ≈øeale, and thing ≈øignified are none of his; for he hath no experience of this my≈øtery, that wants the fir≈øt part of Divinitie; without the which
the ≈øecond cannot worke, no more then a man liue without a ≈øoule.
Q. What is the ≈øen≈øible ≈øigne?

A. That externall part, which is lyable to the ≈øen≈øes, whereby our faith being weake, and our ≈øanctification but in part, our chedience very imperfect, and prayers, not as they ≈øhould be; Notwith≈øtanding the divine Goodne≈ø≈øe witne≈ø≈øeth to our ≈øen≈øes, the con≈øtancie of his purpo≈øe to ≈øaue vs, and it is (as it were) the badge, ≈øymbole, and token, whereby the true Church is married to the ≈øpou≈øe Ie≈øus Chri≈øt; and therefore ≈øeparated from all other companies, and hence it is, to ≈øhew, to whom ≈øhe belongeth, and to di≈øtingui≈øh her from all other ≈øects. Ho≈ø. 2.19.20. Math. 28.19. Act. 8.36.37. 1 Cor. 10.17.18.19.20.21.
Q. Haue the≈øe ≈øignes beene alwayes the ≈øame?

A. No; They haue beene diver≈øe, accerding to the times of Chri≈øt, either as he was to be exhibited, and then they were ordinary, and extraordinary; or el≈øe as he as exhibited in our fle≈øh. Before his comming, he confirmed the ordinary ≈øignes by extraordinary miracles, lea≈øt the Iewes ≈øhould doubt of the Me≈ø≈øias, or of the vertue of ≈øuch externall rites and ceremonies. The Cloud, Pillar of fire, Manna, Rccke, Red ≈øea, &c. were all Sacramentall ≈øignes to the Iewes, as well as Circumci≈øion, and the Pa≈ø≈øeover. 1 Cor. 10.1.2.3.4.
Q. What is the ≈øpirituall part?

A. Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, both God and man, with all his benefits, which hath never varied. Heb. 13.8. The Cup, and the Bread 1 Cor. 10.16. are called, a Communion, that is, the drinking of the wine in the Cup, and eating of the bread, makes a communion betwixt vs and them in corporall nouri≈øhment: So Chri≈øt with all his benefits, being receiued, and the fruit thereof being truly perceiued by faith, is our happie
communion with the body & bloud of Chri≈øt: otherwi≈øe wee communicate no more with Chri≈øt in the Sacrament, then we doe with the bread and wine, whiles they ≈øtand vntouched vpon the Communion Table.
Q. How many Sacraments are there?

A. Two; one of our Nativitie, and another of our education: our Chri≈øtianitie is ≈øealed vnto vs both in the birth, and growing of it; for as the application of Chri≈øt vnto vs, is both for our being in him, and ri≈øing with him: ≈øo the two ≈øeales thereof, are either for our grafting into Chri≈øt, or growing vp with him. Hence the fir≈øt Sacrament may be called the ≈øymbole, or ≈øeale of our entrance, or initiation in Gods Church: it is (as it were) our matriculation, &c. The ≈øecond, is the Sacrament of our ≈øpirituall nouri≈øhment, and continuance therein. It hath beene an auncient cu≈øtome in the Church of God, to ≈øet the Font below in the Church, and the Table aboue, and thereupon haue called it the high Altar, not for to ≈øacrifice Chri≈øt vpon it with the Papi≈øts, but to remember that everla≈øting, and perpetuall ≈øacrifice he offered once for vs vpon the Altar of his Cro≈ø≈øe. This is a humane Ceremony, and not without edification, becau≈øe it carries with it a proportionable ≈øignification to both the Sacraments, and yet are the≈øe places, or in≈øtruments ≈øet vp in them no wayes Sacramentall, though profitably ≈øignificant. 1 Cor. 10.16. The Cup, in the Communion, is no more Sacramentall, then the Font in Bapti≈øme; and yet the Apo≈øtle ≈øayes, the Cup, which we ble≈ø≈øe, is it not the Communion, &c? He makes an holy v≈øe of the Cup which containes the wine, and ≈øo may we of the Font which holds the water: yet mu≈øt we not thinke the Cup more holy then the wine, the Font then the water, or the table then the bread and wine, &c. And therefore it is a ≈øinne in ≈øome ignorant people, that more reverence the high Altar, then the Sacrament it ≈øelfe, and thinke that the ≈øupplene≈ø≈øe of their knees, in bowing
at, or before the Communion Table, ≈øhould be a maske to hide the ≈øtarkne≈ø≈øe and numbne≈ø≈øe of all the ioynrs of their Soules, in their ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to the Commandement it ≈øelfe, in a ≈øpirituall eating and drinking at the ≈øame Table, which is therefore to be reverenced, becau≈øe it is the Table of ble≈ø≈øing ≈øo ≈øpirituall a banquet. For it is too well ≈øeene and knowne, that ≈øuper≈øtitious Papi≈øts, and carnall Prote≈øtants, (for I ≈øpeake not of them that reverence the place for the my≈øteries them≈øelues (as Paul did the Cup for the Sacramentall wine) that their knees, which are Camell like in the common curte≈øie in Gods hou≈øe, are ioyntle≈ø≈øe and Elephant like, in the ≈øpeciall obedience vnto his precepts, to whom the hou≈øe and place is con≈øecrated.
Q. What is the Sacrament of our Nativitie?

A. It is the Sacrament of our ingraffing into Chri≈øt; and therefore but once v≈øed of vs. For wee are but once borne Chri≈øtians, though wee haue daily v≈øe of nouri≈øhment, no grow vp in Chri≈øtianitie, Rom. 6.3.4.5. Col. 2.12.13.
Q. What is the externall part thereof?

A. Before Chri≈øt was exhibited in the ≈øle≈øh, the extraordinary ≈øignes were the pa≈ø≈øing of the I≈øraclites through the red ≈øea, and the Cloud, that was by day to couer them, and the Pillar of fire by night to guide them in the wilderne≈ø≈øe: the ordinary ≈øigne was the circumci≈øing and cutting of the foreskinne of the fle≈øh, but ≈øince Chri≈øts comming our Bapti≈øme, or wa≈øhing of the fle≈øh.
